docs.text: Welcome to BMac's Nonsense Hey there. I'm Brian MacDonald, and this is the place where I keep stuff that I want to be on the web, but is too big for including on socials. It's a blog site, in other words. If you came here looking for professional or serious stuff, you're in the wrong place. These links lead to more official resources about me. MacDonald Editorial , my professional website with my portfolio and services. My Mastodon , pretty much the only social media I bother with anymore. My LinkedIn , for all the usual LinkedIn stuff. What's going on here? I'm verbose. This is a known flaw, known to myself and anyone who's talked to me for more than a few minutes. I often record my thoughts and memories in written form. I'm also fond of "projects," meaning that if I become interested in woozles, I probably won't be happy until I collect all the woozles and write down some thoughts about each. ADHD symptom? Seems likely. At some point, I look at my woozles document and think, "Oh, gosh, that's 100 pages long now." And once I noticed that I had lengthy writing on multiple different topics, I thought I'd put them on a web site, where at least they might persist in some form or be useful to others. Doctor Who Tabletop RPG Adventures I like Doctor Who . Like, a lot. A lot a lot. I also like tabletop role-playing games (TTRPGs). There have been attempts at a Doctor Who RPG in the past, but they've faded out over time. The latest attempt is Doctor Who the Roleplaying Game from Cubicle 7 . I stumbled upon it in the fall of 2023, just as the second edition was coming out. I have a weekly RPG group who is often open to trying new things, and which includes some fans of the show, and everybody else is polite and humors me. After running an initial adventure from the rulebook, I started coming up with my own, and I really enjoyed the writing. I'm putting them here in case anybody else wants to run some adventures. Big Finish Pocket Reviews As I mentioned, I'm a huge Doctor Who fan, and have been since the 1980s. But Doctor Who isn't always around, and these days, you get ten episodes and then a two-year pause. Fortunately, Big Finish is there to fill the gaps with audio dramas. They've got full-length, full-cast audio dramas created by amazing writers and directors, some of whom have worked on the TV show, and as many former actors from the show as they can convince to sit in front of a microphone. They're audio stories, sure, but they've got the feel of real Doctor Who , both the classic and the modern series. When I say Big Finish is there to "fill the gaps," I really mean "stuff as many stories as possible into every possible crack, no matter how small." They've been doing their thing since 1999, which has resulted in a massive library of stories. Although Big Finish doesn't restrict themselves to one era or a specific release order, a few years back I decided to listen to as much of the library as I could, in the order the stories take place in the Doctor's personal timeline, or as close as I could determine. Things...got a little out of hand. And of course I had to write down my thoughts, briefly (for me), and that's what you'll find here. Roller Coaster Journal One of my other unusual hobbies is riding roller coasters. There's a whole community of "coaster enthusiasts" (what we call ourselves) who love to compare and contrast, collect experiences, and rank things. Oh, do we love to rank things. Rankings are always in flux, so I won't subject you to mine. However, I do like to keep a journal of coasters I've ridden and parks I've visited, because it helps with my later recall. Built with mkdocs.org , because if you're a tech writer and spend all day in Markdown, there's no more natural-feeling static site generator.
docs.title: Home

docs.title: Summary

docs.text: Big Finish Pocket Reviews I’m writing this at the end of 2019, and I’ve been a fan of Big Finish Doctor Who for a while now. As a long-time fan of the show, I learned about Big Finish at some point during the “wilderness era,” but they weren’t commonly available in America at the time, so much like the novels, I ignored them. Sometime in 2012, I realized that downloads were available, and I made a few purchases...which I failed to listen to, because I fell asleep while listening. In late 2013, I tried again with the 50th anniversary special, "A Light at the End." Because I was recovering from an injury, the only exercise available to me was walking, so I listened while I walked. That gave me the revelation that the stories are better listened to while doing something that occupies my hands or feet, but not my mind. From that point, I was off to the races. Big Finish has sales quite frequently, and by the time I’m writing this, I’ve acquired all of the Main Range, the Short Trips series, and a good chunk of the Companion Chronicles, as well as the box set specials for a number of the other Doctors. I generally stick to stories in which the Doctor appears, because I have to draw the line somewhere, but I’ve also purchased all the UNIT and River Song sets. I find that I need to have a “project,” some order in which I’m listening to the stories. I usually listen to new ones right as they come out, but that’s not enough for the amount of listening I do. I can’t just pick stories at random to listen to, unfortunately; maybe it’s a lack of creativity. So a few years back, I listened to everything I own in release order, and that took me about three years to finish. In the first part of 2019, I decided to start over, but listening to the stories in chronological order, according to the Doctor’s timeline, as laid out by Craig Brawley in the Big Finish Listeners Facebook group. However, Mr. Brawley doesn’t include a lot of the Short Trips from before 2018 or so. I had to make my best guesses about where those go. At the end of November 2019, I decided to take a few minutes after each story and write down what I thought. I started with the Fifth Doctor, because he’s my favorite, and because my collection has only a few gaps in his era. After I finished with that, I planned to loop back around to the First Doctor, then jump back to the Sixth, then the Second, and so on. I hope that by the time I get to the eras with more gaps, I’ll have filled them in. I’ll present these reviews in chronological order for the Doctor, but I’ll tag each with the real-world date I wrote the review. That means that for most stories, I’ll write the review shortly after listening to the story, but for the Fifth Doctor, I had to backfill some earlier stories I listened to. I don’t know how long I’ll continue this project; it depends on whether I get bored. Update, November 2025: Clearly, I didn't get bored. Equally clearly, this project accelerated my acquisition of Big Finish stories. I now have almost no gaps anywhere in the Doctor's timeline, and I have complete collections of a number of the spin-off series as well. And because Big Finish never stops, my collection of stories from the modern era has grown to a size I never could have imagined when I started this project.

docs.title: Big Finish Pocket Reviews

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor The Eighth Doctor, more than any of the others, is largely (but not entirely) an invention of Big Finish. Although the Eighth Doctor has a long run in both novels and comics, lasting from his inception in 1996 to the return of the new series in 2005, the bulk of the stories featuring Paul McGann during that period were found on Big Finish, which gives them a bit of extra weight. Unlike the Seventh Doctor stories, Big Finish didn’t try to keep their timeline consistent with the other media (mostly) which allowed them to keep the Doctor’s timeline mostly straight, and avoid the temporal complexities that were going on in the novels. Big Finish also kept going long after the novels and comics had finished, and the Eighth eventually became the first Doctor to see a new TV story (sort of) while his Big Finish adventures were still ongoing, tying this Doctor directly to events created for the new series, specifically the Time War. That gives the Doctor a destination and an arc to his life that had previously been open-ended. As a result of the way Big Finish executed the Eighth Doctor stories, release order runs closer to chronological order than for any other Doctor, although there are exceptions of course. His tenure can also be divided into three large chunks: the early period with Charley, when he was one of several Main Range Doctors, and also considered the “current” Doctor; the middle period with Lucie, in which he became the first Big Finish Doctor to have his own specialized series, influenced by the style and pace of the new series; and the “boxed set” era, in which his adventures tended to be part of large sweeping arc of four boxed sets, each containing four stories. This last era tends to be more tied to new-series concepts and characters, and is still ongoing as I write this.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor, more than any of the others, is largely (but not entirely) an invention of Big Finish. Although the Eighth Doctor has a long run in both novels and comics, lasting from his inception in 1996 to the return of the new series in 2005, the bulk of the stories featuring Paul McGann during that period were found on Big Finish, which gives them a bit of extra weight. Unlike the Seventh Doctor stories, Big Finish didn’t try to keep their timeline consistent with the other media (mostly) which allowed them to keep the Doctor’s timeline mostly straight, and avoid the temporal complexities that were going on in the novels. Big Finish also kept going long after the novels and comics had finished, and the Eighth eventually became the first Doctor to see a new TV story (sort of) while his Big Finish adventures were still ongoing, tying this Doctor directly to events created for the new series, specifically the Time War. That gives the Doctor a destination and an arc to his life that had previously been open-ended. As a result of the way Big Finish executed the Eighth Doctor stories, release order runs closer to chronological order than for any other Doctor, although there are exceptions of course. His tenure can also be divided into three large chunks: the early period with Charley, when he was one of several Main Range Doctors, and also considered the “current” Doctor; the middle period with Lucie, in which he became the first Big Finish Doctor to have his own specialized series, influenced by the style and pace of the new series; and the “boxed set” era, in which his adventures tended to be part of large sweeping arc of four boxed sets, each containing four stories. This last era tends to be more tied to new-series concepts and characters, and is still ongoing as I write this.
docs.title: The Eighth Doctor

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor and Bliss We had to end up here eventually. Thanks to the 50th Anniversary special, we know how the Eighth Doctor’s tenure ends, and we know it happens in the middle of the Time War. After several years of saying they’d stay away from the Time War period, Big Finish kept edging closer and closer, until eventually they did the War Doctor series, and then it was Time War for everybody! Well, mostly everybody. The Eighth Doctor is the only other one we know who had direct contact with the war, so we’ve got four boxed sets dedicated to that. Fortunately, Bliss is his companion through all of that time, so I can name this section after her rather than having to call it “The Time War.” Curiously, for a section about the Time War, these stories take place almost exclusively in release order, right up until the end.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor Bliss

docs.title: The Eighth Doctor and Bliss

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor and Charley (and C'rizz) Now we’ve arrived at the party. In 2000, Big Finish was a little upstart side project, although one doing very nicely, having recruited Peter Davison, Colin Baker, and Sylvester McCoy to the cause. But in landing Paul McGann, they had the “current” Doctor (even though the show was off the air), meaning they could claim to be providing the character’s ongoing adventures, especially since the revised series wasn’t even a prospect yet, and so could go on indefinitely. This phase slotted the Eighth Doctor into the Main Range with the other three, supplied a new companion in Charley Pollard, and really defined the Eighth Doctor’s romantic, somewhat manic persona. As the late wilderness years writers tended to do, they start to push the formula after a while with the Divergent Universe arc, and...well, real-world considerations changed where that ended up going. The Main Range stories in this era go pretty much in order, but in subsequent years, any “Eight and Charley” stories have to be dropped in here before “Neverland,” so there’s a whole bunch of inserts. After that point, though, it’s pretty much a straight shot.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor and Charley

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor, Liv, and Helen With Dark Eyes , Big Finish was experimenting with new formats, and in the end established a precedent, at least for Eighth Doctor stories: An epic with a single title, composed of four boxed sets, each with four individual one-hour stories, released twice a year. It became clear pretty quickly that a sixteen-part epic was not a great plan, as you can’t maintain suspense for that long, so the boxes became a balancing act between the series arc and stand-alone stories. At the moment, this era consists of the Doom Coalition , Ravenous , and Stranded arcs. Stability is provided by having Liv present for this whole era, and Helen around for most of it. These were also released after Big Finish obtained the rights to use new-series characters and concepts, and you can see that creeping in slowly over time.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor, Liv, and Helen

docs.title: The Eighth Doctor, Liv, and Helen

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor and Lucie Lucie Miller’s era was pretty much the direct result of the revived TV series. As the show grew in popularity, there was pressure on Big Finish to provide content from the classic series, but in a format more comfortable for fans of the new series. Hence “The New Eighth Doctor Adventures,” which first aired on BBC Radio 7, and were then released on CD by Big Finish. Much like the new series, the stories are roughly an hour, with occasional two-parters, there are ongoing story arcs, and the Doctor has a bit more of an edge to his personality. Most significantly, the companion is a street-smart young woman with an attitude from contemporary times (that is, just like Rose Tyler). Lucie Bleedin’ Miller certainly fulfills the role, being distinctly different from Charley, yet hitting all the companion boxes, and importantly, not in love with the Doctor...at least at first. Because of the season structure, most of these stories go in production order. However, there have been some later inserts, many of which are stuck between Series 1 and 2, because that’s the only spot where they wouldn’t interfere with a cliffhanger.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor and Lucie

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor and Mary Shelley This is a somewhat vague period of stories inserted at the beginning of the Eighth Doctor’s life. Several feature Mary Shelley as a companion, produced later in real time, but returning the Eighth Doctor to the Monthly Range after he’d moved out. Some other stories with a younger, solo Eighth Doctor are wedged in here as well. The novels and comics could take place during this time period, or could be ignored altogether, depending on your tastes.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor and Mary Shelley

docs.text: This is a somewhat vague period of stories inserted at the beginning of the Eighth Doctor’s life. docs.title: The Eighth Doctor and Mary Shelley

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor and Molly (and Liv) With this phase, the Era of the Boxed Sets began. The Eighth Doctor Adventures had ended in early 2011, followed by the Mary Shelley stories from the beginning of this Doctor’s tenure in late 2011, and then this blockbuster set not until late 2012, making a break in the publishing schedule, and a good jumping on point for new listeners (including myself). The experiment worked so well that Big Finish published all the subsequent Eighth Doctor stories in boxed sets, and then expanded the format to other Doctors and series as well, to the point where the Main Range ended in 2021, replaced by boxed sets. The new companion is Molly O’Sullivan, played by Ruth Bradley, except that Big Finish didn’t really plan Molly’s arc, or Bradley’s involvement, beyond the first box, which...complicates things.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor and Molly

docs.title: The Eighth Doctor and Molly (and Liv)

docs.text: The Eighth Doctor Solo As with all Big Finish Doctors, there needs to be a part of their tenure where the writers can stick stories that feature the Doctor alone, without companions. The real-world reason is usually budgetary, or actor availability, or a general feeling that having an additional character around would complicate the story. In this case, we can assume a gap after the Liv & Helen era, the only such gap currently in the Eighth Doctor’s era. Fitting into that spot are two main plotlines: The “Time Lord Victorious” multimedia story from James Goss, which covered the Eighth, Ninth, and Tenth Doctors; and the “Pre-Time War” stories, which cover the period when the Doctor was actively trying to stay out of the war, but before he was dragged in, during the next section. That means he’s mostly appearing in stories as a supporting character, rather than as the protagonist. Plus a couple of other bits and bobs that require the Doctor to be solo.
docs.title: Eighth Doctor Solo

docs.text: As with all Big Finish Doctors, there needs to be a part of their tenure where the writers can stick stories that feature the Doctor alone, without companions. The real-world reason is usually budgetary, or actor availability, or a general feeling that having an additional character around would complicate the story. In this case, we can assume a gap after the Liv & Helen era, the only such gap currently in the Eighth Doctor’s era. Fitting into that spot are two main plotlines: The “Time Lord Victorious” multimedia story from James Goss, which covered the Eighth, Ninth, and Tenth Doctors; and the “Pre-Time War” stories, which cover the period when the Doctor was actively trying to stay out of the war, but before he was dragged in, during the next section. That means he’s mostly appearing in stories as a supporting character, rather than as the protagonist. Plus a couple of other bits and bobs that require the Doctor to be solo.
docs.title: The Eighth Doctor Solo

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor The Fifth Doctor’s era stands out in the TV series as having a lot of companions. That made for some logistical difficulties on Big Finish’s part, both in getting the actors to return (Janet Fielding and Matthew Waterhouse were unwilling for several years), but also finding spots where the stories could fit between the TV episodes. The solution was to add a lengthy period of the Doctor traveling with just Nyssa, and then a period at the end of his tenure when he traveled with Peri for much, much longer than the TV series ever indicated, even adding an original companion into the mix with Erimem. As of 2019, all the actors have returned to their roles, leading to a wide variety of stories scattered throughout the Fifth Doctor’s tenure. This is also the portion of the project where the "Main Range" or "Monthly Range" stories start to appear. Original Big Finish, back in 1999, had one range of stories that alternated between the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Doctors, adding the Eighth after a short period of time. That lasted until 2021, when they had so many other Doctors with their own dedicated series, it made little sense to continue with the monthly releases. As a result, some of the oldest Big Finish stories are found in this section. This is also the place where I started my project, as the Fifth is my favorite of the classic Doctors. I wasn't taking careful notes in the first stage, so many of the "listened" dates are approximations. Also, some of these reviews are very short; I may revisit them someday.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor

docs.title: The Fifth Doctor

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor, Adric, Nyssa, and Tegan It took a very long time, but Matthew Waterhouse eventually became one of the last actors to reprise his role for Big Finish, starting with a box set, and then a series of Main Range stories. The writers were then presented with the challenge of making Adric somehow not annoying, while still keeping him recognizable, and for the most part, they succeeded. Most of the Big Finish insertions come later in the season, when the characters have gotten to know one another a bit better, but also because the early stories in this season are linked pretty tightly together. There’s no indication yet of whether this team will do more together, but I’d welcome it.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor, Adric, Nyssa, and Tegan

docs.text: Cold Fusion Novel Adaptations #11 Released: 15 December 2016 Listened: 1/8/22 This is one of the novel adaptations, and I normally don’t care for those all that much, but it was on sale, so. It’s also a fairly impressive story, featuring both the Fifth and Seventh Doctors, as well as the mysterious Time Lady called Patience. Normally I place multi-Doctor stories with the “latest” Doctor involved, but this is really a Fifth Doctor story that intersects with the Seventh. For Adric, Nyssa, and Tegan, it’s still early days, but fortunately all of them have seen a regeneration quite recently, so they’re clued in to that aspect. The Seventh Doctor is with Roz Forrester and Chris Cwej, so after Ace and Benny, and well into his “chessmaster” phase. It’s also quite long, being a novel adaptation. However, it has several aspects common to the novel series, where things are slightly more adult: Tegan wants a beer, both Nyssa and Tegan are on the receiving end of flirting from Chris, but Nyssa completely misses it and makes some inadvertent innuendo of her own. There’s danger to the entire multiverse, there’s Time Lord history involved, and of course the Seventh Doctor is acting the mastermind while appearing to be somewhat silly. The interactions between the Fifth Doctor and Patience are full of references and vague hints of events in other novels, and none of it is explained properly, which was rather a feature of the novels. The Seventh Doctor is pretty mournful about Adric, but keeps it carefully hidden. However, this adaptation has a few unique features, particularly references to the events of “The Day of the Doctor” and “Time Crash.” Like most of the novel adaptations, I find the plot to be not very memorable, but the character interactions are worth it. And because it’s a Fifth Doctor story, we don’t get a ton of the Seventh Doctor being super-manipulative, which can get old fast.
docs.title: Cold Fusion

docs.text: Ghost Walk Main Range #235 Released: 13 February 2018 Listened: 12/26/19 As Big Finish often does in these trilogies, when one story is silly, the next is dark and scary. The TARDIS crew is split up in this one, which allows them each some solo spotlight time interacting with the minor characters. Specifically, Nyssa gets a romance with Sacha Dhawan (who hadn’t been cast as the Master yet, so this is retroactively creepy), and Adric nearly gets himself hanged. Tegan spends a fair amount of time with the Doctor, which goes about as you’d expect, but you also get to see that the Doctor appreciates Tegan’s determination and perseverance, even while finding her annoying at times. The Fifth Doctor also spends a lot of time with Leanne, played by Fenella Woolgar, who played Agatha Christie in “The Unicorn and the Wasp” on TV, and several other Big Finish roles. It’s not the most memorable spooky Big Finish story, but it’s pretty good.
docs.title: Ghost Walk

docs.text: God of War Forty #1.2 Released: 4 January 2022 Listened: 1/7/22 This is a shorter two-part story by playwright Sarah Grochala, who’s only recently started working with Big Finish. This is still the younger Doctor, having bounced here from “Secrets of Telos,” but for Tegan, Nyssa, and Adric, it’s shortly after “Kinda,” possibly after “The Visitation,” because the sonic screwdriver is mentioned, but not used. The story takes place in ninth-century Iceland, and deals with a group of outcast Vikings, all women, who’ve gone off to make their own settlement. Unfortunately, they come across some Ice Warriors and mistake them for gods, which goes poorly. The Ice Warriors have a tendency to be written as misunderstood, or at least partly sympathetic, but there’s very little of that here. The Doctor seems to be trying to juggle his relationships with his companions based on what he learned in the last story, giving Adric more leeway, being more patient with Tegan, and taking advantage of Nyssa’s scientific expertise. However, the overall effect is to make the characters seem a bit out of sync with how they should be at this point. The resolution is also a bit farfetched. I’d like to hear more from this author, but this story doesn’t quite seem to click.
docs.title: God of War

docs.text: Iterations of I Fifth Doctor Boxed Set #1.2 Released: 12 August 2014 Listened: 12/26/19 This is the second half of the inaugural Fifth Doctor boxed set. The first story was set as early in this crew’s tenure as possible, and this one is deliberately set as late as possible, shortly before Adric’s departure. It’s also a John Dorney story, so you can expect some mental exercises, and he doesn’t disappoint. There’s a locked-room mystery, a creepy cult, lots of early-80s tech, and plenty of math, including a sentient imaginary number. As you can imagine, that gives a lot for Adric to do, but Nyssa and Tegan also get their turns to be helpful. The actors do an impressive job of conjuring the versions of their characters from late in season 19, especially since they recorded this shortly after doing the early versions. I’m glad the boxed set went over well, enough to get us more stories with Adric.
docs.title: Iterations of I

docs.text: Kingdom of Lies Main Range #234 Released: 17 January 2018 Listened: 12/26/19 Although I listened to this story near the beginning of this project, these Adric stories were among the more recent that Big Finish had released at the time of writing, with this second trilogy in 2018. This first entry is silly to the point of being a farce, with a Duke and Duchess vying for control of their shared kingdom, splitting everything down the middle. The Fifth Doctor and Nyssa end up on one side, Adric and Tegan on the other, which allows for some novel character interaction (although the Doctor and Nyssa will get plenty of that shortly in this chronology). The resolution is clever, but manages to be almost equally silly. How much you like this one depends on your tolerance for the silliness, but I enjoyed it. Random note: This is the first release to feature two covers, one with the traditional Big Finish logo (the silver version of the one from the TV movie), and the other with an “era appropriate” logo, in this case the early 80s “neon” logo. This sets the stage for later in 2018, when all releases would have the Jodie Whitaker logo, with an alternate cover with the “era appropriate” logo.
docs.title: Kingdom of Lies

docs.text: Main Range #234 Released: 17 January 2018 Listened: 12/26/19 Although I listened to this story near the beginning of this project, these Adric stories were among the more recent that Big Finish had released at the time of writing, with this second trilogy in 2018. This first entry is silly to the point of being a farce, with a Duke and Duchess vying for control of their shared kingdom, splitting everything down the middle. The Fifth Doctor and Nyssa end up on one side, Adric and Tegan on the other, which allows for some novel character interaction (although the Doctor and Nyssa will get plenty of that shortly in this chronology). The resolution is clever, but manages to be almost equally silly. How much you like this one depends on your tolerance for the silliness, but I enjoyed it. Random note: This is the first release to feature two covers, one with the traditional Big Finish logo (the silver version of the one from the TV movie), and the other with an “era appropriate” logo, in this case the early 80s “neon” logo. This sets the stage for later in 2018, when all releases would have the Jodie Whitaker logo, with an alternate cover with the “era appropriate” logo.
docs.title: Kingdom of Lies

docs.text: Prisoners of London Prisoners of London #5 Released: 5 July 2023 Listened: 8/20/23 Placing this here because they’ve just come from London, and they mention the loss of the sonic screwdriver. This is one of the line of audio novels, although as the fifth, maybe I should stop thinking of them as “new.” It’s written and narrated by Matthew Waterhouse, who presumably knows these characters pretty well. It’s also the second entry by him, so I guess Big Finish is happy with his work. Personally, I find his ideas to be somewhat surreal, and a bit over-descriptive. On audio, some things just have to be described visually, I get that, but Waterhouse seems to delight in bizarre landscapes that can only exist in novel/audiobook form. In this case, the image of a giant theme-park London, with four Tower Bridges and oversized monuments, patrolled by police boxes that continually appear and disappear. It’s a novel, so it’s longer than the usual Big Finish story, but once you’re finished with it, not all that much seems to have happened. The team is split up very early, which almost always happens, but Tegan specifically gets packed off to a prison on the moon, for the crime of being rude to an officer of the law. Although we check in on her periodically, she doesn’t really have any agency in the story. Adric and Nyssa don’t fare a whole lot better, being kidnapped by rebels who want to make changes to the government of the planet. They’re together, so we’re treated to Adric’s inner thoughts much more than Nyssa’s. Which makes sense, given the author, but is kind of a lost opportunity. What’s unusual is that the Doctor intervenes in the assassination of the Emperor, gets arrested, and is almost immediately believed, freed, and trusted (by the Emperor, anyway). In fact, the Emperor remains honest, trustworthy, and responsible throughout the story, which is really rare. Waterhouse does a decent job imitating the Doctor’s breathless delivery, but he’s got a few too many “posh” characters who aren’t easily distinguishable. I’ve enjoyed some of the audio novels, but this one was a slog for me.
docs.title: Prisoners of London

docs.text: Psychodrome Fifth Doctor Boxed Set #1.1 Released: 12 August 2014 Listened: 12/26/19 In 2014, Matthew Waterhouse had been working with Big Finish on Dark Shadows, but hadn’t reprised his role as Adric yet, but was open to it. Before bringing Adric into the Main Range, they tested the waters with a boxed set. This story is appropriately set right after “Castrovalva,” and they make that obvious -- Adric talks about the Fourth Doctor, all the characters reference recent adventures, and really the whole theme of the story is about how these four people see each other, and how they feel about this new status quo. The characters get split up in pairs and then recombined, so that all of them have a chance to interact. Each character also encounters parody versions of how they see the other three, although that’s not obvious at first. The actual plot isn’t hugely important, as this story is distinctly about the character interactions, and it does the job well. The Fifth Doctor gets to use the sonic screwdriver in this story, one of the only times the Fifth Doctor can use it in Big Finish before it’s destroyed in “The Visitation.”
docs.title: Psychodrome

docs.text: Secrets of Telos Forty #1.1 Released: 4 January 2022 Listened: 1/6/22 This story, from the boxed set celebrating the Fifth Doctor’s 40th anniversary, is a little hard to place. For the Doctor, it takes place right after “Four to Doomsday,” but the Doctor is immediately bounced through his own timeline, taking the place of the Doctor right after “Arc of Infinity.” Which means he doesn’t know Tegan had left and come back, or that he’d spent a long time with just Nyssa…or what happened to Adric. If that wasn’t timey-wimey enough, the TARDIS lands on a ship containing the surviving characters from “Tomb of the Cybermen,” who’ve just left Telos following that story. The Doctor does a rather poor job of convincing them of who he is, worse than usual, but he’s a bit time-lagged himself. Tegan and Nyssa, on their part, do OK with keeping quiet about the Doctor’s personal history. It would be interesting if the Doctor behaved a bit differently here, acting more tentative because he’s younger, or wondering why he doesn’t have his sonic screwdriver, but none of that happens. The only change is on the part of Nyssa and Tegan, who are both more experienced travelers than they were when this Doctor met them. The plot itself is mostly just fine, very much fitting with “Tomb of the Cybermen,” as most of the humans have ulterior motives for getting involved with the Cybermen, and that goes as well as you might expect. The Doctor spends a lot of time trying to figure out how the Cybermen relate to his time-hopping, but it doesn’t come together, so that feels like a dangling plot thread.
docs.title: Secrets of Telos

docs.text: Serpent in the Silver Mask Main Range #236 Released: 20 March 2018 Listened: 12/26/19 This one is deliberately a high-concept murder mystery, referencing Kind Hearts and Coronets , with Samuel West playing seven different characters, all from the same family. This story is also fairly silly, giving a whiplash effect to the trilogy, but it’s less farcical and more clever, with a legitimate murder mystery with a timey-wimey solution, which only works on Doctor Who . All of the characters get to use their personal skills to good effect, Tegan gets a love interest (she hadn’t had one yet in the chronology), and Samuel West shows off his range well.
docs.title: Serpent in the Silver Mask

docs.text: Smoke and Mirrors Destiny of the Doctor #5 Released: 1 May 2013 Listened: 12/26/19 This story is part of the 50th Anniversary “Destiny of the Doctor” series, which means it’s a narrated story, in this case by Janet Fielding, who does her best at mimicking the other characters’ speech patterns while still using her Australian accent. This is one of the various times the Doctor has met Houdini, although one of the few where he actually appears as a character, instead of being name-dropped. This is one of my favorites of the “Destiny” stories, not necessarily because of the plot, which goes kind of how you’d expect for a Fifth Doctor story, but for how well it captures the companions’ personalities and reactions to a 1920s fun-fair. The “Destiny” stories also all feature an appearance by the Eleventh Doctor, which is inevitably amusing, and is so again here.
docs.title: Smoke and Mirrors

docs.text: The Auton Infinity Forty #2 Released: 7 September 2022 Listened: 1/7/22 This story, which makes up the whole of the second “Forty” boxed set, is one bumper-sized six-parter. Except this time-lost version of the Doctor isn’t really the focus this time, and in fact doesn’t appear until part 3. Which makes this story a bit tricky to describe for this project. This Doctor is still bouncing through time, and ends up much, much later in his tenure, shortly after “Frontios.” He drops in on an adventure on Earth in the 80s, when he, Tegan, and Turlough accidentally crash a UNIT training exercise with the Brigadier as an observer. An awful lot goes on that’s fairly spoilery, but we get the origin of the Autons (maybe), two different Doctors, and the Master trying to interfere as always. John Culshaw stars as…lots of folks: the Brigadier, the Master, and Kameleon. As an anniversary story, the whole sequence is a bit confused, as it can’t really change anything we know about the Doctor’s history, nor can it be a fun reunion-type story, because of Adric. I’ll have to call it a good try, and leave it at that.
docs.title: The Auton Infinity

docs.text: The Contingency Club Main Range #222 Released: 14 February 2017 Listened: 12/26/19 The second part of this trilogy takes place among the Gentlemen’s clubs of Pall Mall in the 19th Century, a setting that the Fifth Doctor takes to with obvious relish. His companions, not so much, particularly Tegan, as you’d expect. Nyssa gets to be the clever one here, spending a lot of time with Adric and Marjorie. That leaves Tegan and the Doctor together, which works out rather better than you might anticipate. Particularly noteworthy is Lorelei King, an American using her own accent, although she’s playing an alien. Oddly, it still comes out sounding over-enunciated, as Americans often do in Big Finish. I think this one works better for the setting than the story.
docs.title: The Contingency Club

docs.text: The Darkening Eye Companion Chronicles #3.6 Released: 3 December 2008 Listened: 2/1/20 This is an early Companion Chronicle, the first one Sarah Sutton had done, so it follows the pattern of a later-in-life Nyssa telling someone else a story of something that happened when she was with the Doctor. The frame story makes some odd changes to “Terminus” and what Nyssa did after. The flashback story features the Dar Traders, who’ve appeared in one Main Range story, and are interesting enough that I’m surprised they haven’t appeared more. The Doctor spends most of the story off-camera, which relieves Sarah of having to portray him, but she does a pretty good job of capturing the tone of both the Doctor and Adric, and especially Tegan, where she incorporates just a hint of Australian accent. The story itself is a bit hard to follow, and gives a sense that there’s a lot more going on outside the story, but we don’t get to see that.
docs.title: The Darkening Eye

docs.text: The Ingenious Gentleman Adric of Alzarius Short Trips #7.11 Released: 7 November 2017 Listened: 4/19/20 Placed here because the sonic screwdriver features. This is Adric’s story, in which he gets separated from the rest of the crew and ends up in a Don Quixote reference (as you can tell from the title). Unfortunately, Adric isn’t human, and so doesn’t get the reference. Quixote’s role is played by a doppelganger of the Fourth Doctor, conjured from Adric’s subconscious desires. This lets Matthew Waterhouse do a Tom Baker impression, which isn’t half bad, and a Peter Davison impression that’s just OK, and a frankly terrible Janet Fielding impression, but that feels somehow appropriate. There’s not a lot of drama in this story, just some character development for Adric, but it’s mostly about the references.
docs.title: The Ingenious Gentleman Adric of Alzarius

docs.text: The Star Men Main Range #221 Released: 10 January 2017 Listened: 12/26/19 After the Fifth Doctor box set proved popular, Adric appeared in a couple of Main Range trilogies, starting with this one in 2017. Andrew Smith often writes these Adric stories, as he created the character. This one is clearly intended to be a showcase for Adric, as he gets to be clever, heroic, and even has a love interest. As with many Andrew Smith stories, it’s pretty high-concept, with sentient pan-dimensional beings and humanity’s first trip to the Andromeda galaxy. As a showcase for Adric, it works fairly well.
docs.title: The Star Men

docs.text: Main Range #221 Released: 10 January 2017 Listened: 12/26/19 After the Fifth Doctor box set proved popular, Adric appeared in a couple of Main Range trilogies, starting with this one in 2017. docs.title: The Star Men

docs.text: The Toy Short Trips Rarities #1.1 Released: 28 September 2018 Listened: 2/1/20 This Short Trip focuses almost entirely on Nyssa, and takes place within the TARDIS, but it’s also full of continuity references. Nyssa’s been having bad dreams about her father, and stumbles onto a device of Susan’s that allows communication with a much earlier Gallifrey, specifically with a memory of the First Doctor, who believes Nyssa to be Susan, but also with the original Master, who tries to corrupt her. All the imagery on Gallifrey reflects the depictions in the modern series, and there are also descriptions of the first eight Doctors, many of whom Nyssa doesn’t know. Sarah Sutton does a very credible job of imitating Tegan, Adric, and the Fifth Doctor for their parts. It’s got atmosphere, if not a lot of plot, but the atmosphere it conveys is quite satisfying.
docs.title: The Toy

docs.text: Zaltys Main Range #223 Released: 21 March 2017 Listened: 12/26/19 The third bit of this trilogy means that Tegan gets to be the heroic one, but she mostly does it split off from the rest of the crew, with a character named Lusca and a bunch of space vampires. The rest of the characters get a fairly standard “mostly abandoned base” storyline, but with a trio of interesting characters with unexpected depths and significant names. All of the minor characters in this one are well-defined, almost unusually so. It makes for a memorable release.
docs.title: Zaltys

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor and Nyssa These stories made up a large chunk of the early Big Finish output. Sarah Sutton was one of the only companion actors available at the time, and since there was only a short period between stories (and seasons) where the Doctor and Nyssa traveled by themselves, they all have to go here. As with the Big Finish stories with original companions, release order and chronological order seem to match up during this time, with only a couple of exceptions. It certainly gives Nyssa a chance to grow as a character, but she ultimately can’t change all that much, because she needs to get back to the same person she was in “Arc of Infinity.” Still, Big Finish keep returning to this period from time to time, based on actor availability.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor and Nyssa

docs.text: 1,001 Nights Main Range #168 Released: 12 December 2012 Listened: 12/21/19 Another anthology entry, although this one isn’t quite as strong. It has a framing story, and it’s great to hear Alexander Siddig (famously of Deep Space Nine ), who does a fantastic job. Unfortunately, none of the individual stories stand out particularly, although “Smuggling Tales” has a meta-story element that I like.
docs.title: 1,001 Nights

docs.text: A Perfect World Main Range #113 Released: September 2008 Listened: 12/21/19 This is a single-episode story tacked onto the end of “Time Reef,” featuring a fairly standard alternate timeline plot. It’s quick, yet satisfying, and its ultimate purpose is to leave Brewster in 2008, in fairly good circumstances. He’ll be back again in a while.

Of the two, this one is less memorable. However, it also features a twist where it’s difficult to tell which characters are trustworthy and which are lying.

docs.text: Castle of Fear Main Range #127 Released: 16 October 2009 Listened: 12/21/19 This story is the first of a genuine trilogy set in Stockbridge. This part takes place in Stockbridge’s past, and frankly it’s a little bit silly, deliberately so. It’s got one of the few appearances of the Rutans, and as a result, there’s a fair bit of disguising and mistaken identities going on. It’s light, but fun.
docs.title: Castle of Fear

docs.text: Main Range #127 Released: 16 October 2009 Listened: 12/21/19 This story is the first of a genuine trilogy set in Stockbridge. This part takes place in Stockbridge’s past, and frankly it’s a little bit silly, deliberately so. It’s got one of the few appearances of the Rutans, and as a result, there’s a fair bit of disguising and mistaken identities going on. It’s light, but fun.
docs.title: Castle of Fear

docs.text: Circular Time, Autumn Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/8/19 I’m a fan of Paul Cornell, and I like stories that tie the Big Finish timeline to Stockbridge, the small town from the comics where the Doctor likes to show up to rest. Mostly because the Doctor often gets to relax and play cricket while he’s there, and so much of his timeline is about loss, that I like to see him get a break. This story, though, is more about Nyssa’s character than anything else, where she makes some choices that perhaps set her up for her departure in the future.
docs.title: Circular Time, Autumn

docs.text: Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/8/19 I’m a fan of Paul Cornell, and I like stories that tie the Big Finish timeline to Stockbridge, the small town from the comics where the Doctor likes to show up to rest. docs.text: Circular Time, Spring Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/8/19 There are a number of anthology releases set in this “Fifth Doctor with Nyssa” period, but this is the only one of the bunch where the individual stories are spread throughout Nyssa’s timeline. Three take place during this period, and the fourth at the very end of the Fifth Doctor’s life. This particular story is interesting because of some insight into other renegade Time Lords, but it’s not the best story overall.
docs.title: Circular Time, Spring

docs.text: Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/8/19 There are a number of anthology releases set in this “Fifth Doctor with Nyssa” period, but this is the only one of the bunch where the individual stories are spread throughout Nyssa’s timeline. docs.text: Circular Time, Summer Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/8/19 This is my favorite of the Circular Time stories, mostly because I love David Warner in anything, but in this case he performs some amazing feats of deduction based on very little evidence, and I like a clever character (I mean, I watch Doctor Who ).
docs.title: Circular Time, Summer

docs.text: Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/8/19 This is my favorite of the Circular Time stories, mostly because I love David Warner in anything, but in this case he performs some amazing feats of deduction based on very little evidence, and I like a clever character (I mean, I watch Doctor Who ).
docs.title: Circular Time, Summer

docs.text: Creatures of Beauty Main Range #44 Released: 24 May 2003 Listened: 12/21/19 In this story, writer Nick Briggs gets clever with narrative structure, as well as an examination of the connection between morality and physical beauty. The games with flashbacks and recordings make it easier to come up with cliffhangers, but you have to pay attention while listening, and there’s a faint sense that it’s showing off cleverness, rather than serving the story. I’m also not very fond of the “twist” at the end; that’s not the sort of thing that Doctor Who often does.
docs.title: Creatures of Beauty

docs.text: Dalek Soul Main Range #224 Released: 19 April 2017 Listened: 12/21/19 How much you enjoy this one depends on how much you like the twist, and how quickly you figure it out. However, Peter Davison and Sarah Sutton get to act out of character, and they always seem to enjoy that.
docs.title: Dalek Soul

docs.text: Main Range #224 Released: 19 April 2017 Listened: 12/21/19 How much you enjoy this one depends on how much you like the twist, and how quickly you figure it out. However, Peter Davison and Sarah Sutton get to act out of character, and they always seem to enjoy that.
docs.title: Dalek Soul

docs.text: Downward Spiral Short Trips #10.7 Released: 28 July 2020 Listened: 7/31/20 I’m setting this one here because the Doctor and Nyssa have been together long enough to start arguing with raised voices. This story is remarkable because it’s told by Nyssa in the second person, to an astronaut named Siobhan, who’s on one of the first trips from Earth to Venus (why an expedition would have only one astronaut, I can’t say). She’s got an AI for company, but runs into...something...that affects both her AI and her ship. Fortunately, the Doctor and Nyssa are there to help. It’s a fairly standard story from their end, although the Doctor seems a little less empathetic than usual, a little more like the Sixth than the Fifth. The writer also uses the word “roared” quite a bit to indicate shouting, and neither the Fifth Doctor nor Nyssa strike me as the roaring type. Still, it’s a nice emotional short trip for Nyssa, and Sarah Sutton reads these very well.
docs.title: Downward Spiral

docs.text: 1963: Fanfare for the Common Men Main Range #178 Released: 11 September 2013 Listened: 12/21/19 I absolutely love this one, and it’s my favorite of the “1963” trilogy. I’m a sucker for alternate histories around the Beatles, and this definitely delivers. There’s a lot of well-plotted timey-wimey in this one, and that keeps you guessing. The fact that Big Finish provided the Common Men with their own Beatle-esque songs is the perfect touch that takes it over the top. The thick Liverpudlian accents might be a little hard to process on first listen, but that’s part of the price you pay.
docs.title: 1963: Fanfare for the Common Men

docs.text: Masquerade Main Range #187 Released: 18 June 2014 Listened: 12/21/19 This is one of those trippy alternate realities where everybody has amnesia at first and has to slowly figure out what’s going on. However, there’s also rather a lot of proper upper-class behavior, which I can really take or leave, so this story doesn’t do a lot for me until the sci-fi part actually gets going. Hannah departs in this one, and I’m not overly upset about that. She seemed to grow as a person in her travels, but ultimately stuck to the same worldview she started out with, which isn’t great for a companion.
docs.title: Masquerade

docs.text: Moonflesh Main Range #185 Released: 11 April 2014 Listened: 12/21/19 This story reflects a more confident Nyssa. Unfortunately, stories with early 20th Century big game hunters tend to get repetitive and testosteroney. Big Finish rarely does Native Americans well, although this story is better than “The Land of the Dead” in that regard. Hannah Bartholemew makes for a fairly interesting character, which is probably why she gets to tag along into later stories.
docs.title: Moonflesh

docs.text: Plague of the Daleks Main Range #129 Released: 8 December 2009 Listened: 12/21/19 The “future” portion of the Stockbridge trilogy features the Daleks, which is kind of a shame because I’m not sure they needed that connection, but they really aren’t in it all that much. The memorable parts of the story involve creepy future Stockbridge and the various minor characters, who are pretty well developed.
docs.title: Plague of the Daleks

docs.text: Primeval Main Range #26 Released: 23 November 2001 Listened: 12/21/19 This story is intended to deepen Nyssa’s character, and for the most part it succeeds. It establishes Nyssa’s minor psychic abilities, which came up a few times on TV, but were never really explored, and used more often on audio. It also gives us a look into Traken’s past, and Nyssa doesn’t necessarily like what she sees. It’s a decent story from this early era.
docs.title: Primeval

docs.text: Renaissance of the Daleks Main Range #93 Released: 9 April 2007 Listened: 12/21/19 This one has a cool title, and the first of a new cover design, but it also has one of the stranger Dalek plans, and ultimately it’s somewhat forgettable. There’s alternate timelines, and a bunch of stranded-out-of-time soldiers, of which the American ones act out some unfortunate stereotypes of their eras. It’s a middling Dalek story at best.
docs.title: Renaissance of the Daleks

docs.text: Return to the Web Planet Bonus release Released: 11 December 2007 Listened: 12/21/19 This is one of the earlier specials released to subscribers, and somewhat hard to get if you’re not one. It’s a sequel to “The Web Planet,” but I think it doesn’t really have the haunting atmosphere of that earlier story. The Zarbi are less of a threat, and more mindless herd animals. Still, for a short bonus story, it’s pretty good.
docs.title: Return to the Web Planet

docs.text: Spare Parts Main Range #34 Released: 31 July 2002 Listened: 12/13/19 This is one of the legendary Big Finish stories, often referred to as “Genesis of the Cybermen.” I think it’s pretty good, with some interesting minor characters, and Nyssa gets put through the emotional wringer. I have to say, though, that I’m not quite sure it lives up to its billing. The idea that Mondas isn’t just Earth’s twin, but an exact copy of Earth, down to the streets and the holidays, has never rung quite true for me. As an origin story for the Cybermen, it’s strong, and Davison does a great job depicting the Doctor’s anguish here. I’m just not sure if it’s as strong as “The Doctor Falls” from the end of the Twelfth Doctor’s tenure.
docs.title: Spare Parts

docs.text: The Boy That Time Forgot Main Range #110 Released: 30 July 2008 Listened: 12/21/19 Given its position in the sequence, the boy of the title seems like it could refer to Brewster, but (spoiler) it’s actually Adric. Or an alternate version, anyway. Like many Paul Magrs stories, it’s somewhat off-kilter and complicated, with plenty of timey-wimey as well. At the time this was recorded, Adric hadn’t appeared in Big Finish, and seemed unlikely to, so this must have been something of a pleasant surprise to listeners. Of course, old Adric isn’t a particularly nice person, so he comes off the worse in the story. The two Victorian adventurers, Beatrice and Rupert, are remarkably well-drawn and quirky for secondary characters, and make a good impression.
docs.title: The Boy That Time Forgot

docs.text: The Deep Short Trips #1.5 Released: 5 November 2010 Listened: 4/11/20 Placed here because Nyssa is fixing the chameleon circuit on her own. The Doctor is alarmed at first, but then decides to test it by taking them to the bottom of the ocean, where the TARDIS improbably becomes a whale and spits them out. Fortunately, it’s a short story, so the Doctor’s idea to get it back works the first time. It’s a nice contrast between Nyssa asserting herself and the Doctor’s recklessness.
docs.title: The Deep

docs.text: The Demons of Red Lodge and Other Stories Main Range #142 Released: December 2010 Listened: 12/21/19 An anthology entry, and one of the stronger ones, although also one of the ones without a connecting narrative. Most of these stories are pretty good one-shots, although I think “Special Features” is my favorite, given its meta-commentary on DVD extras tracks, which these actors have all done plenty of by this point.
docs.title: The Demons of Red Lodge

docs.text: The Eternal Summer Main Range #128 Released: 11 November 2009 Listened: 12/21/19 The second bit of the Stockbridge trilogy is set in the present, which gives an opportunity to incorporate comics character Maxwell Edison into Big Finish, which goes fairly well. It’s a fairly strong time-paradox story, with enough strange imagery to be worthy of the modern series, although the “big bad” reveal feels slightly off.
docs.title: The Eternal Summer

docs.text: Main Range #128 Released: 11 November 2009 Listened: 12/21/19 The second bit of the Stockbridge trilogy is set in the present, which gives an opportunity to incorporate comics character Maxwell Edison into Big Finish, which goes fairly well. docs.title: The Eternal Summer

docs.text: The Game Main Range #66 Released: February 2005 Listened: 12/21/19 This one, I flat-out dislike, although it does have some positives. William Russell appears as a famous diplomat, one who’s an old friend of the Doctor’s, but who the Doctor keeps meeting out of order -- that’s more of a new series trick, even though the new series hadn’t started when this was recorded. On the other hand, the idea of a sanctioned “sport” in which hundreds of people die in every match is just silly, and worse that the Doctor ends up participating without knowing what’s going on. I also found the athlete characters with their shifting loyalties hard to keep track of, as their accents are all similar.
docs.title: The Game

docs.text: The Haunting of Thomas Brewster Main Range #107 Released: 30 April 2008 Listened: 12/21/19 This story introduces semi-companion Thomas Brewster. As with many stories in Victorian London, it’s fairly dark, and the haunting use of “Oranges and Lemons” will make it more of an earworm than it already is. It’s also got a lot of time travel and paradoxes in it, showing a fairly clear influence of the new TV series. Brewster himself is both sympathetic and entirely untrustworthy, an interesting combination for a companion, and perfectly suited to take advantage of the Fifth Doctor and Nyssa, who are both fairly trusting, especially without Tegan or Turlough nearby to be more skeptical. At the end, Brewster steals the TARDIS and leaves, creating a rare cross-story cliffhanger, or at least rare for this era of Big Finish.
docs.title: The Haunting of Thomas Brewster

docs.text: The Land of the Dead Main Range #4 Released: January 2000 Listened: 12/8/19 Going by release order, this is the first Nyssa story from Big Finish. Unfortunately, like a lot of the very early stories, it’s not very good at all. It’s set in Alaska, which means characters with dodgy “American” accents, and Native mysticism handled rather poorly. Doctor Who doesn’t usually do well when they try to bring in mysticism respectfully, and the psuedo-science story behind it this time doesn’t hold up particularly well.
docs.title: The Land of the Dead

docs.text: The Light at the End Special Released: 23 October 2013 Listened: 12/21/19 This is an Eighth Doctor story, but for the Fifth Doctor and Nyssa, it probably takes place around here. It was during the time just the two of them were in the TARDIS, but it’s hard to pin down closer than that.
docs.title: The Light at the End

docs.text: Special Released: 23 October 2013 Listened: 12/21/19 This is an Eighth Doctor story, but for the Fifth Doctor and Nyssa, it probably takes place around here. It was during the time just the two of them were in the TARDIS, but it’s hard to pin down closer than that.

docs.text: The Mutant Phase Main Range #15 Released: 18 December 2000 Listened: 12/21/19 This is one of the earliest Big Finish crossovers, as it’s one of the stories that kinda-sorta links to the Dalek Empire series. On the whole, unfortunately, it’s just not that memorable, especially for a Dalek story. Nyssa and the Doctor seem more caught up in events than influencing them, and at the mercy of some timey-wimey stuff.
docs.title: The Mutant Phase

docs.text: The Second Oldest Question Short Trips #9.10 Released: 2 October 2019 Listened: 4/21/20 Placing this one here more or less arbitrarily. I’ll spoil the title right away, because the story does too: It’s an old joke involving poultry and thoroughfares. The Doctor and Nyssa encounter a village that has put a chicken on trial for the crime of arson. The story doesn’t take itself seriously, and neither does the Doctor, which makes this a fun little story.
docs.title: The Second Oldest Question

docs.text: The Three Companions Special Released: April 2009 Listened: 12/21/19 This story is kind of an experiment: twelve ten-minute episodes tacked onto the end of Main Range stories, although it has also been sold as a single unit. It features Polly, the Brigadier, and Thomas Brewster as the titular companions, which is a fairly odd combination. The Fifth Doctor doesn’t feature at all, but chronologically, it goes here. It’s fun in the same way that Companion Chronicles are fun, and gives Polly and the Brig more of a Main Range spotlight.
docs.title: The Three Companions

docs.text: Time Reef Main Range #113 Released: September 2008 Listened: 12/21/19 The backdrop of this story is distinctly bizarre, with space-time crows and sailors adrift in the vortex. It’s all very high-concept. The character work, though, with Brewster having impersonated the Doctor and getting gradually caught out, reveals a character out of his depth, and both doing the best he can while utterly failing to do the right thing. The setting definitely makes a lasting impression.
docs.title: Time Reef

docs.text: Tomb Ship Main Range #186 Released: 14 May 2014 Listened: 12/21/19 This story attempts to create an Indiana Jones-type atmosphere, with an alien tomb full of death traps. But the way the family doesn’t get along and the sons are regarded as expendable cannon fodder put me in mind of the brothers from “Journey to the Centre of the TARDIS.” It’s a decent enough story, but Hannah Bartholemew doesn’t add a whole lot to it.
docs.title: Tomb Ship

docs.text: Tweaker Subscriber Short Trips #2014-1 Released: 9 January 2014 I don’t have this one yet.

docs.title: Tweaker

docs.text: Winter for the Adept Main Range #10 Released: July 2000 Listened: 12/8/19 Nyssa’s next outing is marginally better than the last, although not a ton. Nyssa has a lot more agency in this one, but that mostly manifests in her being angry at the Doctor. Once again we’ve got supernatural phenomena with a scientific explanation, which is slightly more plausible than last time. The big highlight for this story is India Fisher as a boarding-school hellion named “Peril,” using her natural voice, which means that Peril sounds exactly like Charley Pollard.
docs.title: Winter for the Adept

Nyssa has a lot more agency in this one, but that mostly manifests in her being angry at the Doctor. Once again we’ve got supernatural phenomena with a scientific explanation, which is slightly more plausible than last time. The big highlight for this story is India Fisher as a boarding-school hellion named “Peril,” using her natural voice, which means that Peril sounds exactly like Charley Pollard.
docs.title: Winter for the Adept

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor, Nyssa, and Tegan Once Janet Fielding agreed to return for more Big Finish audios, but Matthew Waterhouse hadn’t yet, this section became the obvious choice to insert the stories. Tegan is more relaxed than in her earlier stint, with the pressure to get to Heathrow removed. There is some awkwardness in that they really don’t address the fact that it’s been much longer for the Doctor and Nyssa than it was for Tegan, but there was no evidence of that on TV, so it’s best to keep that pretense up. There’s also a large section of this period where the Doctor is traveling alone. That doesn’t correspond to anything from TV, but the idea that he left them in Amsterdam for a bit, which turned out to be much longer than “a bit,” works reasonably well. So any “Fifth Doctor alone” story tends to get shoved into this part of the timeline.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor, Nyssa, and Tegan

docs.title: The Fifth Doctor, Nyssa, and Tegan

docs.text: A Requiem for the Doctor The Diary of River Song #3.2 Released: 23 January 2018 Listened: 12/7/19 The next three stories come from the third Diary of River Song box set. At this point, Big Finish had given up on having River try to tiptoe around the Doctor’s older incarnations, and she just interacts with him directly, for an extended period. It’s implied that the Doctor travels with first Brooke, then River, for quite some time, which stretches credulity on the “Trying to get back to Amsterdam” story, but it’s what we’ve got. This is more River’s story than the Doctor’s, but he does get to be fairly sharp and action-oriented. River relates a little differently to each Doctor, but she seems to have basic affection for the Fifth, probably because of his similarity to the Tenth. The ending is perhaps a bit contrived, but Jac Rayner and Alex Kingston really sell it.
docs.title: A Requiem for the Doctor

docs.title: A Requiem for the Doctor

docs.text: Aimed at the Body Main Range #269 Released: 1 October 2020 Listened: 10/16/20 I’m not 100% sure where these go yet, so I’ll slot them in this “Fifth Doctor solo” period until I learn otherwise. This is another quartet of short stories, under the heading “Shadow of the Daleks 1,” which is odd coming so soon after #266, with the same format. However, this form was a necessity because of the 2020 Covid lockdown, which rendered some actors unavailable. In this one, the Doctor ends up in Australia in 1933, where he immediately runs into cricketer Douglas Jardine, his girlfriend Flora, and her mother, who are on a trek in the mountains, but have lost their guide. Douglas is a famous, and somewhat controversial cricketer, known for an aggressive style of play, and of course the Fifth Doctor has opinions about this. As an American, it went almost completely over my head, but writer James Kettle does put in enough Cliff’s notes that I wasn’t entirely lost. I don’t know how an actual cricket fan would feel about it. There are Daleks lurking about -- and the one the Doctor sees looks like a new-series Dalek, a fact that he comments on -- but they don’t seem to be doing much of anything, except causing a temporal problem. As a one-part story, it’s nearly meaningless, but as part 1 of an eight-part story, it sets the scene and starts the mystery off nicely.
docs.title: Aimed at the Body

docs.text: Aquitaine Main Range #209 Released: 17 February 2016 Listened: 12/7/19 This story was released immediately after “Waters of Amsterdam,” but a lot has happened chronologically in between. This story does the best job we’ve seen in a while of displaying Tegan’s general crossness mixed with her devotion to her friends and determination to see things through. There’s also a decent time-travel plot with a good level of scientific plausibility. And the ship’s robot butler is fantastic.
docs.title: Aquitaine

docs.text: Castle Hydra Main Range #270 Released: 10 November 2020 Listened: 11/10/20 Although we’ve got the same three characters again, this time there’s more than one of each of them, and at least some of them are aware of the repetition. That leads to some of the characters locking the rest up in a spooky castle and doing...something. Into which blunders the Doctor, who proceeds to take it all apart. It’s rather basic, on the whole, but the Doctor starts to get more of an inkling of what’s going on.
docs.title: Castle Hydra

docs.text: Conversion Main Range #258 Released: 12 November 2019 Listened: 12/7/19 Building off of the last story, Marc is being cyber-converted, and even though the Cybermen don’t have a huge role in the story, the Doctor is suffering extreme levels of guilt over the memory of Adric. Peter Davison plays this all the way, with the Doctor seeming quite distraught over the thought of losing Marc. It makes for a powerful story. At the end of the story, the Doctor goes off on his own, consumed by guilt, leaving all three companions behind.
docs.title: Conversion

docs.text: Echo Chamber Main Range #270 Released: 10 November 2020 Listened: 11/10/20 For the second month running, the covid lockdown necessitated a release made of short stories with a very limited cast, continuing directly from last month, which means this is “Shadow of the Daleks 2.” The opener finds the Doctor involuntarily hosting a radio call-in show, but he has no idea why. Someone seems to want very angry callers, but the callers don’t seem to know why either. It results in a lot of talking and filler. I can understand why “radio call-in show” would seem an appealing device for an audio story, especially under lockdown conditions, but this one doesn’t seem to advance the story any. The Daleks only appear after the Doctor has already gone.
docs.title: Echo Chamber

docs.title: Echo Chamber

docs.text: Effect and Cause Main Range #270 Released: 10 November 2020 Listened: 11/10/20 The final part of this eight-part story is by John Dorney, but even by his own admission, it’s less twisty than one of his stories normally is, because the other writers have done most of the high concepts. The Doctor figures out what’s going on, and there are finally Daleks doing something other than intoning ominously in the background. Precisely what that is, I can’t say, and the explanation for the repeated characters is something of a surprise, but not really a big shock. If you’re looking for a major tie-in to the Time War, I’m afraid you won’t find it. On the whole, it’s a bit of a let-down. Maybe listening to it at another time, it won’t be so obvious, but this story really shows that it was made in lockdown with limited resources, and while I salute Big Finish for not interrupting their monthly schedule, it didn’t result in brilliance.
docs.title: Effect and Cause

docs.text: Empire of the Racnoss Classic Doctors, New Monsters #2.2 Released: 27 July 2017 Listened: 12/7/19 After the success of the first CDNM box set, Big Finish immediately did another, and because the Doctor is alone, the story is placed here, chronologically. This time the Fifth Doctor meets the Racnoss, but the Racnoss’ long history with the Time Lords allows him to go pretty far back in Time Lord history as well. The Fifth Doctor seems desperate to give the Racnoss the benefit of the doubt, which is fitting for this incarnation, and a contrast with how the Tenth Doctor treated them. The events of this story justify the Tenth Doctor’s attitude, though. Unfortunately, I find the Racnoss voices grating, and a little ridiculous, and boy are there a lot of them in this story. Adjoa Andoh plays the queen, having played a variety of roles in the TV series, but not a Racnoss. So that’s something, but it’s really not enough.
docs.title: Empire of the Racnoss

docs.text: Fallen Angels Classic Doctors, New Monsters #1.1 Released: 28 July 2016 Listened: 12/7/19 When Big Finish got the rights to use elements from the modern series, one of the first things they did was create some stories with the Big Finish Doctors encountering monsters introduced in the new series, being careful to use only ones the modern Doctors had indicated they’d met before. Obviously, the Weeping Angels topped the list of monsters to use, and yet presented a serious challenge because they’re very visual monsters who don’t speak. This does lead to characters overtly describing what the angels are doing, and announcing when it’s light or dark, rather unlike the Angels’ TV appearances, but it’s not too intrusive. Joel and Gabby make good temporary companions (and it’s always great to hear Sacha Dhawan), in the tradition of Sally Sparrow, and there’s a bonus appearance of Michelangelo, acting grumpy and pompous, rather like Rembrandt from a few stories ago. There’s a fair bit of timey-wimey, which you’d expect in a story with the Angels, even though the Doctor doesn’t actually say the phrase. So far, Big Finish has only used the Angels sparingly, but this is a decent start.
docs.title: Fallen Angels

docs.text: Feast of Fear Main Range #257 Released: 15 October 2019 Listened: 12/7/19 This is also a fairly unimpressive story, which doesn’t give Marc a whole lot to do. In fact, the story mainly focuses on the secondary characters. Nyssa gets to play evil, which the actors always enjoy, but the plot of “evil psychic alien enslaves people, including the TARDIS crew” is a little played-out.
docs.title: Feast of Fear

docs.text: Friendly Fire Conflicts of Interest #1 Released: 5 April 2023 Listened: 5/13/23 This is a John Dorney story, but not the kind you were expecting. Sometimes he goes nuts with twisty stories, and sometimes he just demonstrates how rubbish humans can be. Something goes awry with the TARDIS, forcing the Doctor, Tegan, and Nyssa to evacuate onto a space station. Fortunately, there’s a planet nearby where the Doctor’s old friend Velar (from “Gobbledygook”) lives. Velar has apparently taken up mining in his retirement, which is a bit odd, but maybe not so much if you’re an armadillo-person. The miners that the team encounter are evasive, paranoid, and borderline hostile. It’s clear they’re covering something up, and it’s just as bad as you might think it is. And once they’re in over their heads, they have to go to even greater lengths to continue covering it up. The Fifth Doctor gets to have a moment or two of real anger, which is kind of unusual for him. But mostly he sounds disgusted, which is something Peter Davison didn’t do so easily when he was younger, but he can pull it off now. Even Tegan modulates somewhat, especially once she realizes that “her people” (or some of them) are the bad ones. It’s somewhat dark and sad, but not overly so, as it’s only a three-parter.
docs.title: Friendly Fire

docs.text: Ghost Station Main Range #266 Released: 1 July 2020 Listened: 8/1/20 This story, the first part of a collection called “Time Apart,” follows on immediately from “Conversion,” with the Fifth Doctor alone, recovering from the trauma of that story. Although these are unrelated short stories, they have related themes of forgiveness, and the Doctor not needing to be responsible for other people’s actions. It has a small cast, and was released during the COVID-19 lockdown, but it was recorded much earlier, so the events are unrelated. This first story is a two-hander, set in an abandoned train station in East Germany, where a guard has an experience he wasn’t meant to have, and could potentially change his life. This one is very dark and atmospheric, a good ghost story, best listened to at night with the lights down.
docs.title: Ghost Station

docs.text: Gobbledegook Interludes #4 Released: 5 April 2023 Listened: 5/14/23 The Doctor is solo and says he’s heading for Earth, so I’ll assume this takes place hereabouts. It’s an interlude, so it’s told in a narrated style, but it’s read by Dan Starkey, who can do lots of different voices, so it feels rather full-cast. The Doctor visits Velar, an old friend of his, a member of a race of evolved armadillos called the Batearian. He comes up again in “Friendly Fire” a bit further down the line. At this point, he’s retired from being an ambassador, and is chief librarian at a university on his homeworld. If you’re familiar with university libraries, this immediately creates a visual image…with a giant armadillo. Unfortunately, there’s something wrong with the books; they’re being rendered unreadable, somehow. Lucky for Velar, the Doctor is here to help. It’s not too often that we get to see the Fifth Doctor take over and steamroll people into helping by force of personality, and I wish we did, because he’s terribly nice about it, unlike most of his other incarnations. Maybe he can get away with it when Tegan isn’t undercutting him every second. Because of the narrated format, the story is slow, almost textual, which gives Velar the opportunity to think about the previous times he met the Doctor (an earlier version, apparently), and about his place in his current society. Which is nice character work, if we’re ever going to see Velar again outside of “Friendly Fire,” and I kind of doubt that.
docs.title: Gobbledegook

docs.text: Hexagora Lost Stories #3.2 Released: 9 November 2011 Listened: 12/7/19 This Lost Story makes good use of Tegan’s background in a way the TV show never did, starting out in Brisbane, and making use of an old friend of hers. Tegan isn’t as understanding as she probably should be regarding aliens swapping bodies with humans, unfortunately. Jacqueline Pearce plays an evil monarch, and she will never be anything less than excellent in that sort of role. Also watch out for Dan Starkey in a non-Sontaran role, but you can pretty easily tell it’s him.
docs.title: Hexagora

docs.text: Interlude Main Range #269 Released: 1 October 2020 Listened: 10/16/20 The final of the four stories is even more surreal than what’s come before. The Doctor lands in Renaissance Florence, where he’s roped into performing a play based on Dido and Aeneas for a hostile Duke. But something is wrong, and the world seems to keep getting smaller around him. Dan Starkey wrote this one, and like many things he writes, there’s a lot of fancy language, which can be somewhat distracting. Unfortunately, none of it reveals any more about what the Daleks are doing. I understand this was written and recorded under very trying conditions, and the lockdown messed up the Monthly Range schedule just as the line was coming to an end, but this whole release really feels like filler.
docs.title: Interlude

docs.text: Interstitial Main Range #257 Released: 15 October 2019 Listened: 12/7/19 The rest of this trilogy is a set of two-part stories, kind of. In this release, the two halves aren’t connected at all. In this one, Marc’s first trip takes him into the far future, and again we have to confront the fact that characters from Earth’s ancient history have a tough time in sci-fi settings (Katarina, Erimem). Unfortunately, the story is mostly forgettable.
docs.title: Interstitial

docs.text: Lightspeed Main Range #269 Released: 1 October 2020 Listened: 10/16/20 This short story falls right on the heels of the previous, with the Doctor landing on a transport spaceship in transit. The Doctor encounters some of the same people as the previous story, but they’re obviously different people who look the same. The ship is hijacked by a computer programmed to take revenge on the Doctor for something he hasn’t done yet, which is always fun. There’s some back and forth and identity twists, but the story is really too short to support much twistiness. And the Daleks aren’t doing anything yet except providing occasional spooky voices. This one is forgettable.
docs.title: Lightspeed

docs.text: Madquake Main Range #267 Released: 12 August 2020 Listened: 8/16/20 This is a primarily Doctor-less story, with Nyssa, Tegan, and Marc dealing with the aftermath of “Conversion,” on the unnamed planet where the Doctor left them. The planet seems to have some pacifying properties, which Tegan objects to, but in fairness, that’s because the memory of the Mara is still fresh for her, not just Tegan being irritable. Marc, of course, has it worst of all, as his cyber-conversion has left him feeling disconnected, and his physical strength makes him a danger to the others. Because the Doctor isn’t in the story, that means they can use the Slitheen without causing any continuity errors. And it’s kinda fun to see the Slitheen again, but they’re not my favorite new-series villain, and they aren’t used very creatively here. They’re just implacable hunters, a role that could have been filled by a variety of monsters (the unnecessary and obligatory fart joke is all Slitheen, though). But the Slitheen aren’t really the important part; the internal conflict is. And that isn’t really resolved, so the story is a bit dissatisfying on the whole.
docs.title: Madquake

docs.text: My Dinner with Andrew The Diary of River Song #3.3 Released: 23 January 2018 Listened: 12/7/19 This is a John Dorney story with an artificial structure, and the timey-wimey turned up to the point where even River gets confused, and I love every second of it. This is the sort of time-hopping that’s only really been common in Moffatt-written stories, but that’s fine because River is a Moffatt creation, and Dorney handles it expertly. The Fifth Doctor is basically just a prop in this one, but Davison gets to put on a fake accent and ham it up a bit, which I’m sure he enjoyed.
docs.title: My Dinner with Andrew
