docs.text: Nightmare of the Daleks The Lost Resort #3 Released: 8 September 2021 Listened: 9/15/21 We close out the boxed set with a Dalek story, which happens to be Tegan’s first encounter with Daleks. (I guess “Resurrection” is vague enough on whether she knows what they are.) Marc collapses in the TARDIS, as a result of some signal he’s received with his cyber-parts, and he steers them to a drilling platform on a water world. The Doctor thinks that the sleep pods on the rig should help Marc stabilize, but there’s a problem: The crew of the rig have been having nightmares, and sometimes they don’t wake up. It’s Daleks invading the dreams, which is a trick they haven’t used before, and makes for a heck of a title. But things get a little confusing as there’s a lot of hopping in and out of the dreamscape, and once again the short length of the story means we don’t get to know much about secondary characters who we should care about. Mark departs the crew in this story, which unfortunately was fairly well telegraphed throughout this boxed set; it seems they’d run out of things to do with him. It’s a better departure than Adric’s, but in a story this short, it doesn’t feel entirely justified. I know part of it was due to the pandemic shaking up the schedule, but Marc doesn’t feel like he got a fair chance. So this one ends up somewhat flat.
docs.title: Nightmare of the Daleks

docs.text: Relative Time The Legacy of Time #4 Released: 17 July 2019 Listened: 12/7/19 This story is a chunk of the Big Finish anniversary box set "The Legacy of Time," and probably best listened to as part of that set. The stunt for this story is reuniting the Doctor with Jenny, the first time she’s encountered him since “The Doctor’s Daughter,” so there’s lots of explaining to do. And of course there’s a meta-stunt because Georgia Tennant is Peter Davison’s daughter. It goes more or less as you’d expect, with the Doctor trying to distance himself from Jenny at first, and later coming to like and appreciate her. The “father-daughter driving lesson” is probably the most obvious aspect, and yet they pull it off. Of course, it can’t last, and the Doctor can’t remember it, but you know that going in. The gimmick works, and that’s all you can ask for.
docs.title: Relative Time

docs.text: Sock Pig Short Trips #2.5 Released: 28 February 2011 Listened: 4/11/20 The wiki says this story comes between “Kinda” and “The Visitation,” but there’s no gap there, and the Doctor is alone, so I’m placing it here. This is one of those stories like “Cuddlesome,” where something odd is happening to a perfectly ordinary English household, the Doctor bursts in and takes charge through a combination of charm, bluster, and not listening to anyone who objects, solves the problem, and goes. In this case, there’s a force animating objects in the house of an unnamed woman who lost her infant son recently, including a stuffed pig she knitted for him. The Doctor banishes the invading force, but leaves the pig animated, at least for a while, so the woman can heal. The bluster feels rather new-series, but the kindness is appropriate from the Fifth Doctor. This is one of the more memorable short trips.
docs.title: Sock Pig

docs.text: Tartarus Main Range #256 Released: 17 September 2019 Listened: 12/7/19 This story is a crossover, oddly enough, with Big Finish’s Cicero stories. Obviously, Cicero wasn’t an action hero, and isn’t here, but the Fifth Doctor turns fanboy over him to a level that he rarely does, even for his favorite historical figures. As odd as the crossover is, it mostly works, provided Cicero manages to forget most of it. Fortunately, you don’t need to know the Cicero series to follow this story; a basic historical knowledge will do fine. This is also the first appearance of Marc, a new short-term companion, played by George Watkins, Peter Davison’s nephew.
docs.title: Tartarus

docs.text: The Bookshop at the End of the World Main Range #269 Released: 1 October 2020 Listened: 10/16/20 This one is even more abstract than the previous two, in which the Doctor ends up in a bookshop-slash-pub with a handful of customers, but he’s unable to remember his name or what he was doing. There’s a bit of a feeling of “Midnight,” in that everybody seems to have something they’re hiding, and nobody trusts one another. The same actors recur again from the previous story, except this time nobody notices the resemblance. There are indications that the Time War is raging, but the Daleks don’t really appear at all in this one.
docs.title: The Bookshop at the End of the World

docs.text: The Bridge Master Main Range #266 Released: 1 July 2020 Listened: 8/1/20 The next story continues the vein of forgiveness, with the Doctor stumbling into a scenario to help, and getting hurt for his trouble. There’s a certain amount of mystery while the Doctor figures out what’s going on, and then one of his “fits the crime” kind of punishments for the bad guy. The story is mostly about Agatha, one of the bystanders, which is kind of unusual for a Doctor story. Jac Rayner once again creates a great historical, but it has more sci-fi than usual.
docs.title: The Bridge Master

docs.text: The Burning Prince Main Range #165 Released: 19 September 2012 Listened: 2/1/20 This is one of Big Finish’s “multi-Doctor trilogy” entries, in which a single story crosses between the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Doctors, who all operate without companions. Which means for the Fifth Doctor, it takes place as he’s trying to get back to Amsterdam, but he ponders taking a more scenic route until he can come to terms with having Tegan back on board. The story is by John Dorney, but it’s one of his earlier stories, so perhaps not quite as twisty as you’d expect. It’s a story of politics, war, and a royal wedding that’s supposed to solve everything, but in typical Fifth Doctor fashion, it doesn’t, there are betrayals galore, and everybody ends up dead. Oddly, the legitimate monsters, the Igriss, don’t seem to figure all that much, except being a generalized threat for much of the story, and the “burning” aspect of the burning prince doesn’t seem particularly relevant, although there’s hints that it could become important in the next story. The Doctor is written as particularly snarky in this one; perhaps he gets that way when Tegan’s not around. It’s a decent enough solo story, but as always with these trilogies, probably best listened to together, which I’m not doing in this project.
docs.title: The Burning Prince

docs.text: The Dancing Plague Main Range #266 Released: 1 July 2020 Listened: 8/2/20 The last story in the set is also a historical, with the Doctor encountering the Dancing Plague of 1518 in Strasbourg. The Doctor wants to visit his friend Erasmus, but he’s not there, so the Doctor tries to solve the plague with Erasmus’ assistant, Margareta. Oddly, he can’t find any evidence of alien or mystic intervention. It’s an interesting change, but it detracts a bit from the story when the Doctor can’t really figure out what’s going on.
docs.title: The Dancing Plague

docs.text: The Edge of the War Conflicts of Interest #2 Released: 5 April 2023 Listened: 5/14/23 This story, by Jonathan Barnes, has a different pace to the previous one; it’s nearly dream-like, or fairy-tale-ish. It starts out with one of those “I don’t remember how I got here, and I’ve been shunted into an identity that makes sense for the context” plots, but it doesn’t really stay there very long at all. The setting is a small town in France, near the Maginot Line, not long before the war. That seems like it should be tense, but instead everything is peaceful, languid even. Except nobody will tell team TARDIS what’s going on, for much longer than usual in these sorts of stories. The Doctor and Nyssa get on with working it out, while Tegan spends time with a local soldier. In fact, she gets pretty close to him, despite knowing what’s going to happen to France shortly. It’s nice to see Tegan doing something other than complaining, but she’s still Tegan, and pretty much shouts at people until they listen to her. The villain isn’t quite what you’d expect, or what the Doctor expects. In fact, it’s not really clear what’s going on there. On the whole, it’s more atmosphere than story, but the atmosphere is memorable.
docs.title: The Edge of the War

docs.text: The Elite Lost Stories #3.1 Released: 14 October 2011 Listened: 12/7/19 The next set is a trio of Lost Stories, episodes that could have gone in this season, but were never made. They fit in nicely here, specifically mentioning that the Doctor left Tegan and Nyssa in Amsterdam for a few days. This story is one of the few that features the Daleks while managing to conceal them until they’re revealed mid-story (spoilers, sorry). Other than that, it’s a pretty normal “Ender’s Game” type of story with young people being driven to extremes to keep power. Nyssa gets brainwashed, which happens to her a lot.
docs.title: The Elite

docs.text: The Furies The Diary of River Song #3.4 Released: 23 January 2018 Listened: 12/7/19 The Doctor is barely in this final piece of the story, spending most of it sidelined, which gives River room to work, and it’s a good thing, because River is fairly ruthless in this story. It’s great to have Nina Toussaint-White (Mels) playing an incarnation of Brooke, but the younger River clones sound awfully alike, which can make it a little tough to follow what’s going on. Even more than the previous stories, this one has very strong modern-series sensibilities, and the Fifth Doctor is just around for decoration.

docs.text: The King of the Dead Short Trips #5.5 Released: 5 May 2015 Listened: 4/19/20 I’m placing this here because it takes place in 1982, which is where Tegan says they were just before “The Lions of Trafalgar.” The TARDIS is aiming for the 2012 Olympics, but ends up in an interactive theater presentation. What’s important, though, is a combination of a disgruntled former UNIT soldier and Nyssa working through her feelings toward the Master having killed her father. Ultimately, it ends up being somewhat strange, and the Doctor not doing very much. Sarah Sutton’s impression of Janet Fielding is nearly spot-on, though.
docs.title: The King of the Dead

docs.text: The Lions of Trafalgar Short Trips #4.5 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 4/11/20 Placing this story here because Tegan says they’ve come from 1982, so she’s presumably not trying to get back to Heathrow. The Doctor and company have arrived in Trafalgar shortly before Nelson’s Column was completed, when the architects hosted a large dinner atop the column. Except they’ve been taken over by aliens, who animate the lions (which aren’t supposed to exist yet) to attack the people in the square. There’s an unusual amount of action and bystander deaths for a Short Trip, and the Doctor solves the problem with an “I know you’re in there somewhere” solution, which isn’t terribly satisfying. They also leave behind an unusual number of anachronisms. I usually enjoy stories that take place around familiar landmarks, but this one kind of falls flat.
docs.title: The Lions of Trafalgar

docs.text: The Lost Resort The Lost Resort #1 Released: 8 September 2021 Listened: 9/14/21 This 2021 release is a boxed set continuing the story after the end of the Main Range. I’m not sure what name they’re putting on this series, but it’s fairly clear where it goes in the timeline. In this four-parter, after picking up Nyssa, Tegan, and Marc, all of them still on edge, the Doctor promises that they’ll talk, and tries to head for Gallifrey to do so. They end up instead on a planet with a crumbly, spooky sanatorium. Marc hopes he can get treated for his cyber-conversion, but the robot who runs the place seems most interested in the Doctor’s mental fatigue. As the Doctor tries to induce a trance state, he’s confronted with a vision of Adric (played by Matthew Waterhouse). This is one of those stories with an isolated location and a very eccentric guest cast, almost too many quirks to keep track of. Tegan is annoyed, surprising no one, but even she is careful around the idea that Adric is alive in some way. Marc maybe comes to some acceptance of his condition. And Nyssa proves that she’s capable of acting independently (which should have been obvious from the long stretch she was alone with the Doctor, but never mind). Although there’s a certain amount of deception, and some peril, there isn’t really a bad guy or an evil scheme, just a series of sad circumstances. Because the point of the story is the Doctor coming to terms with Adric’s death, and being able to finally say some last words and let go. Matthew Waterhouse certainly does his level best with the dialog, and I’m glad he was able to show up for this story, but it does give Adric a level of gravitas that he never really had on TV. I’m not sure it accomplishes all it set out to do, but it does hopefully bring to a close the friction that started back in “Warzone/Conversion,” and allows this group to go on to further stories.
docs.title: The Lost Resort

docs.text: The Lost Resort #1 Released: 8 September 2021 Listened: 9/14/21 This 2021 release is a boxed set continuing the story after the end of the Main Range. I’m not sure what name they’re putting on this series, but it’s fairly clear where it goes in the timeline. In this four-parter, after picking up Nyssa, Tegan, and Marc, all of them still on edge, the Doctor promises that they’ll talk, and tries to head for Gallifrey to do so. They end up instead on a planet with a crumbly, spooky sanatorium. Marc hopes he can get treated for his cyber-conversion, but the robot who runs the place seems most interested in the Doctor’s mental fatigue. As the Doctor tries to induce a trance state, he’s confronted with a vision of Adric (played by Matthew Waterhouse). This is one of those stories with an isolated location and a very eccentric guest cast, almost too many quirks to keep track of. Tegan is annoyed, surprising no one, but even she is careful around the idea that Adric is alive in some way. Marc maybe comes to some acceptance of his condition. And Nyssa proves that she’s capable of acting independently (which should have been obvious from the long stretch she was alone with the Doctor, but never mind). Although there’s a certain amount of deception, and some peril, there isn’t really a bad guy or an evil scheme, just a series of sad circumstances. Because the point of the story is the Doctor coming to terms with Adric’s death, and being able to finally say some last words and let go. Matthew Waterhouse certainly does his level best with the dialog, and I’m glad he was able to show up for this story, but it does give Adric a level of gravitas that he never really had on TV. I’m not sure it accomplishes all it set out to do, but it does hopefully bring to a close the friction that started back in “Warzone/Conversion,” and allows this group to go on to further stories.
docs.title: The Lost Resort

docs.text: The Mistpuddle Murders Short Trips #8.11 Released: 29 November 2018 Listened: 4/21/20 I’m placing this here to give Tegan and Nyssa a little break after “Peterloo,” in the absence of other clues. It’s an Agatha Christie style drawing-room mystery, or at least the end of one. The twists are that the Doctor isn’t around for most of it, and the villagers are anthropomorphic animals created by a children’s book author. Simon Forward does a great job of capturing Nyssa’s and Tegan’s personalities, and Sarah Sutton does an amazing job playing Tegan, narrating a chunk of the story and interrupting Nyssa at times. The Doctor shows up at the end, rather ex machina , but the bulk of the story lets the two women take the spotlight, to good effect.
docs.title: The Mistpuddle Murders

docs.title: The Mistpuddle Murders

docs.text: The Perils of Nelly Bly The Lost Resort #2 Released: 8 September 2021 Listened: 9/15/21 Why not follow up a grim, emotional story with a two-part true historical? The TARDIS team lands on the ship carrying Nellie Bly on the last phase of her round-the-world trip, just before it reaches San Francisco. Historical figures in Doctor Who tend to be overwhelmingly awesome, or else rather arrogant and full of their own reputations. Nellie here is the latter, but everyone seems to like her anyway. None of the team have any idea who she is (not that Nyssa or Marc would), which is somewhat amusing. I was aware of her, but I know most people aren’t. Tegan is at first concerned about messing with history, but Nellie has such a force of personality that they’re quickly swapping outfits so Nellie can go incognito and find out what people are saying about her. This one is written by mystery novelist Sarah Ward, and as such, it has a lot of plot happenings, but not really much drama, as all the perilous situations get resolved pretty easily. It’s apparently fairly historically accurate, except that Nellie Bly probably didn’t have someone dogging her steps, actively trying to sabotage her. The story feels very slight, almost cartoonish, and the characters all seem somewhat shallow. It’s OK as a two-parter, but I wonder if it could have been better if it had more room to breathe.
docs.title: The Perils of Nelly Bly

docs.text: The Peterloo Massacre Main Range #210 Released: 15 March 2016 Listened: 12/7/19 Rounding out this trilogy is a pure historical set during the titular massacre. Unfortunately, like many pure historicals, it’s bleak, and this one is even darker than usual, with rather a lot of death and pretty much nobody coming off well, even the reporter sent to cover the events. It’s one of the ones dark enough to make you wonder why Nyssa and Tegan would want to continue traveling.
docs.title: The Peterloo Massacre

docs.text: The Waters of Amsterdam Main Range #208 Released: 11 January 2016 Listened: 12/7/19 A later story, in Main Range numbering, but an early one chronologically. I think that’s a good thing, as it allowed Janet Fielding to get comfortable playing Tegan again before recording her “rejoining” story. As far as the plot goes, it’s more about Tegan and her personal life than the villains as such. Tegan’s ex Kyle makes for an interesting character with a slow unwinding of his backstory. Rembrandt features, with the Big Finish trick of “famous historical figure is actually cranky, put-upon, and rather egotistical.” At the end of the story, the Doctor leaves Nyssa and Tegan in Amsterdam for a bit, which allows him to have a handful of solo adventures...a period which seems to keep growing.
docs.title: The Waters of Amsterdam

docs.text: Thin Time Main Range #267 Released: 12 August 2020 Listened: 8/16/20 The Main Range entry for this month is divided into a pair of two-parters. It’s a bit odd that a significant story would be told this way, but that’s how it is. At first, this story seems to be a continuation of the short stories from “Time Apart.” The Doctor ends up at an English manor house on Halloween 1890. The house is occupied by a writer, his visiting friend, a butler, and a cook, but something is quite wrong. There’s a bit of Lovecraft feel as Things from Outside are trying to get into our dimension where time is thin. The mystery involves the Doctor figuring out who started it, why, and where they currently are, which plays out to a satisfactory conclusion. What happens after that is a major spoiler, so I won’t go into it. However, the Doctor has a good think about the price paid by his companions, and whether he’s responsible for them, or if they choose to associate with him despite the risks. His conclusion leads to the end of the second story.
docs.title: Thin Time

docs.text: Time Crash Children in Need Special 2007 Aired: 16 November 2007 This is real continuity-wonking, but I’m fitting “Time Crash” in here. The Tenth Doctor refers to Nyssa, Tegan, and “Time Lords in funny hats,” and the Fifth Doctor doesn’t disagree, placing this somewhere after “Arc of Infinity.” The Fifth Doctor also knows the phrase “wibbly-wobbly timey-wimey,” which he recently heard from River, so why not put it here, in this solo period?
docs.title: Time Crash

docs.title: Time Crash

docs.text: Towards Zero Main Range #270 Released: 10 November 2020 Listened: 11/10/20 Once again, we’ve got the same bunch of characters, and this time in a time loop built around an Agatha Christie-style manor-house murder mystery, where the Doctor is both the detective and the victim. At least now he’s starting to get an inkling of what’s going on in the larger story, recognizing what the time loop is built from, and that the other four characters are unreal fragments, but this seems like another exercise in letting the guest actors stretch out again. The Daleks are back to being shadowy voices in this one, and barely figure. There are some amusing clues that point to the Master’s involvement, but they don’t come to anything. Seems like more filler.
docs.title: Towards Zero

docs.text: Warzone Main Range #258 Released: 12 November 2019 Listened: 12/7/19 The two stories in this release are directly linked, but their tone is sharply divergent. The first part has Team TARDIS dropping involuntarily into the middle of an amped-up “Tough Mudder” race, with a certain amount of silliness, at least in the first part. Because I often listen to Big Finish while running, including the first time I heard this story, I was particularly amused. Tegan admits that her normal shoes aren’t appropriate for running, and Nyssa seems to want nothing to do with physical exercise, which seems odd, given that she’s in good shape, but maybe Trakenites maintain their figures in other ways. Marc comes off best, as he’s physically suited for the task and enjoys it...until he gets hurt, after which things get very dark, very quickly.
docs.title: Warzone

docs.text: What Lurks Down Under Main Range #266 Released: 1 July 2020 Listened: 8/1/20 The TARDIS lands on a ship of women prisoners being transported to Australia. (Amazingly, he only mentions Tegan once, and doesn’t go for the cheap shot.) It’s one of those “something’s gone wrong, there’s aliens involved, and it’s nobody’s fault” sort of stories that’s more common in the new series. The historical character Mary Ward is the companion substitute for this story, and much like Astrid Peth or Lady Christina, she makes an amazing companion, because she can’t come along. This was the last work by Tommy Donbavand before he passed away, fulfilling his desire to write a Big Finish audio.
docs.title: What Lurks Down Under

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor, Nyssa, Tegan, and Turlough This is an interesting section designed to make use of a TARDIS team that didn’t really get much time together on TV. There seems to be a general agreement not to set stories in the period where Turlough is controlled by the Black Guardian (except for one Short Trip), so in order to get Nyssa back on the team, she needs to return after her departure. It feels a little awkward, but Tegan already did it, and they handle it as best they can. This is another long stretch of stories where the release order mostly matches up with chronological order for the characters.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor, Nyssa, Tegan, and Turlough

docs.title: The Fifth Doctor, Nyssa, Tegan, and Turlough

docs.text: Cobwebs Main Range #136 Released: 15 July 2010 Listened: 12/6/19 One of the more interesting long-term twists Big Finish pulled. In order to get Nyssa, Tegan, and Turlough all together without Turlough being evil, the story has to be set after “Enlightenment,” which means they need to bring Nyssa back at a point in her life after she left, 50 years in this case. At least they deal with it up front, and give Nyssa other concerns in her life, although she keeps some of them secret for now. The rest of the story is serviceable, with some confusing timey-wimey that’s worthy of the TV series. The trick to get out of the big cliffhanger seems contrived. Ironically, behind the scenes this is the first story that Janet Fielding did in her return to playing Tegan on a regular basis, so the extras are more about that than Nyssa, who has been appearing in Big Finish pretty much since the beginning.
docs.title: Cobwebs

docs.text: Eldrad Must Die! Main Range #172 Released: 10 April 2013 Listened: 12/6/19 Interestingly, while the last Main Range story with this crew was a prequel to “Talons,” this one is a sequel to “The Hand of Fear,” and also written by Marc Platt. You don’t need to know as much about the earlier story this time, though. Turlough gets most of the spotlight this time, once again having difficulty with mind control and crystals, but as the Doctor points out, all of them have been susceptible to mind control at one time or another. I hope you don’t mind hearing the title, because the characters say it rather a lot.
docs.title: Eldrad Must Die!

docs.text: Enlightenment TV Season 20, Serial 5 Aired: 1 March 1983 - 9 March 1983 Turlough stops wanting to kill the Doctor, and both Guardians appear.
docs.title: Enlightenment

docs.text: TV Season 20, Serial 5 Aired: 1 March 1983 - 9 March 1983 Turlough stops wanting to kill the Doctor, and both Guardians appear.
docs.title: Enlightenment

docs.text: Equilibrium Main Range #196 Released: 12 February 2015 Listened: 12/6/19 Oddly, the link from the previous story is disposed of almost immediately. There’s another icy planet and another semi-romance for Turlough, so there are echoes of “Kiss of Death” here. It’s also another instance of the Doctor possibly being a bit slow on the uptake to figure out what’s wrong with this society. Unlike the other two stories, this one doesn’t have any strong need to be set in E-Space. And again, the link to the next story is somewhat odd and tacked-on.
docs.title: Equilibrium

docs.text: Freakshow Companion Chronicles Special Released: 4 March 2010 Listened: 5/17/20 I’m not sure exactly why this story was released as a special, instead of a regular Companion Chronicle, but there it is. Mark Strickson narrates, and it’s a Turlough-focused story in the American Old West, but it’s sci-fi, rather than a true historical. The first half has Turlough alone for much of it, and we get a lot of insight into how he feels right after having left the Black Guardian. The second half is more straight-up action story, with the Doctor taking a bigger role, and frankly a deus ex machina resolution. Strickson does a good job of playing both the Doctor and Tegan, just enough of an impression without being a parody. It’s a decent story for the peek inside Turlough’s head, if not for the plot.
docs.title: Freakshow

docs.text: Gardens of the Dead Short Trips #6.1 Released: 28 January 2016 Listened: 12/6/19 A decent short piece. During the “don’t trust Turlough” period, a short bit is about all you can do, and telling it from Nyssa’s point of view is interesting, because she tends to be more trusting.
docs.title: Gardens of the Dead

docs.text: Heroes of Sontar Main Range #146 Released: 14 April 2011 Listened: 12/6/19 This one is probably my favorite of this trilogy, because it doesn’t take itself too seriously. Even as an American with only slight familiarity with Dad’s Army , I immediately recognized it for the parody that it is. The story holds up reasonably well outside of the parody though, with an interesting plot that takes a while to unravel. Turlough’s character is used effectively here, both his survival instincts and his military background. The Sontarans are all distinct characters with their own motivations, a good trick with clones. And surprisingly for a Sontaran story, Dan Starkey is nowhere to be found.
docs.title: Heroes of Sontar

docs.text: Kiss of Death Main Range #147 Released: 19 May 2011 Listened: 12/6/19 This is a Turlough-focused story, which I don’t like nearly as much, unfortunately. A lot of the story hinges on Turlough’s backstory, including a romance which just doesn’t come off very convincingly. Admittedly, most of the characters are lying to one another at most points in the story, but Turlough just seems annoyed about the whole thing.
docs.title: Kiss of Death

docs.text: Mistfall Main Range #195 Released: 14 January 2015 Listened: 12/6/19 Another trilogy with Nyssa, Tegan, and Turlough, but this one is the last, as they wanted to do some with Adric next (which appeared earlier in this project). After the crushing ending of “Prisoners of Fate,” there needs to be some reason why Nyssa didn’t go home, and falling into E-Space is a pretty good excuse, although one wonders why it was necessary (and yet another case of a Fifth Doctor story linking back to a Fourth Doctor one). It feels very odd for the TARDIS crew to go back to Alzarius, but without Adric, although at least Andrew Smith is writing, and he’s the authority. It also features Jemma Redgrave, who has a rather distinctive voice, after she started playing Kate Stewart on TV, but a bit before the Big Finish modern UNIT series started up. As usual for Andrew Smith, there’s a theme of the humans being the bad guys, and a strong pro-ecology bent. The link that connects to the next story is somewhat contrived.
docs.title: Mistfall

docs.text: Prisoners of Fate Main Range #174 Released: 11 June 2013 Listened: 12/6/19 This one is just plain heart-wrenching, as it mostly resolves the “Nyssa out of time” plotline that’s been percolating for years. The strongest parts come when Nyssa is dealing with her family, and fortunately, the trope of keeping various secrets from various people for the sake of preserving the timeline all gets dealt with and shoved aside fairly early on. Sarah Sutton really gets to play up the anguish here. Unfortunately, the story of the Doctor’s other TARDIS doesn’t fit as well with everything else going on, and seems to resolve awkwardly. The very end will break your heart, and I think I might have preferred it if Nyssa’s story had resolved here, instead of going onward.
docs.title: Prisoners of Fate

docs.text: Main Range #174 Released: 11 June 2013 Listened: 12/6/19 This one is just plain heart-wrenching, as it mostly resolves the “Nyssa out of time” plotline that’s been percolating for years. The strongest parts come when Nyssa is dealing with her family, and fortunately, the trope of keeping various secrets from various people for the sake of preserving the timeline all gets dealt with and shoved aside fairly early on. Sarah Sutton really gets to play up the anguish here. Unfortunately, the story of the Doctor’s other TARDIS doesn’t fit as well with everything else going on, and seems to resolve awkwardly. The very end will break your heart, and I think I might have preferred it if Nyssa’s story had resolved here, instead of going onward.
docs.title: Prisoners of Fate

docs.text: Rat Trap Main Range #148 Released: June 2011 Listened: 12/6/19 A decent enough story that gets some mileage out of being set in 1983, so the present as far as Tegan is concerned (and Turlough, more or less). The trappings of the election and the Cold-War paranoia are pretty good. The Rat antagonists, not so much, unfortunately.
docs.title: Rat Trap

docs.title: Terminus

docs.text: TV Season 20, Serial 4 Aired: 15 February - 23 February 1983 Nyssa departs, for now.
docs.title: Terminus

docs.text: The Butcher of Brisbane Main Range #161 Released: June 2012 Listened: 12/6/19 This one is fairly dark and grim, especially for 2012 Big Finish. It’s also a prequel to “The Talons of Weng-Chiang,” and while not required, it helps a lot if you’re familiar with that story. It’s an odd choice for the Fifth Doctor, though. It looks like Mark Platt was intrigued by throwaway lines from “Talons” regarding the Filippino army at Reykjavik, and Brisbane, which gives Tegan a connection to the plot. There’s a bit of timey-wimey involved, which results in Nyssa and Turlough being on their own for a couple of years. Normally I hate it when stories resort to the “stuck for years” trope, but this time it works out fairly effectively. For a prequel, meaning you know how it has to end, there’s a lot going on here.
docs.title: The Butcher of Brisbane

docs.text: The Cradle of the Snake Main Range #138 Released: 13 September 2010 Listened: 12/6/19 With Janet Fielding back, and the opportunity to tell stories post-”Snakedance,” a Mara story seemed inevitable. This time, the setting is less mystical and more technological, which reduces the dream-like quality that previous Mara stories had, but since there’s no visual imagery to work with, that’s all right. Madeleine Potter manages the Big Finish trick of being an American who sounds like she’s putting on an American accent. It’s a fun time for the main cast, though, as Peter Davison gets to play a Mara-possessed evil Doctor, and Sarah Sutton and Mark Strickson get to play sheep (it makes sense in context).
docs.title: The Cradle of the Snake

docs.text: The Emerald Tiger Main Range #159 Released: 17 April 2012 Listened: 12/6/19 I enjoyed this trilogy, and this installment in particular. The Doctor’s enthusing about cricket comes off as more natural this time, and Tegan gets a lot of stuff to do. I found the part-two cliffhanger to be one of the more effective ones I’ve heard in Big Finish. Although Doctor Who often struggles to pull off semi-mystical stories, this one seems to work fairly well. The ending may not be quite as climactic as expected, but it works fairly well. Also, Nyssa gets rejuvenated in this one, which doesn’t seem to affect her attitude any, as she still acts older and wiser. Her voice may change a bit, but mostly it’s just her image on the covers that changes. One wonders why they chose to do that.
docs.title: The Emerald Tiger

docs.text: The Entropy Plague Main Range #197 Released: 12 March 2015 Listened: 12/6/19 Like “Prisoners of Fate,” this one is intended to be a dark, sad story, but it doesn’t pull it off quite as well. There’s a sense of desperation to a universe succumbing to entropy, and people who’ll do anything to find a way out. The pirates, unfortunately, are a bit too stereotypically pirate-y, which takes one out of the story. Nyssa’s departure had been kind of a certainty throughout this trilogy, but I can’t help thinking it would have been more effective if this one hadn’t happened. Nothing is ever certain with Big Finish, but this does seem like the end of Nyssa’s story, not that it’ll prevent Sarah Sutton from making Nyssa stories set prior to this point (as she continues to do).
docs.title: The Entropy Plague

docs.text: The Jupiter Conjunction Main Range #160 Released: May 2012 Listened: 12/6/19 Probably the weak link in this trilogy, mostly because it doesn’t really stick in the mind. There’s the usual mysterious aliens who turn out to be misunderstood, but they don’t turn up until halfway through the story. The rest is the usual future-space politics, which can be hard to care about. It’s mostly reasonable this time, but one the whole, not terribly memorable.
docs.title: The Jupiter Conjunction

docs.text: The Lady of Mercia Main Range #173 Released: 8 May 2013 Listened: 12/6/19 I really liked this one. Like many Paul Magrs stories, this one has strong characters, some unexpected twists, and doesn’t take itself entirely seriously. Tegan has the focus this time, as she gets to show off her leadership skills, and unlike other times she’s been trapped in the past, having a warrior queen to hang around with helps keep her from being angry all the time at the rampant sexism. A very strong story for Tegan.
docs.title: The Lady of Mercia

docs.text: The Whispering Forest Main Range #137 Released: 13 August 2010 Listened: 12/6/19 This one struck me as a bit draggy, with too much running around in the forest. Splitting the characters up into pairs, Tegan with the Doctor, and Nyssa with Turlough, allows for some good character interaction, especially for Nyssa to re-establish herself with Turlough, who can be hard to get along with. The guest cast is quite good, including Haley Atwell in her only Main Range appearance. The plot seems to be something the Doctor could have figured out a bit earlier than he does, though.
docs.title: The Whispering Forest

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor and Peri On TV, Peri met the Fifth Doctor in the previous story, and he regenerated in the very next, so it feels like she doesn’t know him very well, and Peri is most often thought of as a Sixth Doctor companion. Big Finish decided to change that, possibly because there weren’t as many Fifth Doctor companions available at the beginning, or possibly because Peri and the Sixth Doctor mostly bicker, and that gets boring on audio. Anyway, this is a short period of the Fifth and Peri before Erimem shows up.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor and Peri

docs.text: Exotron Main Range #95 Released: May 2007 Listened: 12/1/19 This is an odd story, consisting of three parts with a bonus story, and each of the individual episodes is on the short side. That said, the whole story feels half-baked. The Doctor is unusually quick to condemn a robot-based society, before he even knows what’s going on. He’s also very quick to jump to the sacrifice play. A high number of minor characters die, as well. On the flip side, Peri is still being more clever than normal, and using her botany skills. This is also the first Big Finish with “behind the scenes” extras, which are quite strange and drawn-out.
docs.title: Exotron

docs.text: Red Dawn Main Range #8 Released: 4 May 2000 Listened: 11/30/19 Another of the very early Big Finish stories, and the first with the Ice Warriors. They have a rather distinctive voice because Nick Briggs isn’t involved. Peri seems comfortable with the Doctor, and also seems to be a more seasoned adventurer. She has definite opinions about where she wants to go, and wants to use her botany skills (which she can’t, unfortunately, because they’re on Mars). Although this story plays right into the trope of the noble aliens and the warmongering human, it does lay the groundwork for future Big Finish Ice Warrior stories. This one, like many early Big Finishes, doesn’t have a lot of plot. Characters are always going here and there in spaceships and tanks that are about to crash or get blown up.
docs.title: Red Dawn

docs.text: The Meaning of Red Short Trips #10.10 Released: 6 October 2020 Listened: 10/7/20 Placing this here because Peri specifically states that she hasn’t been with the Doctor long, but she matures some throughout the story. She’s accidentally separated from the Doctor, and stranded on a failing Earth colony with only a few settlers, and a base-under-siege situation going on. Amazingly, they’re not hostile to her, and with her botany skills, she starts to integrate. Of course, there’s the whole “under siege” part to deal with, and this story has an unusually high body count for a Short Trip. Rod Brown’s writing is maybe a bit too descriptive, less narrative than most Short Trips, and although Nicola Bryant tries to infuse it with emotion, it often comes across a bit hurried and breathless.
docs.title: The Meaning of Red

Aside from the Doctor and Peri acting out of character in the flashbacks, there’s not much going on here.

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor and Peri (again) Technically, this is the Fifth Doctor with Peri again, after Erimem’s departure, but half of this period is spent in the “Key 2 Time” trilogy, where the Doctor is traveling with “Amy” rather than Peri. In fact, there aren’t any Main Range stories with Peri at all in this stretch, just specials and a Companion Chronicle.

docs.text: Circular Time, Winter Main Range #91 Released: 20 January 2007 Listened: 12/27/19 Although it was part of an anthology from 2007, this story takes place at the very end of “Caves of Androzani,” as the Doctor is carrying Peri back to the TARDIS. He’s having a vision of a farmhouse and a family, creating an “I don’t want to go” moment several years before David Tennant does his. It’s a trap by the Master, though, and an older Nyssa, with her minor psychic ability combined with her husband’s dream-analyzing machine, is able to break through with lucid dreaming. Although this presented some logistical problems for the stories of Nyssa’s return, earlier in this project, this story is quite poignant, and has a lot of references for long-time fans to enjoy. It helps a lot if you’re familiar with the events at the end of “Androzani,” but it’s not required. It’s worth noting that the Fifth Doctor willingly, even eagerly, accepts his fate, and seems to have a good opinion of the Sixth Doctor who doesn’t yet exist, which is a very generous interpretation of the events of “The Twin Dilemma.” Still, this story goes right to the very end of “Androzani,” making this a very fitting last piece for this part of the project.
docs.title: Circular Time, Winter

docs.text: Mission of the Viyrans Main Range #102 Released: 9 November 2007 Listened: 12/22/19 Oddly, although this story was released with “The Mind’s Eye,” it’s not connected to that story, and actually takes place after “The Bride of Peladon,” so we hear about Erimem’s departure before it happens (unless you deliberately listen to it later, as I did for this project). This is the first audio appearance of the Viyrans, created by Nick Briggs for the 2007 Doctor Who annual, and then transferred to Big Finish, so they’re technically the first new-series monster to jump to audio. It’s short, but the structure is out of sequence, and used to good effect. Also, Nicola Bryant does a better job here of selling panic and distress than I’ve heard in previous stories.
docs.title: Mission of the Viyrans

docs.text: Peri and the Piscon Paradox, parts 1-2 Companion Chronicles #5.7 Released: January 2011 Listened: 12/27/19 A rather famous Companion Chronicle, only the first half takes place at this point in the project, so that’s all I’m listening to here. In this part, Peri and the Doctor land in Los Angeles, where they meet an older Peri who has apparently joined the US equivalent of Torchwood. Older Peri is fairly jaded, and lies to the younger one about how their life went after the Doctor, but we don’t know why. There isn’t much that contributes to solving the greater mystery of Peri’s fate, although the Blinovitch Limitation Effect doesn’t happen, which the Doctor thinks is odd. This story is written by Nev Fountain, and that always means Peri is extra-snarky, and this time he’s got young Peri, old Peri, and the narrating Peri, so there’s snark everywhere, along with some clever turns of phrase. Nicola Bryant does a great job differentiating old Peri’s voice from young Peri’s, although as always, the American accent has a few hitches that probably only Americans notice (she drops her R’s in an English way, rather than an American one). This story is probably best listened to in one go, but the first half ends with the TARDIS headed toward Androzani Minor, which is appropriate for this project.
docs.title: Peri and the Piscon Paradox

docs.text: Rulebook Short Trips #6.10 Released: 19 October 2016 Listened: 4/23/20 Placing this one here pretty arbitrarily. The plot involves the Doctor and Peri showing up, helping a planet, and then being presumed dead because of a legal loophole, which separates them from the TARDIS. Peri seems to be grumpy with the Doctor, much more so than usual, and the Doctor himself seems a little more arrogant. In fact, I forgot that this was supposed to be a Fifth Doctor story, because it seems to work equally well with the Sixth, which isn’t a great sign. Nicola Bryant plays the narrator and several other characters in her native accent, which makes a nice contrast when she slips into Peri’s voice.
docs.title: Rulebook

docs.text: The Chaos Pool Main Range #119 Released: March 2009 Listened: 12/26/19 The final part of the Key 2 Time goes out with a bang. It’s not quite as silly as the previous episode, if you discount intelligent, militant slugs and a certain amount of soap-opera antics. At its heart, it’s a story about identity, and making choices about who you are. It rejiggers the Guardians a bit to suggest that they’re equally undesirable extremes of order and chaos, not the previous assumption that the White Guardian is “good” and the Black Guardian is “evil.” (Spoiler) There’s also an impressive turn by Lalla Ward, playing both Romana and Princess Astra in a nice fake-out that I don’t want to spoil, which turns into a plot twist a couple of episodes later. It’s clever plotting, although there seems to be a bit of Romana Ex Machina. There’s a nice, but probably unnecessary note about why Romana regenerated the way she did. With the Guardians and the Key to Time off the table, later authors don’t have to worry about them appearing again. Amy and Zara go on to star in the Graceless series, but honestly, I don’t find them interesting enough to care about, so I’m not going to bother with that.
docs.title: The Chaos Pool

docs.text: The Destroyer of Delights Main Range #118 Released: 14 February 2009 Listened: 12/24/19 The second part of the “Key 2 Time” is perhaps more notable for who worked on it than what actually happens. If you’re going to have the Key to Time, then the Guardians are bound to turn up, and since omnipotent characters are tricky to write, they have to be taken off the table. As a result, both Guardians are reduced to mortal men who are hanging around in 9th century Sudan. The original actors are deceased, so David Troughton gets to play the Black Guardian, and does a decent job with the somewhat reduced brief. Lisa Bowerman directs, her first story within the main range, and it has her somewhat farcical style on it. On the whole, the story is a bit camp, with the Guardians being annoyed at having lost their powers, and the Doctor being irritated at being used as their errand boy. It’s a fun story, but seems slightly lightweight with the fate of the universe at stake.
docs.title: The Destroyer of Delights

docs.text: Main Range #118 Released: 14 February 2009 Listened: 12/24/19 The second part of the “Key 2 Time” is perhaps more notable for who worked on it than what actually happens. If you’re going to have the Key to Time, then the Guardians are bound to turn up, and since omnipotent characters are tricky to write, they have to be taken off the table. As a result, both Guardians are reduced to mortal men who are hanging around in 9th century Sudan. The original actors are deceased, so David Troughton gets to play the Black Guardian, and does a decent job with the somewhat reduced brief. Lisa Bowerman directs, her first story within the main range, and it has her somewhat farcical style on it. On the whole, the story is a bit camp, with the Guardians being annoyed at having lost their powers, and the Doctor being irritated at being used as their errand boy. It’s a fun story, but seems slightly lightweight with the fate of the universe at stake.
docs.title: The Destroyer of Delights

docs.text: The Garden of Storms Wicked Sisters #1 Released: 12 November 2020 Listened: 11/12/20 This 2020 release is a continuation of the Graceless series, featuring Abby (formerly Amy) and Zara, the “Grace sisters” who were introduced in the “Key 2 Time” stories. That makes this boxed set a bear to place, as it has to be after the “Key 2 Time,” but there’s not much room between that and the end of the Fifth Doctor’s era. It features an older Leela (from after “Time in Office”) rounding up the Fifth Doctor to “deal” with Abby and Zara, who’ve been using their nearly infinite powers in ways the Time Lords don’t like. Leela seems to believe the Doctor can convince the sisters to destroy themselves, which seems a bit harsh, but admittedly the Doctor does tend to do that to omnipotent beings, and Leela’s always had a somewhat harsh viewpoint, which hasn’t been tempered by the events of the Gallifrey series. The Doctor just wants to find out what’s going on. They track the sisters down to a planet where the citizens are euthanized at age 40, for the “good of society.” Abby and Zara have spent a lot of time and effort trying to fix not just this society, but to eliminate the concept from human history, wherever it pops up. That’s required them to learn to be subtle and make small changes over time, which is pretty insightful for omnipotent beings. The Doctor seems torn between supporting what they’re trying to do, not supporting them using their powers to make wholesale changes, and appreciating that they’re trying to show restraint and make incremental changes...all up until he sees the chance to save just one person, and upends society in the process. Writer Simon Guerrier seems to have a lot going on in this story, but he keeps it moving, so it doesn’t devolve into a moral debate. He also has to deal with omnipotent characters through the simple expediency of keeping them apart, so the Doctor is with Abby most of the time, and Leela with Zara. The three stories seem to form a complete arc, so there’s no solid ending to this one.
docs.title: The Garden of Storms

docs.text: The Judgement of Isskar Main Range #117 Released: 22 January 2009 Listened: 12/23/19 The first part of the unfortunately named “Key 2 Time” trilogy, in which, yep, the Key needs to be reassembled by the Grace, the race that created it, because the Doctor messed things up the first time around by using an artificial Sixth Segment. As a result, the Doctor gets a temporary companion named Amy (who’s renamed Abby after this trilogy, and after Amy Pond appears) and an adversary named Zara, both creations of the Grace to hunt the segments. Peri is frozen in time for her safety, and out of this story. Unlike the original series, this one doesn’t obsess over where the segments are hidden; four are found by the end of this story. However, there’s a lot going on in this one. The first section is an Ice Warrior story, set both before and after the disaster that befell Mars, so we get a flashback to the events referred to in “Red Dawn,” which makes it a shame that Peri isn’t here. Part two concerns a somewhat silly race of insect people and their internal politics, and then it all crashes together in Part three. Add in all of Amy’s character development, and there’s a lot going on here, which partially explains why the story ends on a cliffhanger.
docs.title: The Judgement of Isskar

docs.text: The Moonrakers Wicked Sisters #2 Released: 12 November 2020 Listened: 11/12/20 This story starts with the partners split up, then separated in both space and time, so the Doctor is with Zara, and Leela is with Abby. Not that it seems to matter all that much, as Abby and Zara seem to behave rather similarly. The Doctor and Zara are captured by Sontarans, rather more open-minded Sontarans than usual, played as always by the wonderful Dan Starkey. This version of Leela is very different than what we’ve seen before -- she can fly the TARDIS to a certain extent, she’s not sure if she still has her knife skills, and she’s coldly pragmatic at times; Romana is probably rubbing off on her. There doesn’t seem to be a lot of connection to the previous story, which makes it feel like this is a one-hour interlude in a longer story. Simon Guerrier continues to play with issues of morality and power, if not quite as overtly as last time. I’m also never fond of a plot that relies on someone waiting around for years, so that part doesn’t quite work for me. I’ll give it this, though -- the way the title plays into the story is something I never saw coming.
docs.title: The Moonrakers

docs.text: The People Made of Smoke Wicked Sisters #3 Released: 12 November 2020 Listened: 11/13/20 This story returns us to the same point as the first one, but in an altered history (so all three stories happen in the same place, but different times). It looks like Abby and Zara’s alterations have made a positive difference, but as always in this series, there are unintended consequences. The Doctor spends the entire story trying to find a loophole, or in some way to let Abby and Zara escape their fate, which, to be fair, is pretty much what the Doctor always does. It’s a little jarring to see Abby and Zara get caught by long-term consequences, when the Doctor always gets away with it, but that seems to be his superpower. The nature of the Smoke is revealed (stealing from the Seventh Doctor’s line in “Survival”), and the Doctor needs to go to pretty great extremes to deal with it. There are not one, but two different fake-out endings, but that’s pretty normal for this show. Louise Jameson gets to play a more experienced and mature version of Leela, and you can tell she’s loving it. And just maybe they’ve managed to squeeze in a few more adventures for older Leela and the Fifth Doctor while they’re at it. I don’t know if this is the end of Abby and Zara’s story, because you never know that in Big Finish Doctor Who , but if it is, it’s not a bad ending.
docs.title: The People Made of Smoke

docs.text: Wet Walls Short Trips #3.5 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 4/11/20 Placed here rather arbitrarily. There’s a Victorian manor house being used as an artificial womb by an alien, but only women can see it, so Peri has to describe a lot of gross stuff for the Doctor. There’s a minor twist around the inhabitants of the house, but it’s only intended as misdirection, and it’s pretty easy to see coming, so it falls a bit flat. Peter Davison reads, so he gets to try to match Peri’s flat accent, and does reasonably well.
docs.title: Wet Walls

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor, Peri, and Erimem This is an extended area that stretches the idea of Peri’s time with the Fifth Doctor past the point of reasonability, but helps solve the problem that Big Finish couldn’t do any stories with Tegan (at first), and Tegan was around for almost all of the Fifth Doctor’s time. Rather than leaning on Nyssa for all of the solution, they introduced a new companion, the Egyptian pharaoh Erimem. This stretch also features a short “Fifth Doctor Alone” bit when he drops off Peri and Erimem during “The Veiled Leopard.” Aside from that interlude, release order and chronological order match for all the stories, even “The Gathering.”
docs.title: Fifth Doctor, Peri, and Erimem

docs.title: The Fifth Doctor, Peri, and Erimem

docs.text: Cuddlesome Special Released: 6 March 2008 Listened: 12/13/19 While Erimem and Peri are in Monte Carlo, the Doctor goes off on his own, providing another spot where Big Finish can wedge in solo stories, eventually adding up to a long solo period. This special from 2008 doesn’t necessarily take place here, but it’s where the timeline has put it. Like many of the specials, it’s on the short side, so the Doctor turns up, immediately spots trouble, acquires a companion-substitute, and takes care of business. In this case, the villain is pink vampire hamster toys that were a fad in the 80s; looks like there’s some influence from the modern series here.
docs.title: Cuddlesome

docs.text: Special Released: 6 March 2008 Listened: 12/13/19 While Erimem and Peri are in Monte Carlo, the Doctor goes off on his own, providing another spot where Big Finish can wedge in solo stories, eventually adding up to a long solo period. docs.title: Cuddlesome

docs.text: Nekromanteia Main Range #41 Released: February 2003 Listened: 12/6/19 The last few stories have been fairly dark, and feature harsher language than would be acceptable on television. I think that by 2003, the Big Finish writers were starting to take risks much like the novel writers were, taking the series into a darker, more mature place, a trend that reversed once the revived series came around. This story is especially dark, although with a title like “Nekromanteia,” I should have expected that. Erimem is subjected to severe physical assault, and sexual assault is certainly implied, although she later denies it. As in “The Church and the Crown,” there are no “good” characters aside from the TARDIS crew. Even characters who seem to be acting nobly are revealed to have darker motivations. All this jars with the twist at the end, which I think was intended to be played straight, but comes off somewhat silly. The episodes are a bit on the short side, and vary drastically in length, but the cliffhangers are impressive ones. This is the final appearance of Erimem’s cat Atranach.
docs.title: Nekromanteia

docs.text: No Place Like Home Special Released: 9 January 2003 Listened: 12/6/19 This special from 2003 slots in here. This TARDIS crew has been on a few adventures since France, but Erimem hasn’t had a tour of the TARDIS yet, which the Doctor provides, without Peri. This is a story for long-time fans, with some old references as they explore the wardrobe, and a very deep cut with the appearance of Shayde, who has only appeared in the DWM comics before now. There’s also a “rovie,” a Gallifreyan mouse, but that’s never mentioned anywhere else. On the whole, a very lightweight story, fitting for a special.
docs.title: No Place Like Home

docs.text: Special Released: 9 January 2003 Listened: 12/6/19 This special from 2003 slots in here. docs.title: No Place Like Home

docs.text: Son of the Dragon Main Range #99 Released: 6 September 2007 Listened: 12/20/19 The interlude is over, and we’re back with Peri and Erimem again. This is another true historical, which means it’s grim, but this one has a special flavor of grim, because the “Son of the Dragon” is Vlad Dracula. Erimem has no idea who he is, but recognizes a fellow leader. Peri keeps getting hung up on the fictional version of Dracula, and is terrified of him. The Doctor keeps dropping bits of historical fact for the listener’s benefit, but honestly he doesn’t do a lot. As always seems to happen in historicals, the companions are separated, and each spends time with the opposing faction. Normally, this means everybody finds out that the two sides are more alike than different, and not all that bad, really, but in this case, everybody is pretty much equally bad. There’s talk once again of Erimem possibly wanting to leave, but she doesn’t. The extras on this release are extra long and rambly, because they spend a lot of time talking about the revived series (which was in its second season at this point), and how many actors now want to do Big Finish because their children like the new series.
docs.title: Son of the Dragon

docs.text: The Axis of Insanity Main Range #56 Released: April 2004 Listened: 12/7/19 This story isn’t quite as dark as the last, but it’s still fairly grim. After an adventure in the past and the future, Erimem is now treated to one of the more extreme Doctor Who locales in the Axis, similar to the Land of Fiction or the Celestial Toyroom. This is the sole Big Finish story by comics writer Simon Furman, and it draws on quite a bit of Time Lord lore, citing them (perhaps inaccurately) as noble defenders of the timelines, willing to sacrifice themselves if necessary. The main villain is the “Jester,” whose male incarnation seems to be channeling Mark Hammil’s Joker, but the female incarnation has quite a few similarities to Missy. Erimem and Peri don’t seem to get along quite as well this time, perhaps from the stress of Peri teaching Erimem to read English. It also seems to end on sort of a cliffhanger; which I suspect was never resolved.
docs.title: The Axis of Insanity

docs.text: Main Range #56 Released: April 2004 Listened: 12/7/19 This story isn’t quite as dark as the last, but it’s still fairly grim. docs.title: The Axis of Insanity

docs.text: The Bride of Peladon Main Range #104 Released: January 2008 Listened: 12/21/19 This story is full of deep cuts and continuity references. It’s Peladon, so of course there’s an Aggedor (who doesn’t do much), a noble Ice Warrior (Peri knows them from “Red Dawn”), a shifty Arcturan, Alpha Centauri, and trouble in the mines. On top of all that, there’s an Osiran, a reference to “Pyramids of Mars,” which suddenly ties into Erimem’s history in a way we’ve never seen before. It all adds up to large piles of plot, with not a lot of room for characterization. It’s also nowhere near as grim as Erimem’s previous stories. Perhaps that’s why she chooses to stay on Peladon and become queen, much to Peri’s surprise, but not the Doctor’s. It’s a fun story, if ultimately a little light. On the whole, Erimem seems to have been not exactly a great fit, but close. She seemed happy in her travels, but was always looking for a place to stop. She only really pales because the other Big Finish original companions (Evelyn, Hex, and Charlie) are stand-outs. I wouldn’t mind seeing her again, but that hasn’t happened.
docs.title: The Bride of Peladon

docs.text: The Church and the Crown Main Range #38 Released: 28 November 2002 Listened: 12/4/19 This one actually is a true historical, set in 1626, but it manages to be a dull one, because none of the historical characters are likeable. It also drags in the “companion is an exact double for an important character” trope, which you’d think wouldn’t get used as much on audio, but there it is. Peri’s got a good bit of agency, and Erimem is doing quite well for her first trip, but she’s dealing with monarchy and palace intrigue, which is somewhat familiar ground for her.
docs.title: The Church and the Crown

docs.text: Main Range #38 Released: 28 November 2002 Listened: 12/4/19 This one actually is a true historical, set in 1626, but it manages to be a dull one, because none of the historical characters are likeable. docs.title: The Church and the Crown

docs.text: The Council of Nicaea Main Range #71 Released: July 2005 Listened: 12/12/19 Another true historical, but kind of a strange one. The Doctor and crew go to Nicaea intentionally, to witness the Council, except Erimem and Peri seem to have no idea what it’s about. (Erimem was born before Christianity, but she’s met Richeleau, so has some idea. Peri’s a non-practicing American Baptist, and has no clue at all.) I’m at a loss as to why they wanted to go in the first place. Erimem gets awfully invested in a religious argument that has nothing to do with her, and once again seems on the verge of breaking with the Doctor and Peri. It was written by Caroline Symcox, an Anglican vicar and Paul Cornell’s wife, which probably explains why there’s so much time spent making sure the listener understands the religious implications of what’s happening, and why it was so important to the people of the time, and to history. She also leans into the “there’s good people on all sides” explanation, and oddly, a scene of pacifist protesters confronting an army that doesn’t turn into a bloodbath. Historically interesting, but it probably works better if you have an interest in that religion.
docs.title: The Council of Nicaea

docs.text: The Eye of the Scorpion Main Range #24 Released: 17 September 2001 Listened: 12/3/19 The main item of note for this story is that it introduces Erimem. Unlike other companions from the past, she displays some fairly modern attitudes (atheism, women’s equality), and also demonstrates considerable wit and courage in her own place and time, marking her as a potential companion. For her part, Peri is also intelligent and brave, if maybe a bit more hesitant than in the last couple of stories. The plot wanders a bit, with the first two episodes seeming like a true historical, but then aliens and tech and revelations about the Sphinx show up in the last episode, which jars a little. The “I know you’re in there somewhere” ending isn’t terribly original, but it is a Doctor Who staple.
docs.title: The Eye of the Scorpion

docs.text: Main Range #24 Released: 17 September 2001 Listened: 12/3/19 The main item of note for this story is that it introduces Erimem. Unlike other companions from the past, she displays some fairly modern attitudes (atheism, women’s equality), and also demonstrates considerable wit and courage in her own place and time, marking her as a potential companion. For her part, Peri is also intelligent and brave, if maybe a bit more hesitant than in the last couple of stories. The plot wanders a bit, with the first two episodes seeming like a true historical, but then aliens and tech and revelations about the Sphinx show up in the last episode, which jars a little. The “I know you’re in there somewhere” ending isn’t terribly original, but it is a Doctor Who staple.
docs.title: The Eye of the Scorpion

docs.text: The Gathering Main Range #87 Released: 25 September 2006 Listened: 12/18/19 When this story was released in 2006, the big draw was that it was the first appearance of Tegan in Big Finish, and was supposed to be the only one, because Janet Fielding didn’t want to participate at the time. She’s changed her mind since then, so I’ve already seen plenty of Tegan in this project, and her departure was fairly recent. That makes this story more “sad coda after her departure” rather than “sad only appearance.” This story is a sequel to “The Reaping,” which was released immediately before, and “The Harvest,” which was released a while before. Unlike later Big Finish multi-Doctor trilogies, this one happens out of order for the Doctor, and it’s fairly confusing for the listener if you haven’t just heard “The Reaping,” so for the purposes of this project, it’s somewhat confusing. The big draw of this story is the Doctor meeting up with Tegan again after 20 years, and seeing the consequences to a companion when they leave the Doctor. However, TV’s “School Reunion” just did that with Sarah Jane a few months prior to this release, so it’s not quite as fresh as it could have been. The plot itself is nearly an afterthought, and mostly a lot of talking with little action. That allows the focus to stay on Tegan, which I think is a good choice. It has a rather melancholy ending, which has been contradicted by later TV stories and Big Finish audios.
docs.title: The Gathering

docs.title: The Gathering

docs.text: The Heliax Rift Main Range #237 Released: 17 April 2018 Listened: 12/15/19 This is the first part of the 2018 “UNIT trilogy” in which the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Doctors each encounter the UNIT of the 1980s, and specifically Medical Officer Daniel Hopkins, after the Brigadier had retired. There’s no specific information saying when it takes place in the Doctor’s life, but Alan Barnes says it seems like a later Fifth Doctor story, so here it is. This is also one of the earlier appearances of Jacob Dudman, who does a lot of Big Finish parts. The plot itself isn’t all that involved; the story mostly focuses on how the Doctor interacts with a UNIT that doesn’t trust him, and is actually mostly hostile toward him. It gives the Fifth Doctor a somewhat rare chance to be snarky and manipulative, even stubborn, which is always there under the surface, but doesn’t come out too often. For that reason, I enjoyed this story.
docs.title: The Helliax Rift

docs.text: The Kingmaker Main Range #81 Released: April 2006 Listened: 12/12/19 Yet another historical, but hardly “pure.” This one is definitely strange, even goofy, almost right from the beginning. It’s Nev Fountain, so you expect some of that, but this goes a long way. The plot is distinctly timey-wimey, requiring parts of the TARDIS team to wait around for two years in 15th-Century England. There’s also references to the Doctor Who Discovers book series, which is bizarre. John Culshaw delivers his Fourth Doctor impersonation (by way of recordings the Fifth Doctor accesses), and Stephen Beckett plays King Richard III as sounding exactly like Christopher Eccleston, for absolutely no reason that I can determine. (And there’s an off-handed reference to the Ninth Doctor as well.) Not to mention Shakespeare playing a major part in proceedings. This is the first of the Peri/Erimem stories that was written after the new series premiered, so that may explain the lighter tone, but all the time-hopping and hanging out with Shakespeare hadn’t happened yet.
docs.title: The Kingmaker

docs.text: The Mind's Eye Main Range #102 Released: 9 November 2007 Listened: 12/20/19 This is a three-parter, and frankly it’s somewhat forgettable. The TARDIS lands on a planet where the plants cause unconsiousness and vivid hallucinations. Peri and Erimem succumb, but the Doctor finds a scientific expedition that is, of course, looking to exploit the plants for military purposes. All three of the expedition members are unscrupulous in their own way, and they all end up dead, rather stupidly. The focus is more on Peri and Erimem’s dreams: Erimem dreams she’s ruling a futuristic Egyptian space colony, and Peri gets a domestic soap opera. Once again, it plays into the idea of Erimem wanting to leave, and frankly doesn’t say much about Peri. It feels kind of abrupt, but I’m not sure what could have been added to make it longer.
docs.title: The Mind's Eye

docs.text: The Roof of the World Main Range #59 Released: July 2004 Listened: 12/8/19 Things continue to be pretty dark for Erimem, with mind-control this time. There are a lot of character references in this story, to the Doctor’s love of cricket, Peri’s involuntary archaeology training, and filling out parts of Erimem’s past. Which is good, because there’s not a whole ton of plot. It’s another “old gods from before time” monster, but they’re not even particularly good old gods; the Seventh Doctor would laugh at them. The structure is somewhat unusual, with most of episode 2 being an extended vision Erimem is having on the point of death. On the whole, it’s serviceable, but not really a stand-out.
docs.title: The Roof of the World

docs.text: The Secret History Main Range #200 Released: 17 June 2015 Listened: 12/7/19 This is the final part of the “Locum Doctors” trilogy, which saw Doctors stepping into the places of previous incarnations and interacting with their companions. In this case, the Fifth Doctor replaces the First, and interacts with Vicki and Steven. It feels very much like a First Doctor story, taking place in antiquity, and having the characters separated for long periods of time. As a gimmick, it works quite well. Vicki and Steven do a great job coping with this strange Doctor, especially when neither has any idea about regeneration. As the wrap-up to a three-part anniversary story, it perhaps leaves something to be desired. The mastermind behind the whole trilogy is revealed to be a character who’s reacting to something that happened in the last series of The Eighth Doctor Adventures , so of course the Fifth Doctor has no idea what’s going on, and neither will the listener, unless they were listening in production order.
docs.title: The Secret History

docs.text: The Veiled Leopard Special Released: 2 March 2006 Listened: 12/13/19 This is a special release from 2006, where the gimmick is supposed to be that it features Peri and Erimem, and Ace and Hex, in the same story simultaneously, but they don’t interact. Obviously, you’re meant to listen to the whole thing together, but in the spirit of this project, I only listened to the first half, with Peri and Erimem. They mostly don’t know what’s going on, only that they’re at a fancy Monte Carlo party in the 60s, they want to prevent a diamond from being stolen, and from their perspective, they succeed. The two of them seem quite friendly, more so than the last few stories, and they’re enjoying themselves quite a bit. The Fifth and Seventh Doctors aren’t in this story, but we’re told they met and had a discussion. I guess I’ll find out what that was about when I get to that part of the project...in a few years.
docs.title: The Veiled Leopard

docs.text: Three's a Crowd Main Range #69 Released: May 2005 Listened: 12/10/19 There’s continuity here, in that Peri and the Doctor are worried about Erimem after the mind-control in the last story. Unfortunately, they seem to think that maybe Erimem wants to get off the ride (hence the title), when she doesn’t really say that. The story itself has a fairly small cast, consisting of agoraphobic colonists who can’t handle a hallway, much less going outside. That could be clever, but Peri is kind of at a loss of how to interact with them, so the story consists mostly of dragging unwilling people around corridors. When faced with a “kill all the bad guys to save the colonists,” the Doctor only objects weakly, then goes along with it, which is odd. And worse, I’m pretty sure the plan killed a number of colonists too, but they don’t have speaking parts, so nobody mentions them. The Doctor is never much for sticking around after the story ends, but in this case, it really seems doubtful that the colonists will make it on their own, and he just leaves. Wendy Padbury (Victoria) plays the morally corrupt head of the colony, but as noted elsewhere, she really doesn’t sound much like Victoria anymore, so you wouldn’t know if you didn’t recognize her name.
docs.title: Three's a Crowd

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor, Tegan, and Turlough This is an odd set of stories. Even though this TARDIS team lasted most of a season, there aren’t many stories with just Tegan and Turlough as companions. Big Finish released a trilogy focusing on Kamelion in 2019, set early in this season, and the rest of the stories are inserted around here because that’s where they happen to fit. The small trip at the end of “Frontios” is the only time Tegan traveled with the Doctor without anyone else, so some stories get wedged in there.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor, Tegan, and Turlough

docs.text: And You Will Obey Me Main Range #211 Released: 12 April 2016 Listened: 11/30/19 This is the first part of the “Master trilogy” from 2016, which features the Jeffrey Beavers and Alex McQueen Masters, and probably best listened to with its siblings, but in chronological order, it falls here. Although the Doctor is traveling with Tegan and Turlough in this story, they don’t appear. The story is mostly focused on the Master, whose characterization seems a bit off in this story -- he’s more cruel, and very angry. It’ll be explained in the third part of the trilogy, but not here. There’s some good bait-and-switch plotting, as several characters are not what they appear to be at first. The resolution of the plot is a bit of a let-down, though.
docs.title: And You Will Obey Me

docs.text: Black Thursday Main Range #248 Released: 12 February 2019 Listened: 11/30/19 This story is particularly dark, mostly because it’s paired with “Power Game,” but it’s fitting, given that this season’s stories tended to be kind of dark. I think Kamelion’s overactive empathy is used best in this story, where he’s trying to do what he believes is the right thing, but keeps fouling it up. Tegan gets to be justifiably outraged rather a lot too; it’s nice to see her be shouty and right at the same time.
docs.title: Black Thursday

docs.text: Main Range #248 Released: 12 February 2019 Listened: 11/30/19 This story is particularly dark, mostly because it’s paired with “Power Game,” but it’s fitting, given that this season’s stories tended to be kind of dark. docs.title: Black Thursday

docs.text: Devil in the Mist Main Range #247 Released: 15 January 2019 Listened: 11/30/19 I enjoyed this story more in spite of Kamelion than because of him. The space-hippo aliens are interesting as individuals and well-characterized as a group. Tegan gets some solo time to show off her skills, and Turlough is a part of the action without really wanting to be. The plot has enough twists that each episode feels individual, although the ending could have been a bit better.
docs.title: Devil in the Mist

docs.text: Excelis Dawns Special Release Released: 11 February 2002 Listened: 11/30/19 A special release from 2002, it’s part of the “Excelis trilogy,” spread over the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Doctors. As such, it’s very odd to listen to in isolation, but that’s the way this project goes. Even more oddly, it’s specifically set at the end of “Frontios,” when Turlough is left behind on Frontios, and Tegan just...stays in the TARDIS the entire time, uncharacteristically (because it was recorded before Janet Fielding was participating). It’s awesome to hear Anthony Stewart Head in a story, except he’s playing a bombastic warlord, and mostly does a lot of boasting and shouting. And then there’s Iris Wildthyme, played with her usual over-the-top style by Katy Manning. Iris does best when she sparks off the Doctor, but the Fifth Doctor isn’t the best combo with her. He mostly seems put-upon and irritated when she’s around. The plot doesn’t make a lot of sense, but it probably wasn’t intended to. This is the setup for the trilogy, and the point is the actors working together.
docs.title: Excelis Dawns

docs.text: Interludes #7 Released: 9 April 2024 I haven't listened to this one yet.
docs.title: Meanwhile Turlough

docs.text: Nightmare Country Lost Stories #5.1 Released: 14 November 2019 Listened: 1/8/22 This 2019 release was the first appearance of the “Lost Stories” range since 2013. I guess they found a few more that were lost. This one features Tegan and Turlough, possibly after they picked him up again after “Frontios.” The Doctor has agreed to help some Temporal Engineers create a virtual reality to live in, because they lack a world of their own, being outside of time. Unfortunately, the process of creating such a virtual world involves going inside, so it can draw on your experiences. The Doctor and several engineers are inside when the story starts, and whoops, they’ve lost their memories. The Doctor should be the one to guide them out, but he can’t remember how. This seems like it should be a standard “amnesia, so we all have to trust each other to get out alive” story, but it isn’t, because on the outside of the VR, Tegan and Turlough are working with a bunch of engineers to try to help. Tegan is unusually empathetic in this story, convincing the other characters to work with her instead of just shouting at them, although she still has a thread of sarcasm. It’s kind of out of character, but I think I like this Tegan better. Turlough, for his part, is a little more forceful in this story than he normally is. The whole thing takes a twist in part 4, where “can we get out?” takes a back seat to “what do we do about the monsters who got out?” There’s a thread of philosophy involved, discussing the nature of reality, and what death means in VR, but it doesn’t go very deep. Still, this story was apparently rejected in the 80s for being too high-concept, and I guess I can see that, but it can’t have been that strange, because it works perfectly fine now. Also, Big Finish stalwarts Beth Chalmers and Tracy Wiles both appear as secondary characters in this story. Amazingly, this is the first time they’ve ever appeared together in one story. There are a lot of Lost Stories I didn’t care for, especially in the Sixth Doctor era, for hewing too closely to the tone of the original series, and the faults it had at the time. This one is a bit different, and I like it much better.
docs.title: Nightmare Country
