docs.text: TV Season 21, Serial 4 Aired: 8 February 1984 - 15 February 1984 Tegan departs. This is the Daleks’ only TV appearance with the Fifth Doctor.
docs.title: Resurrection of the Daleks

docs.text: Ringpullworld Companion Chronicles #4.5 Released: 12 November 2009 Listened: 2/20/20 This Companion Chronicle is written by Paul Magrs, and introduces the Novelisors, strange aliens who narrate the lives of interesting people. It’s a very Paul Magrs idea, and he’s the only one who uses them, but they are pretty convenient for the structure of Companion Chronicles, and in this case, allows Turlough to do a narrated story while he’s in the middle of experiencing it, instead of the extended flashback that most early Chronicles have. The second part is even more confusing, with the characters narrating things that haven’t happened yet, leaving the story deliberately vague. The plot itself is rather bare-bones, because the emphasis is on the narrative cleverness, which means your enjoyment will depend on whether you find that interesting, or overly clever. For my part, I enjoyed it as a one-off with a short running time. Mark Strickson does a fairly terrible job of sounding like Tegan, but perhaps that’s intentional on Turlough’s part. His Fifth Doctor is rather better, though.
docs.title: Ringpullworld

docs.text: The Auton Infinity Forty 2 Released: 7 September 2022 Listened: 9/12/22 This chunk of the “Forty” story explicitly takes place here, and although the other two pieces focus on the time-displaced Doctor, this one splits the difference. Since the Doctor from the “proper” timeline is the only one to continue after this story, it’s reasonable to cover it here. The Doctor, Tegan, and Turlough arrive in the middle of a UNIT training exercise being conducted by one Captain T. Mears. The Brigadier is along as an observer, having retired from teaching (which never made much sense). Colonel Crichton is stated as being in command, but he’s away. The Brig remembers both Tegan and Turlough, most likely from “Mawdryn Undead,” but possibly from “The Five Doctors” as well. References are made to Time Scoops throughout, so it’s possible the reference is deliberate. The Brig seems unlikely to forgive Turlough over the matter of his car any time soon. As a six-parter, it’s a rather complicated story, with the first two parts dealing with the UNIT exercise, and the Autons’ attempt to use it for cover for an actual invasion. After that, things go distinctly timey-wimey, as the time-lost Doctor shows up, the action moves to an ancient Time Lord ship, and we possibly find out the origin of the Nestene Consciousness, making them rather more dangerous than we’d always believed. Much like “Nightmare Country,” Tegan is more reserved and empathetic in this story. The time-lost Doctor refers to her as an anchor, present throughout all his jumps. She has a lot of sympathy for characters who are injured or killed, and makes a number of overt references to starting to be tired of all the death, which fits nicely into the next story. The Master is around as well, with a seriously half-baked and confusing plan, but honestly, that’s par for the course for this incarnation. The Master is the only weak link in Jon Culshaw’s portrayals. He’s got the quiet, oozing menace down perfectly, but the Master did raise his voice from time to time, and Culshaw doesn’t seem to quite capture that here. Writer Tim Foley does reasonably well with all the plot he has to pack in, but I wonder if maybe this would have gone better as a four-parter. On the whole, the “Forty” series doesn’t seem to hang together as well as one might hope. I wonder if it was a victim of pandemic compromises.
docs.title: The Auton Infinity

docs.text: The Five Companions Bonus Release Released: 11 December 2011 Listened: 11/30/19 This special release takes place in the middle of “The Five Doctors,” specifically while the Fifth Doctor is fooling around with the transmat in the Capitol. It features Ian, Steven, Sara, Polly, and Nyssa, so definitely weighted toward the First Doctor era. It’s nice to see the interactions handled realistically -- some companions know each other, and some know about regeneration -- but mostly it’s nice to see the characters behaving very much like their younger selves, while still acknowledging that they’re older, and not as physically capable as they once were. It’s especially nice for the Doctor to acknowledge Polly’s role on her team. This story was made before the Early Adventures and other series put a spotlight on these early companions, so it was probably nice in 2011 to see them get some attention.
docs.title: The Five Companions

docs.text: The Kamelion Empire Main Range #249 Released: 12 March 2019 Listened: 11/30/19 The third part of the Kamelion trilogy is dedicated to giving him a complete backstory, a hidden agenda, and then a justification for why he gets hidden away in the TARDIS and never mentioned again until “Planet of Fire.” It’s a nice try at closing that hole, but I’m not sure it was necessary. Kamelion’s backstory is OK, if not particularly compelling, and the fourth story in a row with “Kamelion is easily influenced, and therefore dangerous” gets a little wearying. I don’t think this one came out the way it was intended to.
docs.title: The Kamelion Empire

docs.text: The Sirens of Time, part 2 Main Range #1 Released: 19 July 1999 Listened: 11/30/19 This is one segment of the very first Big Finish Doctor Who story, and it’s certainly best listened to as part of its own story, but this is where it falls for this project. Tegan and Turlough are the companions, but they’re locked inside the TARDIS and therefore don’t feature. It’s a fine little adventure, in which the translation circuits play more of a role than usual, and there’s a bit of messing around with history. Fine enough for what it is, but it’s clearly incomplete on its own.
docs.title: The Sirens of Time

docs.title: The Sirens of Time, part 2

docs.text: Time in Office Main Range #230 Released: 12 September 2017 Listened: 11/30/19 This is the anthology release for 2017, but stealthier than anthologies usually are, because the four stories are somewhat linked, and take place chronologically. Because it takes place at the end of Frontios, it’s a rare opportunity for the Doctor to travel exclusively with Tegan, and because of the nature of the story, Leela gets to interact with both Tegan and the Fifth Doctor. She seems to accept him much as he is, even though he’s rather different from his predecessor. I think this story exists because someone realized that the Fifth Doctor is most likely to accept being guilt-tripped into actually serving as Lord President, and not abuse his power. Most of the stories are light-weight, if not actually silly; the twist in “Past Indiscretions” is a particularly good one. Tegan also shines as “Ambassador from Earth,” and shows some particularly quick thinking, as opposed to shouting at everything. It’s no wonder Leela likes her.
docs.title: Time in Office

docs.text: The Fifth Doctor and Turlough With Tegan gone, there are a handful of “just Turlough” stories, sandwiched between “Resurrection” and “Planet of Fire.” A couple of these are some of the earliest Big Finish stories, because Mark Strickson was one of the only companion actors available at the time, but there aren’t a ton of them, because he lives in New Zealand, and travels the world making nature documentaries. They all seem a little bit awkward, because Turlough never really had a taste for adventure, so the stories seem to involve the Doctor dragging an unwilling Turlough into the plot.
docs.title: Fifth Doctor and Turlough

docs.title: The Fifth Doctor and Turlough

docs.text: Death and the Desert Main Range #275 Released: 16 March 2021 Listened: 2/12/21 This is the first part of “The End of the Beginning,” the final Main Range story, so naturally it has to be a multi-Doctor story, to reflect “The Sirens of Time.” Like “Sirens,” each part is mostly complete unto itself, although the stories are brief. Unlike “Sirens,” there are companions involved, but the choices are limited, as the stories were recorded during lockdown. In this case, the Fifth Doctor is with Turlough. The story starts in media res, with the Doctor and Turlough looking for something in the desert near Mesopotamia, but it’s the early 20th century, so of course they’re captured by English treasure hunters who call themselves archeologists. They think the Doctor knows where to find a famous gemstone, but in fact he doesn’t; he’s looking for a data crystal left by one of his old tutors. We’ve never heard of this tutor before, but he went renegade while the Doctor was still young, to look for a lost moon of Gallifrey, which probably inspired the Doctor. The tutor is long gone, but left this data crystal for the Doctor. However, there’s a mysterious Death Lord who has been following the Doctor from the beginning of the story, and turns up at the end to kidnap him and Turlough. Taken alone, the story is fine, if slight. However, this one definitely should be listened to as a whole.
docs.title: Death and the Desert

docs.text: I, Kamelion Interludes #1 Released: 4 January 2022 Listened: 8/7/22 This is the first of the Big Finish “Interludes,” which seem to be kind of a replacement for the Subscriber Short Trips. They appear with some of the boxed sets, and (so far) feature the same Doctor as the boxed set they come with. They’re done audio-book style, with a single narrator, but in this case, that’s Dan Starkey, who’s pretty versatile on the voice front. It’s the first Big Finish story written by Dominic G. Martin, and it finally gives Kamelion something heroic to do. It’s been a while in chronological order since “The Kamelion Empire,” but picks up from there with Kamelion’s wish to be forgotten. The Doctor and Turlough are mostly abiding by it, but when Kamelion malfunctions, they bring him out for repairs on a high-tech planet, which is where the trouble starts. There’s some standard “evil corporation wants to take over the world with tech” story going on, but the key point is that Kamelion gets stuck in an organic body, and has to deal with the ramifications. Starkey does a pretty good Fifth Doctor, sounding slightly breathless all the time, and a decent Turlough as well. However, they’re not in very much of the story, in favor of Kamelion, which seems appropriate. It doesn’t break anything about his established history, and has a sad ending, which also seems fitting.
docs.title: I, Kamelion

docs.text: Loups-Garoux Main Range #20 Released: 21 May 2001 Listened: 11/30/19 Another early story, this is a bit of an improvement on “Phantasmagoria,” but not a huge one. Turlough and the Doctor still don’t seem quite at ease together, and Turlough complains even more than usual about the goings-on. To be fair, he’s probably justified this time, as he keeps getting victimized in this story. Whenever Doctor Who brushes up against mysticism, it doesn’t quite gel, unless the “magic” turns out to be science in disguise, which it doesn’t this time. The character of Rosa has the usual problem of actors doing American accents not quite convincingly, and the story isn’t sure if she’s heroic or just a bit disturbed. Eleanor Bron is in it, but she’s using an accent, so you’d probably never know unless you read the credits. The story could only work on audio, as the villain does a number of things that defy physics, and are impossible to visualize.
docs.title: Loups-Garoux

docs.text: Phantasmagoria Main Range #2 Released: 4 October 1999 Listened: 11/30/19 The very first Big Finish to feature a single Doctor and companion, and...well, it’s awfully forgettable. I’ve listened to it a few times, and it just doesn’t stick in the mind. Turlough seems to have his own motivation half the time, and the Doctor doesn’t seem all that worried about what he’s up to. The actors playing English upper-class folks are a bit over the top with their period accents. The villain doesn’t seem to really do all that much. The whole thing is quite talky, as you might expect of early Big Finish.
docs.title: Phantasmagoria

docs.text: Singularity Main Range #76 Released: November 2005 Listened: 11/29/19 This one is another early story, recorded before the new series premiered, so still free of any of its influence. As a result, the story is darker; the Doctor is a little more harsh, and less friendly to Turlough, which is a bit out of character for the Fifth Doctor. There’s a bit of Time’s Champion here too, where the Doctor knows how history should proceed and won’t brook any interference. Oddly, the plot itself has some echoes of “Utopia” from new Season 3, but I don’t think there was any direct influence. This is the final chronological appearance of Turlough on audio, as they head from here to “Planet of Fire,” since Turlough wants to go somewhere warm after Moscow.
docs.title: Singularity

docs.text: The Blazing Hour Main Range #274 Released: 9 February 2021 Listened: 2/12/21 The second Main Range story had the Fifth Doctor and Turlough, so I guess it’s appropriate that the penultimate Main Range story does too. It has a small cast, as it was recorded under lockdown conditions, but it’s tricky to tell that. In terms of story, it’s rather dark. It takes advantage of the fact that neither the Doctor nor the companion are human, and drops them into a situation where the humans are screwing things up for themselves. It seems to be a period of human history where productivity and profit are more important than human rights, and of course they’ve got an energy source that’s insanely dangerous that they shouldn’t be using, and it blows up in their faces. There’s shades of Chernobyl there, but also the political situation of both the US and UK in 2020. Both characters are put in situations that prey on their weaknesses: Turlough, specifically, has to confront his basic cowardice (or self-preservation, you pick). But the Doctor is trying to play fair and get the authorities to work with him, whereas another Doctor would have simply taken charge and steamrolled any objections. As many Fifth Doctor stories go, victory comes at a price and the Doctor’s conscience takes a hit, but the body count isn’t as high as it could be. The story hammers a bit hard on the foolishness of humans, but it’s a decent story for that.
docs.title: The Blazing Hour

docs.text: The Memory Bank & Other Stories Main Range #217 Released: 12 October 2016 Listened: 11/30/19 Big Finish’s anthology release for 2016, these stories are different in tone to the others in this section. Turlough still has a “long suffering” attitude, but he seems more at ease traveling with the Doctor, who legitimately seems to be trying to take Turlough somewhere he’ll enjoy, or at least enjoy sketching. Most of the stories have a theme of identity, with characters needing other people to know who they are, or not understanding who they themselves are. “Repeat Offender” is my favorite from this set, because there’s some Moffat-style timey-wimey involved, and a police officer who actually listens to the Doctor...eventually. “The Becoming” has good voice acting, but a plot twist that the Doctor really should have figured out long before he does.
docs.title: The Memory Bank

Turlough still has a “long suffering” attitude, but he seems more at ease traveling with the Doctor, who legitimately seems to be trying to take Turlough somewhere he’ll enjoy, or at least enjoy sketching. Most of the stories have a theme of identity, with characters needing other people to know who they are, or not understanding who they themselves are. “Repeat Offender” is my favorite from this set, because there’s some Moffat-style timey-wimey involved, and a police officer who actually listens to the Doctor...eventually. “The Becoming” has good voice acting, but a plot twist that the Doctor really should have figured out long before he does.
docs.title: The Memory Bank & Other Stories

docs.text: Trap for Fools Trap for Fools #8.5 Released: 30 May 2018 Listened: 4/21/20 Placed here rather arbitrarily. The Doctor takes Turlough to someplace where they can supposedly relax, but it turns out to be a British public school...in space. Turlough, of course, has an absolutely miserable time, and complains about it. The Doctor fits in as a caretaker, but vanishes halfway through the story. The baddies are a sort of sentient dimension that wants to devour everything, but that’s not particularly important, and they’re dispatched pretty easily. I get the feeling that there’s a lot of references here that I’m missing, but I don’t have the proper context to get them.
docs.title: Trap for Fools

docs.title: Trap for Fools

docs.text: The First Doctor Here’s where it all starts. (Except I started this project with the Fifth Doctor and then came back here, but whatever.) The First Doctor’s era was known for having lots of historical stories, and for having lots of companions. That mostly gives Big Finish lots of options, except that Jacqueline Hill (Barbara) and Michael Craze (Ben) were deceased by the time Big Finish started recording, which limited their characters’ use, and Jackie Lane (Dodo) declined to participate, making her, as of the time of this writing, the only living companion actor from the classic series never to recreate her role. Of course, William Hartnell passed away in the 1970s, meaning that most of these stories aren’t full-cast dramas, but rather narrated stories in audiobook style. That said, William Russell (Ian) and Peter Purves (Steven), by the time they recorded for Big Finish, were as old, if not older, than Hartnell had been in 1963, so they’re able to do passable impersonations of him. The sequence of stories in the First Doctor’s era is all over the place, unlike the tidy runs of later Doctors where the chronological order matches the release order for lengthy stretches. That’s because these stories are spread over Companion Chronicles, Early Adventures, Lost Stories, and Short Trips.
docs.title: First Doctor

docs.text: The First Doctor and Susan These stories actually take place before the start of the TV series, because Big Finish will tell stories in any gap they can. With Carole Ann Ford willing to participate, there’s a fair amount of opportunity for narrated stories. However, the Doctor as we first see him in “ Unearthly Child ” doesn’t have the empathy he’ll develop later, which makes storytelling with him a challenge. He definitely cares for his granddaughter, though, which is what these stories usually hang on.
docs.title: First Doctor & Susan

docs.title: The First Doctor and Susan

docs.text: An Unearthly Woman The Diary of River Song #6.1 Released: Listened: 12/30/19 For the sixth set of River Song stories, River appears in close proximity to famous stories of the first four Doctors, and for the first of the set, why not “Unearthly Child”? Susan, Ian, Barbara, and the Doctor are played by the “Adventure in Space and Time” cast, so it’s kind of an open question whether this belongs in the project, but this is Doctor Who, so I can do what I like. Of course, it’s a River story first and foremost, so River basically inserts herself right into established history, teaching at Coal Hill, impersonating a police constable, getting very flirty with Ian, and encouraging Barbara. She’s more circumspect with Susan and the Doctor, who barely notices she exists. Unlike the last story, this time there is a legitimate alien threat, a bounty hunter sent by the Ravenous, who’s after the Doctor while he’s still young and defenseless. That part of the story is frankly secondary to River showing off her awesomeness, and Ian and especially Barbara showing a great willingness to interfere in their students’ home lives if they think it’s necessary. It has a fast-paced, action-first feel to it that’s appropriate for River, but not so much for the era it’s set in, or the other Big Finish stories set in the same time frame. As part of a River boxed set, it’s a good romp, but in the context of this project, it rather sticks out.
docs.title: An Unearthly Woman

docs.text: Hunters of Earth Destiny of the Doctor #1 Released: Listened: 12/30/19 The “Destiny of the Doctor” stories were an anniversary project from 2013, a series of 11 linked stories, and the first time Doctors beyond the Eighth were appearing in audio stories. However, they’re narrated by a companion (mostly) and the Doctor’s actors don’t actually appear. As a result, the first batch of stories sound much like Companion Chronicles. This story takes place in London 1963, shortly before the events of “An Unearthly Child.” In the previous story, the Doctor thought that Susan needed the company of people her own age. After several months on Earth, he seems to have changed his mind, treating Susan’s friends with disdain. He’s also much more concerned with keeping a low profile, wanting only to obtain some replacement parts for the TARDIS and get out of there. It’s hard to blame him, though, given the way certain spies treat him in this story; it also sets him up to be suspicious of teachers from Coal Hill who follow Susan home, although Ian and Barbara don’t appear in this story at all. As with all the “Destiny” stories, there’s a message from the Eleventh Doctor, but this one is remarkably restrained, for him, borderline subtle. The only real complaint I have about the story is that it asserts that Bob Dylan is the anti-Beatles, which is just silly.
docs.title: Hunters of Earth

docs.title: Hunters of Earth

docs.text: Quinnis Companion Chronicles #5.6 Released: Listened: 12/29/19 This is the first pre-Unearthly Child story that Big Finish did, although it wouldn’t be the last. This story has a number of links, mainly to Susan’s offhand mention of the planet Quinnis in “Edge of Destruction,” but the framing story continues directly from the story with older Susan and her son Alex, “An Earthly Child,” which continues into “Relative Dimensions” and then into the fourth series of Eighth Doctor Adventures, which I’ll cover eventually. The story itself is strange and bizarre, as Marc Platt stories often are. Much like the other stories from this era, it’s less an adventure, and more the Doctor and Susan stumbling into a situation, finding themselves in trouble, and trying to get out of it again. There isn’t really any injustice to fight, and the Doctor is plainly dismissive of the less advanced natives he runs into. His arrogance is on full display here, and could have led them to quite a bit of trouble if not for some luck.
docs.title: Quinnis

docs.text: The Alchemists Companion Chronicles #8.2 Released: Listened: 12/29/19 Released just a few months before the previous entry, one might expect a reference-heavy anniversary story, but it’s a straightforward pure historical set in 1930s Germany. Susan spends most of the story separated from the Doctor, so the issue of the Doctor’s unformed personality isn’t a problem, although in the frame story, Susan reassures Barbara in a letter that her grandfather is a good man. As a result, the Doctor and Susan stumble into a crucial point in history, and get in trouble through sheer coincidence and the Doctor’s curiosity. There’s a bit of the general Doctor Who theme that people are complicated, even those history paints as villains, although the Brownshirts don’t get any reprieve. Carole Ann Ford does a good job pacing the narration, and although she’s not trying to imitate William Hartnell, she does get his mannerisms down pretty well.
docs.title: The Alchemists

docs.text: The Beginning Companion Chronicles #8.5 Released: Listened: 12/28/19 This story was created as part of the 50th Anniversary celebrations in 2013, and fittingly goes back to the absolute beginning of the Doctor’s story. Writer Marc Platt weaves in a lot of elements from the Hand of Omega to Clara’s appearance to the First Doctor, to elements established in “The Doctor’s Wife,” and yet doesn’t tell us all that much more about why the Doctor left than we already knew. He does add the character of Quadrigger Stoyn, who serves as an antagonist, but honestly, I think he has a legitimate reason to be upset with the Doctor. It’s also somewhat odd that the Doctor’s very first trip is to Earth, and he ends up influencing the development of life here. The Doctor doesn’t behave terribly heroically, but as established elsewhere, he hadn’t reached that point in his development yet, so the story ends more with a departure than a victory. Stoyn is left behind to reappear in a Second Doctor story, but I’ll leave that for much later.
docs.title: The Beginning

docs.text: The Sleeping Blood Companion Chronicles #9.1 Released: Listened: 12/29/19 In 2015, Big Finish semi-retired the Companion Chronicles series, by restricting it to First and Second Doctor stories only. It made sense, as the Third and Fourth Doctors had their own series by this point, so their companions (those whose actors are still living) could be featured in those stories. William Russell had retired from Big Finish, so any story featuring Carole Ann Ford would need to be a “Susan alone” story. Therefore, this was the first story of the inaugural First Doctor box set. The Doctor spends most of the story sidelined by illness, with Susan trying to find medicines that can cure him. She ends up on a world that uses nanomachines for medicine, and encounters a special ops group trying to take down a terrorist. Susan helps by using her advanced knowledge to reprogram some nanomachines, which she regards as interfering in another culture. The terrorist is killed, and Susan is left to wonder about the validity of his arguments. There’s a fairly obvious sermon about healthcare as a universal right, but also the Doctor has to evaluate Susan’s actions, and think about when interference is appropriate and when it’s not.
docs.title: The Sleeping Blood

docs.text: The First Doctor, Ben, and Polly For quite some time, poor Anneke Wills was a bit stuck. She was up for participating in Big Finish, but Michael Craze had died in 1998, and there were no stories with Polly but without Ben. Some Companion Chronicles were possible, and she did a few of those, but they mostly focused on the Second Doctor era, probably because Frazier Hines is always up to play both Jamie and the Second Doctor. Eventually, though, Big Finish recast Elliot Chapman as Ben, and although the focus is still on the Second Doctor era, there have been a few later Companion Chronicles where Polly and Ben are traveling with the First Doctor, which takes us right up to the end of this era.
docs.title: First Doctor, Ben, & Polly

docs.title: The First Doctor, Ben, and Polly

docs.text: Falling Short Trips #7.5 Released: 30 May 2017 Listened: 5/1/20 This one is an odd duck. It’s one of three stories that wants to be set immediately before “The Tenth Planet,” which doesn’t quite work. It also has a framework like a Companion Chronicle, with Polly feeling reflective much later in her life. As for the story itself, the narration seems rather overwritten, with excessive vocabulary that makes it hard to concentrate on the story. Not that there’s a lot of story, really. The TARDIS crew encounters what appears to be an angel, which lectures them on the importance of letting go. The whole story has a rather dream-like quality, which ultimately renders it somewhat forgettable.
docs.title: Falling

docs.text: The Bonfires of the Vanities Companion Chronicles #11.3 Released: 15 June 2017 Listened: 3/4/20 This is the first story in this project to feature both Polly and Ben, but not the first Anneke Wills and Elliot Chapman recorded (they did some Second Doctor stories first). There’s a difference in the way they treat the Doctor here; they’re obviously not used to him yet, but they also treat him as someone who needs a lot of care and protecting, as he’s clearly nearing the end of his life. Wills and Chapman split the narration, which means they each get a chance to voice the Doctor, and they both do reasonably well. Chapman is really uncanny in his impersonation of Ben; I could believe it was Michael Craze. As for the story itself, it revolves around Bonfire Night, which is always going to seem a bit odd to an American. It also features a resolution of the Doctor essentially talking the problem away, which is something we frequently say the Doctor does, but in practice he doesn’t do it all that often. There’s a hint that they were supposed to land in Antarctica, but got diverted; that won’t be explained for a bit. It’s a fairly strong start to this short era of the show.
docs.title: The Bonfires of the Vanities

docs.text: The Crumbling Magician Companion Chronicles #13.4 Released: 18 September 2019 Listened: 3/5/20 In this Chronicle, Anneke Wills gets to show her range, playing Polly, the Doctor inhabiting Polly’s body, and a homicidal medical AI. And if that weren’t enough, David Warner plays an eight-year-old boy. There’s lots of Acting to go around in this story, plus Guy Adams layers lots of time-shifting on top of it, so you have to pay attention to what’s going on. There’s more references to the Doctor nearing the end of his life, and perhaps being tempted by the idea of a younger body. There’s not a lot of direct conflict, and the Doctor’s talked down evil computers before, but the main plot isn’t really the point for this one.
docs.title: The Crumbling Magician

docs.text: The Locked Room Companion Chronicles #9.4 Released: 3 June 2015 Listened: 3/7/20 For the Doctor, this takes place during “The Tenth Planet.” It’s a story with Steven, though, a sequel to “The War to End All Wars” and “The Founding Fathers.” It also connects back to “The First Wave,” also by Simon Guerrier, featuring the Vardans. Unlike the stories just referred to, this one doesn’t have a flashback, so Peter Purves is only playing a version of Steven who’s older than himself, and the Doctor at the very end of his life. It’s clear he’s about to regenerate, but he’s a copy of himself taken away from his body, so it probably happens during episode three of “The Tenth Planet” when the Doctor is unconscious. Although the title implies it, the story isn’t a locked-room mystery. It is, however, mostly a moral dilemma, with Steven facing up to things he’s done as king, and recalling the sacrifices his TARDIS companions made. Steven, more than almost any other companion, has cause to regret what happened to his friends, and that’s reflected upon here. It’s a solid story, mostly reflective, which is appropriate for the last First Doctor story, and also the last chronological appearance of Steven and Peter Purves. They’ll turn up again in this chronology, though, because time travel is a wonderful thing.
docs.title: The Locked Room

docs.title: The Locked Room

docs.text: The Plague of Dreams Companion Chronicles #11.4 Released: 15 June 2017 Listened: 3/6/20 This is another by Guy Adams, and it’s quite metatextual. We get an explanation of both the TARDIS getting diverted back in “Bonfires of the Vanities,” and of the small time-glitches that have been happening throughout this boxed set. The Time War has come for the First Doctor, with his enemies trying to divert his timeline early in life. Another Time Lord is sent to try to put him back on track, except they can’t really talk about Time Lords or the Time War, so it’s all veiled. There are more references to the Doctor being weakened and his time running out. There’s yet another contrivance to let the Doctor speak with Polly’s voice, explaining Anneke Wills’ interpretation. The story itself revolves around a “psycho-active virus,” which basically means dreams coming to life, and the characters having to embrace the “power of stories” to avert the problem. Which means it’s a story about stories, and that’s more important than the plot itself. It’s a rather short recording, but if you hang around through the extras, you can hear the trailer for this box set, which explains the timey-wimey. This is the last Big Finish appearance of Polly and Ben in this part of the chronology, as it leads directly to “The Tenth Planet,” for real this time, but they’ll be back in the next era.
docs.title: The Plague of Dreams

docs.text: The First Doctor, Ian, Barbara, and Vicki There aren’t a ton of stories with Ian, Barbara and Vicki, but the ones that exist are pretty good. Ian and Barbara are pretty comfortable in the TARDIS by this point, and not as fixated on getting home (until they actually do). Vicki is the “new one” for a while, but it’s clear that although the Doctor dotes on her as a replacement for Susan, she’s not as passive or obedient as Susan could be.
docs.title: First Doctor, Ian, Barbara, & Vicki

docs.title: The First Doctor, Ian, Barbara, and Vicki

docs.text: 1963 Short trips #2.1 Released: 26 February 2011 Listened: 4/26/20 The TARDIS finally makes it back to 1963, specifically London on November 23, 1963, but everything is frozen in time, except for the travelers. Ian and Barbara explore the city while the Doctor and Vicki work on the problem in the TARDIS. That gives Ian and Barbara time to reflect on the chaos of the world at that time -- Kennedy’s assassination, the Cold War, and the difficulties faced by homosexuals in that era. In the end, it’s the TARDIS that’s at fault, not the world, and the only thing the travelers can do is leave again.

Daybreak Companion Chronicles #13.2 Released: 18 September 2019 Listened: 1/29/20 Like the last story in this project, this one sees a companion being interrogated by a government agent as its frame story. Unlike the last story, though, Vicki doesn’t relate previous events; she just has flashbacks to an earlier point in the story. The unique element of this story is that it’s set at a point that’s history to Vicki, but the future to Ian and Barbara, so Vicki is the only one who knows what historically happened, except she finds out that history doesn’t always get it right. It’s a darker story than we’ve seen so far with Vicki, and Maureen O’Brien does a good job of showing how Vicki is affected by it.
docs.title: Daybreak

docs.text: Starborn Companion Chronicles #8.9 Released: 13 March 2014 Listened: 1/25/20 This is the first chronological appearance of Vicki in this project (welcome!), but far from Maureen O’Brien’s first Big Finish. The Companion Chronicles series had generally moved on from the format of “older companion telling someone a story of what happened when they were younger,” and instead this story takes place in Vicki’s “present,” with someone else telling Vicki a story of her immediate future, in the hope of changing it. The writing, by Jac Rayner, is pretty clever here, with things seeming to be continuity errors that turn out to be otherwise. The other character in this story is played by Jacqueline King, who played Donna’s mum Sylvia in the TV series, and has done a ton of Big Finish work, and I never would have realized if not for the extras. As for the story itself, it’s slight, given that the flash-forward and the frame story are given about equal time, but pretty good, with some high concept ideas.
docs.title: Starborn

docs.text: The Chase TV Season 2, Serial 8 Aired: 22 May 1965 - 26 June 1965 The Daleks return yet again, and as the title implies, chase the TARDIS crew all over time and space. It’s the first appearance of Steven, and also the first and only TV appearance of the Mechonoids. Ian and Barbara depart in the Daleks’ ship, and it’s confirmed that they made it home (slightly late) in a rather joyful montage scene.
docs.title: The Chase

docs.text: The Dark Planet Lost Stories #4.1 Released: 12 September 2013 Listened: 1/27/20 A lot of Big Finish stories from this era are shorter, as a result of their formats. This is not one of those. As a Lost Story, it follows the six-part format, and its pacing is definitely “of its era.” There are several reveals, which are paced out through the story, and the ending is still unexpected, but it does feel like it could have been trimmed down a bit. Still, it’s a fairly high concept, featuring creatures made entirely of light or darkness, and a giant crystal city, all of which would have been a challenge to render on television, even today, much less 1964. Ultimately, it’s a Cold War metaphor, and although it’s an obvious one on some levels, the ending is still in doubt, and didn’t go where I thought it was going to. The down side is that the TARDIS crew is mostly passive, getting swept along by events, or worse, being used as pawns. It’s a good kernel of an idea, but it didn’t keep my attention as well as I wanted it to.
docs.title: The Dark Planet

docs.text: The Doctor's Tale Early Adventures #1.2 Released: 17 October 2014 Listened: 1/31/20 This is another longer story, from the first set of Early Adventures. The formula hadn’t quite gelled yet, so the story mostly focuses on Ian and Vicki, with Barbara off-stage for almost the entire story. I imagine the story is more effective if you know more about the death of Richard II and the rise of Henry IV, but I don’t, really. One of the main historical characters is Richard’s queen Isabella, who is portrayed as being around Vicki’s age, and a firebrand, although historically, she would have been rather younger. The other figure is Geoffrey Chaucer, who seems like he should play an important role, but mostly just seems to tag along with the others. The plot itself is typical for a second-season historical, with the characters stumbling into trouble, getting separated, and spending the rest of the story trying to find one another again and get back to the TARDIS. It’s not a particularly strong story, which makes it a shame that it leads directly into “The Chase,” which means this is the last appearance of Ian and Barbara in this project.
docs.title: The Doctor's Tale

docs.text: The Fifth Traveller Early Adventures #3.2 Released: 13 October 2016 Listened: 1/30/20 Early Adventures are four-parters, so we’re back to a longer story. Which is good, because the Doctor, Ian, Barbara, Vicki, and Jospa -- what’s that? You don’t remember Jospa? There’s a reason for that. The writer doesn’t really try to trick you for too long about that, but with the longer running time, the mystery can simmer in the background just long enough for you to accept Jospa. The only real flaw is that James Joyce, who plays Captain Carter in the UNIT series, doesn’t really sound like he’s Vicki’s age, which is what we’re supposed to believe. Speaking of voices, though, Jemma Powell plays Barbara again, William Russell plays both Ian and the Doctor, and Maureen O’Brien plays a much younger Vicki. It shouldn’t work with that many different actors, but for the most part, it comes off fine. Russell isn’t the best Hartnell impersonator, but he captures the essence. His Ian mostly sounds the right age, except for a few moments. Maureen O’Brien somehow makes you think she’s a girl without fail, and Powell’s accent, which sounded a bit out of place in the other Early Adventure she’s in, doesn’t really jar here. As for the rest of the plot, it’s serviceable, but a story about psychic orangutans is a little hard to get your head around.
docs.title: The Fifth Traveler

docs.text: The Revenants Companion Chronicles Special Released: 31 May 2012 Listened: 1/17/23 There’s only one story in this gap between Susan leaving and Vicki joining, this Companion Chronicle special. It’s on the long side for a Companion Chronicle, clocking in at a bit over an hour. I have no clue what makes this story warrant a special, but here it is. As often happens, Ian and Barbara get separated from the Doctor early on, but in this case, it’s the TARDIS that leaves, which in this era, means they’ll likely never see him again. So they’re stuck on Orkney, but fortunately, quite close to their own time. And, of course, there’s something weird going on, connected to the ancient legends of Orkney, because of course it is. William Russell continues to sound good as both Ian and the Doctor, but like many Chronicles, this one uses the conceit of Ian telling the story much later in life. The story itself is actually fairly small-scale, without a whole lot of actual peril, but the cliffhanger at the end of Part 1 and the twist at the end of Part 2 are quite well executed.
docs.title: The Revenants

docs.text: The Rocket Men Companion Chronicles #6.2 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 1/31/20 I’ve been looking forward to this story for a while, because I’ve heard other Rocket Men stories, but I hadn’t heard the original. Plus, I love a John Dorney story. This is one of his earlier ones, so it’s relatively straightforward, and not as twisty as his later stories. The storyline is split in two, though, alternating between different time periods within the story, before catching up at the end. That serves to preserve the suspense of the cliffhanger before it happens, but there’s no narrative reason for the story to be split like that. Unlike the older Companion Chronicles, this is just a straight story, without a frame of an older Ian telling a story. While the cliffhanger is very dramatic, and probably would have looked amazing on TV, I was able to figure out the resolution, which takes a little bit away from it. The focus of the story is mostly on Ian, with Vicki in a minor role, and the Doctor mostly off-screen. Specifically, it’s about Ian and Barbara’s relationship finally moving forward, something that the extras imply they felt confident doing because The Sarah Jane Adventures had stated that they end up together. It’s emotionally satisfying, and appropriate that this story takes place late in their tenure. The Rocket Men may not be to everyone’s taste, since they’re modeled on 50s movie-serial villains, but I like them. They’re a legitimate recurring threat, and because their goals are relatively simple, they just have to be stopped when they appear, not completely crushed.
docs.title: The Rocket Men

docs.text: The Sleeping City Companion Chronicles #8.8 Released: 13 February 2014 Listened: 1/28/20 A bit further down the chronology now, this Companion Chronicle’s frame story takes place after Ian and Barbara have returned home, and seem to be in a lot of trouble with spy agencies because of their disappearance, which is realistic, but more of a new-series idea. So Ian decides to tell a story of some random visit to a planet where the citizens all engage in shared dreaming. Except not everything is what it seems, and it wraps up rather nicely. The character work here is particularly strong, capturing not just the essence of the characters, but how Ian sees them as well. It especially highlights Vicki’s more impulsive nature, compared to Susan.
docs.title: The Sleeping City

docs.text: The Unwinding World Companion Chronicles #9.2 Released: 3 June 2015 Listened: 1/29/20 This story was part of the first set of Companion Chronicles after they went to the box set format, and I think they were trying to stretch the format somewhat, without a lot of success. Vicki spends all of this story talking with an A.I., being characteristically flippant and overly sure of herself. The other actor plays all sorts of secondary characters who interact with the Doctor, Ian, and Barbara...all of whom are entirely silent, which just comes off as odd. The story itself is a puzzle, which gradually unwinds as it goes, which means Vicki does a lot of exposition toward the end, but it’s a decent puzzle, so it’s worth it.
docs.title: The Unwinding World

docs.text: The First Doctor, Steven, and Dodo Jackie Lane was the only living companion actor from the classic series who refused the invitation to be part of Big Finish. She quit acting and became a voice-over agent, representing Tom Baker, Nicholas Courtney, and Janet Fielding, among others. However, she retired in 2000, before Big Finish really got started. Although Big Finish could get around her unavailability with Companion Chronicles, they mostly just avoided Dodo for a long time. There were a handful of Companion Chronicles and Short Trips until 2021, when they recast Lauren Cornelius as Dodo. Sadly, Jackie passed away in June 2021, a few months before the first story with Cornelius was released. Since then, Big Finish have released a number of stories with Steven Noonan as the First Doctor and Cornelius as Dodo.
docs.title: First Doctor, Steven, & Dodo

docs.text: Mother Russia Companion Chronicles #2.1 Released: October 2007 Listened: 2/27/20 This is one of the very earliest Companion Chronicles recorded, so it’s a bit more narrated than usual, and Peter Purves’ First Doctor impersonation isn’t quite as polished. It’s an early appearance for Dodo, but it’s definitely set after they’ve been to Tombstone, so she’s more confident as part of the crew. She doesn’t have a ton to do, staying mostly “off-camera,” but the writer has pegged her rebellious streak, and given her some 1960s slang to differentiate her from Susan and Vicki. The story itself features the “companion telling a story to a hostile interrogator” trope that the Companion Chronicles used to use a lot. This time, it’s set in 1812, in Russia, so while it’s not a true historical, there’s still plenty of grimness as they get caught up in Napoleon’s march on Moscow. The baddie is a shapeshifter, who takes several different forms throughout the story, and Steven is really slow to pick up on it. Even accounting for the fact that he’s never met one before, several events hinge on his gullibility. On the whole, it’s a good enough entry for a first appearance.
docs.title: Mother Russia

docs.text: Return of the Rocket Men Companion Chronicles #7.5 Released: 10 November 2012 Listened: 3/2/20 This is a sequel to “The Rocket Men” from earlier in this chronology, and where that one was definitely an Ian story, this one is decidedly a Steven story. It’s written by Matt Fitton instead of John Dorney, and although Fitton tries to mimic some of the structure of Dorney’s story, it doesn’t quite come off. What does come off well is making the Rocket Men seem like a serious and credible threat, which works well with the 60s atmosphere. I don’t think they’re as dangerous in their subsequent appearances. It’s also a good showcase for Steven, operating within his own native era, so he’s the most knowledgeable character for once, and he gets to use his piloting skills, something that never happened on TV. It’s not quite as good as the original, but it’s a strong sequel.
docs.title: Return of the Rocket Men

docs.text: The Demon Song First Doctor Adventures #2.1 Released: 16 February 2023 Listened: 2/26/23 The first boxed set with Stephen Noonan and Lauren Cornelius was a success, so here’s another. This time around, the two-parter comes first. It’s set in Camden in the 2020s, post-pandemic anyway, which is a heck of a thing for Dodo, but she seems to take it all pretty much in stride, once she gets over everybody’s phones. The First Doctor is written brilliantly here, as he clearly knows about the history and technology of this period, but doesn’t seem to have experienced it himself, so he’s both familiar and unfamiliar. The story involves an alien (considered a demon by many) who’s spreading a song that hypnotizes people, and then kidnaps them. Of course, that turns out to be pretty standard stuff. A lot of the scenes with the Doctor are played for humor, as he’s either confused or confusing people. Once again, I feel like Stephen Noonan is playing him too high-pitched, and they’ve still got the tic of Hartnell blowing his lines, which I don’t like. And yet the scenes with Dodo are often serious and very grim, although the wild tracks of screaming and moaning in the background seem rather overdone. On the whole, it’s OK, but the tonal clash hurts it.
docs.title: The Demon Song

docs.text: The Horror at Bletchington Station Short Trips Rarities #3.1 Released: 15 March 2016 Listened: 3/4/20 When this was released, it was a very rare story, with just the Doctor and Dodo. As a result, it’s the first Big Finish story that deals with Dodo’s internal thoughts. That’s an interesting perspective, because we don’t really have enough Dodo around to get a sense of what she’s like. This story also features some introspection on the Doctor’s part, as he seems to realize that he’s reaching the end of his life and reflects on how he’s changed since he started hanging out with humans. The story itself is a bit spooky, but mostly standard, with a Time Lord twist at the end that doesn’t really change much, but lets you feel a bit clever for understanding the reference.
docs.title: The Horror at Bletchington Station

docs.text: The Incherton Incident First Doctor Adventures #2.2 Released: 16 February 2023 Listened: 3/3/23 This four-parter, by Nick Briggs, is set in 1947, in an isolated seacoast town, because Nick Briggs likes both those things. Unfortunately, as a result of a collision in the Vortex, a spaceship has crashed into Incherton and killed a lot of people. In First-Doctor style, it takes quite a while for the Doctor and listeners to figure out what the heck is going on, during which time the Doctor and Dodo are separated, and both of them end up getting shot, although they aren’t badly hurt. Much of the story involves early Cold War politics, with the British army trying to claim alien tech for their own, an American spy claiming that allies should share technology, and a Soviet spy that everybody assumes must be somewhere (see if you can spot them; it’s not actually very hard). There’s something deeper going on here, though, as the aliens are time-travelers looking to arrest the Doctor for things he hasn’t done yet. There are hints that his crime relates to enabling humanity throughout their history, allowing them to become a major power in the universe eventually. We’re not really sure, though, because the First Doctor just assumes it’s all a misunderstanding. There are some pretty heavy-handed parallels about the line between fanaticism and patriotism, but it’s hard not to default to assuming the post-WWII English are the “good guys.” The Doctor has a lengthy speech at the end of the story laying out his purpose in traveling, which seems a bit odd to just drop in at the end here, but it leads to a cliffhanger, so I assume we’re looking at more of these sets later.
docs.title: The Incherton Incident

docs.text: The Miniaturist First Doctor Adventures #1.2 Released: 12 April 2022 Listened: 4/20/22 The second story of this boxed set is only a two-parter, but it’s lengthy for a two-parter. Still, it feels like it has just the right pacing, keeping things moving while preserving the mystery. It’s a very mysterious, almost dreamlike story, one that wouldn’t be out of place in the modern series, something like “Midnight” or “Amy’s Choice.” Writer Lizzie Hopley drops in some scientific facts, like the Zechstein seabed, and geological quiet points. The mystery, though, revolves around a psychic entity that seems to pull images from people’s minds, and also plays with dimensions, leading to some very surreal experiences. Dodo is on her own for a while, and there’s some vague hinting here about traumatic events in her childhood, which weren’t revealed on TV. I liked Stephen Noonan’s performance better in this story; he spends more time pitching the Doctor at a threatening growl than the high-pitched giggle. While both stories are decent, I much prefer this one.
docs.title: The Miniaturist

docs.text: The Outlaws First Doctor Adventures #1.1 Released: 12 April 2022 Listened: 4/19/22 This is the first of a new era of First Doctor Adventures, featuring Stephen Noonan as the Doctor, with Lauren Cornelius continuing as Dodo. It allows an opportunity to flesh out this part of the First Doctor era, and give Dodo a consistent character, which she never really had on TV. Cornelius has really mastered her choices as Dodo, sounding a lot like a modern companion with her accent, word choice, and shaky grasp of history. Stephen Noonan isn’t doing an impersonation, but he’s certainly closer to Hartnell’s performance than David Bradley is. However, he plays the Doctor as frequently high-pitched and silly-sounding, so that when he drops into his gruff, outraged tone, it’s an odd transition. Worse, they’ve kept Hartnell’s tic of stumbling over words. I wish they hadn’t done that, as it seems like a Hartnell thing, rather than a Doctor thing, and as such, it’s rather disrespectful. As for the story itself, it’s almost a pure historical, taking place in Lincoln in 1216. King John is on the throne, the French are about to invade, and Nicholaa de la Haye is Sheriff of Lincoln. Which would be fine, except that Dodo has a 1960s interpretation of John’s reign, and gets herself in trouble. There’s also a band of thieves who appear to be doing the Robin Hood thing, but without the “give to the poor” part. The thing that makes it not a pure historical is that the Monk is here, the Rufus Hound version, helping the outlaws. Although this is much later in the Monk’s personal timeline, he was expecting the First Doctor, and seems to hold a grudge against him specifically for the events of “The Time Meddler.” However, he’s still the Rufus Hound Monk, so it’s always fun to hear him become apoplectic, even if it seems like it would fit better in a more modern story. There are minor historical characters scattered about: the sheriff’s granddaughter, the head of her guards, and the bandit leader, but to be honest, their plot threads don’t really go anywhere, or at least, they aren’t much influenced by the Doctor and Dodo. Their part seems to be mostly “get back to the TARDIS” with a side of “stop the Monk.” On the whole, it feels like the story isn’t all that important, and we’re just listening to the actors do their thing.
docs.title: The Outlaws

docs.text: The Secrets of Det-Sen Early Adventures #7.2 Released: 17 August 2021 Listened: 8/19/21 This is the first story featuring Lauren Cornelius as Dodo. It’s also a trip to Tibet, forming a direct prequel to “The Abominable Snowmen.” If you know that story well, you can probably guess at some of the plot twists here, but most people don’t know it, as it’s currently a lost story. But all the same trappings are in place, including the monks, the monastery, and even yeti, although in this case natural creatures rather than robots. Cornelius plays Dodo with a distinct accent, which doesn’t seem quite what Jackie Lane did on TV, but is closer to the accent that Dodo would’ve had. Dodo herself seems to be doing well in this story, getting along with the pilgrims and the monks, and even the yeti. Fortunately, they all seem to find her irreverence amusing. Steven is having a much harder time of it, starting with altitude sickness that makes him cranky for the whole story. Worse, he’s distrustful of several of the other characters, and flatly dismissive of the monks’ pacifist beliefs. That’s probably not out of line for the 1960s, but I’d expect a character from the future to be less parochial. Peter Purves does his usual fine job voicing the Doctor, who mostly seems respectful towards the monks, but also barges around the monastery like he has the right to go wherever he wants, and considers his own philosophy to be superior. As a true historical and a 1960s story, it’s a little on the slow side compared to modern stories, but probably better paced than other stories from the period. It’s a nice start for full-cast stories featuring Dodo.
docs.title: The Secrets of Det-Sen

docs.text: The War to End All Wars Companion Chronicles #8.10 Released: 9 April 2014 Listened: 3/3/20 This story is the first part of a trilogy, at least as far as the frame stories are concerned, but told out of order for this chronology. The story continues from here to “The Founding Fathers,” which appeared earlier, and then to “The Locked Room,” which comes at the end. But the frame story itself follows Steven’s life from the events of “The Savages,” although much later. We sort of find out what he’s been doing since then, but much of it is kept a mystery. As for the flashback, it’s a pretty heavy allegory, with Steven and Dodo getting caught up in an endless war, and conditioned into fighting. Although they give it their best shot, it’s an off-screen Doctor who solves everything, which is kind of an odd resolution. The frame story is really the meat of the action here, with Steven interacting with his granddaughter and explaining why he’d done the things he’d done since assuming control of this society in “The Savages,” which plays into the follow-up stories. This was the last Companion Chronicle recorded in the main series, but clearly the plan to continue as boxed sets was already in place, because this story sets up a sequel. It seems reasonable this would be the last appearance of Peter Purves in this chronology, but it isn’t, quite.
docs.title: The War to End All Wars

docs.text: This Sporting Life Short Trips #6.5 Released: 31 May 2016 Listened: 3/4/20 This one is lightweight, and mostly a joke on the title, which refers to a film Hartnell was in, in 1963. The story itself revolves around the theft of the World Cup in 1966, which is a strange story you should research if you’re not familiar with it. Much of the humor derives from the fact that it’s set in Dodo’s native time, so she understands what’s going on, and Steven is totally at sea. The rest of the story is serviceable, with a small amount of misdirection that’s not too hard to see coming.
docs.title: This Sporting Life

docs.text: The First Doctor, Steven, and Oliver Oliver is a real rarity in Big Finish: a brand-new companion inserted into the earliest stories. Original companions are unusual, but not unheard of, but this is the only one who was created in the Companion Chronicles, instead of in the Main Range. The three stories after that are the Doctor traveling with just Steven, which is technically what they’re doing in “The Massacre,” but that period tends to be overlooked, since it didn’t last very long.
docs.title: First Doctor, Steven, & Oliver

docs.text: Helmstone Subscriber Short Trips #2017.3 Released: 12 September 2017 Listened: 2/25/20 This is one of the bonus Short Trips for subscribers, which means very little music, minimal sound effects, and in this case, the narration is by Stephen Critchlow, which is something of a surprise after hearing Peter Purves for so long. Some time has probably passed since the last story, as Steven isn’t overcome by grief. It’s one of those stories where the TARDIS crew seems to be welcomed by a group of people, and they have some odd customs the crew doesn’t really understand, which turn out to be masking something horribly wrong. Except in this case, even the natives themselves don’t know what’s wrong, so we’re spared the usual tying up the outsiders and sentencing them to death. The Doctor seems to be unusually tight-lipped for this period, leaving Steven to stumble around by himself, trying to solve what he believes to be the problem. Being a short and rather spare story, it doesn’t exactly stick in the mind, but it’s a nice brief diversion.
docs.title: Helmstone

docs.text: O Tannenbaum Short Trips #7.12 Released: 22 December 2017 Listened: 2/25/20 We’re back to Peter Purves narrating, this time in first-person, and he’s also playing the Doctor. This is the annual Christmas Short Trip, which means a holiday theme hiding a more sinister secret. Both the Doctor and Steven seem to have “reset” to their normal relationship following all the recent death they’ve seen. Which is pretty much all there is to it, although we learn that the Doctor is capable of entertaining young children if he needs to.
docs.title: O Tannenbaum

This is the annual Christmas Short Trip, which means a holiday theme hiding a more sinister secret. Both the Doctor and Steven seem to have “reset” to their normal relationship following all the recent death they’ve seen. Which is pretty much all there is to it, although we learn that the Doctor is capable of entertaining young children if he needs to.
docs.title: O Tannenbaum

docs.text: Out of the Deep Short Trips #10.6 Released: 30 June 2020 Listened: 7/3/20 The Doctor and Steven end up at an archaeological dig in the early 1900s, at the site of Eridu. Unusually for a First Doctor story, it’s not just random; the TARDIS is responding to time distortions. It’s a pretty standard “immensely powerful alien is imprisoned at an ancient site” story, without a lot of twists to it.
docs.title: Out of the Deep

docs.text: Peace in Our Time Short Trips #9.12 Released: 23 December 2019 Listened: 4/30/20 Setting this one here because it fits in the short gap where Steven is alone with the Doctor. They end up in 1906, tracking some folks who are trying to steal the plans for the Dreadnaught , for mysterious reasons. But most of the story is told from the point of view of Ruby, a servant who gets mixed up in all of this, and has to continually remind people (including Steven) that she’s neither deaf nor stupid, and rather refuses to be put off. This all occurs against the backdrop of the Suffragette movement, but Steven doesn’t mention having encountered that before.
docs.title: Peace in Our Time

docs.text: The Cold Equations Companion Chronicles #5.12 Released: 2 June 2011 Listened: 2/23/20 The second part of Oliver’s trilogy again dials down the sci-fi elements, in favor of the human element, and in this case, actual science. When Steven and Oliver end up trapped on a bit of space junk that’s losing air rapidly, Steven gets to show off his pilot’s training, in the form of orbital equations, to help get them out of it. And he narrates every bit of it while he does it, which certainly demonstrates that writer Simon Guerrier did his homework, but also smacks of the writer showing you his homework, which can break the suspension of disbelief. Of course, since they’re going to die, Oliver confesses his “crime” to Steven: he’s gay. In fairness, Steven had been concerned about having a companion who was hiding something, possibly a serious crime. Naturally, Steven laughs it off, which isn’t the best reaction, but to be fair, the story doesn’t immediately turn to “well, it’s the future, so you’re fine.” Oliver’s still left behind everything he knows, and can’t go back, so everything isn’t really OK just because he’s in the future. It’s a strong story, maybe a bit slight given the running time, but a good listen.
docs.title: The Cold Equations

docs.text: The First Wave Companion Chronicles #6.5 Released: 8 November 2011 Listened: 2/24/20 Poor Oliver. Only three stories, and he never left the solar system. Once again, there’s a lot of hard science in this story, perhaps a touch too much. The Vardans are the bad guys, which is somewhat unexpected. The Doctor is aware of them before this story, but it seems to be the first time the Vardans meet him, and they find out about Gallifrey, which will be useful in the future. The Doctor gets rather arrogant again about his responsibility to the Laws of Time, and Oliver calls him out on it in a big way. I won’t spoil Oliver’s final fate, but I find myself wishing he’d stayed around longer. The Doctor and Steven don’t really need more sad departures at this point, and Oliver deserved to be able to see more, I think. I liked him as a companion, and it’s a good trilogy on the whole.
docs.title: The First Wave

docs.text: The Perpetual Bond Companion Chronicles #5.8 Released: February 2011 Listened: 2/23/20 The setup here is strong, with Oliver getting a cold open, and then Steven clearly grieving from the events of “The Daleks Master Plan,” and then the TARDIS landing in Totter’s Lane, perhaps as a kindness. Oliver has a serious problem, which isn’t revealed in this story, but it’s ruining his life enough that he wants to leave and never come back. He’s capable and quick-witted, which is always key in a potential companion, a bit confused by what’s going on, but he adapts quickly. His voice is engaging, and sounds a little bit like James Joyce from the UNIT series. The Doctor is clearly suffering some shock from having lost two companions recently, and he comes off as rather cold, much like he sometimes gets in the new series when he’s pushed far enough. He’s quite willing to let unscrupulous characters suffer the punishment they’ve unknowingly set up for themselves, which is more of a new-series thing. On top of that, it’s got great 1960s flavor. On the whole, it’s a good episode.
docs.title: The Perpetual Bond

docs.text: The Vardan Invasion of Mirth Companion Chronicles #13.3 Released: 18 September 2019 Listened: 2/26/20 This one is somewhat unusual, as it’s not a very serious story, but rather focuses on the state of British comedy in the 1950s, which Steven unwittingly gets involved in. The bad guys are the Vardans, which seems odd in this chronology, because they appeared not long ago, but Steven doesn’t reference Oliver at all. A lot of the humor stems from Steven being bewildered by 1950s British culture, although I wonder how many in the target audience can remember it.
docs.title: The Vardan Invasion of Mirth

docs.text: The First Doctor, Steven, and Sara Speaking of characters who didn’t have any room for their own story, Jean Marsh as Sara Kingdom shouldn’t have any space for added narrative, but “The Daleks’ Master Plan” specifically has a gap in the middle of it, and Jean Marsh seems to enjoy doing Big Finish, so there’s more stories packed in there than you’d expect, some of which are quite good. Jean Marsh herself appears in all of them, which is only slightly unexpected, but pleasant. There’s a trilogy of Companion Chronicles in here that are all part of a connected story, but it’s the frame stories that follow release order, and the flashbacks take place in reverse order. If you’re doing this project yourself, I’ll strongly recommend that you break from the chronological order and listen in release order, just this once.
docs.title: First Doctor, Steven, & Sara

docs.text: An Ordinary Life Early Adventures #1.4 Released: 16 December 2014 Listened: 2/22/20 These last two stories are from the Early Adventures series, which means they’re longer, full-cast stories, which is nice, because Peter Purves and Jean Marsh play off each other quite well. This story is one of my favorites from this era, not because of the high concept, but because of the character focus. The TARDIS lands in London in the 1950s, and it appears the Doctor has left Sara and Steven behind. Because they’re both from the future, they have some trouble adapting, and end up living in a boarding house upstairs from a Jamaican family, newly arrived in London. With their limited knowledge of history, Steven and Sara just don’t comprehend the racism the family faces; they just can’t get it through their heads at all. Which is a nice thought from the writer, but Purves and Marsh have to sell it, and they succeed. The sci-fi plot doesn’t actually start until halfway through, and I don’t mind. It’s a pretty normal body-snatchers subplot, but that’s not really the important bit. I have to salute the guest actors, whose Jamaican accents make a nice change from the voices normally found in these stories.
docs.title: An Ordinary Life

docs.text: Home Truths Companion Chronicles #3.5 Released: November 2008 Listened: 2/22/20 This story is the first part of the trilogy, and therefore the first appearance of Jean Marsh as Sara since 1967, so it’s worth listening to the interviews. This time, the frame story and the flashback are both part of the same story, so listening to this one first sets up the other two properly. It’s creepy and atmospheric, and like a lot of such stories, especially early Companion Chronicles, which are narrated, there’s more telling than showing. In this case, that works to the story’s advantage, as it puts the focus on Sara and what she’s thinking about her situation, both in this story and with the Doctor in general. Also, the ending is ambiguous, which works better if you haven’t heard the subsequent stories. Because the frame story and the flashback mesh so well, this story is more coherent than the other two, and makes this the best of the three, in my opinion.
docs.title: Home Truths

docs.text: The Anachronauts Companion Chronicles #6.7 Released: January 2012 Listened: 2/19/20 The next batch of Companion Chronicles take place in reverse order to their release order. This one is a bumper release with both Jean Marsh and Peter Purves, who once again plays both Steven and the Doctor. Half of it is set on a strange planet, and the other half in 1966 Germany, but there’s head games all around, so you need to be careful about what you’re hearing. Jean Marsh sounds distinctly older than Sara did originally, but she has the advantage that she didn’t have many episodes back then, so most listeners don’t remember what she sounded like. She plays Sara as tough and capable, with a military mind, which makes a distinct contrast to pretty much all the companions so far, women or men. Because it’s a longer story, there’s some time spent on her relationship with Steven, with the Doctor out of the picture, but that relationship is one of strong friendship and loyalty, even though they haven’t known each other very long. There are a number of minor characters who aren’t voiced, because it’s a Companion Chronicle, which detracts from the impact of the story -- a failing that this line doesn’t normally fall victim to. The overall plot may not be the strongest, but it’s a decent story.
docs.title: The Anachronauts

docs.text: The Drowned World Companion Chronicles #4.1 Released: 28 July 2009 Listened: 2/21/20 This is the middle story of the trilogy, both in the frame story and in the flashback. Which you’d think would make things easier, but the frame story seems to be the real story the author is trying to tell. The flashback, regarding some miners trapped by semi-sentient water, is dramatic, but brief, almost inconsequential. It’s the frame story with Sara and the visitor Robert that seems to be important, and in this case, it’s slightly let down by there being only two actors, and in this case, by my knowing already how that part of the story ends. It’s not as surreal as the previous story, but doesn’t carry a lot more impact.
docs.title: The Drowned World

docs.text: The Guardian of the Solar System Companion Chronicles #5.1 Released: 15 July 2010 Listened: 2/20/20 For the first time in this project, I’m disadvantaged by trying to go in chronological order and conflicting with the Companion Chronicles format. These three stories form a trilogy with Sara, where the frame stories go in release order, but the flashbacks go in reverse order. So listening to this story first gives me spoilers for “Home Truths.” Alas. But turning to the flashback, it relies a lot on the listener’s knowledge of “The Daleks Master Plan,” or at least Sara’s role in it. The story about Mavic Chen using a giant mystical clock to keep the Earth Empire running is...kind of surreal, which doesn’t really match my limited knowledge of the “Master Plan,” so that kind of jars, but the frame story is also a bit surreal, so that fits. Even though this is the final part of the frame story, it doesn’t really resolve, just suggests, and maybe that’s appropriate.
docs.title: The Guardian of the Solar System

docs.text: The Little Drummer Boy Short Trips Rarities #1.4 Released: 30 September 2016 Listened: 2/18/20 This is a short trip, set explicitly after the Christmas special “The Feast of Steven” from the middle of “The Daleks’ Master Plan,” and read by Beth Chalmers, veteran of a number of Big Finish roles, but most known for Raine Creevy. Her style doesn’t really match any of the characters in this story, Steven least of all, but that’s all right, because it’s a narrated story. As a Christmas short trip, it’s more whimsical than anything else, and it’s definitely Christmas-related, featuring a boy reliving various Christmases throughout time. The Doctor’s solution to the dilemma may seem a little heartless, and certainly violates the rules of paradox as we’ve been led to understand them, but hey, it’s Christmas, so why not?
docs.title: The Little Drummer Boy

docs.text: The Sontarans Early Adventures #3.4 Released: 14 December 2016 Listened: 2/23/20 At the time of this writing, this is the most recent release featuring Sara, and it came out a few years ago, so I’m not sure if there’ll be more. It’s a shame that Jean Marsh doesn’t have more to do, as Peter Purves does all the narration, and the story clearly leads into the second part of “The Daleks’ Master Plan.” It features the Doctor’s first encounter with Sontarans, and I’m a bit surprised the BBC let Big Finish do something definitive like that, but maybe they don’t care. In a twist, both Steven and Sara know about Sontarans, but haven’t encountered them. New-series Sontarans have been treated as lightweight, often comic relief, thanks to Strax, so making them a credible threat in an early story like this is tricky, especially when you’ve got Dan Starkey playing most of them. These Sontarans seem to be scary and military, but they’ve also got an overdeveloped sense of honor and fair play, to the point of foolishness, which the Doctor uses against them. The Doctor seems a little out of character too, letting people take terrible risks, even fatal ones, to his benefit. Add in some very dodgy geophysics and mountaineering, and I can’t rate this one very highly. It’s a nice expansion into a full-cast story, but not as strong as its predecessor.
docs.title: The Sontarans

docs.text: The First Doctor, Vicki, and Steven With both Peter Purves and Maureen O’Brien actively participating in Big Finish, there’s plenty of room for stories with the two of them, even though they didn’t have much TV time together. The end of this section gets a little strange. “The Destroyers” features none of the regular characters, and is a lead-in to “Mission to the Unknown,” which does the same. Then Vicki leaves and Katarina arrives in “The Myth Makers.” Adrienne Hill passed away in 1997, so she’s unavailable, which hadn’t really mattered as Katarina doesn’t really have a place to fit a story...except this is Big Finish, so they added one in 2019, except it’s also a Second Doctor crossover, so I’ll deal with it then.
docs.title: First Doctor, Vicki, & Steven

docs.text: Across the Darkened City Companion Chronicles 11.2 Released: 15 June 2017 Listened: 2/10/20 This next two stories are slightly odd, because normally the boxed-set Companion Chronicles go in chronological order within a set, but Craig Brawley figures in this case, the second story happens first, because of one aside from Steven in the first story. This box set starts with two Steven & Vicki stories, unlike the previous set (probably because of the unavailability of William Russell again). This is a fairly tight story, with mostly only Peter Purves as Steven, and Nick Briggs as a lone Dalek. It starts in media res, with an awful lot of Daleks killing people, but quickly ends up with just two characters. From there it becomes an “Enemy Mine” story (Nick Brigs even says so in the extras) with Steven and the Dalek being forced to cooperate. But this is a Dalek, so the whole “sympathetic enemy” trick is an open question. I’d say it resolves fairly satisfactorily. The narration works pretty well for this story, because it lets us inside Steven’s head when he’s got nobody else to talk to.
docs.title: Across the Darkened City

This box set starts with two Steven & Vicki stories, unlike the previous set (probably because of the unavailability of William Russell again). This is a fairly tight story, with mostly only Peter Purves as Steven, and Nick Briggs as a lone Dalek. It starts in media res, with an awful lot of Daleks killing people, but quickly ends up with just two characters. From there it becomes an “Enemy Mine” story (Nick Brigs even says so in the extras) with Steven and the Dalek being forced to cooperate. But this is a Dalek, so the whole “sympathetic enemy” trick is an open question. I’d say it resolves fairly satisfactorily. The narration works pretty well for this story, because it lets us inside Steven’s head when he’s got nobody else to talk to.
docs.title: Across the Darkened City

docs.text: An Ideal World Early Adventures #5.2 Released: 17 October 2018 Listened: 7/24/22 We head straight into another story with an ethical dilemma, but unfortunately this one is even more heavy-handed. The TARDIS lands on a planet that’s being surveyed for terraforming. The surveyors are making every effort not to disturb the planet’s natural ecosystem until they’re sure there’s no intelligent life. They even have an ethicist in a senior position, which is apparently standard procedure. Unfortunately, the planet doesn’t really have a breathable atmosphere; the surveyors just created a small, temporary one, which tricks the TARDIS crew into going outside without survival gear, with unfortunate consequences. And which splits up the party, because that always has to happen. We learn that both Vicki and Stephen have nanotech in their blood that protects them from alien diseases, although the Doctor does not…which seems very odd, as the Doctor is normally more resilient than his companions when it comes to disease. Much like the last story, there’s a political power play going on here between the Captain and the Ethicist, and it doesn’t play out well. The Doctor insists on standing on his principles no matter what the cost, which brings strong reactions from Vicki and Stephen, and seems somewhat inconsistent with his later behavior. I think author Ian Potter was trying to set up a “both sides are right” argument, but it really doesn’t look that way to me. It’s unsettling, but not in a good, thoughtful way.
docs.title: An Ideal World

docs.text: Entanglement Early Adventures #5.3 Released: 14 November 2018 Listened: 7/25/22 It’s pretty rare, but every once in a while Big Finish comes up with a story that only really makes sense if you’re English. In this case, it also helps to have a knowledge of the English university system, particularly Cambridge, the works of Lewis Caroll, who Kim Philby and Guy Burgess were, and a smattering of quantum theory as well. As I only have some of that background knowledge, the story didn’t work for me as well as it could have. I’m also not sure why writers Robert Khan and Tom Salinsky chose to fictionalize Trinity College into Sedgwick College, but leave virtually all the other historical names intact. Maybe it’s tradition? Anyway, the TARDIS lands in Cambridge in the 1930s, and it eventually becomes clear that Something Is Off. But it takes a while to get to that point, because it’s a university, so how can you really tell if a student or professor is acting strangely? And Stephen and Vicki really lack the context for this particular situation. These writers have a tendency to show off their cleverness in stories that don’t take themselves entirely seriously. It’s an acquired taste, and not always successful.
docs.title: Entanglement
