docs.text: Etheria Short Trips #5.9 Released: 24 September 2015 Listened: 4/29/20 This one is a rather imaginative story, as Vicki and the Doctor traverse a strange landscape occupied by clouds of invisible vapor that cause hallucinations, accompanied by a native guide. The depth of the characterization makes me wonder if this was intended to be a longer story, but perhaps not. Steven is mostly absent from this story, but Peter Purves gets to play the Doctor quite a bit, so that’s fine. I also noticed that the music was unusually detailed for a Short Trip; not sure why they did that. It’s pretty high-concept for this era, but seems to work well.
docs.title: Etheria

docs.text: Fields of Terror Companion Chronicles 11.1 Released: 15 June 2017 Listened: 2/11/20 This episode is a true historical, set during the tail end of the French Revolution, which means it’s unrelentingly grim and dark. At least the Doctor knows this, because he’s been there before, and for a change, even he wants to just leave, but events prevent them. Out in the French countryside, Republic armies are ravaging the landscape and killing indiscriminately, which the TARDIS crew blunders into. It’s one of those stories where all they’re trying to do is stay alive long enough to leave again, which makes for a bleak story, but fortunately this one is short. One notable aspect is that the Doctor is correct in all of his observations and assumptions, which is pretty rare for the First Doctor. Maureen O’Brien narrates and plays most of the parts. Unlike the previous story, the Doctor is a main character, so O’Brien has to do her Hartnell impersonation, which honestly isn’t the best, but she does have his mannerisms down. It’s a dark downer of a story for Vicki’s last appearance in this project, but there it is.
docs.title: Fields of Terror

docs.text: Frostfire Companion Chronicles #1.1 Released: 19 February 2007 Listened: 2/7/20 The very first Companion Chronicle, but there’s no evidence that the formula hadn’t come together. In fact, this story has a distinct “new series” feel, although it came out in early 2007. The TARDIS lands in London, at the last Frost Fair (good thing they didn’t bump into Eleven and River, or Twelve and Bill (and Pete!)). They quickly get caught up with an alien killing swathes of people in Regency London, and meet up with Jane Austen late in her life, who acts unexpectedly heroic (although Clara isn’t there either). Even the frame story references the new-series concept that a companion’s life after they leave the Doctor may not be all happily-ever-after, which one would really expect for Vicki, living in ancient Carthage. As often happens in these early Companion Chronicles, the frame story and the flashback seem to be entirely separate, but end up being related, in this case by some time-travel trickery. The second actor doesn’t do much, really, leaving Maureen O’Brien to handle all the parts in the flashback, which she does admirably. It’s a good start to the series.
docs.title: Frostfire

docs.text: The Bounty of Ceres Early Adventures #1.3 Released: 14 November 2014 Listened: 2/5/20 Another full-length, full-cast (ish) story, this one from the first box of Early Adventures. As the title implies, this story takes place on Ceres, which lends itself to a “base under siege” scenario, where some of the characters grow increasingly paranoid, except not everything is what it seems. The story proceeds a bit slowly, which is appropriate for the era, but I think it probably could have been compressed without too much difficulty. Peter Purves gets to give his First Doctor impersonation a workout, and does a pretty good job of it. There’s also a good bit of the Vicki/Steven sibling relationship, with a lot of the trope of “Steven is from the future, but Vicki is from further in the future, so she teases him.” On the whole, the story is middling, and not all that memorable.
docs.title: The Bounty of Ceres

docs.text: The Crash of the UK-201 Early Adventures #5.4 Released: 11 December 2018 Listened: 7/25/22 This one is deeply timey-wimey, and in fact has a very modern-series feel, as it’s more or less “Turn Left,” but for Vicki. Something unexplained happens within the TARDIS that sends Vicki back down her personal timeline. It turns out the UK-201 is the spaceship that crashed on Dido, putting this right before the events of “The Rescue.” Given an opportunity like that, of course Vicki tries to set things right, particularly saving her father. Of course, that means she never meets the Doctor, which creates a great whopping paradox, but first we get to see Vicki’s alternate life play out. This gives Maureen O’Brien a chance to really stretch, as she has to play Vicki at various ages from 15 to 170. Peter Purves gets a break as well, as the Doctor is barely present, and Steven seems to randomly bounce around Vicki’s timeline, as he’s also caught in the paradox (without Vicki, the TARDIS may have never gone to Mechanus, so Steven never gets rescued). It’s hard to describe much more without spoiling, but Vicki goes through the same sorts of decisions and anguish that Donna does, and learns that even when you have foreknowledge, “fixing” things doesn’t always get you what you want, and even trying to put things back may not have the same results. It’s a pretty effective tearjerker, even though we know how it has to end up. On the whole, this boxed set brought a lot of newer concepts to an old team, and mostly executed on them successfully. With the Early Adventures winding up, this may be the last story in recording order for this particular team, in which case it’s a good ending.
docs.title: The Crash of the UK-201

docs.text: The Dalek Occupation of Winter Early Adventures #5.1 Released: 12 September 2018 Listened: 1/5/22 These next four Early Adventures break with the previous formula, featuring the same characters, and occurring all in a row. I imagine that had to do with the unavailability of William Russell, or possibly with the “Adventure in Space and Time” team taking over most of the stories featuring the original team. This story, by David K Barnes, takes a look at a different kind of Dalek invasion, and different ways that people might react to it. The TARDIS lands in the city of Winter on an unnamed planet, where winter lasts 500 years. It was colonized by speculators hoping to mine rare ores, but that didn’t pan out, and when they called for help, the only response came from Daleks, who were talked into varying from their standard procedures. In exchange for food, the population builds Dalek casings, not as slaves, but as paid workers with decent conditions. They have no idea what the Daleks are actually used for, thinking them exploration and aid robots. Naturally, the Doctor, Vicki, and Steven react with shock and horror, and immediately try to get a rebellion going. The chief administrator isn’t a fan of the Daleks, but will do whatever’s necessary to keep his people safe and himself in power, not necessarily in that order. The security chief simply wants to be on the winning side, and thinks she can manipulate the situation to her own ends. Even the factory worker who befriends Steven is worried; she can be convinced that the Daleks are evil, but kicking them off the planet would cut off their food supply, and the people would starve. For Vicki and Steven, at least, this is a genuine moral dilemma, and their arguments with the natives are interesting. Barnes is usually a comedy writer, but there’s very little of that here. In fact, the ending is grim even by the standards of Dalek stories. But it’s fitting to have a First Doctor story where they can take time to consider the implications of fighting the Daleks.
docs.title: The Dalek Occupation of Winter

docs.text: The Destroyers Lost Stories #2.2 Released: December 2010 Listened: 2/12/20 This is a prequel of sorts to “Mission to the Unknown” (itself a prequel) which doesn’t feature the Doctor, any companions, or the TARDIS. It does, however, feature Sara Kingdom, and was intended as a pilot for Terry Nation’s proposed Dalek spin-off series, which never happened. It even has its own 60s-style theme music, which wouldn’t be out of place as an unused track from The Incredibles. Sara seems decidedly younger and less tough than in her later appearances, but she spends much of the story worried about her brother David, who never appears again, so we don’t know what happened to him. It also introduces android Mark Seven, who was intended to be a major character if the series took off, and turns up again much later in the Tenth Doctor “Dalek Universe” stories. Like many Dalek-focused stories, the Daleks are an implacable force, and everybody else is just trying to survive. From that perspective, it has a fairly unsatisfying ending, but given that it’s a pilot to a series that never happened, that’s probably expected.
docs.title: The Destroyers

docs.text: The Founding Fathers Companion Chronicles #9.3 Released: 3 June 2015 Listened: 2/6/20 This story is a shorter-form Companion Chronicle, but unlike many of the others, the frame story is almost as important as the flashback, and the frame story forms a sequel to the frame story of “The War to End All Wars,” which comes much later in this project, and unusually, that later frame story really is required listening for this one. The story continues into “The Locked Room,” which takes place at the end of this era. Turning to the flashback story itself, well, I’m a Philadelphian, so any story involving Benjamin Franklin and the Penn family will have some personal appeal for me. Knowing what I know about Franklin’s history, I think the story treats him fairly. It also has a trick for forcing the travelers to stick around that I haven’t seen anywhere else -- the Doctor locks himself out of the TARDIS accidentally. How you get from that to Franklin is kind of a stretch, but there’s a strong implication that the Doctor is manipulating events so that he can meet Franklin. Because this is a Companion Chronicle, Peter Purves plays Steven, the Doctor (fairly well), and Franklin...somewhat less well. He’s clearly aiming for a generic American accent, which probably isn’t accurate, but it’s reasonable for Steven telling a story. Alice Haig does a decent job playing Vicki, but she doesn't have a lot of lines. The story itself has some decent misdirection, but it’s a bit slight.
docs.title: The Founding Fathers

docs.text: The Ravelli Conspiracy Early Adventures #3.3 Released: 10 November 2016 Listened: 2/8/20 Another Early Adventure, which means full cast and a longer running time, with Peter Purves playing the Doctor. It’s also a pure historical, but instead of massacre and plague, we’ve got 16th Century Italian politics, which means the Medicis and Machiavelli, because why not go all the way? It’s not nearly as grim as one might expect from that setup; in fact, nobody dies at all, not even minor characters. Aside from all the machinations, the plot could almost be described as silly, with guards regularly giving up on understanding what’s going on and just doing whatever the nearest character tells them. As far as the TARDIS team is concerned, it’s one of those “get back to the TARDIS and leave without upsetting history” stories, where they just happen to fall into the middle of things. And the plots are very complicated, as you’d expect, given the historical characters. Giovanni de’Medici (Pope Leo X) seems to be portrayed accurately, as a great lover of the arts and interested in keeping the peace at all costs, whereas his brother Giuliano is painted as a bloodthirsty villain. It’s not the most memorable of stories, mostly because the TARDIS crew spend much of it reacting to events.
docs.title: The Ravelli Conspiracy

docs.text: The Suffering Companion Chronicles #4.7 Released: 20 February 2010 Listened: 2/4/20 This is a slightly unusual release, a double-length story (so the same as a Main Range), with both Peter Purves and Maureen O’Brien voicing Steven and Vicki, with no guest actors. It’s a semi-historical, taking place in 1912 not far from London, and is largely concerned with the Women’s Suffrage movement. I didn’t realize that the movement was more violent, on both sides, than it was in America (or at least more than I’ve heard in American history), so there are some pretty brutal descriptions in this story. It’s also a little more heavy-handed than usual on the gender conflict, although it’s subtly tied to the origin of the Drahvins of “Galaxy 4,” so maybe it’s par for the course for this era. The narrative plays a little with the traditional Companion Chronicles format, with Vicki and Steven collaborating to make an intentional recording of these events (Steven somewhat reluctantly), so there’s a little bit of mocking and false starts as they get the story going. It’s a pretty good showcase for their sibling-like relationship, and for Steven’s “action hero” status, replacing Ian. The historical details make it an uneasy listen, though.
docs.title: The Suffering

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #4.7 Released: 20 February 2010 Listened: 2/4/20 This is a slightly unusual release, a double-length story (so the same as a Main Range), with both Peter Purves and Maureen O’Brien voicing Steven and Vicki, with no guest actors. It’s a semi-historical, taking place in 1912 not far from London, and is largely concerned with the Women’s Suffrage movement. I didn’t realize that the movement was more violent, on both sides, than it was in America (or at least more than I’ve heard in American history), so there are some pretty brutal descriptions in this story. It’s also a little more heavy-handed than usual on the gender conflict, although it’s subtly tied to the origin of the Drahvins of “Galaxy 4,” so maybe it’s par for the course for this era. The narrative plays a little with the traditional Companion Chronicles format, with Vicki and Steven collaborating to make an intentional recording of these events (Steven somewhat reluctantly), so there’s a little bit of mocking and false starts as they get the story going. It’s a pretty good showcase for their sibling-like relationship, and for Steven’s “action hero” status, replacing Ian. The historical details make it an uneasy listen, though.
docs.title: The Suffering

docs.text: The Time Meddler TV Season 2, Serial 9 Aired: 3 July 1965 - 24 July 1965 Steven officially joins the crew, meaning both companions are humans from the future, although not the same time period. The travelers meet the Monk, the first renegade Time Lord shown on TV, with his own TARDIS. This is the end of Season 2.
docs.title: The Time Meddler

docs.text: Upstairs Companion Chronicles #8.3 Released: 12 September 2013 Listened: 2/8/20 This is another Companion Chronicle where both Peter Purves and Maureen O’Brien work together, without any other actors, but this time O’Brien plays the Doctor, and it has to be said, not as well as Purves’ version, but that’s not overly surprising. It’s also a very twisty, brain-hurting story that almost seems to take place in an alternate reality. This one probably would have worked quite well on television, with limited sets and cast, but the story is so bizarre that I wonder if they would have dared such a thing in the 1960s. I hesitate to say more about it for fear of spoilers, but the characterizations of the TARDIS team are quite well-written, especially the First Doctor.
docs.title: Upstairs

docs.text: The First Doctor, Susan, Ian, and Barbara As the original TARDIS team, Ian, Barbara, and Susan have a fair number of stories. Full-cast stories have been hampered by the unavailability of Jacquiline Hill, who died in 1993, but William Russell and Carole Ann Ford have been willing to work with Big Finish almost since the beginning. Carole Ann has the advantage of having been quite young when she was on the show, so was still in prime working age when Big Finish came calling. William Russell was also game at first, but as Big Finish has gone on for quite some time, he eventually retired from active participation. As a result, the stories in this set are a mix of Companion Chronicles, Short Trips, and Lost Stories told in a narrated style.
docs.title: First Doctor, Susan, Ian, & Barbara

docs.text: A Small Semblance of Home Short Trips #8.9 Released: 27 September 2018 Listened: 4/27/20 Placed here because Barbara thinks it’s been 40 or 50 days since she left Earth, and she and Ian are still not entirely comfortable with the Doctor. There’s some irritation on their part at being dragged around by the Doctor’s whim, but his questing this time has a deeper purpose. The soundtrack here is notable, giving a kind of a new-series feel when the companions think about home and what their travels mean.
docs.title: A Small Semblance of Home

docs.text: A Star Is Born Short Trips #4.1 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 4/26/20 Placed here pretty arbitrarily. The TARDIS lands on a failing generation ship inhabited by sea-lion-like aliens, who are also dying of radiation poisoning. It takes the Doctor some time to determine that the problem is sabotage, not a mechanical fault. There’s some dodgy science here, of both radiation and genetics, and the TARDIS saves everybody by making a controlled short hop, which wasn’t really possible in this era. On the whole, I’m not impressed with this story.
docs.title: A Star Is Born

docs.text: After the Daleks Early Adventures 7.1 Released: 17 August 2021 Listened: 8/18/21 This Early Adventure is a departure for the series, as it focuses entirely on Susan, and the Doctor doesn’t appear. It starts immediately after “The Dalek Invasion of Earth,” and addresses the fact that maybe leaving Susan on a war-torn planet with a guy she just met wasn’t exactly the best recipe for happily-ever-after. Because humans are humans, and as we’ve learned in the real world, when people are frightened and desperate, they’ll turn to an autocratic strong-man for leadership. It might have been better if the former governor had genuine reasons for believing himself the best leader, but the story was deliberately written in a 1960s style, so he’s basically just a selfish collaborator. The plot also has some 60s-style contrivances, like a creature whose origin is never explained, but who happens to secrete a substance that reverses the Roboman conversion process. But it’s Susan’s arc that’s done properly here, as she goes from feeling somewhat helpless, to trying to channel what her grandfather would do, to trying to stick to her people’s non-intervention policy, to finally taking brave action and making an active choice to stay on Earth with David, instead of having it made for her. David and Jenny from the original story are recast, with David played by Sean Biggerstaff, who’s turning into a Big Finish stalwart. His accent is pretty distinctive, but it’s also fantastic, so I don’t mind at all. Jenny is played by Lucy Briers, taking the role originated by her mother in the original story. All new stories from this early period have to choose between trying to imitate a 1960s style, or going for more modern pacing and storytelling. This time, Big Finish chose the former, and while it gets the job done, I think it might have been a bit more enjoyable if it had gone the other way.
docs.title: After the Daleks

docs.text: Domain of the Voord Early Adventures 1.1 Released: 4 September 2014 Listened: 1/3/20 The Early Adventures are like the Companion Chronicles on steroids. They’re full-cast stories, although because of the lack of William Hartnell and companion actors, they’re still partially narrated. They also tend to be longer, a traditional four-part story, which enables the story to expand in a way that feels more true to the original stories. This story feels like it could have fit nicely into the first season. It features the return of the Voord, but like many Andrew Smith stories, we discover a lot more about the villains and their society. There are a number of First Doctor tropes: The Doctor puts Susan’s safety, and the TARDIS, over that of the other people they meet. Ian is strangely competent at a number of skills (SCUBA diving, commando raids). The only real difference is that Barbara doesn’t get as much to do. She and the Doctor get sidelined and are missing for most of episodes 2 and 3, which lets the story concentrate on Ian and Susan, who have actual actors. As often happens, the Doctor wins in the end by doing something clever and sciency that’s never entirely explained. Russell and Ford sound closer to their actual ages, and Russell has William Hartnell’s mannerisms down, but doesn’t quite match the voice. Still, there’s enough of the feel of an early story here that it’s a success.
docs.title: Domain of the Voord

docs.text: E Is for... Early Adventures 13.1 Released: 18 September 2019 Listened: 1/6/20 This story is from much later in Big Finish’s recording history, and it shows. Susan spends almost the entire story separated from the others, and Carole Ann Ford is starting to sound more like Old Susan than Young Susan. But the key point of this story is that it’s a superhero pastiche, specifically the X-Men. Doctor Who has always stayed away from superheroes in the past, but after “The Return of Doctor Mysterio,” it seems they’ve become fair game. From the extras, it seems like most of the creators (except the writer, of course) don’t realize just how much of an X-Men reference this story is, but if you’re at all familiar with Marvel history, the references stick out a mile. I think you could have gotten away with this story with different characters, possibly one of the modern series Doctors, but it just seems strange and out of place in the First Doctor era.
docs.title: E Is for...

docs.text: Farewell, Great Macedon Lost Stories #2.1a Released: 10 November 2010 Listened: 1/1/20 All of the stories in this part of the project so far have been on the shorter side. Companion Chronicles and other such formats run about an hour. Which is unusual, because this early era had some lengthy stories, and this is one of them. Also written by Moris Farhi, this is a true historical in the way that they really only did them in the First Doctor’s era, hanging out with historical figures, getting tangled in historical events, and yet not changing the overall course of history. The chronology establishes this as the first true historical, before “Marco Polo” or “The Aztecs,” but it does rely on the listener having some knowledge of those stories, and how this team behaves when they’re in Earth history. Alexander is presented as nuanced, mostly being a good man with strong ideals and some rather progressive ideas about race relations, but also prone to flying into rages and jumping to conclusions, which can make him look quite stupid at times. The villains, on the other hand, are straight-up baddies; if they had mustaches, they’d twirl them. But the villains’ plot isn’t really the important part of the story, because the course of history is set, and there’s nothing the travelers can do about it, except get caught up and falsely accused. This leads to the Doctor using his scientific knowledge to do something unexpected, and Ian being unexpectedly proficient at hand-to-hand fighting, both of which are pretty standard for this sort of story. The only divergence is that Barbara hides her historical knowledge of what’s going to happen from her companions, who have no idea until nearly the end of the story. As a production, Big Finish did this in a narrated style, with William Russell and Carole Ann Ford playing all the parts except for Alexander, who’s played by John Dorney (usually a writer, but he’s an experienced actor too). The music and sound effects are minimal, in a nod to how stories from this era were made. As with many historicals, how much you like it depends on how much you like that era, but I think it’s a fantastic example of both a First Doctor story, and a historical, one that Big Finish has only rarely matched.
docs.title: Farewell, Great Macedon

docs.text: Flywheel Revolution Short Trips #5.1 Released: 5 January 2015 Listened: 4/29/20 The first of the monthly Short Trips range isn’t a complete story by itself, but an interlude set in the part of some other story when the Doctor has been imprisoned and is separated from his companions for a while. It’s read by Peter Purves, but Steven isn’t in it; the Doctor specifically wants to get back to Susan, Ian, and Barbara. A lot of this story depends on the unique point of view of its narrator, so I’m reluctant to spoil it, but it’s fun for a listener, seeing the events of a normal Doctor Who story from an outside perspective. It’s a strong start for the series.
docs.title: Flywheel Revolution

docs.text: Here There Be Monsters Companion Chronicles #3.1 Released: July 2008 Listened: 1/6/20 After several stories in a row featuring Ian, now we get two focusing on Susan. This is the earliest Big Finish story focusing on Susan (she appeared in a couple of Unbound stories before this), and Carole Ann Ford sounds distinctly younger here than she does in other stories. However, it’s an early Companion Chronicle, which means it’s rather talky, with very little in the way of music or sound effects, which is appropriate for this era, but it makes the story tricky to get into. It’s a nice spotlight for Susan, but not a great story.
docs.title: Here There Be Monsters

docs.text: Home Again, Home Again Subscriber Short Trips #2020.2 Released: 10 November 2010 Listened: 7/4/20 Placed here, later in Ian and Barbara’s timeline, because they’ve lost track of how long they’ve been traveling. The TARDIS comes back to Coal Hill School, and Ian and Barbara think they’re home, but unfortunately it’s June, several months before they left. They try to stay anyway, which results in some comedy as they try to avoid their earlier selves. The Doctor has a very early-seasons understanding of the laws of time, and won’t explain just why it’s so bad to cross one’s own timeline. Of course we know Ian and Barbara can’t stay, because of the larger narrative, but you’d think they could do a bit better job of hiding than they do. Stephen Critchlow’s First Doctor is getting to be quite good. I get a little tired of the “they’re home, but something’s wrong” stories with Ian and Barbara, but there aren’t quite as many of them as I thought.
docs.title: Home Again, Home Again

docs.text: Planet of Giants TV Season 2, Serial 1 Aired: 31 October 1964 - 14 November 1964 The beginning of Season 2. The team is back on Earth in the 20th Century, but they’re all shrunk to tiny size. Which makes this a special-effects extravaganza, by 1960s BBC standards.
docs.title: Planet of Giants

docs.text: TV Season 2, Serial 1 Aired: 31 October 1964 - 14 November 1964 The beginning of Season 2. The team is back on Earth in the 20th Century, but they’re all shrunk to tiny size. Which makes this a special-effects extravaganza, by 1960s BBC standards.

docs.text: Rise and Fall Short Trips #1.1 Released: 5 November 2010 Listened: 4/23/20 Placed here because Ian says they’ve just come from France. As the very first Short Trip, this one goes high-concept. The Doctor and Ian step out of the TARDIS, leaving the women behind momentarily. The natives of this world are primitive, but occupy a separate time stream, so they evolve, form a civilization, and then destroy themselves in the span of a few moments for the travelers. There’s barely a plot, more of an impression, but it’s a strong impression, and a story that sticks with me.
docs.title: Rise and Fall

docs.text: The Age of Endurance Early Adventures #3.1 Released: 14 September 2016 Listened: 1/3/20 This Early Adventure was recorded a few years later, and there are some differences. Jemma Powell steps in to play Barbara, but she’s still sidelined for most of the story, which seems an odd choice. Then again, Carole Ann Ford and especially William Russell sound quite a bit older than even the last story, and might make a poor contrast to Powell. Russell even plays the Doctor sounding rather older than previously, although he does spend most of the story injured and fatigued. As for the story itself, it seems like it should be part submarine thriller, and part morality tale regarding the dangers of genetic engineering, but the baddies don’t really stick in the memory, and the sacrifice play at the end is fairly obvious. The nebula the story takes place in probably would have looked great on TV if this story were made with modern-series special effects, but likely not in 1964 black-and-white.
docs.title: The Age of Endurance

docs.text: The Flames of Cadiz Companion Chronicles #7.7 Released: 9 January 2013 Listened: 1/5/20 This is a departure from the Companion Chronicles formula, being four parts (the length of a Main Range story), and featuring both William Russell and Carole Ann Ford, in addition to a supporting actor. It’s another historical, set in Spain in the 1580s, which means the Inquisition and the Armada, so it’s pretty grim, as historicals often are. The spotlight is definitely on Ian, but he’s unusually reckless in this one, beyond his normal levels. Getting arrested by the Inquisition because he doesn’t want to see injustice done is typical Ian, but running off to meet Francis Drake just for fun, while he’s still wanted by the Inquisition, is over the edge. The Doctor also mis-steps badly, in a way that’s unexpected for him. And there’s a definite push in developing a relationship between Ian and Barbara, although it can’t go too far while there’s still TV episodes left to cover.
docs.title: The Flames of Cadiz

docs.text: The Fragile Yellow Arc of Fragrance Lost Stories #2.1a Released: 10 November 2010 Listened: 12/31/19 These next two stories come from the “Lost Stories” First Doctor box set. There’s no telling whether these two were originally intended to appear at this spot in the chronology, but this is where the timeline cues place them, and oddly, the second story in the boxed set happens first. This is a one-part story, written as a “proof of concept” by Moris Farhi, never really intended for production. And you can see why, because it’s a very high concept, too far out there for the classic series, and maybe even the modern one, but it’s good as a short audio story. The early placement means that Ian and Barbara are just friends at this point, and the Doctor is still making arbitrary decisions for the whole group, which is required for the plot to work.
docs.title: The Fragile Yellow Arc of Fragrance

docs.text: The Library of Alexandria Companion Chronicles #7.10 Released: 10 April 2013 Listened: 1/6/20 This story was released just a few months after the last, and there’s definite connections. It starts out seeming like yet another historical, and it acknowledges several stories that have come before, specifically the fact that the travelers met Alexander the Great and Ptolemy. However, that all quickly gets turned on its head with an alien invasion, giving this story a much more modern-series feel. The Ian/Barbara relationship that was gently hinted at in the previous story is much more obvious here, which seems a bit out of place with the TV stories, but a reasonable development within the audio timeline. The Doctor also has a more modern-series attitude as well, striding up to the alien monsters and demanding that they listen to him. It’s probably not a particularly accurate early-era story, but within this project, it makes a nice palette-cleanser.
docs.title: The Library of Alexandria

docs.text: The Light at the End Special Released: 23 October 2013 This is an Eighth Doctor story, but for the First Doctor, it could take place sometime around here, as we know it happened when he was with Susan, Ian, and Barbara. There’s a temporal projection from later in time, featuring Steven and Sara Kingdom, who gets to threaten Charley Pollard.

docs.text: The Masters of Luxor Lost Stories #3.7 Released: 16 August 2012 Listened: 7/23/22 This Lost Story was originally intended to be the second serial of the series, but fortunately, we got “The Daleks” instead. In its current form, though, it’s established as taking place immediately after “Farewell Great Macedon.” The characters are still a bit uneasy with each other, and Susan addresses Ian and Barbara by their titles. It’s a six-parter, and those often feel stretched out. Plus, it’s of its time, meaning the story is kind of pokey. As an example, it gets most of the way through Part 2 before the travelers even begin to figure out what’s going on. Even “The Daleks” wasn’t that slow. “Luxor” implies Egyptian, but there isn’t anything like that here, except that the huge building where the story takes place is pyramid-shaped. The TARDIS lands, and is drained of power, so they have to go exploring to figure out what’s wrong so they can leave. This leads to lots of wandering around, exploration, and speculation before they eventually discover the building is pretty much a way-station for Luxorites, staffed by robots, and currently empty. (So the story isn’t even set on Luxor, and only one of the “Masters” ever makes an appearance.) What follows should be rumination on the nature of artificial life and robot rights, except it’s held back by a rather basic understanding of what robots are capable of, for which you can blame 1963. Even the Doctor states several times that one action or another is “impossible” for robots, when moderately advanced AI could probably handle it. It eventually turns into one of those “mad computer thinks it’s god” stories, and while those are somewhat tiresome, this would have been the first time the show had told such a story, had it been televised. Much like “Macedon,” the story is partially narrated, with William Russell playing both Ian and the Doctor, Carole Ann Ford playing Susan and Barbara, and Joseph Kloska playing everybody else…which is to say, mostly robots. Unfortunately, William Russell’s age is showing, and it’s sometimes difficult to tell if a line was meant to be spoken by the Doctor or Ian. Sadly, it’s not the best Lost Story, especially compared to “Macedon.”
docs.title: The Masters of Luxor

docs.text: The Time Museum Companion Chronicles #7.1 Released: 23 July 2012 Listened: 1/1/20 For the first time, I’m not certain why Craig Brawley placed this story at this point. It’s a Companion Chronicle told by a much older Ian, or maybe an alternate Ian, from near the end of his life. Normally Companion Chronicles flash back to a single story that can be placed, but this story features bits and pieces from throughout Ian’s time as a traveler, brought up in random order. The plot isn’t too involved, as most of the enjoyment of the story comes from Ian’s memories, and you’ll probably see the twist coming. But if you’re looking for an explanation, you’ll find part of one after the closing credits.
docs.title: The Time Museum

docs.text: The Transit of Venus Companion Chronicles #3.7 Released: 22 January 2009 Listened: 1/4/20 This was the first Companion Chronicle to feature Ian, and therefore the first to be read by William Russell, in 2009, although the series had been going for a little while at that point. It very much follows the “classic” Companion Chronicle formula, with Ian relating the story to an “off screen” listener, later in his life, which relieves Russell of having to make himself sound younger, but he does do a good job playing the Doctor as well. As for the story, Susan and Barbara spend most of it off-screen, even though Barbara is on the cover. It’s a historical, in the sense that there aren’t any aliens or monsters, just the Doctor and Ian on Captain Cook’s voyage to Australia, but the time travelers accidentally present themselves as aliens from Venus, and Susan’s telepathy plays a role, so it’s not quite a “pure” historical. Unlike a lot of historicals, it’s not unrelentingly grim, with most of the danger coming from Ian himself, entirely by accident. In that respect, it’s lightweight, but it’s valuable because it gives a lot of insight into Ian’s frame of mind, how his attitude toward the Doctor is softening, and his feelings toward Barbara.
docs.title: The Transit of Venus

docs.text: The Wanderer Companion Chronicles #6.10 Released: 18 April 2012 Listened: 1/6/20 Another semi-historical, this time in early 20th century Russia, although there are aliens involved, so it’s not straight history. Given when and where it’s set, though, that means that a young Rasputin shows up (spoilers, sorry), and his interaction with the crew is partially responsible for his later career. The plot itself is fairly basic, with the focus being on Ian and Rasputin. How much you enjoy this story depends on how much you enjoy listening to mad Russian raving.
docs.title: The Wanderer

docs.text: Sidestep In 2013, as part of the 50th Anniversary celebrations, the BBC produced the docudrama An Adventure in Space and Time by Mark Gatiss, a semi-fictionalized account of the creation of Doctor Who. It starred David Bradley as William Hartnell / The Doctor, Claudia Grant as Carole Ann Ford / Susan, Jamie Glover as William Russell / Ian, and Jemma Powell as Jacqueline Hill / Barbara. Jemma Powell was recruited by Big Finish to play Barabara in the third series of Early Adventures in 2016, and in 2018, Big Finish decided to go whole-hog and cast all the actors to recreate the roles of the first TARDIS team. This would be the second time that Big Finish specifically recast a Doctor, and the first time they recast parts whose original actors are still alive -- although in fairness, William Russell was over 90 at the time, and had retired from Big Finish. What nobody knew at the time was that the BBC was about to cast Bradley to play the First Doctor in “Twice Upon a Time,” which came out around the same time as the first box set here. Craig Brawley, whose timeline I’m following for this project, doesn’t consider these stories to be canon, as they feature none of the original actors, so he isn’t placing them in the timeline. The Big Finish covers feature the likenesses of the new actors, not the originals, and they haven’t made any reference to these stories from others, thus “canonizing” them, although James Dreyfuss has appeared as the First Master in other Big Finish stories. I’m not including any other “unbound” stories in this project, but I think these are pretty good stories, and I’m buying them, so I may as well include them at this point, just after Susan’s departure.
docs.title: Sidestep

docs.text: For the Glory of Urth First Doctor Adventures #5.1 Released: 27 April 2021 Listened: 5/1/21 In release order, it’s been a while since there was a release in this series, so hearing these actors again is welcome. As usual, there’s one sci-fi story and one historical, but the sci-fi is a bit off the usual path. The TARDIS crew have landed on a planet called Urth, which claims to have the last descendants of humanity living in a squalid city. However, it’s a dystopia of the fairly silly variety, not unlike “The Happiness Patrol” or possibly “Vengeance on Varos,” where the people in charge are so terrible that you wonder how they could have gotten there at all. Ian and Barbara don’t really have a lot to do in this story (aside from being generally appalled), and Ian’s “hero moment” goes decidedly poorly this time around. Susan has a lot of the action, as does Phyllida Nash as a blobby gestalt alien. The various revelations are interesting the first time through, but the ruling-class characters are annoying enough to discourage a re-listen.
docs.title: For the Glory of Urth

docs.text: Last of the Romanovs First Doctor Adventures #4.2 Released: 18 March 2020 Listened: 3/24/20 This is the true historical for this boxed set, and as you might expect from the title, it’s a grim one. The TARDIS lands in Russia in 1918, right outside the palace where the Romanovs are being held, because of course it does. To their credit, as soon as the Doctor and company realize where they are, they immediately want to leave, but of course it’s too late. In a twist, Ian and the Doctor are merely sent to hard labor, but the women end up caught in a British plot to smuggle the Romanovs out of Russia. Interestingly, Susan is displaying a much broader independent streak, which fits with “Tick-Tock World,” but wasn’t much in evidence in “Return to Skaro.” The plot itself has the characters wandering around, trying not to get killed, and bumping into the Romanovs, but a number of the secondary characters are not what they seem. In the background, though, there’s some “Aztecs”-like discussion of what can and can’t be changed, with the Doctor invoking “fixed points” quite deliberately. In the end, though, he seems to be questioning just how fixed they actually are, putting a new-series tinge on everything.
docs.title: Last of the Romanovs

docs.text: Return to Skaro First Doctor Adventures #4.1 Released: 18 March 2020 Listened: 3/21/20 These stories were released a couple of months after I was at this point in the chronology, and it’s a welcome return. Either the actors are relaxing into their roles and toning down the RP a bit, or I’ve just gotten used to it. This story is an interesting one to place in the chronology, because it’s made clear that the crew haven’t encountered Daleks since the first time, and think they were all destroyed at the end of that adventure. It’s also the first time they’ve explicitly returned to a place they’ve been before (courtesy of the Fast Return Switch) although many years later. The Thals have apparently taken over and all the Daleks are gone...except ha-ha, of course they’re not. Susan gets bullied into going to the Dalek city...except she’s the one who wants to explore once they get there, so that’s a nice twist. There’s also the scientist who’s gulled into believing that the Daleks want to be nice this time, except none of the listeners are going to buy that, so the plot dispenses with it early. The TARDIS crew split up and recombine often, allowing everybody to get a chance to play the hero. The Daleks, for their part, get the idea to investigate time travel, and the Black Dalek is introduced. However, the crew leaves things pretty much as they found them, believing that the Daleks are gone for good. On the whole, it’s not as exciting of a story as I would have hoped.
docs.title: Return to Skaro

docs.title: Return to Skaro

docs.text: The Barbarians and the Samurai First Doctor Adventures #2.2 Released: 25 July 2018 Listened: 1/13/20 Keeping with the pattern of these box sets, we’ve had a sci-fi story first, then a pure historical. The TARDIS crew arrives in 19th Century Japan, during the isolation, and for once realize that they need to just get back in the ship and leave. But of course that doesn’t work out. The crew ends up separated, the Doctor blusters a lot at the local lord, who wants Barbara as a concubine (of course), while Ian and Susan meet a local ronin who has not only extraordinary fighting skills, but also knowledge of the lord’s castle, and is in love with the lord’s daughter. It follows pretty much the path of a typical 1964 historical, with escapes, recaptures, more escapes, and noble sacrifices. According to the extras, they cast Japanese actors to play the appropriate roles, but they still sound rather badly stereotypical. I have this feeling, probably unjustified, that American stories handle Japanese culture better than British ones. It’s a perfectly acceptable story, but not a stand-out.
docs.title: The Barbarians and the Samurai

docs.text: The Destination Wars First Doctor Adventures #1.1 Released: 25 December 2017 Listened: 1/10/20 The first thing I notice with this series is the voices. None of the actors are attempting to imitate their predecessors, but to capture the spirit of the characters. Jamie Glover does that reasonably well, I think, but Jemma Powell and Claudia Grant especially are emphasizing their RP accents, which makes Susan sound like a parody of herself, sometimes. David Bradley is definitely playing his own version of the First Doctor, which is a reasonable substitute, but it’s noticeably different. The writing also changes the characters somewhat, emphasizing some of their characteristics at the sake of others. The Doctor in particular is supercilious to the humans, and quicker to argument than William Hartnell’s was. Ian seems to have been toned down a bit, in order to give the others more “hero time,” which is probably to the good. This story features James Dreyfuss as the Master, presumably the “first” version of the Master. He’s more of a “suave” Master than the later “insane” Masters of TV, somewhat like Delgado, with some clever phrasings. There’s rather more use of time travel, and of the Fast Return Switch, than normally would have happened in the First Doctor era, but this story seems to be straddling the line between a traditional story and the style of the new series.
docs.title: The Destination Wars

docs.text: First Doctor Adventures #1.1 Released: 25 December 2017 Listened: 1/10/20 The first thing I notice with this series is the voices. None of the actors are attempting to imitate their predecessors, but to capture the spirit of the characters. Jamie Glover does that reasonably well, I think, but Jemma Powell and Claudia Grant especially are emphasizing their RP accents, which makes Susan sound like a parody of herself, sometimes. David Bradley is definitely playing his own version of the First Doctor, which is a reasonable substitute, but it’s noticeably different. The writing also changes the characters somewhat, emphasizing some of their characteristics at the sake of others. The Doctor in particular is supercilious to the humans, and quicker to argument than William Hartnell’s was. Ian seems to have been toned down a bit, in order to give the others more “hero time,” which is probably to the good. This story features James Dreyfuss as the Master, presumably the “first” version of the Master. He’s more of a “suave” Master than the later “insane” Masters of TV, somewhat like Delgado, with some clever phrasings. There’s rather more use of time travel, and of the Fast Return Switch, than normally would have happened in the First Doctor era, but this story seems to be straddling the line between a traditional story and the style of the new series.
docs.title: The Destination Wars

docs.text: The Great White Hurricane First Doctor Adventures #1.2 Released: 25 December 2017 Listened: 1/11/20 The second story of this set is a pure historical, set in New York during the Great Blizzard of 1888, which I had never heard of before this story, much to my embarrassment. As with most historicals, it’s a little on the slow side, and a bit grim, but not bleak as they often are. The pace is sustained by separating Ian and Barbara from the Doctor, and all of them from Susan. Ian and Barbara get involved in a domestic dispute, and then a rescue of some folks from a train, while the Doctor and Susan get caught up in some gang warfare. Ian gets sidelined early, so he can’t go into full Hero Mode until later. The Doctor is particularly cantankerous, but he’s worried about Susan and stuck with a bunch of violent Americans. The American accents are rather good, better than usual for Big Finish, although they tend toward stereotypical “Noo Yawk” accents, and there are still some English phrasings. I’m rather fond of this story; although historicals usually aren’t my favorites, I gravitate toward stories that take place in locations I’m familiar with.
docs.title: The Great White Hurricane

docs.text: The Hollow Crown First Doctor Adventures #5.2 Released: 27 April 2021 Listened: 5/1/21 The second story means it’s time for a historical, and unusually for this particular series, they don’t land someplace entirely horrible and immediately want to leave again. It’s time to meet Shakespeare! Again! This story takes place later in Shakespeare’s life than “The Shakespeare Code,” so he remembers meeting someone called “The Doctor,” but the First Doctor doesn’t react to that. Shakespeare is not played by Dean Lennox Kelly, as he was on TV, but rather by Nicholas Asbury, who’s had a tiny role on TV and several Big Finish parts. Writer Sarah Grochala (an award-winning playwright, but with only a few Big Finish credits yet) tells a tight story, leaning in on the Shakespearean tropes of noble rebellion, main characters in disguise, and gender-swapping, as well as slipping in rhyming couplets here and there. The TARDIS crew can’t seem to help quoting the plays at every opportunity, but it’s not like the Tenth Doctor resisted either. There’s also a nice subplot where Ian and Barbara once again test the limits of how much one can go against recorded history, which sometimes records incorrectly. In the end, though, this is the Essex Rebellion (which I knew very little about), and it has to go more or less to form, but with a nice romantic twist that’s very appropriate to the tone. And it ends on a sudden cliffhanger, a nice 1964-ish twist, so I hope it won’t be long before that’s resolved. I enjoyed this story much more than I expected to, and I hope to hear more from this writer in the future.
docs.title: The Hollow Crown

docs.text: The Invention of Death First Doctor Adventures #2.1 Released: 25 July 2018 Listened: 1/12/20 This is the first John Dorney story in this series, and as might be expected, it’s high-concept. The TARDIS crew happens upon a species of aliens who appear to be immortal, and therefore have no fear of death, no concept of pain or discomfort, no means of reproduction, and no spur toward scientific progress. That last concept seems to be most important in this story, as far as it provides some motivation for some very alien characters. Otherwise, there isn’t really a “bad guy” or any sort of threat, which makes the story drag a little bit. There’s also an odd interlude in which the cast sings “London’s Burning” as a round, for no real reason. This is another one of those stories that I don’t think could have been done on TV, not just because of the special effects, but because the concept is too far out there for the TV audience.
docs.title: The Invention of Death

docs.text: The Phoenicians First Doctor Adventures #3.1 Released: 29 January 2019 Listened: 1/16/20 This third box set switches up the order a bit and puts the historical first, for reasons that will become apparent. This time they’re in Tyre, participating in the events that led to the founding of Carthage -- and I do mean participating, as they’re interfering more than they would have in 1964. Unusually for historicals from this era, there’s no real “good guy.” Princess Elissa is sympathetic, but also acts in her own self-interest most of the time, which doesn’t always coincide with our heroes’. King Pygmalion is almost a caricature, with no redeeming qualities at all; he’s possibly mad, which is apparently appropriate to the story. The Phoenecians are all played by actors of appropriate backgrounds, which wouldn’t have happened in 1964, but they still sometimes sound stereotypical, as did the actors in “Samurai.” Ian still jumps into hero mode at the drop of a hat, but it goes badly for him much of the time, which leads to a pretty good first-episode cliffhanger. Susan gets some character growth too, and seems to be seeking some independence from her grandfather. Not the most memorable of the historicals, but not bad either.
docs.title: The Phoenicians

docs.text: Tick-Tock World First Doctor Adventures #3.2 Released: 29 January 2019 Listened: 1/16/20 The gimmick in this story is that Carole Ann Ford appears, credited as “Woman,” but it becomes clear quickly that she’s an older version of Susan. Not the Susan from Earth, but an alternate future Susan. Claudia Grant still sounds quite different than Carole Ann, but either she’s toned down her RP accent some since starting, or I’m just getting more used to it now. The oddest vocal clashing is that the guest characters all use their own regional accents, which makes the four leads stand out more than usual. This is another high-concept time-traveley story, from Guy Adams, and another that probably wouldn’t have worked on TV in 1964. Susan, as you can imagine, is the focus, with a lot of attention being paid to her growing up and becoming more of her own person. If they were in the regular timeline, it would make a great lead-in to “The Dalek Invasion of Earth.” There are also much stronger hints at a deepening relationship between Ian and Barbara, which kind of fits in the timeline as well. Carole Ann Ford does well in the role, despite being mostly a phantom with not much to do. She bounces off Bradley in just the same way she would Hartnell, which works nicely.
docs.title: Tick-Tock World

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor The Fourth Doctor: the scarf, all teeth-and-curls, that mellifluous voice. This is the Doctor who everyone thought of first, at least until that Tenant chap came along. Unfortunately, Tom Baker had a bit of a troubled relationship with the character, and often declined to reprise the role. For quite some time, Baker declined to work with Big Finish, for a variety of reasons. However, from 2009 to 2011, he participated in the “Hornet’s Nest” series for BBC Audio, and after that joined Big Finish for some Lost Stories in 2011, and his own series starting in 2012. I suspect that long-time Big Finish participant Louise Jameson may have had a part in his return to the role. Now, he’s extremely enthusiastic about the audios, having recorded several series years in advance, and popping up in specials and guest roles. Although he doesn’t sound precisely like his younger self anymore, his voice is unmistakable, and a great fit for audio.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor

docs.title: The Fourth Doctor

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor and Ann You say you don’t remember a companion named Ann in 1978? That’s because she only exists in Big Finish. There’s a gap of undetermined length between “The Invasion of Time” and “The Ribos Operation,” but rather than sneaking in another solo period, or having the Fourth Doctor with just K-9, the folks in charge created a new companion, and a new adventure running through eight stories. Unlike other stories that feature TV companions, listeners don’t come in already knowing how Ann’s story ends. Even better, this is a complete story arc for Ann, making this boxed set self-contained…except it’s more complicated than that, because it always is.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor and Ann

docs.title: The Fourth Doctor and Ann

docs.text: Fever Island Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.6 Released: 13 February 2019 Listened: 5/2/22 This story appears to be a standalone, the only one in this boxed set. And boy, is it trippy. The Doctor and Ann investigate a temporal anomaly taking place on an isolated Scottish island in 1978. There’s also a secret agent there, by the name of Jason Vane, who’s basically a parody of every spy novel ever. He even does narration in deeply purple prose, until Ann reveals that she can hear him doing it. Turns out there’s something here that’s changing the nature of people and things, and for a while, the Doctor behaves like a cliche spy villain. Which is silly on the face of it, but Tom Baker leans in to the sinister element of the role, and his lines drip with menace. The actual plot isn’t really any great shakes; it’s mostly an excuse to let people run around and play secret agent. But at that goal, it succeeds handily.
docs.title: Fever Island

docs.text: Planet of the Drashigs Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.2 Released: 16 January 2019 Listened: 4/26/22 This story is technically the first chronological appearance of K-9 Mark II, as the Doctor has just finished building him as the story opens. It’s also Ann’s first TARDIS trip, and unfortunately for her, she’s got a full-blown Jurassic Park reference, complete with electric fences, a mad billionaire owner, a laconic gamekeeper, and a panicky safety inspector. (Sadly, no Wayne Knight or Sam Jackson, but the story is only an hour.) And instead of foolishly messing with dinosaur DNA, the scientist is foolishly messing with mind-controlling Drashigs. Even though they only appeared in “Carnival of Monsters,” Drashigs have become kind of synonymous in the fandom with “unstoppable beasts.” (Despite the fact that their name is an anagram of “dishrag.”) Introducing smaller, smarter variants creates even more parallels to Jurassic Park , but it does allow the baddies some agency, instead of just being a force of nature. As for Ann, although she drew an unusually dangerous first adventure, the Doctor does try to keep her out of mortal peril. She’s asking a lot of questions and making inferences here, which makes her a nice step between Leela and Romana.
docs.title: Planet of the Drashigs

docs.text: The Enchantress of Numbers Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.3 Released: 16 January 2019 Listened: 4/27/22 Doctor Who is rather fond of Ada, Countess of Lovelace, and honestly, why not? As a result, Ada’s timeline is getting as crowded as her father’s and Mary Shelley’s with visits from various Doctors. This visit takes place toward the end of Ada’s life, after she’s retired to the countryside and given up working on mathematics. Ada is played well as a woman hovering on the edge of madness, afraid of what she’s inherited from her father along with his genius. Of course, it doesn’t help that there are actual apparitions and sinister plague doctors popping up around her. Ann gets to do some more investigating in this story, and she’s pretty happy to violate cultural norms about her “place” in order to get her job done. K-9 is noticeably absent from this one, probably because a mobile, talking computer would change the story dramatically. The monsters are a little anticlimactic, but they’re not given a lot of space in the story. Good characterization, so-so plot.
docs.title: The Enchantress of Numbers

docs.text: The False Guardian Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.4 Released: 16 January 2019 Listened: 4/30/22 This is where things start to get a bit strange. Because it turns out that to follow this storyline, you’re going to have to remember things from “The Daleks’ Master Plan,” which is a lost episode, so you’ll have to know the plot somehow. You’ve got the planet Kembel, somehow still around, complete with Varga plants, you’ve got Mavic Chen (or someone who thinks he’s Mavic Chen), and you’ve even got Zephon, son of Zephon, from the planet Zephon (not very imaginative). Ann, K-9, and the Doctor spend the first half of the story in mortal peril from the elements, and the second half split up, trying to figure out what’s going on in this institution that calls itself a retreat, but is very probably an asylum. And that’s pretty much it. Ann gets to use her skills, but then the story ends on a cliffhanger, which in this case, was also the end of the first boxed set of Season 8.
docs.title: The False Guardian

docs.text: The Perfect Prisoners, part 1 Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.7 Released: 13 February 2019 Listened: 5/15/22 This two-part finale is what the whole boxed set has been building to. It’s a John Dorney story, so that means it’s twisty. The Doctor and Ann continue their investigations, finally involving the Space Security Service. The Syndicate turn out to be the members of the Galactic Council from “The Daleks’ Master Plan,” or their descendants, and they all have an issue with the Doctor. Their big plot involves controlling the minds of everyone in the galaxy, or rather, controlling their perceptions, which amounts to the same thing. However, most of the Syndicate members end up getting killed while in close proximity to Ann, which finally becomes suspicious.
docs.title: The Perfect Prisoners, part 1

docs.text: Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.7 Released: 13 February 2019 Listened: 5/15/22 This two-part finale is what the whole boxed set has been building to. It’s a John Dorney story, so that means it’s twisty. The Doctor and Ann continue their investigations, finally involving the Space Security Service. Their big plot involves controlling the minds of everyone in the galaxy, or rather, controlling their perceptions, which amounts to the same thing. However, most of the Syndicate members end up getting killed while in close proximity to Ann, which finally becomes suspicious.
docs.title: The Perfect Prisoners, part 1

docs.text: The Perfect Prisoners, part 2 Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.8 Released: 13 February 2019 Listened: 5/15/22 The big secret is finally revealed: Ann Kelso is revealed to be Anya Kingdom of the Space Security Service, operating as a sleeper agent on Earth in the 1970s. In fact, Ann Kelso never existed at all. Beyond that cover, Anya is a brainwashed agent of Zaal of the Syndicate, using her to wipe out the other members. That explains, among other things, Ann’s ability to fly the TARDIS accurately. Which makes for a great reveal the first time around, but knowing that doesn’t really add much to a relisten. However, Jane Slavin’s portrayal makes Ann/Anya vicious and cunning at many points, but ultimately sympathetic when it becomes clear she wasn’t responsible for her actions. If Anya never appeared again, it would seem odd that nothing was ever made of her family connections. However, she’ll be back again in the Dalek Universe stories, when considerably more time has passed for the Doctor, and he’s got a better perspective on the matter. On the whole, this season represented a strong attempt to do something different, give the Fourth Doctor a new companion, and give that story a strong twist, all of which succeeded. Having the story tied so tightly to “The Daleks’ Master Plan” seems like a less-good idea, partially because it’s a lost story, but also because the villains didn’t do much in that story, so they don’t seem very effective or threatening here.
docs.title: The Perfect Prisoners, part 2

docs.text: The Sinestran Kill Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.1 Released: 16 January 2019 Listened: 4/25/22 With the Doctor at loose ends, he answers a signal indicating unusual technology being used on Earth in 1978 (when the story would have aired, if this had been a TV season). Investigating, he discovers an area of London that’s having some trouble with organized crime. WPC Ann Kelso patrols the area, but doesn’t normally deal with the gang unit. Except the Doctor knows there’s more going on here, and it turns out that both the gangsters and their targets are aliens, or being controlled by aliens. All we know about this group right now is that they’re called the Syndicate, and that’s what this boxed set is all about. Ann has all the hallmarks of a good companion right from the start, being logical, open-minded, cool under fire, and yet empathetic. She even comments that she would expect to freak out after seeing a giant insectoid alien, but she didn’t. Equally unflappable is DCI Neilson, played by Frank Skinner, comedian and super-fan. Fortunately, Neilson was in Special Branch for several years, so he’s conversant with UNIT in general and the Doctor specifically, which really saves a lot of time in this story. Writer Andrew Smith was in an anti-terrorism squad himself during his time in the police, so his knowledge of procedure adds a little bit of realism to the story. It’s a pretty good kickoff, and the gangsters give it some 70s flavor.
docs.title: The Sinestran Kill

docs.text: Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.1 Released: 16 January 2019 Listened: 4/25/22 With the Doctor at loose ends, he answers a signal indicating unusual technology being used on Earth in 1978 (when the story would have aired, if this had been a TV season). Investigating, he discovers an area of London that’s having some trouble with organized crime. WPC Ann Kelso patrols the area, but doesn’t normally deal with the gang unit. Except the Doctor knows there’s more going on here, and it turns out that both the gangsters and their targets are aliens, or being controlled by aliens. All we know about this group right now is that they’re called the Syndicate, and that’s what this boxed set is all about. Ann has all the hallmarks of a good companion right from the start, being logical, open-minded, cool under fire, and yet empathetic. She even comments that she would expect to freak out after seeing a giant insectoid alien, but she didn’t. Equally unflappable is DCI Neilson, played by Frank Skinner, comedian and super-fan. Fortunately, Neilson was in Special Branch for several years, so he’s conversant with UNIT in general and the Doctor specifically, which really saves a lot of time in this story. Writer Andrew Smith was in an anti-terrorism squad himself during his time in the police, so his knowledge of procedure adds a little bit of realism to the story. It’s a pretty good kickoff, and the gangsters give it some 70s flavor.
docs.title: The Sinestran Kill

docs.text: Time's Assassin Fourth Doctor Adventures #8.5 Released: 13 February 2019 Listened: 5/1/22 The second boxed set of Season 8 opens right after the cliffhanger of the last one. A few things become slightly clearer…but not really. Most intriguingly, Ann reveals one layer of her deception, but only to the listener, not the Doctor. As for the rest, it’s a Guy Adams story, so there’s plenty of absurdity. In fact, just about every character in this story who’s not part of Team TARDIS is mad in one way or another. Special credit goes to Blake Ritson as Dr. Elmore, the maddest mad scientist I’ve seen in a while, and Jon Culshaw as Zephon, son of Zephon, who takes pettiness, paranoia, cruelty, and vengeance to the next level, while still remaining pathetic at the core. The only real downfall to the story is that the Doctor doesn’t seem to solve any problems. Bad guys lose, but not as a result of the Doctor’s actions, and the Doctor himself only survives through a deus ex machina. (Well, machina ex machina, or something.) What’s clear, though, is that the first half of this season appeared to be just a bunch of disconnected stories, and now we’re finding out that it definitely isn’t.
docs.title: Time's Assassin

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor and Leela (and K-9) Louise Jameson has been one of the biggest supporters of Big Finish almost since the beginning. She’s now written and directed for them, as well as playing Leela, which she does with astonishing skill. Even though Leela is a very physical character, Jameson manages to perfectly recreate her on audio. Unfortunately, without Tom Baker, she could only participate in some Companion Chronicles and Short Trips. This has never been confirmed, but I imagine she’s played a large part in getting Tom Baker to return on audio. That makes this section unusually long, given her somewhat short tenure on TV, but that’s fine, because Big Finish is able to flesh out the “education” subplot that didn’t see much action on TV.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor and Leela

docs.text: A Ghost of Alchemy The Eighth of March #3.1 Released: 8 March 2023 Listened: 5/6/23 This story is from the third "Eighth of March" collection, and it plays a little bit with the formula. It’s a full-length story, which is unusual for these sets. It’s also written by Louise Jameson, who is multi-dimensional in the Big Finish realm. It has Leela, but also the Fourth Doctor. The Eighth of March stories tend to minimize the Doctor to accentuate the women in the story, but this one doesn’t. Maybe Louise didn’t think it was necessary, because the big historical guest of this story is one Madame Curie, pioneer of radioactivity research. Of course, that same research also killed her, and the story never lets you forget it, with Marie’s continual cough, exhausted manner, and terrible stage-fright. The story takes place in America in 1920, when Marie had a national tour. Unfortunately, a scientist named Browman believes that Curie is a fraud riding on her husband’s success, and is determined to discredit her. He also believes that he should have access to the radium that Curie is being gifted with. He’s sexist, which makes sense in an Eighth of March story, but he’s so remarkably foolish and evil that he might as well be twirling his mustache. His henchman in Curie’s party is also pathetic and weak-willed. On top of which, President Harding is presented as rather foolish as well, delegating most responsibility to his wife Florence. This isn’t out of line with Doctor Who ’s treatment of American presidents, or even with historians’ assessment of Harding, although I don’t recall hearing that he was dominated by his wife. Leela, as you might expect, does reasonably well for herself, and the Doctor expresses quite a lot of confidence in her. However, she does end up captured and drugged at one point, which is fairly unusual for her. On the whole, it’s kind of a runaround, not too different from most stories, except for the fairly low stakes and caricatured presentation of the men.
docs.title: A Ghost of Alchemy

docs.text: Antillia the Lost Fourth Doctor Adventures #12.2 Released: 2 March 2023 Listened: 5/6/23 For her second trip, Margaret again gets a sci-fi setting. The TARDIS ends up unexpectedly on Antillia, a huge space station with its own environment that was host to a lot of scientific research, then disappeared, leaving a legend. They’re here because a ship with an experimental drive has located the station, and drawn the TARDIS off-course. Author Phil Mulryne has a lot of high concepts here, from the mystery of the disappearance to what happened to the inhabitants, to what the explorers are really up to. The secondary characters are very well-drawn, including a journalist played by Anjli Mohindra, who is always awesome, and a bodyguard who Leela forms an unusual respect for. And speaking of respect, she’s getting closer with Margaret, although they do spend a chunk of the story apart. Younger Leela might not see this so readily, but she recognizes Margaret’s innate bravery and sense of adventure, even if she hasn’t lived a life that brought that out of her before. Admittedly, there’s a lot of plot in this one, and not so much time for personal relationships. It zips along readily, with perhaps a touch too much capture and deathtraps and escapes and running, but that’s fairly common for the period. It’s good, but not a particular standout.
docs.title: Antillia the Lost

docs.text: Black Dog Short Trips #5.4 Released: 6 April 2015 Listened: 2/20/22 This story doesn’t have to do with depression, at least, not directly. The TARDIS lands on an Earth mining colony that’s now been mined out, so the few remaining humans are about to leave. There are natives on the planet, but for once, they’re not in conflict with the humans; in fact, they don’t seem to care whether the humans stay or go. Both groups are troubled by a black dog that appears in dreams, and marks the dreamer for death. The natives believe it’s a god, who has supplanted their other gods, and honestly the humans pretty much believe that too. When Leela has the dream, and has her energy sapped, the Doctor goes into full atheist mode to get to the bottom of the problem. In fairness, the Doctor has been vanquishing gods quite a bit lately (Sutekh, Xoanon), so he’s got form. He ends up praising Leela’s skills rather a lot, to inspire her, which gives Leela a glimpse into how he sees her.
docs.title: Black Dog

docs.text: Death-Dealer Short Trips #1.4 Released: 5 November 2010 Listened: 2/20/22 This is one of the shortest of Short Trips, just over 10 minutes. The Doctor takes Leela to a planetary bazaar, and she badly misunderstands what one vendor is selling. Honestly, it’s amazing this sort of thing doesn’t happen more often, given companions’ tendency to wander off, and the Doctor’s tendency to not notice.
docs.title: Death-Dealer

docs.text: Death Match Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.4 Released: 16 April 2015 Listened: 4/5/22 After a rather impressive cliffhanger, in which Leela left the Doctor and then found herself kidnapped by the Master, we find out what’s going on. The Master has used Leela to take over a multi-system deathmatch competition. With her as his champion, he’s amassing plenty of resources and attracting the attention of the rich and powerful of this corner of space. It’s a little small-fry for him, but he seems to be enjoying himself. Marshall, the reformed Rocket Man with an attachment to Leela, calls in the Doctor to help, and amazingly, he shows up in time. This story is much more straightforward than the previous, with the Doctor and the Master in their accustomed roles, because this is a Matt Fitton story, not a John Dorney one. Which means that there are layers of emotional content, Marshall’s for Leela, Leela’s more complex ones for Marshall, the Doctor’s for Leela, and even K-9’s, although he claims not to have any. Of course we know what the outcome has to be, but that doesn’t make it any less heartbreaking, mostly because Louise Jameson is awesome.
docs.title: Death Match

docs.text: Destination: Nerva Fourth Doctor Adventures #1.1 Released: 9 January 2012 Listened: 2/23/22 Now we’re getting into it! In 2012, Big Finish began releasing a dedicated series of Fourth Doctor Adventures. These were similar to the Eighth Doctor Adventures in format, being shorter stories of two parts, each 25-30 minutes. That results in a somewhat zippier pace, intended to appeal to new-series fans. Unfortunately, this story isn’t the strongest premiere. It starts immediately after “Talons,” and goes only a few years into the future, where some English military-types manage to get their hands on a crashed alien spaceship and somehow use it to get into space, despite the technological difficulties, where they proceed to colonize “for Queen and Country.” This could be an interesting investigation of British history and colonialism, but instead it just jumps forward a thousand years, where the Victorians are now just a generic “ooze monster” threat to the brand-new Station Nerva. There’s no good reason for it to be Nerva; aside from a couple of references only the Doctor could get, its history doesn’t figure in. Baker and Jameson both sound in good form; I could believe this is from Season 14. Also, a pre-Third-Doctor Tim Treloar plays Lord Jack, the chief baddie, but he doesn't really have a lot of lines.
docs.title: Destination: Nerva

docs.text: Destroy the Infinite Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.6 Released: 18 June 2014 Listened: 3/7/22 In 2013/2014, Nick Briggs created the Eminence and the Infinite Warriors as a “big bad” exclusive to Big Finish. As such, it pops up in a variety of stories, with its timeline out of order relative to the Doctor’s. This story, however, is their first meeting from the Doctor’s point of view. Beyond that, though, it’s a fairly standard story. The Eminence is busy waging war on humanity, the Doctor turns up and tries to stop it. Leela gets a lot of agency in this one because she’s separated from the Doctor and has to fight her way back on her own. There could probably be some interesting questions of identity in this story, or perhaps some timey-wimey nonsense given the out-of-sync timelines, but there isn’t. It’s mostly military action and explosions, which is fine for what it is. The Doctor can’t get a clean win, however, because the Eminence is needed further down the timeline. Although he finds that disturbing, he doesn’t really seem to do anything about it right now.
docs.title: Destroy the Infinite

docs.text: Empathy Games Companion Chronicles #3.4 Released: October 2008 Listened: 4/2/22 The frame story picks up directly from the previous one: Leela is still a prisoner, but the Z’nai have all been wiped out. Oddly, the torture machines are now keeping her alive. She hears a child crying nearby, and tries to tell it a story, leading to the flashback. Which is, honestly, very strange. The Doctor spends a large chunk of it in a coma, so Leela is left to function on her own, which means things are going to get a bit violent. The planet they’re on is very high-concept, supposedly totally peaceful, with an astonishing water sculpture that would look amazing with modern SFX, and some rather odd hunting “games” that Leela takes to right away, although they’re not what they seem. David Warner is the backup actor in this one, and although his character doesn’t actually do a whole lot, I’ll take David Warner in anything, thanks very much. Unexpectedly, we get an explanation for what happened to the wooden console room, and why it hasn’t been seen since. Even with the strangeness, there’s a strong visual quality to the story that makes it stand out. The frame story, however, is quite weak this time out, and doesn’t resolve, so we’ll have to wait for that.
docs.title: Empathy Games

docs.text: Energy of the Daleks Fourth Doctor Adventures #1.4 Released: April 2012 Listened: 2/27/22 Of course, if you’re launching a new Big Finish series, you need to have Daleks in there somewhere, especially since Leela has never encountered Daleks on TV. So they land in 2025 London, when apparently holograms are common, and the National Gallery has been turned into the HQ of an energy company, but nobody has smartphones, they have “tiny TVs” instead. Leela gets to wear contemporary clothing, including trainers, which she likes quite a lot. These Daleks are a fairly classic bunch; they’re trying to wipe out humanity in 2025 to alter the timeline. Which is a nice reversal of “Genesis of the Daleks,” although 2025 seems a bit early to try it. It’s a fairly straightforward story, as Nick Briggs stories often are, with not much in the way of surprises, but that’s OK. It’s mainly about a standard Dalek conflict, and it works well for that.
docs.title: Energy of the Daleks
