docs.text: Ice Heist Fourth Doctor Adventures #12.1 Released: 2 March 2023 Listened: 5/5/23 This particular series brings in Nerys Hughes as Margaret Hopwood, introduced a while back in “The Ravencliff Witch,” but not invited as a companion. Back then, the Doctor was alone, but this time Leela is also present. She’s pretty experienced by this point, and almost immediately takes Margaret under her wing. A bit unusual, as Leela doesn’t really care for people who flap around and panic, but she knows Margaret helped the Doctor before. He’s picked her up to bring her to an art auction a few hundred years in the future, where one of her sculptures is going for an absurd amount of money. He thinks of it as a treat, but Margaret sees it as a sign of her own mortality and blows a fuse, which sets off Leela’s protective instincts. The Doctor spends an unusual amount of time being wrong in this story, and also spouting nonsense as he does when he wants to impress a new friend, which Leela isn’t willing to let him get away with. There’s some actual story going on as well, with Ice Warriors who are also present at the auction for nefarious reasons. Writer Guy Adams deliberately wanted to subvert the idea of Ice Warriors as honorable Klingon-types, and he succeeds here. The only flaw is that results in a lot of Martian bickering, which means lots of hissing Ice Warrior dialog. Nick Briggs normally does monster voices extremely well, but when he’s got a lot of exposition to fire off, you can tell it’s him. Adele Lynch, who played the Ice Warrior empress on TV, returns here as a different Ice Warrior, and she’s clearly enjoying herself. There are also quite a few memorable secondary characters, including a curator who’s completely determined to ignore anything that might be going wrong, her laconic head of security, a pompous artist who holds the buyers in contempt, and even a guard with a remarkably upbeat outlook on life. The story gets a little hard to follow at times, especially when so many characters are around, but ultimately it's worth it.
docs.title: Ice Heist

The only flaw is that results in a lot of Martian bickering, which means lots of hissing Ice Warrior dialog. Nick Briggs normally does monster voices extremely well, but when he’s got a lot of exposition to fire off, you can tell it’s him. Adele Lynch, who played the Ice Warrior empress on TV, returns here as a different Ice Warrior, and she’s clearly enjoying herself. There are also quite a few memorable secondary characters, including a curator who’s completely determined to ignore anything that might be going wrong, her laconic head of security, a pompous artist who holds the buyers in contempt, and even a guard with a remarkably upbeat outlook on life. The story gets a little hard to follow at times, especially when so many characters are around, but ultimately it's worth it.
docs.title: Ice Heist

docs.text: Kill the Doctor! Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.7 Released: 16 May 2018 Listened: 4/15/22 This is the first half of a two-part story by Guy Adams, which brings back Sutekh, but in a futuristic setting, which hasn’t been done before. Fortunately, Gabriel Woolf is still around to voice Sutekh, but I’m not sure anyone else could, and he sounds just as quietly menacing as ever. However, he’s not really the main driver of this first half. The Doctor and Leela arrive on a planet not unlike present-day earth. People are obsessed with their smartphones, in a not-veiled-at-all reference. But more important, Leela runs headfirst into late-stage capitalism, and is appalled by the treatment of the underclass. She assumes the Doctor will help overturn the government, a reasonable guess on her part, but he’s not willing to go stomping on inequality wherever it exists. Leela ends up angrier than she’s been yet with the Doctor, and decides to go fight the power on her own. The Doctor, meanwhile, gets chased by zombified mobs everywhere he goes, which he has to admit is a bit extreme even for his lifestyle. As far as the dialog goes, it’s an open secret that Tom Baker likes to punch up his lines, and he might be taking it a bit too far this time around. The Doctor seems positively flippant, even goofy at times, which isn’t really what he was like back in this season. Still, it’s a well-paced setup for a longer story.
docs.title: Kill the Doctor!

docs.text: Last of the Colophon Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.5 Released: 14 May 2014 Listened: 3/6/22 This Johnny Morris story is also a bit slight, or at least the threat doesn’t get to be quite as big as it should. The planet Colophos is a dead world, destroyed by a virus centuries ago and lost to history. However, an Earth Empire survey ship turns up to assess the planet at exactly the same time the Doctor and Leela show up for a (questionable) holiday. That leads to their uncovering Morax, the titular last of the Colophon, who’s been imprisoned all this time. The first half of the story has a kind of Indiana Jones feel, with the trap-laden tomb and such. The second half is The Invisible Man , by the writer’s own admission. Doctor Who is famous for using invisible monsters as a budget-saving tool, but they rarely have a sentient invisible psychopath, which works reasonably well on audio. Gareth Thomas (Blake of Blake’s Seven ) plays Morax with lots of gravely menace, which is good. However, the short length makes it feel like either half of the story could have been longer.
docs.title: Last of the Colophon

docs.text: Night of the Stormcrow Fourth Doctor Adventures Special Released: 12 December 2012 Listened: 3/1/22 This bonus release is a bit odd because it feels like it should be part of Series 1 of the Fourth Doctor Adventures, and it was released between Series 1 and Series 2, yet it’s labeled as a special. Anyway, it’s a spooky, atmospheric, “Fang Rock” kind of story. The Doctor and Leela land near an observatory on a small Pacific island, where the lead astronomer has found something unusual orbiting the Earth, something she’s chosen to call “Stormcrow.” It’s never entirely clear what the Stormcrow is, just a kind of sentient blackness, as are the scavengers that follow it, which the Doctor calls “no-things.” Apparently they eat time, and cause despair and jealousy in people. It’s a Mark Platt story, so the whole thing has a semi-mystical feel, and most of it you have to take on faith. In the absence of a hard plot, you’re left with the performances, which are quite good all around. Ann Bell does a great job as the astronomer, seeming like the “older eccentric scientist” character common in this era, but there’s a lot more going on there. American Chase Masterson (of Deep Space Nine ) plays the authority figure with bad intentions, for the Doctor to bounce off of. Tom Baker gets an interesting turn when the Doctor is affected by the scavengers, giving Louise Jameson the chance to air Leela’s feelings of homelessness. She hasn’t really expressed how she feels about traveling before, so this makes for an interesting twist. Mark Platt stories, while interesting, usually leave me feeling like I’ve missed something, and this one is no different. It’s a fine addition to the first series, but not particularly memorable.
docs.title: Night of the Stormcrow

docs.text: Requiem for the Rocket Men Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.3 Released: 13 March 2015 Listened: 4/4/22 The Rocket Men have appeared in a few stories, and usually end up losing badly to the Doctor, which is starting to hurt their reputations. However, the Doctor still treats them as a serious threat. This story is by John Dorney, creator of the Rocket Men, and it has some nods toward his original story, like an extended bluff in Part 1 that’s explained by a flashback in Part 2. Unfortunately the misdirect isn’t as strong as in the original, but I don’t think it was trying to be. The misdirects lie in other places: any time you use the Master as a secondary character, something fishy is going on. The only real hitch is that it requires substantial planning on the Doctor’s part, which isn’t something the Fourth Doctor normally goes in for. That’s more of a Seventh Doctor thing, but maybe he felt that the Rocket Men merited that level of attention. The last couple of scenes, though, are entirely unexpected, and create a strong desire to listen to the next story.
docs.title: Requiem for the Rocket Men

docs.text: Return to Telos Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.8 Released: 11 August 2015 Listened: 4/10/22 This story follows on directly from the previous, but it’s a little more traditional. A little, anyway. K-9 has been suborned by the Cybermen, unfortunately in one of their Borg-like phases where a single touch can cause complete conversion. But the Doctor does a clever thing that accidentally drops them into “The Tomb of the Cybermen,” except in a way where the Doctors never meet, and the original story is undisturbed. So it’s not really a multi-Doctor crossover. In fact, there’s a lot of time spent on the timey-wimeyness of it all, with the Doctor’s moral dilemma from the last story brushed aside because the Cybermen cheated first. Unfortunately, a 60s-era Cyberplanner and Cybercontroller talking to one another, while probably fun for Nick Briggs, is a ring-modulated slow-speed assault on the ears, and tough to enjoy. I get what Briggs was going for here, but I don’t think that either story really succeeds fully.
docs.title: Return to Telos

docs.text: Shadow of the Sun Fourth Doctor Adventures special Released: 12 May 2020 Listened: 4/16/22 This one is slightly unusual. It was recorded in March 2020, the first remote recording Big Finish did because of the pandemic. The intent was to shelve it and release it with series 13. (The Fourth Doctor Adventures are recorded years in advance, at Tom Baker’s request.) However, Big Finish thought it would be a nice gesture to release it early, to help fans cope with lockdown. Unfortunately, they had no way of knowing just how long covid would last, and that remote recording would become standard procedure. Listening to the extras is almost surreal. Anyway, the story involves a cruise liner rented by a society of spiritualists, on which the TARDIS lands for emergency repairs. Which would be fine, except this particular cult believes there’s a habitable area inside the sun, and intend to prove it by going there. Their leader is a charismatic, but disgraced, scientist, who’s basically dragging everyone else along by force of will. The Doctor has about as much luck as ever, talking down insane tyrants. However, he does seem a bit more desperate than usual, and confused by the cult’s behavior. The theme of people ignoring science in favor of their own personal beliefs is pretty clear here, probably hammered a bit too hard, really. Tom Baker and Louise Jameson both sound a bit closer to their actual ages in this story; I don’t know if that’s a result of when it was recorded, or the new recording process, or just my imagination. It was a nice gesture as an early release, but ultimately it’s just OK.
docs.title: Shadow of the Sun

docs.text: Sound the Siren and I'll Come to You Comrade Short Trips Rarities #1.5 Released: 22 December 2014 Listened: 3/15/22 Short story, long title. It seems like the title should be a reference, but I can’t find out to what. The Doctor wants to take Leela to the court of Peter the Great, but they miss and land in a Soviet H-bomb testing site in the 1950s, most likely this test . There’s a monster around, a beast that thrives on radiation, but the Doctor is more concerned about the fact that they’re testing an H-bomb. In the end, history is history, and the Doctor really does nothing, and solves nothing. However, it’s a look into the Soviet mindset of the time, and a really close look at what the first milliseconds of a nuclear explosion actually look like, so writer John Pritchard has done his homework here. Stephen Critchlow narrates, and does an excellent Fourth Doctor. He also gives the Russian characters distinct accents, so it feels like a full-cast play.
docs.title: Sound the Siren and I'll Come to You Comrade

docs.text: Stone Cold Fourth Doctor Adventures #12.5 Released: 21 June 2023 Listened: 7/22/23 This is one where if you can manage to avoid the spoilers right on the cover (and the hint in the title), you’ll be much better off. The Doctor is trying to take Margaret somewhere pleasant, but the nice forest planet he’s aiming for turns out to be a barren rock with some active volcanism. It’s just rocks and more rocks…until they find the grave. And then the crashed spaceship. Which is bad, because there weren’t supposed to be any people here, ever. We do the usual runaround with the travelers being accused of murder before the crew start trusting them. The tension builds all throughout the first half of the story, before the monster is revealed. And as I said, if you don’t know, it’s a fairly effective reveal as the hints pile up. At least, it worked that way for me. The rest of the story is tight and claustrophobic, which is appropriate for these particular monsters, and writer Roland Moore uses what we know about them to great effect. There’s also a Bob Holmesian double-act in the form of a couple of tourists from the ship, who bicker and snipe most of the time. It might be a shade long, but I think it’s well-executed.
docs.title: Stone Cold

docs.text: Suburban Hell Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.5 Released: 21 May 2015 Listened: 4/8/22 At the halfway point of the season, this story is a much lighter story, despite the title. The Doctor and Leela land in a suburban English town, and the TARDIS immediately leaves with K-9 aboard, writing him out of this story. They crash a dinner party, and assume they’re in 1977 again, but it turns out to be a 70s-themed party, and they’re actually in the 2010s. That doesn’t mean there’s no temporal shenanigans going on, though, as events in the present are linked to those in 1977, causing paradoxes, slippages, “long way rounds,” and the whole timey-wimey ball. It’s a well-paced story, with the first half entirely occupied with figuring out what’s going on, and the second taking a distinctly sci-fi turn as they try to use the temporal shenanigans to fix the problem at the root. Annette Badland makes yet another guest appearance, as Thelma-from-over-the-road. Alan Barnes gets special credit for creating a couple of characters in Belinda and Pete who are thoroughly unpleasant from the get-go, and stay that way even through mortal peril, which is a neat trick. It’s a small story, but it’s memorable.
docs.title: Suburban Hell

docs.text: The Abandoned Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.7 Released: 11 July 2014 Listened: 3/8/22 This story is remarkable for a number of reasons: It’s written by Nigel Fairs and Louise Jameson, in her writing debut. It also takes place entirely within the TARDIS, although there are more than two characters present. The gist of this one is that there’s a malevolent entity trapped in the TARDIS, which has been there since before the Doctor “borrowed” it. And now it’s doing something that involves other people’s imaginary friends? You’d best be in the mood for giggling and cackling, wailing and shrieking, because there’s a lot of all of those in this story. And painting. Lots of painting, which doesn’t really translate on audio. Louise Jameson seems to like the stories that have a more dreamlike quality, but I prefer them to have a bit of internal logic, and I wasn’t finding that here. I remember liking this one on my first listen, but it didn’t work for me this time around.
docs.title: The Abandoned

docs.text: The Age of Sutekh Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.8 Released: 16 May 2018 Listened: 4/15/22 The concluding part of the story isn’t quite as good as the setup, but it does come close. The issue is that Sutekh has a very primal objective: He wants to wipe out everything, full stop. That’s a little tricky to work with, so Guy Adams has him in a situation where his power is limited, and he needs to conserve it. Which leads to the best sequence, Leela out-maneuvering him in a jungle while calling him “horse-face” all the while. Leela versus a god is a match I wouldn’t really like to bet on, but don’t tell Leela that. She’s very nearly at the peak of her capability in this story, able to read and pretty good at understanding technology, while still retaining her fighting and tracking skills. The guest cast in these stories, beyond Gabriel Woolf, is worthy of note: Sophie Myles (Reinette from “The Girl in the Fireplace”), Eleanor Crooks (Naomi Cross in various UNIT stories), John Dorney as Carlton Joyce, and Barnaby Edwards as the entire rest of the population of the planet. That’s some quality Big Finish casting there. Oddly, K-9 is left out again, meaning he’s barely appeared at all in this season.
docs.title: The Age of Sutekh

docs.text: The Bad Penny Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.6 Released: 16 May 2018 Listened: 4/14/22 This one is written by Dan Starkey, and although it doesn’t have the excessive verbiage that his stories sometimes do, it’s stuffed full of ideas, perhaps more than are needed. It’s a “mysterious hotel” story, of which Doctor Who has had plenty, and a big old time paradox as well. It’s also got a “self-made man” taking advantage of the paradox, various characters out of their time, and also a monster. I’m not sure the monster was strictly necessary, but someone decided that Doctor Who stories should have a monster in them. Leela does fairly well, for a story that takes place entirely inside a hotel, using her skills to read people. The Doctor seems a bit more banter-y than usual, but that’s probably the writing. (K-9 is absent once again.) One element to note is that there are more characters than usual in a Big Finish story, because Dan Starkey is able to voice them all himself, which gives him a bit of leverage in the scope, which is ironic considering the claustrophobic nature of the story.
docs.title: The Bad Penny

docs.text: The Catalyst Companion Chronicles #2.4 Released: January 2008 Listened: 4/2/22 A couple of Companion Chronicles slip in before we jump back to the full-cast stories, which gives Louise Jameson a chance to stretch by playing several characters, including the Doctor. She says it’s difficult to do a Tom Baker impersonation, but hers is one of the better ones I’ve heard. Like most early Companion Chronicles, the frame story takes place later in Leela’s life, but for her, that’s complicated, because this was recorded in 2007, when not a lot of detail was known about the Time War. So she survived, Gallifrey didn’t, and now she’s prisoner of a race called the Z’nai. The flashback relates her first encounter with the Z’nai, which involves visiting a Victorian-era mansion (again). The owner, Joshua Douglas, was apparently a previously unknown companion of the Third Doctor, never mentioned in any other story, who parted ways with the Doctor after a disagreement about how to stop the warlike Z’nai. Leela seems pretty inexperienced herself; her reading is rudimentary, she doesn’t know table manners, and she’s very quick to violence, but the story has to be placed here for Reasons. The story itself is quite dark. The body count is absurdly high, but also the Doctor has to try to convince several people that genocide is bad, even in self-defence. And he fails. It’s really kind of a grim moment in Leela’s relationship with the Doctor, and if we didn’t have a whole bunch of Fourth Doctor Adventures to offset it, it might be quite depressing. But Louise Jameson’s fantastic acting makes up for a lot.
docs.title: The Catalyst

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #2.4 Released: January 2008 Listened: 4/2/22 A couple of Companion Chronicles slip in before we jump back to the full-cast stories, which gives Louise Jameson a chance to stretch by playing several characters, including the Doctor. She says it’s difficult to do a Tom Baker impersonation, but hers is one of the better ones I’ve heard. docs.title: The Catalyst

docs.text: The Cloisters of Terror Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.6 Released: 4 June 2015 Listened: 4/8/22 Unlike the last story, this time they really do land in 1977, at a women’s college that’s part of Oxford. Like the last story, K-9 doesn’t feature at all. The Dean of the college is Dame Emily Shaw, mother of Liz, and still the most well-connected and influential woman in England, aside from the Queen. I can’t see any reason for her to return, aside from the fact that she’s awesome, and Rowena Cooper is awesome, so that’s enough. It does save time to have an authority figure who trusts the Doctor completely, once he establishes his credentials. Because the college is haunted by three nuns, girls are disappearing, and all the living nuns seem to be determined to hinder the investigation. Naturally, the explanation turns out to be less supernatural than it appears, as it almost always does, but it takes a good while to unravel. Leela gets to engage in a good bit of action, and has a solid respect for Dame Emily, who admittedly earns it. I think this one would have done quite nicely on television.
docs.title: The Cloisters of Terror

docs.text: The Crooked Man Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.3 Released: 14 March 2014 Listened: 3/6/22 This is a bit of a surreal one, but then, it involves the Land of Fiction. But not in the way you’d expect – there’s no famous characters here, just characters from unpublished novels, TV spin-offs, and tabloid representations of actual people. It’s unusual, but not twisty in the way that John Dorney stories normally are. There is, however, room for some really cracking dialog. The Crooked Man himself, the monster of the piece, is a pretty amazing visual (good thing the cover helps with that), and definitely scary. There’s a certain amount of parenting horror in this one as well, so be warned. And yet a lot of the dialog is quite funny, with a few very gentle jabs at the idea that Doctor Who is of course fictional as well.
docs.title: The Crooked Man

docs.text: The Crowmarsh Experiment Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.2 Released: 18 January 2018 Listened: 4/10/22 This story, though, is all about Leela. It’s one of those where a main character wakes up in a different life, and everyone keeps telling them the old life is a dream. Which is pretty standard stuff, but Louise Jameson plays it brilliantly as always, to the point where you can hear her starting to unravel and doubt herself. A big part of that is because Damian Lynch is back as Marshall, but a human version, not a Rocket Man this time. This is much more effective listening to those stories close together, rather than years apart as I originally heard them, having totally forgotten who Marshall was. Dan Starkey also has a small role as Linus Strang, a milder human version of his Sontaran Strang from “The King of Sontar,” and he’s subtle enough that I missed it completely. I was expecting a slightly ambiguous ending or a twist or double-bluff, none of which happen, but the emotional impact is probably stronger because of it.
docs.title: The Crowmarsh Experiment

docs.text: The Dalek Protocol Fourth Doctor Adventures special Released: 13 April 2021 Listened: 4/17/22 This one, unfortunately, is one of those times when the timeline of this project doesn’t serve well. If you listen to this before the next era’s boxed set, you’ll run into a major spoiler. It also connects to the Dalek Universe stories in the Tenth Doctor era, but it can be safely viewed as a prequel to those. You can tell it’s a Nick Briggs story, because it starts out on Exxilon, and Briggs loves “Planet of the Daleks” to pieces. You can also tell because Briggs is playing Captain Bernard with his “northern” accent, which could also double for “congested” if need be. This story is the first meeting of Space Security Service agents Mark Seven and Anya Kingdom, who will make up a lot of Dalek Universe, so they get plenty of screen time here. However, Mark spends a lot of time “not himself,” and Anya spends a lot of time trying to avoid the Doctor, for…reasons. She’s not entirely successful, but that seems to be OK. Leela doesn’t have the biggest role here, but she’s clearly come a long way. She remembers Exxilons, Daleks don’t phase her, her reading skills are improved, and she’s starting to learn when the Doctor is blowing smoke. The Doctor himself seems a little too flippant again, especially when Daleks are involved, but I think that’s the influence of Tom Baker on the scripts. Bottom line: If you like the Dalek Universe characters, you’ll like this.
docs.title: The Dalek Protocol

docs.text: The Darkness of Glass Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.2 Released: 12 February 2015 Listened: 4/3/22 This is one of those stories that grabs onto a particular historical phenomenon and explores it from multiple angles. In this case, that’s the “magic lantern” practice of slide projection from the 16th to the 19th centuries, when it fell into disuse after movies became popular. In this case, a bunch of enthusiasts are gathered in a spooky castle to remember the work of a (fictional) famous lanternist, who was said to be so skilled that he captured a demon in his images. Which means, of course, the Doctor and Leela will have to deal with that demon. K-9 stays behind, which happened from time to time on TV, but it does seem a bit odd, given that K-9 has recently joined the crew. That gives Leela more space to shine, and although stone castles aren’t her forte, shadowy creatures that need hunting is right up her street. There are a number of secondary characters, well-drawn, if briefly, which makes it hard to determine the villain. The monster itself doesn’t get a lot of explanation. It’s mostly a mcguffin while everybody else figures out the mystery. Not the strongest story from this set, but it’s a quality outing.
docs.title: The Darkness of Glass

docs.text: The Day of the Comet Fourth Doctor Adventures #10.2 Released: 20 January 2021 Listened: 3/19/22 This one moves out into space, to a doomed planet that’s about to get smacked by a comet. Most of the population left months ago, and the remainder…well, it isn’t going well. Unfortunately, the Web of Time has spoken on what happens to these people, because the consequences would be terrible otherwise. Writer Jonny Morris wanted to trap the Doctor in a no-win situation, and it shows. The story has a lot of room to breathe, enough that it’s essentially got a separate plot for each half: one in which they figure out the problem and struggle to help the survivors, and one where some other folks come along to try to exploit the planet. The first part has the moral dilemma, and the second has all the running around in corridors. There are some plot twists that allow for some convenient deaths, relieving the Doctor of that particular dilemma, and sometimes the seams show. Special mention must be made of Janet Henfrey, an actress who’s appeared in both the classic and new TV series, and has had several Big Finish roles, as an astronomer who gets increasingly fed up that everyone calls her “old woman” instead of using her name. In the end, though, it might last just a bit too long.
docs.title: Day of the Comet

docs.text: The Demon Rises Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.4 Released: 18 January 2018 Listened: 4/12/22 The tone of this story is about the same as the last one, but the focus becomes different. The Doctor is still trying to figure out what’s going on and who’s hunting the Mind Runners, but the emphasis shifts to locating the Nightmind and what’s going on with the evacuation rocket. If you guessed “something sketchy,” you’d be right. I’ve seen the “sneak on board the mysterious evacuation rocket” more than a few times in Doctor Who , but this particular variant is probably the most unusual, and comes with the most body horror as well. Dorney’s reach may have exceeded his grasp a little bit here. He tries for an even higher concept than the ones he created in the last story, and in my opinion pushes the boundaries of plausibility a bit. The well-drawn characters are still around, but they’re less individualized this time, and more playing their expected roles in a Doctor Who story. There’s lots of running around, the Doctor talking the bad guy into a corner, and K-9 blasting things. The build-up is a little more dramatic than the actual climax. I’ll remember this one more for all the wild ideas zipping around than for the actual plot.
docs.title: The Demon Rises

docs.text: The Devil's Armada Philip Hinchcliffe Presents #1.2 Released: 5 September 2014 Listened: 4/1/22 This one is a four-parter, but it still feels nicely paced, like the previous story. It’s almost a historical, taking place in 1588, at the time of the failed Spanish Armada. There’s also plenty of witch-hunting and Catholic-hunting going on in the countryside. Against that historical backdrop, there’s an alien invasion to deal with, of demonic-looking creatures who are crossing a dimensional barrier, which plays right into the witch-hunters’ hands. All the Catholics who appear are quite sympathetic characters on the wrong end of unfair persecution. The action bounces from a village to a castle to London and then to the English fleet and back, so this story likely would have been unfilmable as a TV episode. The monsters are fairly stock, and not particularly clever, which leaves room for the humans to be the real monsters. Watch out for Beth Chalmers as one of Queen Elizabeth’s handmaidens, but the Queen herself doesn’t appear, nor do Raleigh, Drake, or Walsingham, which is probably good, given the number of versions of the Doctor running around in this time period. Although there are some tonal similarities between this story and the last, the historical elements make for a nice differentiator.
docs.title: The Devil's Armada

docs.text: The Evil One Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.4 Released: 11 April 2014 Listened: 3/6/22 It’s time for another story with the Master, because he’s going to be recurring for the Fourth Doctor, especially since Geoffrey Beevers is willing and available. However, this Nick Briggs story is kind of slight. It starts well, as an investigation into the murder of the passengers and crew of a luxury star-liner, but that part fizzles out fairly quickly, as the focus is on the Master brainwashing Leela into becoming an assassin tasked with killing the Doctor. Michael Keating (Vila from Blake’s Seven ) has a nice role as an investigator, but he’s written out rather abruptly. The coda with Leela reflecting on what her father meant to her is great, but the whole story is unfortunately less than the sum of its parts.
docs.title: The Evil One

docs.title: The Evil One

docs.text: The Exxilons Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.1 Released: 15 January 2015 Listened: 4/3/22 Now we’re back to the Fourth Doctor Adventures, but with added John Leeson! K-9’s presence does make a distinct change to the dynamic. Specifically, they’re toting around a third-party with a ranged weapon, and a distinct willingness to use it. Even though he only shoots sentient beings with a stun ray in this story, he quite frequently threatens with it, and does quite a bit of plot-relevant property damage. I can’t help thinking that the Doctor couldn’t have solved problems this way just a couple of stories ago. It’s also to Leela’s detriment, as she doesn’t get to show off her growing knowledge when there’s a talking computer with all the answers hanging around. As for this story, it’s related to “Death to the Daleks,” as you might be able to tell from the title, but it’s not a sequel. In fact, it takes place long before that story, and gives some insight into just what the Exxilons were doing when they were a functioning civilization (hint: it wasn’t great). Of particular note is Jacqueline King (Sylvia Noble in the modern series) playing another role where you’d never recognize her, particularly this time, because she’s using an American accent just for fun. Tim Treloar also features, doing a rather guttural native. The pacing is a bit better than previous one-hour stories, although the ending is a little abrupt.
docs.title: The Exxilons

docs.title: The Face of Evil

docs.text: The Fate of Krelos Fourth Doctor Adventures #4.7 Released: 8 July 2015 Listened: 4/8/22 This story and the next are connected, but not so tightly that they can be considered one story. In fact, in this first part, not a lot seems to be happening at first. Basically, the Doctor wants to go fishing, and convinces Leela to come along. The planet where he chooses to go, Krelos, is at a point in its development where most of society’s tasks are automated, although there are still some citizens who object to that. It’s a very small plot, with the Doctor and Leela basically trying to rescue one person. There’s also an extended sequence where K-9 reactivates an older control room, in which a piece of Jamie’s kilt is snagged on the console, leading to the Doctor telling Leela about Jamie. (I’m guessing neither of them remember the events of “Dumb Waiter.”) After a timeslip, Leela and the Doctor have an argument about interference. It’s one of those in which the Doctor pulls out the “I can’t interfere” card for reasons known only to Time Lords, and the companion simply doesn’t buy it, except even more so, because it’s Leela. Parts of it are interesting, and parts seem kind of drawn out and repetitive (the number of times they climb up or down the mountain). Kudos to Nick Briggs for wanting to do a story without mortal peril (to the TARDIS team, anyway), but I’m not sure it really works, except as an extended lead-in.
docs.title: The Fate of Krelos

docs.text: The Foe from the Future Lost Stories Special Released: 9 January 2012 Listened: 2/21/22 This story comes from a boxed set of Lost Stories released during Series 3, but not officially part of that series. Why, I have no idea. This story was originally intended as the finale to Season 14, but writer Robert Banks Stewart was unable to finish it, so Robert Holmes wrote “The Talons of Weng-Chiang” instead, and it’s hard to argue that wasn’t the better choice. Anyway, that means this is a six-parter, making a sharp contrast to the Short Trips we’ve been doing for the last little while. There are a number of elements that are present in “Talons,” such as a man from the future coming back to the present and being badly damaged in the process, an interesting and sadistic henchman, and the involvement of the police. However, unlike “Talons,” this story jumps to the future, where we see exactly what the people of that time are afraid of, and spend a lot of time running around there. It’s still early days for Leela, but she’s starting to get the hang of things, and is generally pretty fearless in the face of danger. She’s still fairly vicious, though, threatening the villains when the Doctor isn’t around, and wanting to hunt down giant insects for fun. The villain, Lord Jalnik, is quite memorable, especially because he doesn’t have despotic ambitions for a change. Special mention should go to Charlotte-from-the-village (as she’s often called), who was apparently invented by John Dorney for the adaptation, but it’s hard to imagine the story without her. I’d never want to replace “Talons,” especially not Jago & Litefoot, but this probably wouldn’t have been a bad story either.
docs.title: The Foe From the Future

docs.text: Lost Stories Special Released: 9 January 2012 Listened: 2/21/22 This story comes from a boxed set of Lost Stories released during Series 3, but not officially part of that series. Why, I have no idea. This story was originally intended as the finale to Season 14, but writer Robert Banks Stewart was unable to finish it, so Robert Holmes wrote “The Talons of Weng-Chiang” instead, and it’s hard to argue that wasn’t the better choice. Anyway, that means this is a six-parter, making a sharp contrast to the Short Trips we’ve been doing for the last little while. There are a number of elements that are present in “Talons,” such as a man from the future coming back to the present and being badly damaged in the process, an interesting and sadistic henchman, and the involvement of the police. However, unlike “Talons,” this story jumps to the future, where we see exactly what the people of that time are afraid of, and spend a lot of time running around there. It’s still early days for Leela, but she’s starting to get the hang of things, and is generally pretty fearless in the face of danger. She’s still fairly vicious, though, threatening the villains when the Doctor isn’t around, and wanting to hunt down giant insects for fun. The villain, Lord Jalnik, is quite memorable, especially because he doesn’t have despotic ambitions for a change. Special mention should go to Charlotte-from-the-village (as she’s often called), who was apparently invented by John Dorney for the adaptation, but it’s hard to imagine the story without her. I’d never want to replace “Talons,” especially not Jago & Litefoot, but this probably wouldn’t have been a bad story either.
docs.title: The Foe from the Future

docs.text: The Friendly Invasion Fourth Doctor Adventures #12.4 Released: 21 June 2023 Listened: 7/21/23 This one is a reasonably nice historical. It’s Westbourne, England, 1943, the middle of WWII. There are a bunch of American troops stationed in the town: Dainty company, who will soon leave for deployment and play a critical role in the invasion of Normandy. Their presence is causing some friction with the locals, but that’s not really the problem. There’s another temporal anomaly here, and it’s pulled the TARDIS off-course. Turns out there’s some time-tourists here from the 51st century, inhabiting other people’s bodies. And since 51st-century time travel tech is rubbish (ask Magnus Greel), things are going sideways. It ends up with a big scene of zombie villagers with flaming hands attacking an old pub defended by Leela and a bunch of Americans. It’s certainly fun to watch her order around the “Dainty men,” as she calls them. Margaret, meanwhile, faces the fact that she’s alive in this time, if a teenage girl. She’s not very good at keeping her future knowledge hidden, but it mostly turns out all right. So it’s a nice mix of adventure, character-building, and drama, along with some rather decent American accents for a change.
docs.title: The Friendly Invasion

docs.text: The Genesis Chamber Philip Hinchcliffe Presents #2 Released: 6 September 2016 Listened: 3/26/22 This next run of stories is from the “Philip Hinchcliffe Presents” range. We’re lucky enough that Hinchcliffe is still with us, and for this range, he came up with the story concepts and provides feedback on the scripts. So they’ve got that thread of darkness to them, with some Bob Holmes dark humor, and they’re long, a mix of four- and six-parters. This one has some interesting concepts, but I’m not sure it really gels properly. There’s a colony planet with a bunch of pampered city dwellers beholden to a central computer, and an outside group of back-to-the-land luddites. Which is a decent start, but it gets interesting when you throw in some invaders, and an alien “helper” who’s a bit too good to be true. There’s a Romeo & Juliet story, which works reasonably enough because the actors sell it well. Unfortunately, the Doctor and Leela aren’t really controlling events all that much, and mostly just seem to be along for the ride. The bad guys are done in by infighting and a deus ex machina, which is kind of unsatisfying.
docs.title: The Genesis Chamber

docs.title: The Genesis Chamber

docs.text: The Ghost of Margaret Fourth Doctor Adventures #12.6 Released: 21 June 2023 Listened: 7/23/23 Margaret has had enough. After the last story, where she came pretty close to doom, she wants to get off the ride, although she’s sad and her life is still empty. Unfortunately, in putting her back, the TARDIS jumped a time track, which isn’t clear until after they’ve already left (the Doctor not being one for goodbyes), leaving Margaret stranded in a “nowhere place,” with manifestations of her depression out to get her. Oddly, Captain Ray Hunter turns up, one of the soldiers from “The Friendly Invasion.” He’s 30 years older, as we’re in Margaret’s present. Apparently Margaret sent for him, but she doesn’t remember doing that. So we’ve got timey-wimey, and spooky dreamscapes, and time slippage. It’s a fairly tight story, as it’s mostly concerned with Margaret’s personal anxieties. In the end, she manages to decide what she wants, which is a nice closing to her story. There are enough stories here that it doesn’t feel like Margaret outstayed her welcome, but few enough to justify her not coming up again later.
docs.title: The Ghost of Margaret

docs.text: The Ghost Trap Short Trips #5.4 Released: 6 April 2015 Listened: 2/20/22 This Short Trip is probably longer than it actually needs to be, but it lets us spend time in Leela’s head while she’s still relatively new. They land on an entirely organic spaceship, but unfortunately the crew is dead, as are a bunch of humans who don’t belong there. While trying to figure out what’s going on, they encounter some ghosts, which gives Leela some more mental trouble trying to figure out exactly what’s going on. Like a lot of short trips, there’s not so much an enemy to fight as a problem to resolve. Louise Jameson puts a lot of effort into this one, ramping up the tension.
docs.title: The Ghost Trap

docs.title: The Ghost Trap

docs.text: The Ghosts of Gralstead Philip Hinchcliffe Presents #1.1 Released: 5 September 2014 Listened: 3/31/22 This story, the first of the Phillip Hinchcliffe collection, leans in hard on the tropes that era is famous for. It’s a ghost story with a scientific explanation, set in Victorian England, with strong secondary characters. Leela even mentions wanting to see Jago and Litefoot again, but they’re 40 years too early. Plot-wise, it bounces around somewhat, from ghost story to Africa to gods in epic combat, and yet it’s paced quite well, so it doesn’t feel over-long. The origin of the bad guys is never fully explained, nor their motivations, but that’s also appropriate to the era. Leela does pretty well in Africa, better than she did in the Amazon in the last story. She also gets to do a more-than-usual amount of fighting, and isn’t at all hesitant to kill if she thinks it’s warranted. A large component of the story is a macguffin that can heal or even resurrect the dead, which allows for more dramatic cliffhangers in which our main characters actually do die, but cheapens it by making resurrection easy. You’d think there’d be some psychological repercussions to that, but apparently not. Also of note are the bit characters: an unscrupulous poor-house matron, and a pair of body-snatchers that fit the Robert Holmes mode quite nicely. A decent story, especially for a six-parter.
docs.title: The Ghosts of Gralstead

docs.text: The God of Phantoms Philip Hinchcliffe Presents #4 Released: 19 August 2021 Listened: 3/28/22 This one is huge, long even for a six-parter, and there’s a lot going on. There’s a planet with a bunch of Earth colonists, but instead of living as one civilization, there are multiple factions, some back-to-nature types, some more traditional, and some aggressive. One thing they all have in common is that they’ve regressed technologically, and while they’re aware of their ancestors’ tools, they can’t use them. So the battles are nasty, but not horrific. There’s also some rudiments of religion, with the villagers seeming to hold to a mild form of Christianity, and the commune-dwellers worshiping forest spirits and ghosts. And there’s a bunch of ghosts in this story, which are mostly treated as rather matter-of-fact. The Doctor is dismissive of ghosts as always, but he seems more on edge than usual in this story, and there’s a reason for that. Leela fits into the society better than she has in quite a few stories, although formal dancing eludes her. You’d think that would be enough to go on with, but as the story goes on, it gets more and more complex, getting involved in the Doctor’s personal history, and extending all the way to a war of the gods. Even though the story is lengthy, seeming to have several different climaxes along with a lengthy coda, some parts of the backstory are still fuzzy, but Philip Hinchcliffe seems to like it that way. The secondary characters here are well-drawn, with differing agendas and motivations. Many of them have nuanced relationships to the Doctor and Leela, instead of the stubborn caricatures you often find in these stories. It’s a quality entry, although boy is it long.
docs.title: The God of Phantoms

docs.text: The Helm of Awe Philip Hinchcliffe Presents #3 Released: 11 April 2017 Listened: 3/26/22 This story is a four-parter, and yet it packs a lot of ideas into its running time. It’s set way up north in the Shetland Islands, on an island so small and insular that official records say that it’s uninhabited, and the locals like it that way. It has an unusually warm climate for its latitude, and rather spectacular aurora (the titular “Helm of Awe,” which really doesn’t play into the plot at all). In addition to the people’s distrust of strangers, there’s the local laird, who’s heavily into archaeology, his daughter, who’s caught between the urge to see the world and her deep roots on the island, and a family curse that’s more than it seems. Because this is a Philip Hinchcliffe story, we need a local ancient ritual, this one an annual Viking celebration of the turning of the year. Which heightens the emotions nicely, but also gives Leela a chance to participate in a longboat race, which she likes very much. There’s a timey-wimey jaunt back to WWII, to determine the roots of the mystery. As before, the actual sci-fi element is a bit of a disappointment, and the story just sort of ends instead of wrapping up, but that seems to be par for these stories.
docs.title: The Helm of Awe

docs.text: The King of Sontar Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.1 Released: 15 January 2014 Listened: 3/4/22 This next season with Leela looks like it’s trying to take some more chances with the Doctor and Leela’s relationship, as their philosophies on the necessity of killing come into conflict. They’re dropped into a conflict between a rogue Sontaran superman and, well, every other Sontaran. Super-Sontaran was a genetic anomaly, and in the way of such entities, he’s judged himself superior to the rest of his race, and therefore needs to wipe them out and take over. Rather than just getting some popcorn, the Doctor thinks that would be bad for the timelines, and sets about stopping him. Leela gets separated early on, and ends up leading a slave rebellion, because that’s what happens when you leave a Companion alone with some slaves for more than 10 minutes. Leela does quite well on her own, because battle is something she knows, possibly even more so than on TV. Unfortunately, she’s also becoming quite skilled with a variety of weapons that were far outside her experience before, and that’s what’s got the Doctor worried. John Banks and Dan Starkey provide the Sontaran voices, because of course they do. Starkey is still recognizable, but he puts enough of a spin on Strang that there’s no danger of mistaking him for Strax. And John Dorney accomplishes the goal of making the Sontarans believable and scary, which isn’t always easy in the modern era.
docs.title: The King of Sontar

docs.text: The Mind Runners Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.3 Released: 18 January 2018 Listened: 4/11/22 The next two stories are really a single four-parter, no matter how they’re numbered, although the tone of each is different. This is a John Dorney story, and it’s stuffed with high concepts. There’s the Mind Runners, who use headsets to tap into the consciousness of strangers and look out through their eyes. All they do is watch, though, so it’s less intrusive than other such tropes. There’s the “Digitals,” people who’ve uploaded their consciousness into robots, and would like everybody else to do the same. There’s a mysterious assassin of unusual abilities. There’s a malevolent force that’s apparently killing mind runners. There’s a rocket that’s supposed to evacuate the population of the planet, but oddly this is only a minor point in the first story, barely mentioned. All of it against a Blade Runner style sci-fi-noir backdrop. K-9 is present in this one, which is good, because he’s quite useful. Leela also transfers her hunting skills quite easily to the urban jungle, in ways that are surprising, but explained plausibly, because Dorney is just that good. The secondary characters are well drawn and sympathetic. The longer format really benefits the story here, because we still have very little clue what’s happening at the end of the first part, even though rather a lot has happened.
docs.title: The Mind Runners

docs.text: The Oseidon Adventure Fourth Doctor Adventures #1.6 Released: June 2012 Listened: 2/28/22 This is the second part of the finale of the first season of Fourth Doctor Adventures, and honestly, it’s a bit odd. It continues from the previous story, but it’s almost completely different. The previous story seemed rather of its time period (the classic series) with the small-town mystery. This one is full-blown alien invasion, and much of it is borderline farcical. All the nonsense from the last episode was so that the Master could bring the Kraals to Earth. Having failed in “The Android Invasion,” they want another go. Which forced the Doctor to call in UNIT, just not any characters we actually recognize, but rather the second string. And Kraals mean androids, specifically android duplicates who are so convincing that they can fool almost anyone, including themselves. Alan Barnes plays this for laughs, as he so often does, but it does become a little silly with duplicates on top of duplicates, most of them created almost instantly. Nobody seems to take the Kraals particularly seriously, so they end up more or less stand-ins for the Sontarans, and it’s not helped that they’re clearly voiced by veteran Sontaran actors Dan Starkey and John Banks. Add in some absurd dialog about Z-radiation, and O-radiation, and Z-O-radiation, and it’s hard to take any of it seriously. The entire cast seems to be having a ball, but it’s kind of a weak finish for a new series. Fortunately, there was never any doubt whether Big Finish would continue it.
docs.title: The Oseidon Adventure

docs.text: The Primeval Design Fourth Doctor Adventures #10.4 Released: 10 February 2021 Listened: 3/21/22 Leela and the Doctor have seen a handful of dinosaurs recently, so the Doctor takes her to meet Mary Anning, an English pioneer in the field of paleontology. Unfortunately, as a woman in the early 19th century, her work has gone unrecognized for over 100 years after her death. The Doctor is in full bluster mode, plowing into Mary’s life and getting himself involved in an investigation into an unusual death. Leela, of course, is a source of inspiration to Mary, as she fails to abide by any suggestions that she should “know her place.” Unfortunately, the story has an absurd amount of shouting and shrieking, which is kind of tough to listen to. I have to ascribe that to director Nick Briggs, rather than writer Helen Goldwyn or any of the actors. Still, these are the loudest exhausted, drowning people I’ve ever heard, especially since one of them has literally just given birth. Obviously, in this kind of a story, you can expect dinosaurs for monsters, but the theory posited is that alien creatures designed to be the “ultimate killing machines” are…dinosaur skeletons. Which is kinda strange no matter how you slice it. But the Mary Anning parts are pretty cool.
docs.title: The Primeval Design

docs.text: Fourth Doctor Adventures #10.4 Released: 10 February 2021 Listened: 3/21/22 Leela and the Doctor have seen a handful of dinosaurs recently, so the Doctor takes her to meet Mary Anning, an English pioneer in the field of paleontology. Unfortunately, as a woman in the early 19th century, her work has gone unrecognized for over 100 years after her death. The Doctor is in full bluster mode, plowing into Mary’s life and getting himself involved in an investigation into an unusual death. Leela, of course, is a source of inspiration to Mary, as she fails to abide by any suggestions that she should “know her place.” Unfortunately, the story has an absurd amount of shouting and shrieking, which is kind of tough to listen to. I have to ascribe that to director Nick Briggs, rather than writer Helen Goldwyn or any of the actors. Still, these are the loudest exhausted, drowning people I’ve ever heard, especially since one of them has literally just given birth. Obviously, in this kind of a story, you can expect dinosaurs for monsters, but the theory posited is that alien creatures designed to be the “ultimate killing machines” are…dinosaur skeletons. Which is kinda strange no matter how you slice it. But the Mary Anning parts are pretty cool.
docs.title: The Primeval Design

docs.text: The Renaissance Man Fourth Doctor Adventures #1.2 Released: February 2012 Listened: 2/24/22 One of the themes of the Fourth Doctor Adventures was that the Doctor was attempting to educate Leela about her heritage, so in this story, they visit a museum covering anything and everything related to Earth. However, somewhere along the line, the museum got the idea to drain specialists of their knowledge, leaving them empty shells. The casting is very referential: the baddie and his henchman are played by Ian McNeice, not playing Churchill for once, but still unmistakeable, and Gareth Armstrong, who starred in “The Masque of Mandragora” a very long time ago. Also of note is Daisy Ashford, daughter of Caroline John and Geoffrey Beevers, in a minor role. Leela is certainly exposed to many different aspects of Earth history, but it’s all somewhat random, and leads to her pronouncing “Renaissance” as “runny-science,” which will never not be funny. But it’s clear that she’s starting to get the hang of the Doctor, particularly determining when he’s trying to snow her with technobabble. The acting and dialog make this one more memorable than the plot.
docs.title: The Renaissance Man

docs.text: The Revisionists Short Trips #9.1 Released: 31 January 2019 Listened: 2/20/22 The first part of this subsection is mostly a lot of short trips, but that’s OK, because Louise Jameson often reads them. Her Tom Baker voice isn’t an impersonation, but usually gets the effect right. In this story, Leela is clearly very new in her travels, still getting used to a lot of things. The Doctor takes her to Geneva, where they meet the Brigadier, who’s in the process of retiring from UNIT. Of course, something weird is going on, in this case, people encountering the ghosts of their ancestors, after which they forget ever having known them. Solving the problem isn’t particularly dramatic, but that’s not the point. The idea is to get Leela and the Brig talking, and each coming to terms with the heritage that caused them to become warriors. The Brig and Leela are definitely kindred spirits here, and it’s great to have a story that puts them together.
docs.title: The Revisionists

docs.text: The Shadow of London Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.5 Released: 16 May 2018 Listened: 4/14/22 This one is OK, pretty much. It’s another one of those stories in which the TARDIS lands in what seems to be London, in this case in 1940, but something is off. There aren’t enough people, it’s unusually quiet and cold, and the few people they meet are acting oddly. Experienced listeners might suspect Kraals, which isn’t the case, but that just points up how often the show does this plot. K-9 isn’t in this one either, probably because his scanners would reveal what’s up far too early. This story continues the pattern from this set of spending all of Part 1 trying to figure out what’s going on, rather than resolve it. Of course, there’s a monster, because there has to be, but it doesn’t leave much of an impression. Leela is getting a little better at operating in urban areas, but the Doctor seems oddly annoying this time. He often doesn’t explain his odd phrases to Leela, but this time he seems on the verge of mocking her with them. And he’s much less concerned about people getting killed than he has been in other stories. It’s a fine story, but no more than that.
docs.title: The Shadow of London

docs.text: The Smallest Battle Subscriber Short Trips #2018-3 Released: 11 September 2018 Listened: 2/22/22 This one is pretty long for a Short Trip, and as such, tells a complete story. It’s not a terribly involved story: The Doctor and Leela land on a war-torn planet, help a young person, and maybe inspire the people to think differently about their enemy. The Doctor is pretty good at that sort of thing. It’s read by Stephen Critchlow, which is the first narration other than Louise Jameson we’ve had in a while. As usual, he does an excellent job, but his Fourth Doctor is the closest to Tom Baker of any of the various narrators.
docs.title: The Smallest Battle

docs.text: The Sons of Kaldor Fourth Doctor Adventures #7.1 Released: 18 January 2018 Listened: 4/10/22 A new season starts here, with some twists on the formula. This story is a reference to “Robots of Death” without being a direct sequel, because it takes place a considerable time later, when the political situation has changed and robots are no longer trusted. K-9 doesn’t appear, perhaps because he could have shortcut parts of the story. The Doctor has always been particularly sympathetic toward Kaldor robots, and that’s still true here. Andrew Smith is pretty good at stories where the antagonist isn’t what you think they are, and that’s in here too. Leela doesn’t get quite as much to do, but it’s clear that she’s growing in experience, handling robots and spaceships with ease.
docs.title: The Sons of Kaldor

docs.text: The Talents of Greel The Diary of River Song #6.4 Released: 27 August 2019 Listened: 2/22/22 This is another one from the River Song set where she jumped in right before, or during, some classic stories, in this case, the imminent “Talons of Weng-Chiang.” In this case, she pops up beforehand, and the Doctor doesn’t even figure, which is fine, because the Doctor has Jago and Litefoot to help in “Talons,” and River would just get in the way. That doesn’t mean she can’t tweak some things before the story starts, though. Specifically, she gets to meet up with Jago and perform at the Palace Theater, which allows her to push Greel’s plans back a bit. And along the way, explain some things about “Talons” that hadn’t been before, such as: Why is Greel’s lab beneath a theater? How did Greel get so messed up in the first place? What were Greel and Chang doing before coming to London? What happened to Chang’s monkey? Oh, did you not know that Chang had a monkey, who was more popular than Mr. Sin? That’s because he was invented for this story. Angus Wright does an awfully good job capturing the voice of Greel, returning to the role from “The Butcher of Brisbane,” and Nicholas Goh helps fix the racist casting from “Talons,” so that’s a good thing. Come for the references, but stick around for the River/Jago banter.
docs.title: The Talents of Greel

docs.text: The Time Vampire Fourth Doctor Adventures special Released: 31 May 2010 Listened: 4/17/22 This story continues the trilogy from “The Catalyst” and “Empathy Games,” supposedly putting a final end to Leela’s story…which is now completely unnecessary, because of all the other appearances she’s made. Frankly, this is a very strange one, full of time loops and paradoxes and reincarnation and other strangeness. The secondary actor in this is John Leeson, playing K-9 as well as other characters. It covers Leela’s rescue from the Z’nai torture machine where she’s been for…a long time? However, that kicks off a loop of paradox that’s…well, it’s really hard to follow, especially with just one listen. Honestly, I found it hard to focus on. I can see what Nigel Fairs is going for, as he’s done similar work on other Companion Chronicles, but this one just didn’t work for me. And unfortunately, that’s the end of Leela’s part of this project. However, both she and Louise Jameson will be back, in plenty of other stories.
docs.title: The Time Vampire

docs.text: The Tivolian Who Knew Too Much Classic Doctors New Monsters #3.2 Released: 28 July 2022 Listened: 8/4/22 Like the previous CDNM3 story, the “monster” in this one is more of a friendly alien we’ve seen before, in this case the Tivolians from “The God Complex” and “Before the Flood.” They’re the folks who like to be conquered, to a degree that’s nearly disturbing. The title is a reference to “The Man Who Knew Too Much,” but it doesn’t have much in common with the Jimmy Stewart film except for a tourist who becomes unwittingly involved in a greater plot. Our poor Tivolian protagonist is trying to have a restful holiday in Rome, 1977 (Tivolians apparently look human enough to pass, in Rome), when he gets caught up in a web of organized crime and blackmail where almost nobody is what they say they are. Writer Rob Valentine apparently couldn’t resist the idea of Tivolians in actual Tivoli, hence the Italian setting. The translation circuits also get a workout, with lots of Italian phrases dropped in, as well as every figure of speech involving “Rome” that you can imagine. Unfortunately, Big Finish was unlikely to get David Walliams or Paul Kaye to reprise their Tivolian roles, but the ones we got work just fine. There are a few moments in this where Tom Baker and Louise Jameson sound closer than usual to their actual ages, but it isn’t too much of a distraction. On the whole, it’s a lighter story, and everyone involved seems to be having a good time.
docs.title: The Tivolian Who Knew Too Much

docs.text: The Tribulations of Thadeus Nook Fourth Doctor Adventures #10.3 Released: 10 February 2021 Listened: 3/2/22 We’re jumping a ways ahead from a production standpoint, but it’s made clear in this story that Leela is still learning to read, so it belongs here. In later seasons, the Fourth Doctor Adventures converted back to full-length stories, so this one stands out at two hours. The Doctor and Leela run across the titular Thadeus and his girlfriend, who have stumbled into possession of a rather sketchy time machine, one that causes temporal damage when used. Thadeus doesn’t know that, though, and he’s running tours to critical flashpoints in history, like D-Day and the Kennedy assassination. Leela ends up with him, with the Doctor trying to catch up. Leela expresses a lot of confidence in the Doctor’s abilities, which is partially unwarranted. There’s something bigger going on, though, involving acolytes of a dead warlord who want to change history. It’s a very mobile story, with scenes in lots of different places and times, which wouldn’t really work on TV, so Andrew Smith is really taking advantage of the medium here. The secondary characters are well developed here, with Brendan Murphy playing the con man with a good heart, and Laura Riseborough as his long-suffering girlfriend who sees him as more than what he is. The baddies don’t make as much of an impression, but that’s OK, because it’s the character growth that’s important. Running across other time travelers is always good fun, and this story plays with the conventions nicely.
docs.title: The Tribulations of Thadeus Nook

docs.text: The Valley of Death Lost Stories Special Released: 9 January 2012 Listened: 3/29/22 This particular entry is a Lost Story, rather than a Philip Hinchcliffe Presents, so it lacks the same sense of gothic horror, but it’s still a four-parter. It involves an explorer who went missing in the Amazon in 1873, and a follow-up expedition in 1977 that the Doctor and Leela join under UNIT credentials. Leela should be in her element here, and she certainly thinks she is, but she fails to track one tribe, and then fails to notice another before they capture her. She’s clearly having an off day. In fact, the whole story is slightly off, just a bit too whimsical and humorous. Even though it came from an idea from Philip Hinchcliffe, it’s a Jonathan Morris story, with the attendant off-kilter tone. In that sense, it feels like it belongs in the Graham Williams era of the show. Halfway through, the setting abruptly changes to London, and UNIT gets involved, but only ineffectually without the Brigadier. It does have slightly higher stakes and a more dramatic ending than the previous few stories, but mostly it feels a bit strange. Of particular note is Jane Slavin, playing an American journalist with a pretty decent New York accent. We’ll see more from her in a little while.
docs.title: The Valley of Death

docs.text: The Wizard of Time Fourth Doctor Adventures #12.3 Released: 21 June 2023 Listened: 7/20/23 The second half of series 12 goes by the name “Angels and Demons,” which is kind of unfortunate, because it’s awfully close to a spoiler. This half has three two-part stories and one four-parter, which gives a feeling of a lot of content, so that’s nice. This story is by Roy Gill, and has a distinct fairy-tale feeling to it. In fact, it’s one of those where the TARDIS crew don’t really feature that much, as the emphasis is on the narrator, Jacob Harmer. The story starts with an older Jacob at the end of his life, telling a caretaker stories in flashback of when he’d met the Doctor, Leela, and Margaret. Jacob eventually went on to become a famous writer, using the TARDIS crew as inspiration for his “Dirk Forever” stories. Jacob stumbles into a pesky temporal anomaly behind his house, and eventually stumbles back out of it again. As a result, he meets the Doctor and friends at several different points along his lifespan, but doesn’t stay with them long. One of the latest meetings features a distinctly older Doctor, and I don’t really like it when the Doctor solves a problem by simply waiting around for decades, but there’s enough timey-wimey going on in this story that maybe that’s not really what happened. It’s definitely a departure in storytelling terms, which may be enough for variety.
docs.title: The Wizard of Time

docs.text: The World Traders Fourth Doctor Adventures #10.1 Released: 20 January 2021 Listened: 3/17/22 The next block is a bunch of full-length stories, making a contrast to the previous series. This one takes place in London, in the early 21st century, probably around 2021, given the release date. There’s a corporation with an extraordinary amount of wealth in a short time, which is slightly suspicious, but they’re also very secretive and have tech that’s too advanced for the time. That results in a bunch of interesting alien races, some time travel, and some very creative real estate investment strategies, some of which border on the silly. There’s a bonus companion in journalist Emma Fremantle, mostly so that the Doctor has someone to bounce off of while separated from Leela. Unfortunately, she’s not a patch on Sarah Jane, but she also spends a good chunk of the story brainwashed. Leela gets to be in her element, hunting an alien in the late Cretaceous. She’s also quite a bit more primal, even violent, in this story. She’s not even attempting to adapt to the culture she’s in; instead, she’s using her skills to take advantage of people who don’t have them, and being frankly disdainful of the trappings of a high-tech society. It’s a bit of a change for her, and I don’t know if it’ll serve her well long-term, but she’s definitely more confident.
docs.title: The World Traders

docs.text: Fourth Doctor Adventures #10.1 Released: 20 January 2021 Listened: 3/17/22 The next block is a bunch of full-length stories, making a contrast to the previous series. This one takes place in London, in the early 21st century, probably around 2021, given the release date. There’s a corporation with an extraordinary amount of wealth in a short time, which is slightly suspicious, but they’re also very secretive and have tech that’s too advanced for the time. That results in a bunch of interesting alien races, some time travel, and some very creative real estate investment strategies, some of which border on the silly. There’s a bonus companion in journalist Emma Fremantle, mostly so that the Doctor has someone to bounce off of while separated from Leela. Unfortunately, she’s not a patch on Sarah Jane, but she also spends a good chunk of the story brainwashed. Leela gets to be in her element, hunting an alien in the late Cretaceous. She’s also quite a bit more primal, even violent, in this story. She’s not even attempting to adapt to the culture she’s in; instead, she’s using her skills to take advantage of people who don’t have them, and being frankly disdainful of the trappings of a high-tech society. It’s a bit of a change for her, and I don’t know if it’ll serve her well long-term, but she’s definitely more confident.
docs.title: The World Traders

docs.text: The Wrath of the Iceni Fourth Doctor Adventures #1.3 Released: March 2012 Listened: 2/26/22 This story is the stand-out of this first series, for me. Of course, it’s a John Dorney story, but there’s no twist, no timey-wimey. It’s a straight historical, initially pitched as “Leela meets Boudica,” which is an amazing idea, and executed even better. Because of the speedy nature of this story, the Doctor and Leela run into Boudica almost immediately, and Leela immediately recognizes her as a kindred spirit, and pledges herself to Boudica’s cause. The Doctor doesn’t like that at all, mostly because of the Web of Time, but he has no real way of explaining that to Leela that she’ll understand. It goes far enough that Leela is forced to choose between them, and although we know how the story will end up, the anguish in the Doctor’s voice is unmistakable. It’s a powerful story, with both characters doing what they believe is right, based on the values of their own cultures; it gives Leela more agency than just doing whatever the Doctor says all the time. Boudica, as played by Ella Kenion, is also impressive; she has a bold, commanding presentation that radiates self-confidence. It’s easy to see why Leela would be attracted to her. Even better, Leela makes her own decision about who’s right in the end, and adds some nuance to what she considers an “honorable warrior” to be. As a result, this is one of my favorite historicals, period.
docs.title: The Wrath of the Iceni

docs.text: Trail of the White Worm Fourth Doctor Adventures #1.5 Released: May 2012 Listened: 2/28/22 Since the only Master who Big Finish had access to in 2012 was Geoffrey Beevers, they mostly didn’t use him, but if they’re going to do a Fourth Doctor series, he’s fair game. He seems to have recovered a bit from the events of “The Deadly Assassin,” so he’s a little more physically capable, but this version of the Master is more cruel and less suave than the Delgado or Ainley versions. This story is set in a contemporary time to where it would have fallen in the classic series, although it’s set in Derbyshire, so the values are a little old-fashioned. And that’s what it appears to be at first: a murder mystery in the country, with legends of a monster, and a couple of eccentric figures for the Doctor and Leela to bounce off of. Except it’s not that at all. There is a monster, the titular White Worm, but it’s not monstrous. The Lord of the Manor isn’t just eccentric; he chases Leela around with a tank. And on top of all that, the Master is here, with a typically convoluted plan. Because this is the first half of a two-part story, it gets more time to breathe, which really just means the Doctor and Leela are separated, and spend a fair amount of time running around on their own. The oddly named Demesne Furze is played by Rachael Stirling, known as the daughter of Dame Diana Rigg, both of whom appeared in “The Crimson Horror” in the new series not long after this. However, I wouldn’t get used to any of the characters from this story, as they won’t stick around.
docs.title: Trail of the White Worm

docs.text: White Ghosts Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.2 Released: 14 February 2014 Listened: 3/5/22 The second story is intriguingly linked to the first, as the Doctor forgives Leela, she takes a stronger hand in her own education, and we see what can push the Doctor close to the ultimate sanction. They land on one of those permanently dark planets, which Big Finish is fond of because they wouldn’t work on TV, but are great on audio. The danger starts almost immediately, as violent, speedy plants grow with any tiny bit of light, and there’s a missile headed for the planet as well. Writer Alan Barnes has a brilliant insert where we hear a battle from Leela’s internal point of view, with her instincts doing the narrating, more or less. But it’s vampires, and the Time Lords’ instinctive hatred of them, that dominates the closing part of this story, and provides a contrast to Leela’s treatment of the Sontaran clones from the previous story. No breakthroughs yet, but I wonder if there will be. On the side, Leela’s reading skills are improving rapidly, and she’s learning the difference between reality and fairy tales.
docs.title: White Ghosts

docs.text: Zygon Hunt Fourth Doctor Adventures #3.8 Released: 15 August 2014 Listened: 3/7/22 We don’t get Zygon stories very often, and it’s nice to see one with the Fourth Doctor. Even more unusually, these Zygons aren’t on Earth, although they’d still like to invade it. A jungle planet gives Leela a good opportunity to practice her skills, and the Zygons are also doing a better job of infiltration than they normally do. There’s a bit of moral dilemma, as the defenders of Earth are shown to be thoroughly reprehensible people, but that doesn’t mean the Doctor can just abandon them. Although it has some good flashes, the story just isn’t all that memorable in the end. That seems to be true of most of the stories from this season; they simply don’t have as much time to develop as I’d hoped. I don’t know if that’s because of the shorter format, or some other reason.
docs.title: Zygon Hunt

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor and Romana I This era of the TV show was something of an experiment. It was the first full season to have a single story arc, the search for the Key to Time. It also introduced Romana, played by Mary Tamm, intended as an extreme contrast to Leela. Since the Key to Time stories are all pretty much connected, it wouldn’t initially appear that there’s much space to fit in more. However, nobody had yet accounted for the space after the Key to Time story finished, which could have gone on for a while before “Destiny of the Daleks.” Although Mary Tamm appeared as Romana in small parts in Gallifrey stories, and in a few Companion Chronicles, once Tom Baker returned to the role, she was able to star in one season of full-cast dramas before her death in 2012. Although she died too young, it’s remarkable that there’s one season of stories to better flesh out her character.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor and Romana I

docs.title: The Fourth Doctor and Romana I

docs.text: Ferril's Folly Companion Chronicles #5.11 Released: 12 May 2011 Listened: 6/4/22 The first appearance of Romana in this project is a Companion Chronicle, which means lots of Mary Tamm. It doesn’t have the usual form of a companion telling a story later in their life, because that’s not possible for Romana I. Instead, it takes place in “real time” as it were, which means in the middle of the hunt for the Key to Time, which is a little odd, but doesn’t take too much handwaving to fix. The action takes place in Norfolk in 2011, which is a bit odd right after “The Stones of Blood,” but oh well. The baddy is played by Madeleine Potter, with a fairly strong American accent. She also does half the narration, which means sometimes Lady Ferril’s point of view conflicts with Romana’s, which is kind of amusing. Her impersonation of Tom Baker is fairly dire, but she doesn’t get to do it that often. Mary Tamm’s, while not really an impression, has a nice cadence to it that’s very effective in evoking the Doctor. The story itself, about a former NASA astronaut badly injured on a mission, and now possessed of numerous prosthetic parts, and the ability to control metal, is a bit far-fetched, even by Doctor Who standards. There’s rather a lot of sciency bafflegab, mostly to prove how clever Romana is, but it does threaten to overwhelm the story at times. Still, it’s a nice start to this section.
docs.title: Ferril's Folly

docs.text: Luna Romana Companion Chronicles #8.7 Released: 17 January 2014 Listened: 6/5/22 This story is also a Companion Chronicle, but it’s a bit more complicated. It’s part of the 50th Anniversary celebration, so it continues from “The Beginning” and “The Dying Light” in continuing the story of Quadrigger Stoyn. The story is constructed in four parts, featuring both Romana I and II. Unfortunately, Mary Tamm had passed away by this point, so the first Romana’s story is told in flashback by Romana III, played by Juliet Landau. Her voice is a bit of an acquired taste, and doesn’t really mesh that well with Romana I’s imperious personality, but at least she’s written properly. The Doctor and Romana stop off in ancient Rome, where they believe the last segment of the Key To Time will be found. Except the Doctor would rather see the latest comedy by Plautus instead, a play called Luna Romana . Romana eventually gets fed up with the Doctor (as she often did), and goes to finish the job on her own, except she ends up in peril at the cliffhanger. That cliffhanger waits until part 3, because of timey-wimey shenanigans, because it continues from part 2, which actually happens later. Yeah. It’s a little odd that we get another insert with a segment of the Key to Time that’s not what it appears to be, but there’s an interesting bit implying that the Doctor is stalling on finding the last segment because he’s not sure what the outcome will be. The coda with Romana III is a bit elegiac of Romana I, which is appropriate after Mary Tamm’s passing, but most Time Lords aren’t often nostalgic about their earlier personas (“Time Crash” notwithstanding). Then again, Romana was always pretty well in touch with herself.
docs.title: Luna Romana

docs.text: Phantoms of the Deep Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.5 Released: 8 May 2013 Listened: 6/10/22 It’s Doctor Who meets The Abyss . The Doctor parks the TARDIS at the bottom of the Mariana Trench so they’ll be undisturbed while he repairs K-9. So of course a handful of explorers happen upon them almost immediately, and there’s something alien going on nearby. Something alien that uses a force field so that the local pressure is just 3 atmospheres instead of over 1,000, because otherwise the story wouldn’t work. Because there’s swimming, an awful lot of swimming. K-9 sat out the last story, and in this one, he ends up getting mind-controlled on multiple occasions. He’s just not having a good series. There’s nothing particularly special about this one, although Alice Krige is in it, best known as Star Trek’s Borg Queen.
docs.title: Phantoms of the Deep
