docs.text: The Auntie Matter Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.1 Released: 14 January 2013 Listened: 5/30/22 The official full-cast stories start out, rather oddly, with a farce, a P.G. Wodehouse parody, with all that entails. The Doctor decides to hang out in 1920s London for a while, annoying Romana, who goes in search of intellectual stimulation. Enter stereotypical upper-class twit Reginald "Reggie" Comely-Bassett, along with his stereotypical dry valet Grenville. Reggie’s searching for a bride at the insistence of his maiden aunt, and being not terribly bright, he latches onto Romana as the first person he sees, and brings her home to meet Auntie. It seems that something odd is going on at Bassett Hall, which independently attracts the Doctor’s attention. The cast is top-notch, with Robert Portal putting on an outrageous speech impediment as Reggie, Alan Cox doing his best Stephen Fry as Grenville, and national treasure Julia McKenzie as the evil Auntie, well before she played The Twelve. Most of the plot is dedicated to keeping the Doctor and Romana apart as they work at the same problem from opposite ends, and giving Reggie as many absurd lines as possible. It’s a strange choice to start this run with a comedy, but it’s definitely a memorable story.
docs.title: The Auntie Matter

docs.text: The Dalek Contract Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.6 Released: 11 June 2013 Listened: 6/10/22 Big Finish, and Nick Briggs especially, like to make sure that every companion gets a turn with the Daleks, especially those who didn’t have a crack on TV, so that’s where this story comes in. And if you’ve got David Warner signed on to your series, you’ll want to use him as much as possible, so he’s back as Cuthbert, along with Toby Hadoke as Dorrick. It’s rather later in Cuthbert’s life at this point, but he’s still conducting whatever transdimensional experiment he was up to in “The Sands of Life.” Unfortunately, that means damaging some unsuspecting planet and ticking off the populace, so he’s actually hired the Daleks to be his muscle. Or at least, he thinks that’s what he’s done, because anybody who’s seen a Dalek story knows better than that. Because this is the first half of a two-parter, not much really gets done in this story. There’s a lot of running around with the rebels on the planet, Romana and K-9 get separated from the Doctor, and the usual threats and surrenders take place. It’s always fun to have Nick Briggs as the Daleks, but the story itself is a bit ordinary.
docs.title: The Dalek Contract

docs.text: The Final Phase Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.7 Released: 15 July 2013 Listened: 6/11/22 Cuthbert may very well be the single most stubborn opponent the Doctor has ever dealt with. Although he’s smart enough to realize that the Daleks have screwed him over…when the evidence slaps him in the face repeatedly…he’s determined not to reveal why he wants to build a dimensional gateway. The Daleks are very nearly equally stubborn in trying to get it away from him. K-9 gets to be clever in helping the rebels fight the Daleks. Romana gets to be clever in figuring out much of what Cuthbert is doing, but not all of it. And the Doctor gets to have a go at making the Daleks see sense for once in their lives, but you can imagine how well that goes. The nice bit of character development is Romana coming to realize that she does like the Doctor somewhat, laying the seeds for her regeneration. There’s plenty of sound and fury here, but on the whole, the story feels a bit unfinished. And it’s kind of a shame to have four out of seven stories this season taken up with Cuthbert, when “The Auntie Matter” and “The Justice of Jalxar” are pretty clear stand-outs. One wonders if more could have been done, but without Mary Tamm, that’s unlikely to happen.
docs.title: The Final Phase

docs.text: The Iron Legion Comic Strip Adapatations #1.1 Released: 13 March 2019 Listened: 6/5/22 This little interlude is a bit unusual, because it’s an adaptation for which I’ve read the source material. It’s an adaptation of a couple of the most popular stories from Doctor Who Magazine from that era. Oddly, neither Romana nor K-9 is with the Doctor at this point, and no explanation is offered. The action starts in the village of Stockbridge, its first appearance in the Doctor’s timeline. They’re invaded by the Iron Legion, a robot army from a parallel dimension where Rome never fell. The Doctor pursues them back home to rescue everybody. Although the original comics were short, the audio story follows the plot quite closely (deviating a bit at the end), adding dialog and embellishments to make it a full-length story. There’s more action than in a usual story, and it’s noticeably more fanciful and wider-screen. Also, the Doctor behaves a bit more broadly, with heightened dialog, and more action, which you’d expect from a comic strip. If you like your Doctor Who with some farce, this one is for you.
docs.title: The Iron Legion

docs.text: Comic Strip Adapatations #1.1 Released: 13 March 2019 Listened: 6/5/22 This little interlude is a bit unusual, because it’s an adaptation for which I’ve read the source material. It’s an adaptation of a couple of the most popular stories from Doctor Who Magazine from that era. Oddly, neither Romana nor K-9 is with the Doctor at this point, and no explanation is offered. The action starts in the village of Stockbridge, its first appearance in the Doctor’s timeline. They’re invaded by the Iron Legion, a robot army from a parallel dimension where Rome never fell. The Doctor pursues them back home to rescue everybody. Although the original comics were short, the audio story follows the plot quite closely (deviating a bit at the end), adding dialog and embellishments to make it a full-length story. There’s more action than in a usual story, and it’s noticeably more fanciful and wider-screen. Also, the Doctor behaves a bit more broadly, with heightened dialog, and more action, which you’d expect from a comic strip. If you like your Doctor Who with some farce, this one is for you.
docs.title: The Iron Legion

docs.text: The Justice of Jalxar Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.4 Released: 11 March 2013 Listened: 6/9/22 This story is a bit more actiony than the last one, at least on the part of our heroes. The Doctor and Romana detect alien tech where it shouldn’t be, and go to investigate, ending up in Victorian London. It’s just about 10 years after “Talons of Weng-Chiang,” so they go looking for Jago and Litefoot to help. They’re unaware that J&L have probably met his later incarnations at this point, and have their own series by now. For their part, George and Henry are pleasantly surprised to see the Fourth Doctor again, and are very surprised by Romana, since they were expecting Leela. In fact, Romana gets a lot of agency in this story, running around solving mysteries on her own, with Jago in tow, who has developed a crush on her. This is a John Dorney story, and although the plot isn’t as twisty as he normally writes, it is interesting. There’s a vigilante running around London punishing wrongdoers, but neither Jago or Litefoot, nor the Doctor or Romana, have the cultural context for a “super hero,” so it just never gets mentioned. The ending is a bit darker than anticipated, but not in a bad way. It’s another strong story in this set.
docs.title: The Justice of Jalxar

docs.text: The Sands of Life Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.2 Released: 11 February 2013 Listened: 5/31/22 This story is the first half of a two-parter, and oddly, it’s an extended story, told in three parts. The big draw here is David Warner as Cuthbert, wealthiest and most famous man on Earth, and head of the Conglomerate, which is conducting some dodgy time experiments. It seems to take place in the future, although not too far, as capitalism is still running strong, and the military still seems to use conventional weapons. However, the story is a bit drawn-out to fit. A species of time-sensitive space whales are headed for Earth, disrupting both the TARDIS and Cuthbert’s experiment. Naturally, the powers-that-be react badly to a few billion creatures dropping in on the Sahara. And they have a point, because their spawning process will be destructive to the planet. They’re willing to psychically talk to Romana because she’s a female, but we don’t really know yet how far the connection goes. It’s a decent enough opener, but it’s just an opener.
docs.title: The Sands of Life

docs.text: The Star Beast Comic Strip Adapatations #1.2 Released: 13 March 2019 Listened: 6/8/22 Although I don’t have nostalgic memories of “The Iron Legion,” like many nerdy Whovians, I’ve heard of Beep the Meep, so this story holds more interest for me. Unlike the comic story, K-9 doesn’t feature, but the well-drawn secondary characters of Sharon and Fudge, teenagers who find Beep after he crashes on Earth, make up for it. Fudge has more of a role this time, although he’s still slightly pathetic. Of course, if you already know that (spoiler) Beep is the baddie of the piece, that takes quite a bit of the suspense out of the story. Sharon, Fudge, and Fudge’s mother all have rather thick Sheffield accents, and speech patterns that I assume are normal for the era. I can deal with most accents in Big Finish, but the characters’ tendency to drop articles from their sentences was remarkably distracting, more than I’ve encountered before. As in the comic, Sharon ends up as a companion, which was perhaps intended as an ongoing role for Rhianne Starbuck, but to date, there haven’t been any more comic adaptations. I think that’s probably fine by me, as some of the later stories get rather surreal, which is perfect for comics, but not so good for audio. (This review was written before the Fourteenth Doctor's version of "The Star Beast," which likely blows continuity to smithereens, but why not enjoy as much Beep the Meep as possible?)
docs.title: The Star Beast

docs.text: The Stealers from Saiph Companion Chronicles #3.12 Released: June 2009 Listened: 6/12/22 This was the first Companion Chronicle (in release order) to feature Mary Tamm as Romana I, and they absolutely gave her a workout in this story. There’s no second actor, so Mary plays everyone, from the Doctor and Romana to upper-class twit Tommy to a German professor to an American millionaire to alien sludge. The storyline is a little bit convoluted, with body-snatching and some “whodunnit” qualities that take the Doctor and Romana time to unravel. Romana is mostly treated like an equal partner in this one, except in a few spots where the Doctor has greater experience. The story as a whole is serviceable rather than excellent, but the acting is really amazing, so that’s a good one on which to bid farewell to Mary Tamm for this project (mostly).
docs.title: The Stealers from Saiph

docs.text: The Warren Legacy Short Trips Rarities #3.4 Released: 28 September 2018 Listened: 6/12/22 This short trip is read by Stephen Critchlow, who does an excellent Fourth Doctor, so that makes this one special. It’s also on the long side for a Short Trip at 35 minutes. That gives enough room to tell a full story, one full of timey-wimey and paradoxes, where the Doctor and Romana come in on the end and have to work their way backwards. The baddies don’t leave much of an impression, and you wonder if maybe this would have been better if expanded somewhat. There’s no particular reason that Romana I is in this story; it really could have been any companion. Not the best story to end on for this era.
docs.title: The Warren Legacy

docs.text: War Against the Laan Fourth Doctor Adventures #2.3 Released: 11 March 2013 Listened: 6/1/22 If you thought the guest stars in part 1 were fun, I didn’t mention Toby Hadoke as Cuthbert’s right-hand-man, Jane Slavin in her first-ever Big Finish role, and Haley Atwell as the President of Earth (not a bad promotion, Agent Carter!). Unfortunately, as far as the plot goes, I’m a bit unimpressed. Although Haley Atwell is always awesome, her “unexpected presidential candidate” is just a little too naive and trusting to be believable as the president of a planet, new to the job or not. And no matter what the Doctor says, if you’ve got a species that’s about to wipe out all life on Earth because they made a mistake and got lost, well, there’s a point where you stop talking and take the tough action to save all your constituents. But this is a Nick Briggs story, so it all comes out well in the end. I wish Romana had a more active part, although she has some moments of brilliance. And Cuthbert is interesting enough that he’ll be back again later.
docs.title: War Against the Laan

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor and Romana II Although Mary Tamm is awesome, Lalla Ward made a strong impression as Romana II. She was smart enough to equal the Doctor, and in her new form, a little more whimsical and flexible, deliberately chosen to match the Doctor’s lifestyle better. There was certainly plenty of chemistry between this Doctor and Romana, as the actors married, but only briefly. Lalla Ward has also been a strong supporter of Big Finish, appearing in a number of Companion Chronicles and also headlining the Gallifrey series. It seemed somewhat inevitable that she’d participate in the Fourth Doctor Adventures series. Although Big Finish goes to great lengths to hide it, it seems that she never actually records with Tom Baker, but always does so remotely. Unfortunately, it seems like some of that bleeds into her performance, as she quite often seems exasperated, with little of the joy from her first few TV stories.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor and Romana II

docs.text: Babblesphere Destiny of the Doctor #4 Released: 1 April 2013 Listened: 7/6/22 This one is from the “Destiny of the Doctor” series, which means it’s a narrated story, in this case by Lalla Ward. She’s got Roger Parrott to play the various male roles, but Lalla narrates the Doctor, and doesn’t attempt Tom Baker’s voice at all. Unfortunately, a lot of the banter doesn’t come across as well with the constant “he said,” “she replied,” and so on. As for the story itself, it’s a critique of social media and the inanity it entails. That was probably more insightful in 2013, but in 2022, it’s not very impressive. Johnny Morris can do better. It also has another over-used trope, the “mind-sucking monster is feeding on human brains, so we’ll give it a Time Lord brain and it won’t be able to handle the inflow.” Which is fine if done properly, but there isn’t any interesting twist on this one, really. As always in these Destiny stories, there’s an insert from the Eleventh Doctor, but it doesn't add a whole lot, except giving the Fourth Doctor the opportunity to comment on the Eleventh’s youthful looks.
docs.title: Babblesphere

docs.text: Casualties of Time Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.8 Released: 10 August 2016 Listened: 7/1/22 The closing half of this story brings us answers to a bunch of questions: Who exactly is Cuthbert, and where did he come from? What is his actual goal? Why does he only have one name? What’s up with that parrot in the TARDIS? What does the Black Guardian have to do with all of this anyway? As to whether those answers are particularly satisfying…well, maybe not so much. Some things still seem arbitrary, and the science is kind of wonky, even by Doctor Who standards. It seems to be one of those stories that aims for “charmingly ambiguous,” but lands on “confusing” instead. Romana continues to sound irritated with everyone and everything. Toby Hadoke’s Mr. Dorrick gets to be properly menacing this time around, even if it’s ineffective.
docs.title: Casualties of Time

docs.text: Dethras Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.4 Released: 20 April 2017 Listened: 7/6/22 This story has a fairly high concept: creatures that can hyper-evolve to withstand any environment, and the people who want to weaponize them. So of course it starts on a WWII-era submarine. In space. And there’s also a monkey. All of which seems kind of wacky for a story, and in fact, there doesn’t seem to be as much story here as one would think. The hitch is that the villain is fairly irrational and gives up way too easily, but this is only a one-hour story. The Doctor also seems rather angrier than usual, and even says so outright. It’s also somewhat odd in that it leaves a potentially dangerous resource around for anyone to find, and the Doctor is OK with that. Writer Adrian Poynton has only done a few stories for Big Finish; this and a couple of “Jenny” stories, which is probably why it seems kind of different. Not necessarily good different or bad different, just different. And it leads directly into “The Leisure Hive,” which is the first instance we’ve seen of one of these series taking a break in the middle.
docs.title: Dethras

docs.text: Gallery of Ghouls Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.5 Released: 10 May 2016 Listened: 6/28/22 This one is set in Brighton, 1833, where two competing exhibitions of waxworks are competing rather aggressively for customers. One of them is a thinly-veiled copy of Mme. Tussaud’s (although they also reference her by name), and the other is slightly more gruesome, but neither is entirely what they appear to be. Apparently the public was fascinated by the French Revolution at the time, particularly beheadings, so there are a lot of figures of Frenchmen hanging around. The guest cast is an impressive list of Big Finish talent: Celia Imrie, Nikolas Grace, Stephen Critchlow, and Helen Goldwyn…not that you can tell, because most of them are doing accents of one sort or another. The Doctor continues being somewhat antic, and Romana, unfortunately, keeps being irritated, although usually at people other than the Doctor, at least this time. I’m sure the actors all had a lovely time, but the story doesn’t really stand out.
docs.title: Gallery of Ghouls

docs.text: Legacy of Death Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.4 Released: 13 April 2016 Listened: 6/27/22 This story continues on from the previous, with 100% more timey-wimey. In particular, the flavor of timey-wimey in which people in the past can leave messages for people 1,000 years in the future, and people in the future can leave messages that later travel to the past to affect earlier events. Even Doctor Who doesn’t go to this well all that often (Steven Moffat notwithstanding), but Douglas Adams wasn’t afraid of it, and Johnny Morris is channeling that here. There’s also an unusually high body count, given that in the first half, the two sides tried to avoid killing each other. There’s also a religious cult and double agents confusing things, and I think only K-9 knows the whole story. I’ve said before I’m not really a fan of “wait here for 1,000 years and then do a Thing” plans, and this one isn’t giving me reason to make an exception. Still, if you’re going to do a time-twisty plot, doing it when the companion is also a Time Lord, and therefore doesn’t need to ask for exposition, isn’t a bad idea. So far, this story is the most notable of the season.
docs.title: Legacy of Death

docs.text: Luna Romana Companion Chronicles #8.7 Released: 17 January 2014 Listened: 6/16/22 This is where the rest of the story from the last segment comes in, and as Romana herself says “where it gets complicated.” The TARDIS lands on the moon, which in the future was host to a Westworld -style theme park of historical recreations, including a Roman section (hence “Luna Romana”), all abandoned now. Except Stoyn is here again, an even more bonkers, raving version of Stoyn, which Terry Malloy excels at. Stoyn is trying to approximate Gallifreyan technology with only several thousand years of Earth tech as a starting point. So things get timey-wimey in short order, which allows part 2 of the story to come between parts 1 and 3. Romana is rather better at crossing her own timeline than the Doctor is, in that she manages to avoid meeting herself or planting any memories that shouldn’t be there. In fact, the Doctor is portrayed at his most annoying and supercilious in this story, and Romana is a willing accomplice. Admittedly, it’s the easiest way to get Stoyn riled so he’ll make a mistake, but it also has the effect of making Stoyn’s hatred of the Doctor almost sympathetic. In the end, that’s the problem I have with this whole trilogy: Although Stoyn does some terrible things in his madness, he should never have been there in the first place, and that’s the Doctor’s fault. Stoyn doesn’t handle his situation well, but he was never temperamentally suited to leaving Gallifrey, so it’s kind of hard to blame him for anything. I don’t know if that was the goal, but the Doctor doesn’t seem very self-reflective here.
docs.title: Luna Romana

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #8.7 Released: 17 January 2014 Listened: 6/16/22 This is where the rest of the story from the last segment comes in, and as Romana herself says “where it gets complicated.” The TARDIS lands on the moon, which in the future was host to a Westworld -style theme park of historical recreations, including a Roman section (hence “Luna Romana”), all abandoned now. Except Stoyn is here again, an even more bonkers, raving version of Stoyn, which Terry Malloy excels at. Stoyn is trying to approximate Gallifreyan technology with only several thousand years of Earth tech as a starting point. So things get timey-wimey in short order, which allows part 2 of the story to come between parts 1 and 3. Romana is rather better at crossing her own timeline than the Doctor is, in that she manages to avoid meeting herself or planting any memories that shouldn’t be there. In fact, the Doctor is portrayed at his most annoying and supercilious in this story, and Romana is a willing accomplice. Admittedly, it’s the easiest way to get Stoyn riled so he’ll make a mistake, but it also has the effect of making Stoyn’s hatred of the Doctor almost sympathetic. In the end, that’s the problem I have with this whole trilogy: Although Stoyn does some terrible things in his madness, he should never have been there in the first place, and that’s the Doctor’s fault. Stoyn doesn’t handle his situation well, but he was never temperamentally suited to leaving Gallifrey, so it’s kind of hard to blame him for anything. I don’t know if that was the goal, but the Doctor doesn’t seem very self-reflective here.
docs.title: Luna Romana

docs.text: Shada TV Season 17, Serial 6 Aired: 19 January 1980 - 23 February 1980, except it never actually aired. The famous lost story, only partially completed at the time and never aired, but completed and released in varying methods over the years, including linking narration and animation. Douglas Adams co-wrote, and swiped some ideas for his novels. Season 17 ends here.

docs.text: Subterranea Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.6 Released: 14 June 2017 Listened: 7/8/22 This story isn’t an unfortunate sequel to “Underworld,” thank heavens. Instead, it takes place on a planet covered in porous rock, easily burrowed through. The inhabitants are evolved mole-people, dressed for some reason in 19th-century outfits. (Good thing they weren’t trying this on TV.) They live on large steampunk vessels that burrow continuously through the ground, because the surface is no longer habitable, after a war long ago. Unfortunately, they’re being stalked by a mysterious force of cyborgs…which aren’t terribly original, as they go in for capture and conversion, like some other famous cyborgs we know. However, they’re also not terribly bright, so resolving the story doesn’t seem like much of a challenge. Jane Slavin makes an appearance as a plucky young rebel, and seems to be having a ton of fun with it. There’s one plot twist that may catch you off guard, but other than that, the setting is more original than the plot.
docs.title: Subterranea

docs.text: The Beast of Kravenos Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.1 Released: 11 January 2017 Listened: 7/3/22 This new series of Fourth Doctor Adventures is meant to take place during Season 18 of the show (or a bit before), and carries the new theme music that John Nathan-Turner requested. However, the story itself is a return to Gothic horror, as it features Jago & Litefoot. It’s clearly later in J&L’s personal timeline, because they remember meeting Romana I (although they believe Romana II is a different person with the same name). Also, Inspector Quick is here, played by Conrad Asquith, who originated the role in “Talons.” And it’s written by Justin Richards, who created the Jago & Litefoot series. Outside of all that, though, the story is a bit low-key. Jago and Litefoot are now pretty experienced with otherworldly stuff, so they’re not as credulous or cowardly as they may have been earlier. The Doctor and Romana aren’t concerned about blending in this time either, so they openly bring K-9 around with them. And with K-9’s abilities of computation, scanning, and defense, they don’t actually need long to deal with a J&L-style mystery. Which is more or less fine, as it’s a one-hour story, but it does seem to be a bit of a wasted opportunity. Romana seems a bit more cheerful and less exasperated than usual, but who could be exasperated with Professor Litefoot?
docs.title: The Beast of Kravenos

docs.text: The Beautiful People Companion Chronicles #1.4 Released: 19 February 2007 Listened: 6/13/22 Welcome Lalla Ward to the project! This is a very early Companion Chronicle, and that shows in some peculiarities. The story is four parts, with (increasingly punny) episode titles, even though the full thing is only a little over an hour. The Doctor gets sidelined early on, which gives plenty of focus to Romana, but the actual explanation for his sidelining is laughable. Writer Jonathan Morris is definitely trying to channel some of the Douglas Adams era here, with some overt references, as well as a general sly humor to the dialog. Unfortunately, the “exasperated Romana” persona is in full effect here. Although Romana supposedly regenerated to be more in sync with the Doctor, she sounds annoyed with him most of the time, as though she’s outgrown him. The story takes place at a health spa, where the super-wealthy go to get miraculously thin, but of course there’s something sinister going on with the process. This results in rather a lot of cheap shots about fat people. Although both Romana and the Doctor profess that it doesn’t matter what someone looks like on the outside, it’s clear from Romana’s inner thoughts that she does harbor some prejudice and refuses to acknowledge it. It’s also fairly hypocritical coming from a character who looks like Romana, and especially from someone who can change their physical appearance. On the whole, the story seems rather badly dated, even though it’s only 15 years old, and it caused some cognitive dissonance to listen to it while working out.
docs.title: The Beautiful People

docs.text: The Doomsday Contract Lost Stories #6.2 Released: 17 March 2021 Listened: 6/18/22 This is one of the more recent Lost Stories, a “B-Side,” if you will, to go with “Return of the Cybermen” earlier. As such, it didn’t really get a ton of attention. It was originally commissioned by Douglas Adams and written by John Lloyd. Here, it’s adapted by Nev Fountain, and they lean into the Douglas Adams schtick so hard, they’re nearly horizontal. All the minor characters and the planets have absurd Adams-type names, bureaucracy has run amok to the level of absurdity, and the Earth is an insignificant planet in danger of being bulldozed in the name of development, unless the Doctor can prove it has sentient life on it…without revealing that he’s ever been there, as that would be a violation of the law. There’s not a lot of plot to be had, as the emphasis is on the style, and Douglas Adams stories have never been huge on plot. Still, the resolution stretches the timey-wimey well past the breaking point. If you’re not looking for seriousness, this is good, Adams-y fun.
docs.title: The Doomsday Contract

docs.text: The Eternal Battle Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.2 Released: 15 February 2017 Listened: 7/4/22 Who’s up for some Sontarans? We haven’t seen them in a while, and Romana never has, so that’s a good start. There’s an attempt here to do something both different and traditional with Sontarans, as we see a whole bunch of them engaged in a huge campaign, which we haven’t really seen them do on TV. In fact, this campaign has gone on for so long that even the Sontarans are getting tired of it, which is something that really doesn’t happen. Plus, the dead keep coming back as zombies, which is a bit tough on the usual “honorable death” trope. Clearly, something fishy is going on here, and it’s up to the Doctor to find out what. As usual, Dan Starkey plays a whole bunch of Sontarans, and as usual, he’s excellent. I’m a particular fan of Sergeant Major Stom, a Sontaran with an unfortunate habit of thinking, and a wonderful habit of snarking at the Doctor under his breath. Even the Doctor starts to like him. Romana is back to being fully exasperated again, although to be fair she has plenty of good reason. I just thought she’d be a bit more collected by now.
docs.title: The Eternal Battle

docs.text: The Haunting of Malkin Place Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.5 Released: 17 May 2017 Listened: 7/8/22 We’re back into the Adventures season proper, this time with a good old-fashioned ghost story. It’s slightly past the end of World War I, and Malkin Place is inhabited by a pair of twins, Maurice and Beatrice, who lost their father not long ago. Maurice is haunted by events that happened to him during the war, and the house seems to be just plain haunted on top of that. So they invite in a spiritualist to help, who bumps into the Doctor and Romana on the train. The Doctor is once again rather angry with the spiritualist, and dismissive of his “arts.” Romana just flatly disbelieves and doesn’t bother getting upset. Of course, ghosts in Doctor Who always have another explanation, but the story takes its time getting there, leaving the listener plenty of time to guess about it. It holds together rather nicely as a story, mixing the period and time travel together.
docs.title: The Haunting of Malkin Place

docs.text: The Labyrinth of Buda Castle Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.2 Released: 18 February 2016 Listened: 6/22/22 We’re dumping any silliness with this story, which seems to be aiming for Hinchcliffe-style horror. Buda Castle and its labyrinth are in Budapest, where Vlad the Impaler was once imprisoned, which in 1980 makes it popular with vampire hunters. Except that what’s here isn’t exactly a vampire, just an alien using blood as a gestalt organism, and taking people over. Romana is a lot more clinical about the possibility of vampires than the Doctor normally is, but she hasn’t met one yet, so probably regards them as myths. The Doctor is rather unusually shouty and righteous in this one, perhaps more appropriate to season 18 than 17. Mark Bonnar is unrecognizable as the baddie, but has a laconic tone that’s fitting for an immortal, and manages to be all the more sinister for it. Not too scary, but effective.
docs.title: The Labyrinth of Buda Castle

docs.text: The Movellan Grave Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.7 Released: 12 July 2017 Listened: 7/9/22 With this TARDIS crew, it makes sense to include some Movellans eventually. Although I think the best thing about Movellans is their striking visual, the characters do a pretty good job of describing them on audio, so it works out. And this time around, it’s just Movellans, with no Daleks around, although creating a weapon to win the Dalek war is part of the Movellans’ motivation. Unfortunately, they crash-landed just south of London around 1 AD, and weren’t uncovered for 2,000 years. These Movellans no longer have the weakness of deactivating when somebody pulls their power pack off their belt, which was a silly flaw to start with, and means we don’t have to endure any slow-motion deactivations on audio. In fact, this story gets a lot of mileage out of the fact that Movellans generally, and one in particular, are much stronger than humans. There’s still not a ton of peril going on, but it’s a decent enough story.
docs.title: The Movellan Grave

docs.text: The Old Rogue Short Trips #4.4 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 6/15/22 This is one of those early, short Short Trips where not much happens. It’s told from the point of view of the villain, an alien conqueror stuck in the body of a London cafe owner, for reasons that become apparent later in the story. The Doctor drops in to check on him once a decade, and this time it’s the Fourth Doctor’s turn, along with Romana. It’s kind of fun to see the alien’s impressions of the various Doctors; he calls this one “the lunatic,” which seems on-the-nose. He’s also very dismissive of Romana, but Romana is being unusually snotty on this story. Which is pretty much all there is to it, but the ancillary action is fun: K-9 is forced to wait outside, and gets up to various antics with the passersby (that would be fun to see on TV, action going on through the windows while the main characters chat in the cafe). There’s also a tiny twist at the end, more of a mint than a real plot development. The story is read by Louise Jameson, although Leela doesn’t appear in the story. Her acting gift comes through clearly, as she captures the tone of the various characters quite well.
docs.title: The Old Rogue

docs.text: The Paradox Planet Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.3 Released: 16 March 2016 Listened: 6/27/22 This story attempts to channel another part of the Douglas Adams era: not the silliness, but the high-concept sci-fi of ideas. In this case, it’s a planet at war with its own past. The people of the past era used up their fossil fuels and let many species of animal go extinct, despite having access to high-energy zenox crystals. So their descendents from the future travel back in time to snatch up both the animals and the crystals. You can probably see where this is going. Romana gets separated from the Doctor almost immediately, and they each spend a good portion of the story trying to puzzle out what’s going on, a process that takes some time, because this is the first half of a two-part story. Romana II seems to work better when she’s not just parroting things back at the Doctor, but instead she finds entirely new people to be exasperated with. Admittedly, the people of both time periods are fairly exasperating.
docs.title: The Paradox Planet

docs.text: The Pursuit of History Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.7 Released: 13 July 2016 Listened: 6/30/22 It’s the end of the season, which means it’s time for a dramatic two-parter, and in this case, the return of Cuthbert, his quantum gateway, and his time-sensitive space manatees. Who once again kidnap Romana to save them, so she and the Doctor are separated early on. She’s ever-so-slightly less exasperated than usual as she figures out the technological end of what’s killing the Laan, and is mostly in control of her situation. The Doctor is much less in control, as he ends up following Cuthbert up and down the timeline, discovering that he’s gone as far back as 1853 to plant the seeds of his business empire. Unfortunately, following a quantum tunnel is tough on the TARDIS, so there’s a lot of crashing sound effects. Because this is a two-part story, not a lot more happens in the first half.
docs.title: The Pursuit of History

docs.text: The Pyralis Effect Companion Chronicles #4.4 Released: October 2009 Listened: 6/15/22 Another early Companion Chronicle, this one has the potential to be something special, but unfortunately falls short. The action takes place in Kasterborous, not far from Gallifrey, where a colony ship carrying a gene bank is looking for the Doctor, as he helped their planet in the past. Unfortunately, they only remember the First Doctor, so they don’t believe the Fourth is the same person. Worse, they accidentally open a prison that the Time Lords sealed 1,000 years ago. (The Time Lords are really bad at cleaning up their trash.) You’d think this would have some interesting implications for the Doctor and the Time Lords, but it just turns into a standard-issue “strange invader” story mixed with a murder mystery. The story is told in present tense from Romana’s perspective. Fortunately, there’s much less “exasperated Romana,” but unfortunately, there’s quite a lot of “terrified Romana” instead. Lalla Ward oversells the cliffhangers, putting too much emotion into the narration. She also seems to have less agency in this story, making for a dissatisfying story overall.
docs.title: The Pyralis Effect

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #4.4 Released: October 2009 Listened: 6/15/22 Another early Companion Chronicle, this one has the potential to be something special, but unfortunately falls short. The action takes place in Kasterborous, not far from Gallifrey, where a colony ship carrying a gene bank is looking for the Doctor, as he helped their planet in the past. Unfortunately, they only remember the First Doctor, so they don’t believe the Fourth is the same person. Worse, they accidentally open a prison that the Time Lords sealed 1,000 years ago. (The Time Lords are really bad at cleaning up their trash.) You’d think this would have some interesting implications for the Doctor and the Time Lords, but it just turns into a standard-issue “strange invader” story mixed with a murder mystery. The story is told in present tense from Romana’s perspective. Fortunately, there’s much less “exasperated Romana,” but unfortunately, there’s quite a lot of “terrified Romana” instead. Lalla Ward oversells the cliffhangers, putting too much emotion into the narration. She also seems to have less agency in this story, making for a dissatisfying story overall.
docs.title: The Pyralis Effect

docs.text: The Romance of Crime Novel Adaptations #3 Released: 13 January 2015 This novel adaptation, and the following two stories, all by Gareth Roberts, are regarded as some of the best. The adaptations are by John Dorney, one of my favorite Big Finish writers. Unfortunately, I haven't listened to this one yet.
docs.title: The Romance of Crime

docs.text: Novel Adaptations #3 Released: 13 January 2015 This novel adaptation, and the following two stories, all by Gareth Roberts, are regarded as some of the best. The adaptations are by John Dorney, one of my favorite Big Finish writers. Unfortunately, I haven't listened to this one yet.
docs.title: The Romance of Crime

docs.text: The Silent Scream Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.3 Released: 22 March 2017 Listened: 7/5/22 The Doctor and Romana visit 1930s Hollywood, which at the time is full of silent movie stars suddenly unemployed because they’re not suited for talkies. And there’s something out there made of celluloid and stealing actresses’ voices. James Goss is the writer, and as you might expect, it’s a love letter to the silent film era, with lots of sympathy for silent film actors trying to stay relevant. And of course it’s a little bit meta as there’s talk of lost film reels hidden in back rooms, but also whether the Doctor and Romana’s regular lives are actually “adventure stories.” K-9 becomes a GPS about 60 years early. Of course, there are lots of actors trying out American accents, and on the whole, it comes off better than usual for Big Finish, so well done them. The ending is a little more deus ex sonic than I’d like, but there is at least an effort made at handwaving it. A decent story.
docs.title: The Silent Scream

docs.text: The Skin of the Sleek Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.8 Released: 16 August 2017 Listened: 7/9/22 We’ve reached the end of the season, so it must be time for a two-parter. The stakes don’t initially seem very high, as the TARDIS lands on a fairly primitive planet. There’s a nature-documentarian here, along with his assistant and pilot, but they’ve crashed and need help. Mark Platt throws in a twist, though: the planet’s surface is one big, sluggish ocean. You can walk on it, but if you stop, you’ll sink. And that’s just the start of things. Romana’s old friend from the Academy is here as well, but strangely reluctant to say what’s going on. And there’s more going on with the natives than meets the eye too, but we get only the vaguest of clues. It seems like one kind of story, yet the fact that it doesn’t end after two parts indicates it’s an entirely different kind.
docs.title: The Skin of the Sleek

docs.text: The Thief Who Stole Time Fourth Doctor Adventures #6.9 Released: 13 September 2017 Listened: 7/9/22 The second part of this story provides an awful lot of sturm und drang, with people chasing about on the dangerous surface, giant electric eels threatening everybody, and oh yeah, it turns out the planet is a gigantic gelatinous mass engineered by the Time Lords eons ago to plug up a space-time rift, as one does, and then forgotten about. Romana’s old friend Sartia, it turns out, has always hated her, and in addition she’s got a plan to take over all of space and time, as renegade Time Lords often do. When it comes to evil villain ranting, Joannah Tincey has it down. In the extras, several people think she might make a good recurring villain, but that hasn’t happened yet. Jane Slavin and Kieran Hodgson put on their best Cornish accents as natives, and yet still somehow managed to sound like themselves. It’s a big, blowout season finale, but having Mark Platt do it instead of Nick Briggs gives a different quality to the whole thing.
docs.title: The Thief Who Stole Time

docs.text: The Trouble with Drax Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.6 Released: 14 June 2016 Listened: 6/29/22 This one is a John Dorney story, so you can expect twists…and more twists…and some more on top of those. The story brings back Drax, Time Lord, friend of the Doctor’s, and general reprobate, last seen in “The Armageddon Factor.” He was played there by Barry Jackson, who had agreed to reprise the role, but sadly passed away shortly before recording. He was replaced by Ray Brooks, also with a thick Cockney accent. While the previous version of Drax was a troublemaker, this one is a bit more nefarious. He needs something stolen, and has no problem forcing the Doctor to do it. He also carries a “Blinovitch Limitation Effect Limiter,” which is the sort of nonsense Douglas Adams would make up. Other cast members are particularly notable, including John Challis, Hugh Fraser, and Miranda Raison, all of whom have some history with the show. Eventually, the plot becomes so convoluted that it passes the point of absurdity, but by that time, you probably won’t care anymore. It has just the right lightness of touch that you can’t really blame anybody.
docs.title: The Trouble with Drax

docs.text: Wave of Destruction Fourth Doctor Adventures #5.1 Released: 12 January 2016 Listened: 6/20/22 As we move into the full season of Fourth Doctor Adventures, it looks like the Adams-style sensibility is continuing, if not quite as overtly. The story is set in the 1960s, with the Vardans trying to invade a planet that’s currently swimming in radio waves. Which gives the characters the opportunity to say things like “modulated frequency wave cancellation signal generator,” which they do, in full, many times. I’m not sure that the science actually works the way it’s described, but that doesn’t matter too much, as it’s all technobabble. More fun is the pirate radio station “Radio Frantic,” which is described as having remarkably catchy jingles, and darned if they’re not right. Some of these may be stuck in your head for days. “Exasperated Romana” is back here, even though she does get some plot to do on her own. She’s particularly dismissive of shopping for shoes and 60’s plastic handbags. I can see why that style may not be to her taste, and she probably doesn’t want to shop simply as a distraction for a young woman who’s witnessed traumatic events. But still, someone who wears outfits as fabulous as hers must spend some time shopping and accessorizing. Kind of a forgettable kick-off to the season.
docs.title: Wave of Destruction

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor, Romana, and Adric For many years, Matthew Waterhouse didn’t want to work with Big Finish, mostly because he didn’t think he could reproduce the voice of his younger self. However, after doing some Dark Shadows stories for them, he came around. At first, he did exclusively stories with the Fifth Doctor’s TARDIS crew, but eventually he did a handful of Fourth Doctor stories as well. This period on TV was kind of tumultuous, and took its toll on Tom Baker. As a result, his Doctor appears a bit darker and more reserved in this era.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor, Romana, and Adric

This period on TV was kind of tumultuous, and took its toll on Tom Baker. As a result, his Doctor appears a bit darker and more reserved in this era.
docs.title: The Fourth Doctor, Romana, and Adric

docs.text: A Full Life Short Trips #6.9 Released: 29 September 2016 Listened: 7/16/22 This is an awfully long short trip, a full story and then some. In fact, it’s an alternate timeline in which the Doctor and Romana sacrifice themselves, and Adric ends up living a whole life, which he doesn’t get to do in the main timeline. It takes a while for the horror to dawn that Adric really is stranded alone forever, and there’s a gut-punch at the end with “I’ll never know if I was right.” Matthew Waterhouse narrates in-character as a much older Adric, and it really works. He doesn’t pull any punches about what he was like as a kid. This is one time when the extended short trip is justified.
docs.title: A Full Life

docs.text: Short Trips #6.9 Released: 29 September 2016 Listened: 7/16/22 This is an awfully long short trip, a full story and then some. docs.text: Chase the Night Fourth Doctor Adventures #9.2 Released: 22 January 2020 Listened: 7/11/22 The TARDIS answers a distress call from a pretty high-concept planet: it’s too close to its star, but the night side is habitable. However, it’s not tidally locked, so the only way for anyone to survive is to keep moving, at about 10 mph. Which this particular ship did by constructing a railway track all the way around the planet. Unfortunately, if anything goes wrong, they’re all dead…and things are going wrong. The Doctor and Romana cause some of the problems themselves by lying when first asked who they are and where they’re from. Still, the colony has been engaged in some pretty brutal social Darwinism for a while now, and that’s impairing their ability to trust anybody. The image of being stuck while the terminator creeps closer is pretty tense, although the story goes to that well a few too many times, resulting in a few false climaxes. Where the story gets weird is in the resolution, and the revelation of how life on this planet actually works. There’s an interesting coda in which Romana ponders what she wants to do with her life, and wonders if it’s compatible with the Doctor’s lifestyle. Credit for a good concept, and some strong tension, although it maybe goes on a bit too long.
docs.title: Chase the Night

docs.text: Erasure Short Trips #8.4 Released: 30 April 2018 Listened: 7/20/22 Story time with Narvin! This is an unusual Short Trip, told in the style of a Companion Chronicle, with a narrator relating a flashback. In this case, though, it’s Narvin talking to Leela. The frame story takes place after Gallifrey: Enemy Lines and before the Time War series. They’ve been in a battle, Leela is injured, and Narvin tells her a story so she’ll stay awake. Except it really is more of a “young Narvin” story than a story about the Doctor. As a young CIA agent, Narvin gets sent to stop some other species from mucking around with time, except he finds the Doctor and Adric already there. The aliens try to strong-arm the Doctor by popping back in history and blowing up the star-liner carrying Adric’s ancestors, erasing him from history. In response, the Doctor sends Narvin to fix it. Sean Carlson narrates quite well, telling the whole thing from Narvin’s biased point of view. He’s never seen the Doctor before, and is well-positioned to relate how intimidating the Fourth Doctor can be, especially when he’s angry. But ultimately, it’s a story about how Narvin himself has changed due to his interactions with Leela and Romana, which is a point of view you don’t really get, even in the Gallifrey series.
docs.title: Erasure

docs.text: Logopolis TV Season 18, Serial 7 Aired: 28 February 1981 - 21 March 1981 Last story of Season 18. Tegan is introduced. Nyssa reappears and joins up. First proper appearance of the Antony Ainley Master. Introduces Logopolis and the concept of Block Transfer Computations, the Cloister Room and its Bell, and the idea of the Watcher. And of course, for the Fourth Doctor, this is the end…but the moment has been prepared for.

docs.text: Messages from the Dead Short Trips #11.2 Released: 15 February 2022 Listened: 7/16/22 Unlike a lot of Short Trips, this one has a full flashback that takes place here. Adric is thinking about when they ran across a derelict ship at the edge of a black hole in E-Space, and insights he got into the Doctor and Romana’s relationship at that time. Honestly, it’s rather more insightful than you would expect from a teenager, especially one who’s bad at reading social cues. It’s also rather worshipful of both Time Lords, as Adric desperately tries to prove that he belongs. Matthew Waterhouse does a decent job narrating, although his Fourth Doctor kinda sounds like David Warner.
docs.title: Messages from the Dead

docs.text: Messages from the Dead Short Trips #11.2 Released: 15 February 2022 Listened: 7/16/22 The frame story takes place here, which I normally don’t note, but Adric spends a lot of the narration time comparing the events of the flashback to what it’s like now, after Romana has gone. The Doctor is acting differently, and Adric is mostly unable to help.
docs.title: Messages from the Dead

docs.text: Purgatory 12 Fourth Doctor Adventures #9.1 Released: 22 January 2020 Listened: 7/10/22 This series of Fourth Doctor Adventures promises to focus on the interpersonal relationships between the Doctor, Romana, and Adric, and boy, this one dives right in. Adric is already feeling ignored and out of place when the story starts, and almost immediately decides to leave the ship. The Doctor thinks he’s being clever by dropping him off and jumping 15 minutes ahead in time, but this is Doctor Who , where a whole lot can happen in 15 minutes. In this case, getting kidnapped by an entire prison asteroid full of convicts and very strange rust storms. Gotta give Adric credit for committing to the bit; for a while, he even insists he wants to stay at the prison rather than going with the Doctor and Romana. He’s really at his most petulant here, but the story makes the point that he’s never processed his grief for his brother Vash, and both the Doctor and Romana pretty much ignored that. He does get a bit of the “Artful Dodger” act that was supposed to be part of his persona, but rarely showed up. Unfortunately, that can undermine the reader’s trust in him. Romana does a decent job of sticking up for him, but she’s really not experienced at being the big sister, and I’m not sure she’s sorted out her own feelings about Adric. There’s some sci-fi in this story too, with a bodiless entity who feeds on brains, but honestly the resolution to that drags out a bit longer than it should have. Writer Mark Platt knows how to create interesting secondary characters, and there are a bunch of them here, all with their own agendas. It doesn’t leave a ton of room for the plot, though.
docs.title: Purgatory 12

docs.text: The Invasion of E-Space Companion Chronicles #5.4 Released: 13 October 2010 Listened: 7/16/22 This Companion Chronicle takes place rather late in Romana’s tenure in the TARDIS, when Adric is present, but K-9 isn’t. In good Companion Chronicle style, the Doctor gets sidelined early and stays that way for at least half the story. That allows Romana to take the lead, but also allows her to spend a little time with Adric, whom Romana admits she hasn’t given much of a chance. It’s kind of her to realize that Adric really didn’t fit in with his home society, and doesn’t have many alternatives. Of course, the story is written by Andrew Smith, Adric’s creator, who always puts him in a good light. The other speaking role goes to Suanne Braun, a well-known actress who’s also appeared in Stargate and Red Dwarf , so she gets a bigger role than usual as a police inspector investigating a series of murders. Oddly, though, she doesn’t interact with Romana all that much, but carries the narration for parts of the story where Romana’s not around. She also sounds enough like Lalla Ward that it can cause confusion. It’s no fault of this story, but the whole “search for the CVE” thing is starting to get a little tired. This is also the final appearance of Lalla Ward in this part of the project, although she’ll be back later in various Main Range stories, and in Gallifrey .
docs.title: The Invasion of E-Space

docs.text: TV Season 18, Serial 6 Aired: 31 January 1981 - 21 February 1981 Nyssa is introduced, but doesn’t join up. First appearance of the Master in some time. Antony Ainley takes over the role.
docs.title: The Keeper of Traken

docs.text: The Planet of Witches Fourth Doctor Adventures #9.3 Released: 12 February 2020 Listened: 7/13/22 The third story in the set finds the Doctor and Romana taking a methodical approach to finding a CVE and getting out of E-space, which bores Adric to death. Although Romana was defending him not too long ago, she seems frustrated by him now, even though he’s being less peevish and more typical teenager. This story emphasizes the fact that the entire TARDIS crew is extremely intelligent and rational-minded, because although everybody else is concerned with witchcraft and magic, none of the four of them believe it for even a second. This is one of those stories that seems to change dramatically which each part, starting out with prisoners on a ship, then wandering a mysterious planet with an enigmatic godlike being lurking nearby, to trying to stop religious fanatics. All that contrast makes the story more engaging, but it does seem like the characterizations jump around a bit, even if there is an in-story explanation for all of it. There’s an awful lot of bluffing and concealed identities in this story, to the point where it can be tricky to figure out what’s going on. Romana always seems exasperated these days, but in this story it’s worse than usual. Some of Lalla Ward’s line readings seem quite off, as if she can’t find an emotion other than “really annoyed.” There’s some interesting stuff going on here, but I don’t know if it adds up to much.
docs.title: The Planet of Witches

docs.text: The Quest of the Engineer Fourth Doctor Adventures #9.4 Released: 12 February 2020 Listened: 7/16/22 Andrew Smith, writer of “Full Circle,” where Adric and E-space were introduced, writes this one. He’s known for writing stories with monsters who turn out not to be so monstrous, or at least are only following their natures. This time, though, while the villain does have an understandable motivation beyond conquest, it’s still an amoral one. The action mostly takes place on an artificial planet that the Engineer has constructed, and can move portions of its crust around seemingly at will. It’s a fascinating image that probably wouldn’t have worked on TV, and unfortunately is hard to capture on audio. No sound effect can convey “a huge chunk of rock has ripped itself out of the surface and is carrying three people away at speed.” So the characters are forced to verbally describe things that are right in front of them, an audio trap Big Finish usually avoids. The various minor characters are well drawn and acted, although the main plotline itself doesn’t seem like enough for a four-parter. Oddly, although there are several stories left to go in this section, this is the last full-cast one, so that’s the last of Tom Baker in this part of the project, except for the inevitable multi-Doctor appearances later on.
docs.title: The Quest of the Engineer

docs.text: Watchers Audio Novels #2 Released: 12 January 2022 Listened: 7/19/22 This is the second of the original audio novels, written and narrated by Matthew Waterhouse, which is an interesting twist. Unfortunately, he’s not as adept a mimic as John Culshaw (who is?), so we’ve got his David-Warner-sounding Fourth Doctor. Because it’s an audio novel, it’s also quite long, which allows for lots of additional detail, but also affects the structure of the story. The Time Lord “Milady” and her companion Marcel are introduced early in the story, but don’t join the main plot until much later. This mostly gives Waterhouse the opportunity to describe the features of an advanced TARDIS in detail, followed later by tons of other TARDISes of various times and purposes, even a child’s “play” TARDIS with a cardboard console and painted controls. The majority of the story takes place in a timeless spot in the Vortex, where something is pulling other time ships together and fusing them into a single mass. (TARDISes are more advanced, so they just land inside, but can’t get away.) Of course there are Daleks here, because who can resist telling a story with Daleks? Plus it allows Nick Briggs to be a second voice actor, relieving the monotony. The Daleks act like Daleks always do, but at least it gives Adric the opportunity to encounter them, which he never did on TV. Much of the story revolves around a couple of other groups of aliens, one a race of cyborgs with a superiority complex, and one a race of lizard-types with a penchant for slavery. There’s not much here that affects the larger story of the Fourth Doctor, except that he becomes exhausted by the end of the story, perhaps contributing to his tiredness in “Logopolis.” The pace seems unnecessarily languid to me, but maybe that’s because I’ve been listening to radio plays, not audio books. Maybe if this were in print, it wouldn’t bother me so much. But as it is, there’s too much description, too much musing, and way too much denouement.
docs.title: Watchers

docs.text: The Fourth Doctor and Sarah Jane (and Harry) In a tragedy of bad timing, Tom Baker’s joining Big Finish happened right around the same time as Elisabeth Sladen’s death. According to Baker’s website, he had just agreed with Big Finish to do a series of stories with Sladen as Sarah when she died. She did record two series of solo adventures with Big Finish in 2002 and 2006, which are covered elsewhere, and while she was making The Sarah Jane Adventures on TV, she was unavailable to Big Finish. As of 2022, They’ve very tentatively started using Sadie Miller (Sladen’s daughter) as Sarah Jane, but mostly in Third Doctor adventures for now. UNIT Doctor Harry Sullivan is around for the first half of this era, but Ian Marter sadly died in 1986, and is unavailable. Actor Christopher Naylor has played Harry in a few stories, but none from this section. All of which means this section is quite short, despite covering two and half seasons on TV. The inserts here are mainly Short Trips.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor and Sarah

docs.text: Chain Reaction Short Trips #2.4 Released: 28 February 2011 Listened: 2/13/22 This Short Trip is barely even a story, just a kind of a goof, for which the Fourth Doctor is perfect. He’s at a shopping center, waiting for Sarah, and rolls a pound coin across the pavement, setting off a Rube Goldberg chain of events. The cycle repeats a few times, so it bears careful listening. (And I’m not sure how that works with the Laws of Time, but whatever, it’s a Short Trip.) There’s a small twist, but it’s not really important. And that unimportance makes it a fun story.
docs.title: Chain Reaction

docs.text: Collector's Item Subscriber Short Trips #2017-1 Released: 21 March 2017 Listened: 8/5/22 This later Short Trip is still fairly vignettey, without a bad guy as such, just a guy messing with things he shouldn’t be messing with. It’s a nice piece for Sarah, though, as it starts in her own era, at a jumble sale, a tradition Sarah is quite fond of. Writer Paul Salamoff has Sarah’s mannerisms down perfectly, especially when she leads a fellow on for information, and then immediately drops the act once she has what she wants. Steven Critchlow narrates, and as usual, does a fantastic job with the Fourth Doctor’s lines. Finally, this story gives the origin of the TARDIS hatstand, which I’m reasonably sure no one has ever asked about.
docs.title: Collector's Item

docs.text: Genesis of the Daleks TV Season 12, Serial 4 Aired: 8 March 1975 - 12 April 1975 The legendary story that introduces Davros and shows the origin of the Daleks, as the Time Lords send the Doctor to stop that from happening. Retroactively, this story will be considered the first act of the Time War.
docs.title: Genesis of the Daleks

docs.text: #HarrySullivan Short Trips #9.8 Released: 29 August 2019 Listened: 2/13/22 Yes, this title is pronounced “Hashtag Harry Sullivan,” which makes it hard to alphabetize, and neither Sarah nor Harry should understand the meaning of the word. Yet that’s what the story is about: The TARDIS crew is on a ship full of journalists orbiting a resort planet and running low on life support, because the celebrities won’t allow the paparazzi to land. Amazingly, the Doctor’s usual bluster and charm is ineffective, so the solution is to make Harry temporarily famous. Writer Eddie Robson clearly intends this to be a commentary on the attention marketplace of the early 21st century, and there’s a certain new-series flavor about it, which makes Harry and Sarah stand out somewhat. It’s read by Louise Jameson, as sadly Ian Marter and Elisabeth Sladen are both unavailable. However, Jameson is an excellent narrator, putting just enough impression in the characters’ voices to achieve the effect.
docs.title: #HarrySullivan

docs.text: How to Win Planets and Influence People Short Trips #7.6 Released: 29 June 2017 Listened: 2/12/22 This short trip has a rather unusual structure, with Rufus Hound not narrating, but telling the story in-character as the Monk. Except he’s the keynote speaker at a corporate function, giving a talk on “How to invade the Earth.” Which is, to be fair, an excuse to take lots of cheap shots at humans and their foibles, which James Goss is certainly equipped to do. In the form of anecdotes, the Monk mentions a few recent times that he was defeated by the Fourth Doctor, Sarah Jane, and Harry, probably in chronological order. Which means that Rufus Hound gets to play the Monk imitating all three of them, which he does reasonably well, although his Tom Baker isn’t as stentorian as one might hope. Of course, the joy of Rufus Hound’s Monk is hearing him go apoplectic, which he quite kindly does by the end of the story. It’s not really the best entry, but it is funny.
docs.title: How to Win Planets and Influence People

docs.text: The Pescatons Argo Records Special Released: July 1976 Listened: 2/14/22 This story has a strong up-side and down-side. On the one hand, it’s the first ever Doctor Who audio, recorded in 1976, featuring a remarkably young-sounding Tom Baker and Elisabeth Sladen. As Sladen’s only appearance in this part of the project, that’s welcome. On the other hand, the story is strange, and frankly, not very good. It’s heavily narrated, with small patches of dialog here and there, which is fine, but it’s narrated from the Doctor’s point of view, revealing him to be not just excessively wordy, but also frequently frightened, which just doesn’t fit at all. The bad guys are the Pescatons, a race of humanoid shark-people from a dying planet (in the constellation of Pisces, rather too on the nose). They’re supposedly vicious on a hand-to-hand level, but honestly they’re kind of low-rent, even for a classic-series monster. And yet the Doctor describes them as irredeemably evil, and needing to be destroyed, which is entirely out of character, almost as much as him being afraid of them. Sarah Jane doesn’t seem to have a purpose in this story, as her conversations with the Doctor are usually unimportant, with the big dramatic bits being covered in narration. There’s also a completely unnecessary flashback that doesn’t make a lot of sense, given how short the story is. And the aliens do an absurd amount of damage worldwide, and rack up rather a high body count, yet UNIT is never seen or mentioned, which really makes no sense given where it’s set in Doctor Who history. As a historical artifact, it’s amazing. As a story, it’s fairly terrible. It’s probably best to think of it like a TV story from its era; not able to pull off what it promises.
docs.title: The Pescatons

docs.text: The Wondrous Box Short Trips #3.4 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 2/13/22 This Short Trip, in contrast, is a story, although a brief one. The TARDIS lands in P.T. Barnum’s circus in 1885. Of course the Doctor loves a circus, although Sarah Jane is less thrilled. The Doctor delights in pointing out the original Jumbo the Elephant, but the fun ends when a circus performer steals the TARDIS key and accidentally moves it a short distance. Unfortunately, that accident leads to tragedy, and it seems to be one of those times where the Doctor is predestined to be involved with an established historical event. It’s neat if you want to learn a bit about Jumbo and the circus, but otherwise, kind of sad.
docs.title: The Wondrous Box

docs.text: Short Trips #3.4 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 2/13/22 This Short Trip, in contrast, is a story, although a brief one. The TARDIS lands in P.T. Barnum’s circus in 1885. Of course the Doctor loves a circus, although Sarah Jane is less thrilled. The Doctor delights in pointing out the original Jumbo the Elephant, but the fun ends when a circus performer steals the TARDIS key and accidentally moves it a short distance. docs.text: The Fourth Doctor Solo Every Doctor needs a solo period for Big Finish to drop solo stories into. Fortunately, the Fourth Doctor was polite enough to provide a solo period actually in the TV canon. What goes in here is a hodgepodge of specials and one-offs of various types, all of which require the Doctor to be alone.
docs.title: Fourth Doctor Solo

docs.text: Blood of the Time Lords Fourth Doctor Adventures #11.1 Released: 16 March 2022 Listened: 3/22/22 This particular set of Fourth Doctor Adventures, released in 2022, takes place specifically just “hours” after “The Deadly Assassin.” The Doctor is feeling responsible for a change, and lands on Gallifrey’s moon, the Recusary, which is apparently where old Time Lords retire when they’re getting close to death. There’s a lot of continuity stuff going on with this one, but not so much that it becomes a burden. The old hermit friend who the Doctor mentions from time to time gets a name, Ansillon, and is currently running the Recusary, so that makes for some interesting interactions. Of course, there has to be a companion substitute, in the form of Elanora, played by Emma Noakes as a mousy librarian who’s a bit more than she seems. Timothy X Atack produces a story with rather a lot of layers and misdirection, and a villain that I really didn’t see coming. The Doctor is at a pretty arrogant point in his life, without Sarah, having just saved Gallifrey from the Master, and it almost seems like he treats the proceedings with contempt. He certainly succeeds in getting under everybody’s skin. As a bonus, there’s even a hint of explanation about one of the Doctor’s oldest mysteries, although I don’t know if any other story will pick up on it. Definitely worth a listen, and probably a re-listen.
docs.title: Blood of the Time Lords

docs.text: Genetics of the Daleks Time Lord Victorious Special Released: 10 December 2020 Listened: 2/20/22 This story is part of the sprawling Time Lord Victorious storyline…except the connection to that overall plot is quite tenuous. Specifically, it’s a prequel to the “A Dalek Awakens” escape room game, but you don’t need to experience one to enjoy the other. So, viewing this entirely in isolation: The Doctor arrives on a generation ship, halfway through its journey. Unfortunately, some criminals have infiltrated and replaced some of the crew. Worse, they found what seems to be an empty, frozen Dalek shell floating in the Oort Cloud, and they’re letting the science officer experiment on it by himself. Never a good idea. What follows is a tight, well-paced horror story, in which the Doctor is slightly more clever than usual with establishing his bona fides, and the commander is less stupid than usual in accepting his help. Unfortunately, when multiple members of the crew are lying about their identities, for different factions, that may not be enough. The win isn’t quite as clean as it seems to be, because then there couldn’t be an escape room sequel. But credit to Jonny Morris for telling a Fourth Doctor story in the Time Lord Victorious framework without messing up any timelines.
docs.title: Genetics of the Daleks

docs.text: Night of the Vashta Nerada Classic Doctors, New Monsters #2.1 Released: 27 July 2017 Listened: 2/19/22 This is the Fourth Doctor’s first appearance in the “Classic Doctors, New Monsters” line, and he’s paired up with the Vashta Nerada, which at this point he’s only ever heard of, but hasn’t seen. The story connects to “Day of the Vashta Nerada,” the Eighth Doctor story later in the set, but there’s no indication of that here. The Doctor has come to Funworld, a whole planet that’s a fun-fair, because he wants to…have fun. However, it’s closed because something killed the original staff, so the owner has turned up with a bunch of hunters to clear it out. It’s very Jurassic Park, except the raptors are microscopic. The Doctor spends an inordinate amount of time shouting at people, trying to get them to leave, but they’re stubborn and won’t go. Which makes it remarkably like “Silence in the Library,” except there’s no River Song. John Dorney is the writer, but there’s nothing twisty here; it’s just straight-up sci-fi horror. The Vashta Nerada are kind of tricky to do on audio, since they don’t speak and hide in shadows that listeners can’t see, but Dorney does a nice job piling up the tension, especially using the “two shadows” trick. It’s atmospheric, but feels like half a story…because it is.
docs.title: Night of the Vashta Nerada

docs.text: Only Connect Short Trips Rarities #3.3 Released: 28 September 2018 Listened: 2/19/22 Tip for the non-British: “Only Connect” is the name of a game show in which contestants try to find the common link between groups of disparate items. This Short Trip is longer than the previous, but it’s equally a vignette. An architect gets a taxi ride from a strange driver who turns out to be the Doctor, of course. The Doctor claims that he drives a cab because it’s a source of interesting information that may save lives someday. Of course, we’ve never known the Doctor to spend much time as a cab driver, so it doesn’t make a ton of sense. The architect gives the Doctor a bit of info about Chase Manor, site of “The Seeds of Doom,” but if this timeline is correct, the Doctor no longer needs that information. I expected there to be a twist, but there really isn’t. John Banks narrates, and does a slightly better job of matching Tom Baker’s tone than Hugh Ross did, but still without being an impression.
docs.title: Only Connect

docs.text: Out of Time Out of Time #1 Released: 26 August 2020 Listened: 2/19/22 This is really a Tenth Doctor story, but it’s a crossover, and for the Fourth Doctor, it definitively takes place here. He’s taking a break after the events of the past few stories, and has gone to a cathedral outside of space and time to have a rest and paint some frescos. And apparently talk about himself a lot. When the Tenth Doctor turns up in the midst of his own identity crisis near the end of his regeneration, there’s some abrasion, but also mutual appreciation, as in the best multi-Doctor stories. When the Fourth Doctor calls out the Tenth on his arrogance, the Tenth Doctor – accurately – replies that it’s rich for the Fourth to call anybody arrogant. And yet, the Tenth Doctor really deserves the criticism at this point in his life. Oh, and there’s Daleks too, but that really just gives the Doctors something else to argue about. Matt Fitton excels at the interpersonal dynamics, and he really nails this one.
docs.title: Out of Time

docs.text: Peake Season Fourth Doctor Adventures #11.5 Released: 21 June 2022 Listened: 6/26/22 This bonus two-parter has the Doctor fanboying over Mervyn Peake, artist and writer of several novels, particularly Gormenghast . As you can imagine, the story is replete with Gormenghast references, most of which I didn’t get. The Doctor is at his most Fourth Doctory in the surreal setting, full of bizarre observations and commentary that drive Peake to distraction, but Peake finds himself liking the Doctor despite himself. David Holt, well-known English actor, does a very impressive job as Peake. It’s a rather strange story, but if you can roll with it, it’s fun.
docs.title: Peake Season

docs.text: Shellshock Fourth Doctor Adventures #11.4 Released: 21 June 2022 Listened: 6/25/22 The Doctor unexpectedly finds himself in World War I in France, and of course in No Man’s Land, because that’s how these stories always go. This time, though, when the Doctor is knocked unconscious by shelling, he’s taken to a German hospital instead of an English one. Not that it really matters, because something alien is going on that’s affecting both sides equally, but it’s interesting to see the story from the German point of view. He gains a nurse, Hanna Schumann, as a temporary companion, and it’s kind of hard not to see parallels with Molly O’Sullivan, but he won’t meet her for some time yet. Hanna is very patriotic and dedicated to duty, but also believes in doing the right thing, and very willing to give the Doctor sass when he acts oddly or doesn’t explain things, which is most of the time. Much of the story is spent unraveling the mystery, and traveling back and forth through No Man’s Land, which does get a bit tedious after a while. But there really aren’t any baddies to speak of, which is an interesting twist on this kind of story.
docs.title: Shellshock

docs.text: Someone I Once Knew The Diary of River Song #4.4 Released: 4 September 2018 Listened: 2/19/22 This is a River Song story, but it’s kind of an alternate one. At this point in production order, Big Finish and River had worked their way back through the Eighth, Seventh, Sixth, and Fifth Doctors, with a memory wipe each time. So when they got to the Fourth, they pulled a twist of having the Fourth Doctor not only know River, but he’d always known her, all the way back to Gallifrey. That’s because the baddies in this boxed set are the Discordia, beings who simply go back and rewrite time every time they lose, or want something, or any excuse, really. They’re apparently immune to paradox. What’s going on with River and the Discordia makes a lot more sense if you’ve been listening to the entire box. The Doctor’s part in it is to mostly swoon over River, and attempt to save the day, but it’s River’s story, after all. The schmoopy bits between River and the Doctor are a bit much, especially because Tom Baker sounds closer to his actual age in those scenes. So it’s a bit hard for it to come across as poignant. John Dorney is at his best with paradoxes, but maybe not so much with romance.
docs.title: Someone I Once Knew

docs.text: Storm of the Sea Devils Fourth Doctor Adventures #13.1 Released: 5 March 2024 This story, and the next several, are part of Series 13 of the Fourth Doctor Adventures, featuring the period in which the Doctor traveled with an older Harry Sullivan and Naomi Cross. These adventures were connected to Seventh Doctor stories released much earlier in real time, but recorded around the same time. Because why should the timey-wimey be confined to the fiction? Unfortunately, I don't have this set yet.

docs.text: The Deadly Assassin TV Season 14, Serial 3 Aired: 30 October 1976 - 20 November 1976 The only TV story in which the Doctor doesn’t have a companion. Introduced the “decayed” version of the Master. Also introduced a lot of background about Gallifrey: Rassilon, the Presidency, the chapters, the robes, and the Matrix.

docs.text: The Dreams of Avarice Fourth Doctor Adventures #11.3 Released: 21 June 2022 Listened: 6/25/22 The second boxed set of this season was called “The Nine,” and this story is why, as John Heffernan’s Nine makes a return. The Nine’s various voices aren’t quite as distinct as Marc Bonnar’s Eleven, but they actually only play a small part in this story. The Nine is a kleptomaniac, as displayed in his other major appearance in Doom Coalition. This time, though, he’s even more insane than usual, not even willing to part with a cup of coffee. His “companion” Thana from “Relative Time” appears in this story, later in her personal timeline, but they’re not getting along. The real highlight here is the temporary companion, Detective Inspector Probert, played by Richard Dixon. Probert starts out arresting the Doctor, but of course that never lasts long. He’s reasonably bright, but completely out of his depth following the Doctor around, so it’s fun watching his policeman’s cynicism turn to confusion and panic, and then reach the stage where he’s just rolling with it. Unfortunately, because the Nine’s mental problems are so severe, he’s fairly predictable, and not too difficult to thwart. As a result, this story falls a little flat.
docs.title: The Dreams of Avarice

docs.text: The Ravencliff Witch Fourth Doctor Adventures #11.3 Released: 16 March 2022 Listened: 3/24/22 In contrast to the previous story, this one is a very Hinchcliffe-style “gothic horror” story, with supernatural elements that turn out to not be so supernatural after all. Writer David Llewellyn captures the tone of the era quite nicely. It’s not specifically stated that it takes place in the 1970s, but it certainly has that feel. You’ve got your usual power plant run by idiots, messing with things they don’t understand, and locals who don’t want the power plant there. British national treasure (and star of “Kinda” way back when) Nerys Hughes plays temporary companion (or more, but that will come later) Margaret Hopwood, a driftwood sculptor. Lucy Pickles plays the other, a local woman who works at the power plant. The Doctor indulges in quite a bit of technobabble, but the main problem is caused by another time-traveling species, so technobabble is to be expected. It’s a tight story, with good tension, and it holds together quite well.
docs.title: The Ravencliff Witch

docs.text: Waiting for Gadot Short Trips Rarities #2.2 Released: 29 September 2017 Listened: 2/19/22 This particular Short Trip is more of a vignette than anything. A wildlife photographer spends months alone on a barren planet waiting for a rare bird, a “gadot,” to come along. Instead, he finds the Doctor, who decides to help him out. The moral is that even when the Doctor helps you, it can lead to unexpected consequences. Hugh Ross is the narrator, and his Fourth Doctor isn’t what you’d call an impersonation, but it more or less captures the tone.
docs.title: Waiting for Gadot
