docs.text: The Second Doctor The Second Doctor, like the First, had a slow start when it comes to Big Finish. Patrick Troughton was unavailable, as was Michael Craze. However, the saving grace for Second Doctor audios has been Frazer Hines (Jamie). Jamie is with the Second Doctor for almost the entirety of his tenure, so doing stories without him would have been nearly impossible. Fortunately, Frazer Hines loves Big Finish, is more than happy to do audios, and even better, does a very convincing impersonation of Patrick Troughton. He started off doing some Companion Chronicles, in which it’s pretty common for the narrator to voice the Doctor, and did it so well that when Big Finish transitioned to the Early Adventures, he just started playing the Doctor outright. The various companion actors (bar Michael Craze) have been willing, leading to a decent number of Second Doctor stories. There aren’t any big gaps in his tenure, so the stories are spread somewhat evenly throughout his three seasons, weighted a bit more toward the end. There’s also the “Season 6B” issue, but we’ll deal with that later.
docs.title: Second Doctor

docs.text: The Second Doctor, Ben, and Polly This is a tiny section, because there’s only one story before Jamie shows up, and Big Finish didn’t want to extend it much, because they need Frazer Hines to play the Doctor (or they did, anyway). Anneke Wills continues to play Polly throughout, and Elliot Chapman was recast as Ben, doing an excellent job of impersonating Michael Craze. In this section, they’re mostly befuddled by the new Doctor (as were the viewers), as none of them had experienced regeneration before.
docs.title: Second Doctor, Ben, & Polly

docs.title: The Second Doctor, Ben, and Polly

docs.text: Lost and Found Short Trips #6.6 Released: 16 June 2016 Listened: 9/21/20 Another light-hearted story, if not quite as silly. The TARDIS crew ends up on Earth, shortly after World War II, while rationing was still enforced. The Doctor stumbles upon a sentient can of baked beans, which leads them to a department store in London (Henrik’s, which will employ Rose Tyler in 55ish years). Polly remembers being there as a child, and losing her stuffed bear, so she and Ben go looking for it, while the Doctor tries to deal with the beans’ problem. The solution has a threat of paradox to it, but ultimately that’s put aside because the emotional content of the story is more important. Anneke Wills does the narration, and does quite a credible job of imitating both Ben and the Doctor, which is impressive.
docs.title: Lost and Found

docs.text: The Curator's Egg Companion Chronicles #12.1 Released: 20 June 2018 Listened: 9/21/20 As this was one of the Companion Chronicle boxed sets that Big Finish had been making the past few years, a bit more cast was available. Although Jamie isn’t in this story, Frazer Hines plays just the Doctor, and Elliot Chapman plays the main secondary character and the antagonist, as well as Ben. However, Ben and the Doctor are written out fairly quickly to give Polly the spotlight, as this is the only story from this set in which she appears. Anneke Wills gets to narrate as well. The story itself is actually somewhat silly, taking place in Dorset, using Durlston Castle and the stone globe there, but also heavily featuring cyborg dinosaurs. There’s a Jurassic Park vibe, with a mad billionaire and his scientist brother creating the dinosaurs, and of course it goes horribly wrong. The scientist is notably bad with people, and resorts to quipping when he’s nervous, which is most of the story. This allows Polly to exercise her empathy, and take charge in an action-hero way with lots of running. It’s not exactly how Polly was portrayed on TV, but it gives her a good spotlight episode. If you think of it kind of like a new series episode and just roll with the silliness, it’s a lot of good fun, especially because Wills makes the most of it as narrator.
docs.title: The Curator's Egg

docs.text: The Dead Star Audio Novels #4 Released: 5 January 2023 Listened: 2/26/23 Big Finish’s audio novels have been all over the place in terms of who they feature. This time, it’s the Second Doctor, Polly, and Ben, shortly before Jamie joins up. It’s narrated by Michael Troughton, who now has the role of the Second Doctor in full-cast stories. I wasn’t too impressed with his version of the Doctor before, but somehow the contrast between his narration voice and his Doctor voice makes him sound more like his father. His secondary characters sometimes sound a bit odd, but they’re consistent, and you get used to them fairly quickly. Like all audio novels, it’s long, but it’s also split into several distinct parts, not unlike “The Mind Robber.” The first part is in a dimensionally fractured, empty, version of London, which would have been terribly difficult to pull off on TV in 1966, and might even be now. The next chunk takes place in London, 1968, which is a bit odd for Ben and Polly, as it’s two years after they left, but they mostly fit in. This time, the disaster is a small black hole passing through the solar system, which gets hung up on a time corridor that brings it straight toward the Earth. The third chunk takes place on a space station some distance into the future, but it’s more of a realistic station than one would have seen in the 60s. And the last bit is surreal to the point of being indescribable. The story is written by Kate Orman, who wrote several of the Virgin New Adventures novel series, but hasn’t written anything since then; Big Finish were determined to track her down for this series. That background shows in the story, as she pushes the boundaries of the story in ways that go beyond what Big Finish would normally do. She introduces a number of high concepts, such as reconfigurable robots held together by muon fields, and liquid knowledge transfer, which can impart skills and knowledge to anyone, Matrix-like, for a limited period of time. As a result, Polly gets to literally be action-girl, and Ben becomes a physics genius for a bit. There’s also a non-binary character from a human colony where gender simply isn’t considered important, and is referred to with female pronouns in one time period, male ones in another. This does throw Polly and Ben for a loop, but they adjust quickly enough. What’s interesting is that the Doctor really doesn’t understand what’s going on for most of the story. The black hole is a threat, but the underlying reasons remain unknown, so the Doctor spends a lot of time poking at the problem and being frustrated. I don’t normally mention the sound design in Big Finish, but it’s really excellent here, and takes the novel series beyond just an audiobook into creating a real sense of presence. So far, all the novels have been very different in tone, but that’s starting to feel like a feature.
docs.title: The Dead Star

docs.text: The Power of the Daleks TV Season 4, Serial 3 Aired: 5 November 1966 - 10 December 1966 The Daleks return, although they haven’t been gone that long. The Doctor acts somewhat erratic after his regeneration, setting up a pattern. Polly and Ben have to deal with this new Doctor.
docs.title: The Power of the Daleks

docs.title: The Power of the Daleks

docs.text: The Second Doctor, Ben, Polly, and Jamie In this section, Jamie joins the team, and the Second Doctor starts to act more like himself. Most of the TV stories are linked, so they take place early in this phase, with the new stories being inserted before “The Faceless Ones.” With three companions for the first time in years, and a more active Doctor, the TARDIS seems a bit crowded. The major characterization issue was ensuring that Ben wasn’t overshadowed by Jamie, so the Big Finish writers made sure to balance the scales and give Ben his share of spotlight.
docs.title: Second Doctor, Ben, Polly, & Jamie

docs.title: The Second Doctor, Ben, Polly, and Jamie

docs.text: House of Cards Companion Chronicles #6.8 Released: 6 February 2013 Listened: 9/26/20 This one is somewhat silly, much like “The Selachean Gambit,” but takes place at a casino rather than a bank. The TARDIS crew ends up in a space casino, which has Jamie fairly baffled, Polly wary, and Ben enthusiastic. The baddies are the Sidewinder Syndicate, who’d previously only appeared in Doctor Who Adventures comics with the Tenth and Eleventh Doctors. They’re snake-like aliens who’ve adopted the mannerisms of 1920s Chicago gangsters, as aliens seem to be wont to do. This is their only audio appearance, perhaps because they’re a bit too silly for believability. There’s also quite a bit of timey-wimey, because time travel is forbidden in a casino, as you might imagine, so of course that’s what ends up happening. Frazer Hines and Anneke Wills split the narration again, but Polly gets the spotlight this time, leaving Jamie mostly confused. It takes a repeat listen, or very careful listening the first time, to follow all the back-and-forth going on, or you can just be like Jamie and roll with it. It’s a fun, lightweight story for all that, more new-series than Classic Season 4.
docs.title: House of Cards

docs.text: Resistance Companion Chronicles #3.9 Released: March 2009 Listened: 9/26/20 This story is a bit of a throwback at this point in the project. This is the first story that Anneke Wills did for Big Finish as Polly, so it has a lot of tropes common to earlier stories. It’s a true historical, for one thing, set in Vichy France in 1944, as the Doctor and Polly encounter the French Resistance, helping to smuggle French loyalists and foreigners out to Spain. Ben and Jamie get written out fairly early, and stay gone for most of the story. In a later Companion Chronicle or Early Adventure, they probably would’ve gotten their own plotline, because there’s a story there. In particular, though, this story focuses firmly on Polly, and she spends a lot of time pondering her role on the team, and not really liking the answers she comes up with. Big Finish has done a good job rehabbing her character, as they’ve done to other classic characters, but in this early story, it feels a bit defensive. Polly’s got plenty of agency, though, as the story turns a bit personal for her and she takes decisive action independent of the Doctor. Anneke Wills does a fairly good job playing the Doctor, Ben, and Jamie, but she shares the narration with John Sackville, so she doesn’t have to work for the full 60 minutes. It’s a decent enough story, if a slightly awkward fit in the project from Polly’s point of view.
docs.title: Resistance

docs.text: The Faceless Ones TV Season 4, Serial 8 Aired: 8 April 1967 - 13 May 1967 Set on present-day Earth (which means 1966 in this case). Ben and Polly depart. Leads directly into the next story.
docs.title: The Faceless Ones

docs.text: TV Season 4, Serial 8 Aired: 8 April 1967 - 13 May 1967 Set on present-day Earth (which means 1966 in this case). Ben and Polly depart. Leads directly into the next story.
docs.title: The Faceless Ones

docs.text: The Forbidden Time Companion Chronicles #5.9 Released: March 2011 Listened: 9/27/20 This story is all about the high concept. An alien race called the Vist, with very odd physical appearance (helpfully reproduced on the cover) has walled off an area of time, which the TARDIS has bounced off of, so the Doctor wants to investigate. The setting, and its accordant weirdness, is more important than what actually happens in the plot, or its resolution. The story is set up in the traditional Companion Chronicles manner that Big Finish has since discarded, with an older Polly telling the story to a third party, in this case a government committee who’s concerned about a psychic message the Vist sent to the entire planet, and Polly’s basically explaining that the Doctor dealt with it while they weren’t looking, so no problem. Frazer Hines appears as Jamie in the form of recordings he made on Polly’s dictaphone, which seems a bit of a stretch to work him into the frame story. Ben gets written out early, and the focus is primarily on Polly, who does a game job impersonating Patrick Troughton. There’s less hand-wringing than in “The Resistance,” but she’s not action-girl Polly of stories recorded later. Andy Lane wrote this one under a pseudonym, and I’m not really sure why. It’s an odd story, and I’m not really sure I enjoyed it. And that’s a wrap for Anneke Wills for this project, but I hope there will be opportunities to tell more stories with Polly in the future, as she’s a great sport, and does a great job recreating her character.
docs.title: The Forbidden Time

docs.text: The Forsaken Early Adventures #2.2 Released: 15 October 2015 Listened: 9/24/20 This one is a “base under siege” story, very typical of the era, although this time the base is a hotel on a small island in Singapore, 1942. Complicating matters, Ben’s father is one of the soldiers stuck on the island awaiting evacuation, so it can’t be one of those times where everybody dies except for the TARDIS crew, or Ben won’t be born. Writer Justin Richards does a pretty good job of keeping the monster and its nature under wraps, with each of the four episodes revealing a new piece of information about it. There’s a nice feeling of claustrophobia, even though the setting is partially outdoors. Also props to Richards for getting in several of the Second Doctor’s catch-phrases. Ben and Jamie get to hang out a lot with the soldiers in this story, by benefit of their military training and penchant for physical activity, although the story focuses more on Ben. Polly is left with the Doctor or left behind to play nursemaid several times, which she complains about, to her credit, but does it anyway. The Doctor seems to have settled into his new persona quite thoroughly at this point, and approaches the situation differently than how the First would have done it. It’s a somewhat typical story for the era, but a good example of the breed.
docs.title: The Forsaken

docs.text: The Home Guard Early Adventures #6.1 Released: 13 November 2019 Listened: 9/25/20 This is one of those “everything you know is wrong” stories, where the crew are living in an English countryside village, in a nation that’s at war, with plenty of “pull together” spirit, but it’s later than WWII, judging by the level of technology. Of course, the Master is involved (not a spoiler; he’s on the cover), which means nothing is what it seems. How long that goes on, and how they come back to reality, are both somewhat unexpected, though. In fact, the remainder of the story, and the outside threat, is somewhat underplayed, but the focus is on the interplay between the characters. Ben has more spotlight than usual in this story, as he’s something of an idea person. There’s clearly something going on between him and Polly, but it’s still unspoken as yet. This is the final appearance of Elliot Chapman as Ben for Big Finish, as the actor said he did not want to play Ben in more stories than Michael Craze did, out of respect. The Doctor has slightly less to do than in other Early Adventures, due to the nature of the story. James Dreyfus returns as the Master, having appeared in “The Destination Wars” with the (recast) First Doctor team, and once again seems to be playing a slightly less polished version of the Roger Delgado Master, which works pretty well for the story. The atmosphere makes this one nicely memorable.
docs.title: The Home Guard

docs.text: The Morton Legacy Early Adventures #4.3 Released: 14 September 2017 Listened: 57/21 This story begins with the TARDIS materializing in London, leading Ben and Polly to briefly believe they’ve gotten home, which sets them up to have conflicted feelings about leaving. However, it turns out to be the 1860s rather than the 1960s, they lose the TARDIS again, and in tracking it down stumble across a murder mystery. There’s safari explorers, treasures from dark continents, thugs from the workhouse, a mostly silent butler, and the lord’s lonely young daughter, who Jamie takes a shine to (and Ben and Polly won’t stop teasing him about). The Doctor thinks that the murders may be connected to one of the native artifacts, which may itself be extraterrestrial, but there’s a twist that I won’t spoil, except that it’s a twist that Doctor Who almost never goes for, possibly never at all. Still, the story takes a while getting to that twist, and I’m not certain this needed to be a full-length story. The Doctor has a bit more expository dialog than usual, and sometimes Frazer Hines’ natural accent shows through, but one can overlook that. It’s a fine installment, and the last appearance of Elliot Chapman in this project.
docs.title: The Morton Legacy

docs.text: The Mouthless Dead Companion Chronicles #10.1 Released: 23 June 2016 Listened: 9/22/20 This one is a spooky, atmospheric story. The TARDIS arrives at a train station in Devon in 1920, just before the train carrying the Unknown Warrior from WWI is due to pass by. The TARDIS is damaged on landing, and combined with the outpouring of grief in the area at the time, manifests ghosts of fallen soldiers. The story is tightly focused with one location and a only a few guest characters, which enhances the spooky feeling, much like “Midnight” or “Knock Knock” from the modern series. Jamie’s status as a man out of time is emphasized here, as he doesn’t understand trains or electricity, but he and Ben get to bond over their common military experience, which is needed if Big Finish is going to squeeze in more adventures with both of them. Polly gets split off on her own, in a plotline that once again emphasizes her empathy, but she has a moment of courage as well. Because it’s a Companion Chronicle, the Doctor doesn’t have as much to do, but he does get the exposition at the end, and geeks out rather a lot over the 1920s railway mechanisms, which is a very Second Doctor thing to do. The atmosphere is the important factor in this one, and it holds up quite well.
docs.title: The Mouthless Dead

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #10.1 Released: 23 June 2016 Listened: 9/22/20 This one is a spooky, atmospheric story. The TARDIS arrives at a train station in Devon in 1920, just before the train carrying the Unknown Warrior from WWI is due to pass by. The TARDIS is damaged on landing, and combined with the outpouring of grief in the area at the time, manifests ghosts of fallen soldiers. The story is tightly focused with one location and a only a few guest characters, which enhances the spooky feeling, much like “Midnight” or “Knock Knock” from the modern series. Jamie’s status as a man out of time is emphasized here, as he doesn’t understand trains or electricity, but he and Ben get to bond over their common military experience, which is needed if Big Finish is going to squeeze in more adventures with both of them. Polly gets split off on her own, in a plotline that once again emphasizes her empathy, but she has a moment of courage as well. Because it’s a Companion Chronicle, the Doctor doesn’t have as much to do, but he does get the exposition at the end, and geeks out rather a lot over the 1920s railway mechanisms, which is a very Second Doctor thing to do. The atmosphere is the important factor in this one, and it holds up quite well.
docs.title: The Mouthless Dead

docs.text: The Night Witches Early Adventures #4.1 Released: 14 September 2017 Listened: 5/9/21 Despite the title, there’s nothing supernatural going on in this story; it’s actually a true historical. It takes place in Russia, near St. Petersburg, during WWII, and the title refers to a group of women aviators, who flew crop-dusters and other old planes against the Germans. (The Night Witches are historically accurate, but the individual characters are invented for the story.) Which is pretty cool, except that when Polly turns out to be an exact double for their best pilot, they suspect the TARDIS crew of being spies who want to replace her. And Polly’s double happens to be a skilled mimic, so the law of plot convenience says that at some point she’ll replace Polly. For what it’s worth, the story doesn’t draw out the threat of the Doctor taking the doppelganger along and leaving Polly behind; the Doctor’s too smart for that. The rest of the story involves the usual mistrustful commanding officers, imprisonments, escaping, and trying to get back to the TARDIS. Polly doesn’t get to play action hero, but she does spend some time by herself lost in a nasty storm, without needing to be rescued, so that’s something. Ben gets a bit of a love interest, but just enough for the others to tease him, not an actual relationship. As pure historicals go, it’s decent, and somewhat dark, but not quite so bleak as historicals often are. It does end with the Doctor and friends essentially bailing in the middle of a pitched battle, which is unusual for them, but the Doctor is pretty clear that they can’t interfere in WWII, so it kind of makes sense.
docs.title: The Night Witches

docs.text: The Outliers Early Adventures #4.2 Released: 14 September 2017 Listened: 5/9/21 As the previous story in this boxed set was a pure historical, it makes sense that this one would be a sci-fi story. It’s by Simon Guerrier, who’s a top-tier Big Finish writer, but sometimes when these accomplished writers set out to evoke a certain era, they do so almost a bit too well. In this case, that means the pace is a bit languid, and makes the story feel overly drawn out. For example, the Doctor doesn’t appear in Episode 3, because he’s off talking to the aliens, and Ben, Polly and Jamie spend the whole episode being worried and coming up with various plans to rescue him, which he ultimately doesn’t need. As often happens in these sorts of stories, there’s a big corporation doing insensitive corporate sounding things for the “good of humanity,” and not noticing the indigenous life forms they’re harming until things start to go wrong. The manager who speaks only in corporate slogans and can’t get his head around the real problem is a bit of a wet dishrag this time around, so there’s less tedious shouting and threatening of executions, but he’s still not easy to deal with. I have to give credit to Guerrier’s writing of narration (spoken by Anneke Wills), who really evokes rather silly-seeming space-age corporate uniforms, and the prefab housing sets. It’s remarkably visual for an audio story.
docs.title: The Outliers

docs.text: The Selachian Gambit Companion Chronicles #6.8 Released: 10 February 2012 Listened: 9/26/20 This is a kind of story we haven’t really had in this era: a slightly silly one. The Doctor and friends are in a bank (trying to get some small bills to pay a parking fine for the TARDIS) when it’s robbed by the Selachians, shark-like aliens in mech suits. Created by Steve Lyons, they mostly appear in print, but they have a couple of audio appearances. Frazer Hines and Anneke Wills split the narration, with Frazer playing the Doctor as he does so nicely. There’s a bit more emphasis on Jamie, so Polly doesn’t get to play action girl as she’s done in the last few stories, but she does get a plotline of her own. This one is short, so there’s not a ton of time for plot, but there are a bunch of switches and betrayals -- it’s not quite a heist story, but it has some elements of one. I like a good heist story, which Doctor Who doesn’t do very often, so I’m fond of this one.
docs.title: The Selachian Gambit

docs.text: The Yes Men Early Adventures #2.1 Released: 15 October 2015 Listened: 9/23/20 Although the last story had a new-series feel, this one mostly has a more classic tone, appropriate for an Early Adventure. The crew goes to visit one of the Doctor’s old friends, and as often happens, finds that they’ve died. There’s a lot of references to the last time the Doctor was here, in his previous incarnation, with Dodo along, a story that’s never been told, but it causes some problems here, probably the earliest chronological instance of the “I was here before, but I looked different” problem. In proper classic fashion, the Doctor and Polly get split off from Jamie and Ben early on, and don’t meet up until close to the end. (Ben is mostly absent for Part 3, as if the actor had some time off.) The Doctor and Polly are busy trying to solve a murder, while Ben and Jamie get caught up in a robot revolution, which gives them some more time to bond. There is one distinctly new-series concept, though: what happens to the people left behind when the Doctor saves your world and then goes away. There’s a little “Christmas Invasion” twist going on. In keeping with the Big Finish revamp, Polly gets to be a bit more action hero when Ben and Jamie aren’t around, and also shows off her soccer skills. Since the Doctor has a larger role this time, Frazer Hines spends more time playing him, and some cracks show; his impersonation slips a bit when the Doctor needs to be forceful, or give a lot of exposition. Still, the Early Adventures tone is a nice contrast with the other stories so far.
docs.title: The Yes Men

docs.text: The Second Doctor, Jamie, and Victoria Deborah Watling (Victoria) suffered from having most of her TV stories lost, until “Tomb of the Cybermen” famously showed up. She did some Big Finish, but not a lot. Unfortunately, because she was a heavy smoker for most of her life, she had more difficulty than most companion actors in sounding like her younger character. As a result, this era only has a handful of stories in which she appears. This is the first time that both the companions have been from the past, relative to the viewer, which leaves Jamie acting as the more knowledgeable of the two, and often serving as protector, which Victoria lets him do. Victoria is also part of the “Season 6B” timeline, which accounts for “The Two Doctors.” It’s been supposed to take place after “The War Games,” but Big Finish also supplied an opportunity for it to exist here. That also creates a space to put stories where the Second Doctor is alone, or traveling with just Jamie, neither of which happened on TV.
docs.title: Second Doctor, Jamie, & Victoria

docs.text: Deleted Scenes Short Trips #10.2 Released: 14 February 2020 Listened: 9/30/20 This story seems to be set after Victoria’s departure, but before Zoe arrives. Unfortunately, there’s no gap there, so setting it here is perhaps the next best option. The Doctor and Jamie end up in Paris, in the early days of film, and run into Simone Tessier, an aspiring director. In typical artiste fashion, she’s got a vision for a film, but not really the money to make it, so she surrounds herself with various other artistic types, and folds Jamie into the mix, eventually falling for him. Unusually for a Short Trip, there’s a frame story, involving one of Simone’s descendants, and her research into her ancestor’s famous lost film, which features a cameo appearance by an entirely different Doctor and companion. The whole story has a bit of a gauzy feel to it, which is appropriate, given the setting. It’s also nice to let Jamie have an actual romance, as he never seems to have time for that in other stories. We’re back to Frazer Hines doing the narration and playing the Doctor and Jamie, all of which makes it feel rather more substantial than most Short Trips.
docs.title: Deleted Scenes

docs.text: Dumb Waiter Companion Chronicles #12.2 Released: 20 June 2018 Listened: 10/1/20 This story is a big deal, because it features a crossover with Leela, played by Louise Jameson. The Fourth Doctor uses a time ring to send Leela back to the Second Doctor’s time, because he remembers some, but not all, of an adventure he had then. There’s a lot of illusion and things that aren’t what they seem, but the main point is to put Leela and Jamie together...and have them fight, of course. Leela is kind of contemptuous of Jamie, calling him “Little Knife,” and it’s to Jamie’s credit that he doesn’t take the bait on that one. Louise Jameson is excellent as always, taking part of the narration and playing a fairly ridiculous side character with obvious relish. Frazer Hines plays the Doctor with his usual skill. Sadly, this was recorded shortly after Deborah Watling’s death, so she’s not available. Interestingly, Victoria is pathetic throughout most of this story, much more than in previous stories, and it’s suggested that she may want to leave off traveling. However, she finds her courage to a level that impresses even Leela. The crossover is the main draw, and it works effectively. It’s nice to see two of Big Finish’s most dedicated actors working together.
docs.title: Dumb Waiter

docs.text: Helicon Prime Companion Chronicles #2.2 Released: November 2007 Listened: 9/30/20 This is an early Companion Chronicle, so it has a frame story attempting to justify why Jamie sounds older, the usual trick of having older Jamie be the narrator, telling the story to a third party. Except Jamie shouldn’t remember his time with the Doctor, so there’s a bit of nonsense about him being struck by lightning, causing him to regain his memories. But that’s mostly unnecessary, because Frazer Hines does a great job portraying both younger Jamie and the Doctor. The story is specifically mentioned to take place while Victoria is away studying graphology, so during “The Two Doctors.” The Doctor and Jamie arrive at a fancy resort in an area of space that exudes tranquil vibes, so of course there are mysterious deaths right away, and they get caught up investigating them. The mystery, such as it is, isn’t terribly difficult to figure out, and like a lot of early Big Finish, ends a little anticlimactically. Still, without a companion, this is about as close to pure Frazer Hines as you’re likely to get.
docs.title: Helicon Prime

docs.text: The Black Hole, episodes 1 & 2 Early Adventures #2.3 Released: 17 November 2015 Listened: 9/29/20 This is an Early Adventure, the only one with Victoria, which means it’s a full-length story. However, it takes place with a distinct gap in the middle, from the Doctor’s point of view, so for this project, I’ll split them. The TARDIS lands on a space station, which is experiencing time dilations as a result of a gravitational anomaly. It turns out to be a black hole, and an unusual one at that. There’s another Time Lord present, a constable named Pavo. The Doctor is very nervous about meeting him, because the Doctor assumes Pavo will arrest him. But they’ve got bigger problems with the Black Hole, and they’re forced to do a sciency thing to close it, at the cost of Pavo’s TARDIS. That leaves him injured, and unable to complete his stated mission, to meet with Dastari, so the Doctor and Jamie go in his place, which leads into “The Two Doctors.” Deborah Watling, unfortunately, sounds her age, and not much like Victoria. There’s no attempt to cover it up; you just have to ignore it. The narration is provided by David Warner, and I’ll always listen to David Warner, but it’s odd that he doesn’t play a character at all. And finally, this is the first appearance of Rufus Hound in Big Finish, which is a spoiler if you’ve ever heard him before. This half of the story is mostly just setup, but it carries itself well for all that.
docs.title: The Black Hole part 1

docs.text: The Black Hole, episodes 3 & 4 Early Adventures #2.3 Released: 17 November 2015 Listened: 10/1/20 Now, having returned from Season 6B, the story continues. So I have to drop at least one spoiler: Pavo is actually the Monk, which is a trick that doesn’t work well anymore, because Rufus Hound has been playing the Monk (fabulously) in a bunch of other Big Finish stories. In fact, the Doctor and Jamie return before Part 1 of the story, which sets up the fact that there’s a big ball of timey-wimey in the second half of this story. With Simon Guerrier as the writer and John Dorney as the script editor, it’s hard to expect anything else. So as not to spoil, I’ll say that there are Time Lords, regenerations, Stattenheim remote controls, and a bunch of TARDIS vs TARDIS chess, but not necessarily in that order. There’s also an unusual piece of Time Lord tech (never seen again) which masks Time Lords from others of their species, and can influence the minds of lesser species (which for the Time Lords, means everybody), including performing memory wipes, which is how the writer gets away with a story that Jamie and Victoria can’t be allowed to remember. The monsters are very nearly irrelevant, as often happens in such stories, but they have an interesting visual. This makes for a fun, memorable story, whether you accept the “Season 6B” solution or not. I have to say, I’m more inclined to do so now, especially listening to other stories in the middle, as this project allowed me to do.
docs.title: The Black Hole part 2

docs.text: The Death of the Daleks Companion Chronicles #14.1 Released: 26 April 2022 Listened: 5/17/22 This 2022 release had been delayed for some time, probably because of covid-related reasons. It returns to the Companion Chronicles format of mostly being a story related by the companion to a third party, which keeps the cast small. As usual, Frazer Hines plays both Jamie and the Second Doctor. Victoria is stated to be asleep in the TARDIS, because this story explicitly takes place immediately after “Evil of the Daleks.” For all the time and energy spent on the Doctor wiping out the Daleks in the Time War, and revisiting the “do I have the right?” scene from “Genesis,” it’s often overlooked that the Doctor willingly wiped them all out before. And because TV was very episodic back in 1967, that was never dealt with. So this story mostly deals with the Second Doctor trying to decide if genocide was justified to rid the universe of the Daleks, and he mostly seems to think not, which makes sense at this point in his life. There’s also the idea of a kind of Dalek Grim Reaper that goes around erasing all evidence of Dalek defeats (including injured survivors) so that Dalek tech can’t fall into enemy hands. That bit doesn’t come off as well, but it’s mostly a thinky story, as opposed to an action one. The other character in the story is played by the famous Emma Samms, who does an excellent job as another person who sacrificed a lot to defeat the Daleks. It’s a grim story, but it fits nicely with what we know of later history.
docs.title: The Death of the Daleks

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #14.1 Released: 26 April 2022 Listened: 5/17/22 This 2022 release had been delayed for some time, probably because of covid-related reasons. It returns to the Companion Chronicles format of mostly being a story related by the companion to a third party, which keeps the cast small. As usual, Frazer Hines plays both Jamie and the Second Doctor. Victoria is stated to be asleep in the TARDIS, because this story explicitly takes place immediately after “Evil of the Daleks.” For all the time and energy spent on the Doctor wiping out the Daleks in the Time War, and revisiting the “do I have the right?” scene from “Genesis,” it’s often overlooked that the Doctor willingly wiped them all out before. And because TV was very episodic back in 1967, that was never dealt with. So this story mostly deals with the Second Doctor trying to decide if genocide was justified to rid the universe of the Daleks, and he mostly seems to think not, which makes sense at this point in his life. There’s also the idea of a kind of Dalek Grim Reaper that goes around erasing all evidence of Dalek defeats (including injured survivors) so that Dalek tech can’t fall into enemy hands. That bit doesn’t come off as well, but it’s mostly a thinky story, as opposed to an action one. The other character in the story is played by the famous Emma Samms, who does an excellent job as another person who sacrificed a lot to defeat the Daleks. It’s a grim story, but it fits nicely with what we know of later history.
docs.title: The Death of the Daleks

docs.text: The Emperor of Eternity Companion Chronicles #4.8 Released: 9 March 2010 Listened: 9/29/20 Another Companion Chronicle, read again by Deborah Watling. Frazer Hines is the guest star, but unusually, he’s just playing Jamie, not the Doctor. (This is an early recording, so Frazer’s expertise at playing the Doctor hadn’t been established yet.) As a result, the Doctor is absent for a large chunk of the story, and unusually quiet even when he’s present. It’s a true historical, set in China at the beginning of the Qin dynasty. There are omens and prophecy, strict caste rules, assassination plots, and lots and lots of disguises and hidden identities. Victoria isn’t an action girl this time, but with no monsters, she’s not reduced to screaming in terror either. Instead, the focus is on her compassion and capacity for forgiveness, as she mentions she’s even forgiven the Daleks who killed her father. (I’m not sure she had any reason to do that, but it’s consistent.) The depiction of ancient China seems consistent, as far as I can tell, with detailed descriptions of the Imperial palace, including the Terracotta Warriors. This isn’t the strongest pure historical, but it’s not bad. This is the last appearance of Deborah Watling in this project. She may not have done much for Big Finish, but I’m grateful for what she did, and she seems to have enjoyed it.
docs.title: The Emperor of Eternity

docs.text: The Evil of the Daleks TV Season 4, Serial 9 Aired: 20 May 1967 - 1 July 1967 Victoria joins. This is the first appearance of a Dalek Emperor, and the story seems to show the final end of the Daleks. At least, they won’t be seen again on TV for several years. Season 4 ends here, although it still leads directly into the next story…sort of.
docs.title: The Evil of the Daleks

docs.text: The Great Space Elevator Companion Chronicles #3.2 Released: August 2008 Listened: 9/28/20 This is a Companion Chronicle, one of the very few read by Deborah Watling, and it puts the spotlight squarely on Victoria. It features the Chronicles conceit of having an older Victoria relating a story that happened earlier in her life, explaining Watling’s much older-sounding voice. Her portrayals of the Doctor and Jamie aren’t the greatest, but that’s to be expected. The story involves a space elevator, as the title indicates, which makes the space-borne end a perfect “base under siege” scenario. Victoria displays a much greater sense of adventure and determination in this story than she has previously, disobeying instructions to stay put, and demanding to carry out a scouting mission on her own. She believes the Doctor and Jamie to be patronizing her at times. At other moments, though, she appears quite frightened, which matches her shifting characterization on TV. Writer Johnny Morris tries to fit in quite a lot of information about how electrical currents behave in magnetic fields, mostly by having the Doctor explain to Jamie and Victoria, who don’t follow much of it. Small trivial note: The Doctor plays his recorder, which the Second Doctor had mostly stopped using by this time on TV, but hasn’t appeared in Big Finish before now. It’s a fairly basic story, but it’s good to get inside Victoria’s head for a change.
docs.title: The Great Space Elevator

docs.text: The Last Day at Work Short Trips #8.X Released: 29 December 2018 Listened: 9/30/20 This extra 2018 Short Trip is the Paul Spragg Memorial award winner, by Harry Draper. On its face, it involves the policeman seen at the beginning of “An Unearthly Child” (and “Day of the Doctor”), but of course it’s rather more than that. In fact, it’s a bit surreal, and somewhat hard to credit, so it may be better viewed as one of those fairy-tale sorts of stories. Nick Briggs is the narrator, and unfortunately doesn’t do the best Second Doctor or Jamie, but it’s unfair to compare to Frazer Hines. It’s an interesting story, well-suited for a Christmas treat, if you don’t think too much about it.
docs.title: The Last Day at Work

docs.text: The Phantom Piper Companion Chronicles #14.2 Released: 26 April 2022 Listened: 5/18/22 This 2022 Companion Chronicle is specifically set during the gap in “The Black Hole,” with Jamie wanting to get back to the space station where Victoria is. This is an even smaller story than “The Death of the Daleks,” with only two actors. Of course Frazer plays both Jamie and the Doctor, but the Doctor is sidelined for most of the story, almost literally. They’ve landed on a planet where all citizens have brain implants called Shards, which are supposed to simply be a memory aid. As a visiting human, Jamie is forced to get one as well (the Doctor is exempt). However, the implant seems to be subtly changing Jamie’s persona, and the Doctor is concerned, so they consult with a scientist who worked on the implants. The story is entirely told through the sessions with the scientists, although other events are described. We also spend a lot of time in Jamie’s memories from before he met the Doctor. In that sense, it’s a rather nice dialog-driven story, almost like a “therapist and patient” story, but with a sci-fi twist. Of course, it depends on the scientist being reasonable and open to new interpretations of data, which isn’t really common for scientists in Doctor Who , especially from this era. Still, it makes for a refreshing story.
docs.title: The Phantom Piper

docs.text: The Story of Extinction Companion Chronicles #10.2 Released: 23 June 2016 Listened: 9/27/20 This story is from the first Companion Chronicles boxed set with the Second Doctor, so it would be odd not to have a story with Victoria in it. However, this is the final Big Finish appearance of Deborah Watling before her death in 2017. Unfortunately, the thing that stands out most is that she doesn’t really sound like Victoria at all here. If you can get past that, it’s a fairly straightforward sci-fi story. It’s one of those where a new piece of technology is introduced to the main characters and the listener, and sure enough, that particular technology (and the way it’s abused) ends up being the core of the story. It looks like Ian Atkins had some things to say about Internet culture and social media, but it’s not terribly subtle. From a character perspective, there’s an emphasis on Jamie and Victoria’s relationship, as he asks her to teach him to read, which is a pretty vulnerable thing for him to do. Victoria also has a bit of internal dialog, in which it’s made clear that she’s not exactly companion material, and the Doctor isn’t really keeping her safe, despite his best efforts. It’s a fine story, but not one that stands out.
docs.title: The Story of Extinction

docs.text: The Way Forwards Short Trips #2.2 Released: 28 February 2011 Listened: 10/1/20 Oddly, Victoria is in this story, but Jamie isn’t, not even in the TARDIS scenes. The Doctor turns up at a high school science fair attended by a boy named Sherman, who has created a theory of time travel that nobody understands. Of course, because this is a Doctor Who story, he’s got it mostly right, and when the Doctor fills in the rest for him, paradoxes ensue, causing havoc. It’s mostly absurd, and Sherman is a reference to the “Sherman & Mr. Peabody” cartoons, as are several other names. As long as you can sympathize with a teenager who thinks he’s smarter than everybody else (and he is), you’ll be fine.
docs.title: The Way Forwards

docs.text: The Web of Time The Diary of River Song #6.2 Released: 27 August 2019 Listened: 9/27/20 This story is from the boxed set where River was jumping into various classic episodes, this time a prequel to “The Web of Fear.” In fairness, this story doesn’t belong in this project, because River doesn’t encounter the Doctor or his companions, but I don’t like to pass up a John Dorney story. She does meet Captain Knight, a member of Lethbridge-Stewart’s command who’s killed by a Yeti in the later story. There’s continuity references galore, although this seems to be before “The Name of the Doctor” from River’s perspective, as she doesn’t mention having met the Intelligence before. It’s also somewhat talky, as Knight forces River to confront her amoral attitude toward historical events she participates in. It’s probably not the best of this boxed set, but it’s definitely worth a listen.
docs.title: The Web of Time

docs.text: Year of the Drex Olympics Short Trips #9.4 Released: 16 April 2019 Listened: 9/28/20 This is a Short Trip, and a rather absurd one at that. The TARDIS has landed on Venus, in the city of Drex, and the Doctor decides it’s time to learn some form of self-defense, so he tries to make a deal so he can learn Venusian aikido. The Venusians, at this point in time, are an array of genetic variations, but at least some are green with five arms and five legs. However, aikido isn’t what the story is about. Once again, the crew has lost the TARDIS, and has to compete in the Drexian games to get it back, which should go disastrously, but there’s a third party with an interest in them winning. Frazer Hines reads this story, so you get his excellent version of the Second Doctor as well as Jamie. Victoria once again pleads her fragility to try to get out of participating, but it goes better than she thinks. There are references to shanghorn, but no perigosto sticks or lullabies, unfortunately. It’s lightweight and fun, what you’d expect from a short trip.
docs.title: Year of the Drex Olympics

docs.text: The Second Doctor, Jamie, and Zoe Wendy Padbury (Zoe) is the most prolific Second Doctor companion, after Jamie, so this section has the most stories. She provides more of a contrast with Jamie, being from the future, and a mathematical genius (a fact she doesn’t hesitate to point out). Her intelligence puts her on the Doctor’s level at times, which causes friction with Jamie, but they generally value each other’s friendship.
docs.title: Second Doctor, Jamie, & Zoe

docs.text: A Stain of Red in the Sand Short Trips #1.2 Released: 5 November 2010 Listened: 10/10/20 This is the quintessential sort of early Short Trip, in which the Doctor and companions don’t really appear. It’s surreal, with a limited and uninformed narrator, who doesn’t really understand what’s going on. Only that her boyfriend’s apartment can see to another world where the Doctor is, and the boyfriend is doing something to help Zoe. It’s atmospheric, but that’s all that it is.
docs.title: A Stain of Red in the Sand

docs.text: Daughter of the Gods Early Adventures #6.2 Released: 13 November 2019 Listened: 10/7/20 This release got a lot of hype when it came out, because it features the chronologically earliest multi-Doctor story (assuming you count such stories as “belonging” to the “newest” Doctor involved). In this case, the Second Doctor’s TARDIS collides with the First Doctor’s, immediately after “The Myth Makers” and Katarina joining that crew. This is remarkable because Katarina dies in the very next story, “The Dalek Master Plan,” and there’s no room between them to fit another story. Further, actress Adrianne Hill passed away in 1997. But by this point, there’s no temporal restriction Big Finish can’t get around, and they cast Ajjaz Awad to take over the role. The TARDIS collision did a lot of damage, and both TARDISes end up on the same planet, with the First Doctor arriving about three months before the Second. This means the events of “The Dalek Master Plan” didn’t happen, and both crews find themselves in the middle of an alien invasion. Writer David Barnes splits everyone into pairs, so that Steven is with Zoe, and they work quite well together (although Steven finds Zoe a bit arrogant); Jamie is with Katarina, which works because they both relate to the Doctor and the TARDIS in similar manners, and Katarina triggers Jamie’s protective instincts. Of course, the highlight of any multi-Doctor story is putting the Doctors in the same room and watching sparks fly. The First Doctor has always been irascible, and going by the other multi-Doctor stories, the Second Doctor always seems to bring out the worst in...himself. There’s some awareness that this is Peter Purves and Frazer Hines, rather than Hartnell and Troughton, but if anyone’s earned the right to play the Doctor, it’s the two of them. Katarina, of course, is the core of this story, and while I haven’t seen enough of Adrianne Hill’s portrayal to tell how Ajjaz Awad imitates her, she definitely sells the character as someone mostly confused by her surroundings, but trying to cope based on what she knows. The story doesn’t shy away from her destiny, and if anything, the plot falls down a bit because the whole goal is to get history back on track, not to fix what’s going on in front of them. It’s not a huge triumph like “Day of the Doctor,” but it’s a very good two-Doctor episode.
docs.title: Daughter of the Gods

docs.text: Echoes of Grey Companion Chronicles #5.2 Released: 12 August 2010 Listened: 10/21/20 This Companion Chronicle is narrated by Wendy Padbury, which means it’s focused on Zoe. This is the first part of the frame story that leads into “The Memory Cheats,” with a mysterious Company, represented by an analyst named Jen, who wants to take advantage of Zoe’s perfect memory to recover things from her adventures that might be used to military advantage. In this case, it’s a hospital that’s curing the incurable, but at a cost. Because this is one of Zoe’s stories, she and the Doctor end up doing a lot of sciency stuff, which leaves Jamie mostly out in the cold. It makes for a sort-of base under siege story, where the siege is coming from within. There’s a higher than usual body count, depending on how you count it, but the monsters don’t really seem all that threatening. It’s a middle of the road story at best.
docs.title: Echoes of Grey

docs.text: Fear of the Daleks Companion Chronicles #1.2 Released: 19 February 2007 Listened: 10/2/20 This very early Companion Chronicle is Zoe’s first Big Finish appearance, as well as Wendy Padbury’s. It takes place immediately after Zoe joins the TARDIS, and even contains a recollection of the Doctor showing her “Evil of the Daleks” to cover the re-run. That sets up the rest of the story, where Zoe knows who the Daleks are. They’re not terribly effective in this story, although Zoe is justified in being afraid of them. They’re interfering in a war between two other species, as a cover to test a mind-projector device with the help of a collaborator. As part of the test, they take control of Zoe’s mind and attempt to force her to assassinate one of the leaders of the peace talks. This has the effect of keeping the narrative squarely on Zoe, with the Doctor’s role reduced, and Jamie altogether sidelined. That’s a good thing, because Wendy Padbury doesn’t really attempt to imitate either the Doctor or Jamie. She sticks with the frame story, of an older Zoe relating this story to a counselor, as if it were a dream. (The story points out what should be obvious -- for someone with an eidetic memory, having part of her memory wiped must be traumatic.) It’s a fairly bland story on the whole, overly talky, but not bad for starters.
docs.title: Fear of the Daleks

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #1.2 Released: 19 February 2007 Listened: 10/2/20 This very early Companion Chronicle is Zoe’s first Big Finish appearance, as well as Wendy Padbury’s. It takes place immediately after Zoe joins the TARDIS, and even contains a recollection of the Doctor showing her “Evil of the Daleks” to cover the re-run. That sets up the rest of the story, where Zoe knows who the Daleks are. They’re not terribly effective in this story, although Zoe is justified in being afraid of them. docs.text: Lepidoptery for Beginners Short Trips Rarities #1.3 Released: 30 September 2016 Listened: 10/18/20 This wonderfully titled Short Trip is one of the distinctly silly ones. In this case, the Doctor, Jamie, and Zoe meet an enemy that they can’t possibly hope to defeat, because he can predict the future with absolute accuracy. The title refers to the enemy’s ability to weaponize the Butterfly Effect, and as you might imagine, some of the chains of events become quite absurd. It would be criminal to say more than that, so I’ll just say that I enjoyed this one.
docs.title: Lepidoptery for Beginners

docs.text: Little Doctors Short Trips #5.2 Released: 6 February 2015 Listened: 10/11/20 Placed here because Zoe is described as a recent addition to the crew. One of the first monthly short trips, this one is rather bizarre. The TARDIS lands on an Earth colony run by an AI, and for once, it’s not a horrible dystopia; it’s just a bit boring -- to the Doctor; Zoe thinks it’s perfectly fine. The Doctor’s attempts to fix that only make things worse, in a fairly crazy manner, and it’s up to Zoe to solve the problem. Frazer Hines does the narration, which means that you get Jamie, the Doctor, and some other characters all as unique voices. It’s a little too strange for me, and the title plays into it in a way I didn’t expect.
docs.title: Little Doctors

docs.text: Lords of the Red Planet Lost Stories #4.3 Released: 15 November 2013 Listened: 10/21/20 Although the last Lost Story was kind of short, this one’s bumper-sized. It’s a six-parter, and each part is over 30 minutes. If this one had been made in Season 6, it likely would’ve replaced “Seeds of Death,” because it’s an Ice Warrior story. In fact, it’s trying to be a “Genesis of the Ice Warriors” story. The TARDIS crew arrive on Mars during Earth’s prehistory, so the Doctor thinks there won’t be any intelligent life around, but he’s got that wrong. In this case, the Ice Warriors are the product of deliberate genetic engineering, an attempt to create a slave race. It was adapted by John Dorney, but he sticks mostly to the outline of original writer Brian Hayles, who created the Ice Warriors, with none of Dorney’s typical trickery. The characters are rather two-dimensional, which befits a 60s story, but it’s a little unsatisfying to have to rely on for six parts. And unfortunately, because it’s a “genesis” type of story, the Doctor can’t fully succeed, as the Ice Warriors are needed further down the timeline. The casting is a family affair, with Michael Troughton and Charlie Hayes, Wendy Padbury’s daughter, both in major roles. Ultimately, it’s a decent enough story, but somewhat long.
docs.title: Lords of the Red Planet

docs.text: One Small Step Short Trips Bonus Released: 20 June 2016 Listened: 10/18/20 This is the shortest of short trips, barely an interlude. Read by Nick Briggs, it’s the story of a young boy, and his encounter with the Doctor on the day Niel Armstrong walked on the moon. But that’s not relevant to the story in any way. It’s also rather more scatalogical than I expect for a Doctor Who story. It’s not particularly important, just a kind of after-dinner mint.
docs.title: One Small Step

docs.text: Penny Wise, Pound Foolish Short Trips #4.2 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 10/11/20 This small Short Trip is fairly forgettable. The Doctor, Jamie, and Zoe land on a planet with a mine, and investigate the working conditions there. The story is mostly told from the point of view of an alien in the story, which should be interesting, but mostly just obscures what’s going on.
docs.title: Penny Wise, Pound Foolish

docs.text: Prison in Space Lost Stories #2.2 Released: December 2010 Listened: 10/10/20 The First and Second Doctors don’t have a lot in the way of Lost Stories, at least not in the sense of stories that were commissioned but never produced, so Big Finish can make them later. And honestly, this one probably deserved to stay lost, because it’s silly, but not in a good way. The TARDIS crew land somewhere in the future, when the Earth is controlled entirely by women, in particular Chairman Babs, who promptly develops a thing for the Doctor, against all logic. The Doctor and Jamie are sent to the titular prison, and Zoe is brainwashed. And honestly, that’s about all the plot there is, which is kind of amazing, given that it’s awfully long for a four-parter. Aside from the sexism inherent in the plot, most of the women are appalling stereotypes. They’re so caricatured that I have to believe it was intentional, in which case, Big Finish bears some responsibility. And the less said about the resolution, the better. I don’t think there’s anything redeemable about this story; it’s just terrible.
docs.title: Prison in Space

docs.text: Second Chances Companion Chronicles #8.12 Released: 17 June 2014 Listened: 10/22/20 This is the final part of the story that’s been cooking through the frame stories of the Zoe-narrated Companion Chronicles. This time, Jen from “Echoes of Grey” is back again, as is Kim from “The Memory Cheats,” but only in a non-speaking part. It’s written by John Dorney, rather than Simon Guerrier, and unusually for Companion Chronicles, it has one of Dorney’s timey-wimey plots, so only the first half plays out like a Companion Chronicle, and it would be criminal to say more than that. Zoe once again has the focus, both past and present, doing a bunch of computery stuff. This was the last Companion Chronicle before the series switched over to boxed sets, and also before the Early Adventures were introduced. Oddly, it has no extras, which is a shame. However, it does wrap up Zoe’s story very neatly, which is quite well done.
docs.title: Second Chances

docs.text: The Light at the End Destiny of the Doctor #2 Released: 1 February 2013 Listened: 10/14/20 This is one of the “Destiny of the Doctor” stories created for the 50th Anniversary in 2013. Which means the Doctor and companions act just a bit more stereotypically. It’s very much a base under siege story, with a side of invisible monster thrown in, which is a little gratuitous on audio, but it’s doing its best to be of the period. There’s also a bit of timey-wimey involved, but not a whole lot. The plot actually isn’t very much; it’s fairly basic, but in fairness, there’s only an hour of time to work with. As with the other stories in this series, there’s an insert from the Eleventh Doctor, but it’s relatively restrained. (I would have expected some gushing over bow ties, but no.) It’s read by Frazer Hines, which means you get the Doctor for free.
docs.title: Shadow of Death

docs.text: Destiny of the Doctor #2 Released: 1 February 2013 Listened: 10/14/20 This is one of the “Destiny of the Doctor” stories created for the 50th Anniversary in 2013. docs.text: The Apocalypse Mirror Companion Chronicles #7.11 Released: 8 May 2013 Listened: 10/22/20 This chronicle is fairly high-concept, with timeslips, worlds that exist when you believe in them, and transforming robo-death-birds. There’s no bad guy or monster, unless you count human stupidity, which is always the bad guy, isn’t it? The Doctor uses the Sonic Screwdriver more than usual for the Second Doctor, but writer Eddie Robson is careful only to have him use it to disassemble things, not as a universal hacking device, which is appropriate for the period. Both Frazer Hines and Wendy Padbury appear in this one, but unusually, the load is distinctly unequal. Frazer plays both Jamie and the Doctor, and has the bulk of the narration, whereas Zoe is sidelined for much of the story. This is a rare Companion Chronicle where I wonder what could have been done with a longer story, perhaps with a proper villain, but the setting is memorable as it is.
docs.title: The Apocalypse Mirror

docs.text: The British Invasion Short Trips #7.8 Released: 29 August 2017 Listened: 10/11/20 The TARDIS arrives in London, 1951, during the Festival of Britain. The Doctor is thrilled to visit the festival; his companions less so, because each is dealing with feelings of loneliness and isolation. This is one of the longer Short Trips, long enough to have an actual plot with a twist in it, which I won’t spoil. It’s read by Wendy Padbury, who doesn’t quite have the ability as a mimic that Frazer Hines has, which makes this one sound more like a narrated story than a performance, and oddly, Jamie sounds more stereotypically Scottish than usual. It’s a decent story that evokes a bit of history effectively.
docs.title: The British Invasion

docs.text: The Deepest Tragedian Companion Chronicles #14.4 Released: 26 April 2022 Listened: 5/21/22 This is another two-hander with just Zoe and another actor, in this case Richard Unwin. It’s also one of the more surreal style of story, in which Zoe is bored with the usual logic puzzles and asks for something different, which may or may not be what she gets. She ends up spending time with Tommy Waugh, a man who’s both an actor and a soldier at different points in his life, but he’s having memory problems. Acting out scenes helps piece the puzzle back together, and Zoe needs to realize that some things have aspects of a puzzle, but they’re also people with feelings that need to be taken into account. Although it’s possible to read Tommy as a WWI soldier from Earth, there are hints that he may be something more than that. In the manner of these sorts of stories, it’s deliberately unclear. So don’t follow this one just for the puzzle, or for the story, but for the emotions it creates. I don’t know if the Companion Chronicles will continue after this, and if this turns out to be Wendy Padbury’s last outing with Big Finish, it’s a pretty good one to end on.
docs.title: The Deepest Tragedian

docs.text: The Dying Light Companion Chronicles #8.6 Released: 19 December 2013 Listened: 10/5/20 This is the middle story of a trilogy that came out in 2013 for the 50th Anniversary, so it’s a sequel to “The Beginning.” That story was impressive because of when it was set, but this one suffers a bit from middle-story syndrome. The TARDIS lands on an interesting planet -- the seas are made of sand, and the solid rocks are porous, so they float. The inhabitants are entirely castaways, and they mostly eschew technology. However, Quadrigger Stoyn (played by Terry Malloy) from “The Beginning” is here, he’s even more desperate to get back to Gallifrey, and he still very much blames the Doctor. He’s sane enough not to blame Jamie and Zoe, but he’s willing to take insane risks to reach his goal. The resolution is a bit abrupt, and basically kicks the can down the road for the Fourth Doctor to deal with, but that’s middle stories for you.
docs.title: The Dying Light

docs.text: The Edge Companion Chronicles #10.4 Released: 23 June 2016 Listened: 10/23/20 This story focuses squarely on Jamie, to a greater degree than other stories. That’s nice, because this is the last time Frazer Hines gets to play a younger Jamie, and the Second Doctor. Frazer's other appearances feature an older Jamie, and the Doctor was played by Michael Troughton from this point on. The TARDIS crew lands on an asteroid devoted to academic research, which excites the Doctor and Zoe, but bores Jamie, and brings out feelings of inferiority, although he tries to hide it. It’s also a perfect setup for a base under siege, but that doesn’t happen. The Doctor and Zoe get sidelined fairly early in the story, which leaves Jamie to rescue them. He does so in his usual action-hero style, but he displays several instances of cleverness that indicate how much he’s learned about advanced scientific concepts since traveling with the Doctor. He’s no scholar, but he’s bright, and picks things up quickly, as almost all companions do. And he gets to display his steadfastness, loyalty, and even mercy. It’s a straight-up win for Jamie, which makes this a very nice story with which to end his official part in the project. This isn’t the last thing Frazer recorded for Big Finish, and I hope he gets to continue for a while yet.
docs.title: The Edge

docs.text: The Five Dimensional Man Short Trips #3.2 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 10/10/20 Also placed here pretty arbitrarily. Once again, the focus is on Zoe, although this time she actually appears. Specifically, she ends up in the living room of a 1950s housewife who’s also a budding science-fiction writer, with writer’s block. Betty is a stand-in for all of us who dream of the Doctor popping up and inviting us along for a trip. David Troughton does a good job with the American accents, but it’s not the most memorable story.
docs.title: The Five Dimensional Man

docs.text: Short Trips #3.2 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 10/10/20 Also placed here pretty arbitrarily. Once again, the focus is on Zoe, although this time she actually appears. docs.title: The Five Dimensional Man

docs.text: The Glorious Revolution Companion Chronicles #4.2 Released: 22 August 2009 Listened: 10/18/20 This is an early Companion Chronicle, so there needs to be a frame story: in this case, a Time Lord doing some research restores Jamie’s memories so he can hear a story firsthand. Specifically, the TARDIS crew ends up in London in 1688, at the “Glorious Revolution” when James II attempted to flee England (although Jamie steadfastly calls him James VII). For once, Jamie is the one most fully conversant with the history involved, and with strong personal feelings about it. Although he says that he merely wants to see the king, he ends up interfering and causing a paradox. The rest of the story is an attempt to set history right again. It’s interesting to see Jamie in an element where he’s comfortable, because that almost never happens in any story. Zoe, while present, has pretty much nothing to do, and barely factors into the story. This is Frazer Hines’ second Companion Chronicle, and he’s given more space to do his Second Doctor impersonation, which is only improved over his last outing. It’s a historical, and a decent one at that.
docs.title: The Glorious Revolution

docs.text: The Horror of Hy-Brasil Subscriber Short Trips #2017.2 Released: 23 June 2017 Listened: 10/13/20 Placed here, in defiance of Craig Brawley, because Zoe is stated to be a recent addition, and Big Finish says it takes place between “The Mind Robber” and “The Invasion,” although there’s no gap there. This is one of the bonus Short Trips, and an unusually long one in spite of that. It’s also one of those stories where ancient legends turn out to be Sufficiently Advanced Aliens. In this case, it’s the Irish legends of Hy-Brasil, Balor, and Eithne. Even though they’re Irish legends, Jamie is completely familiar with them, and they consider him to be one of the natives they’ve had contact with before. Balor is a scientist who accidentally doomed his people with some ill-considered time-travel experiments, and he wants the Doctor’s help. Of course, not everything is what it seems, which the Doctor seems to realize almost immediately, because he’s unusually wary and unhelpful. Stephen Critchlow narrates this one, and does a bit more voice acting than usual with the Doctor and Jamie, perhaps inspired by Frazer Hines. There’s an unusual amount of cruelty and body horror in this one, which doesn’t match the tone of the 1969 stories; it feels more like a Fifth or Sixth Doctor story. I imagine this one works better if you’re familiar with th Celtic legends the names are drawn from, but I’m not, so it falls a bit flat.
docs.title: The Horror of Hy-Brasil

docs.text: Subscriber Short Trips #2017.2 Released: 23 June 2017 Listened: 10/13/20 Placed here, in defiance of Craig Brawley, because Zoe is stated to be a recent addition, and Big Finish says it takes place between “The Mind Robber” and “The Invasion,” although there’s no gap there. This is one of the bonus Short Trips, and an unusually long one in spite of that. It’s also one of those stories where ancient legends turn out to be Sufficiently Advanced Aliens. In this case, it’s the Irish legends of Hy-Brasil, Balor, and Eithne. Stephen Critchlow narrates this one, and does a bit more voice acting than usual with the Doctor and Jamie, perhaps inspired by Frazer Hines. There’s an unusual amount of cruelty and body horror in this one, which doesn’t match the tone of the 1969 stories; it feels more like a Fifth or Sixth Doctor story. I imagine this one works better if you’re familiar with th Celtic legends the names are drawn from, but I’m not, so it falls a bit flat.
docs.title: The Horror of Hy-Brasil

docs.text: The Integral Companion Chronicles #10.3 Released: 23 June 2016 Listened: 10/12/20 After so many stories narrated by Frazer Hines, this one is narrated by Wendy Padbury, with Frazer playing Jamie and the Doctor. Not only does it provide a break (the Companion Chronicles were being released in boxed sets at this point, so listeners might hear them all in a row), but it also serves the story well. The TARDIS lands on a 21st-Century institute seeking a cure for people affected with a disease that makes them overly aggressive. There are aliens who generate a psychic pacifying field, but the corporation that owns the facility is trying to replace them with a mechanical solution. The field affects Jamie’s emotions as well, but not Zoe’s or the Doctor’s. Because it’s told from Zoe’s point of view, we can see her struggling to come to grips with the fact that her friend has a lot of aggression, because his culture required it, and he channels that into protectiveness. In a way, that’s more effective than Jamie trying to examine his own emotions. The story doesn’t mock Jamie, but it also doesn’t elevate him to “noble savage” status. There’s a bit of a mystery, but not really much of one. At its core, it’s a base-under-siege story, and while it’s not bad, it’s not particularly memorable either.
docs.title: The Integral

docs.text: The Iron Maid Companion Chronicles #12.3 Released: 20 June 2018 Listened: 10/6/20 This one is atmospheric, somewhat spooky, and slow-paced, almost like an old-school story. It also has the spotlight squarely on Zoe. The TARDIS crew lands in 14th-century France, where a time rift has opened to World War I, causing the French village to become abandoned, save for one young woman who believes she’s having religious visions. (Not Joan of Arc; Marie is a historical figure, but predates Joan.) Zoe puts together what’s going on, with the Doctor’s help, while Jamie is nearly out of the story entirely. Wendy Padbury does the narration and most of the acting; sometimes even narrating the Doctor’s and Jamie’s lines, although Frazer Hines is in the story. It’s a reasonable time-rift kind of story, although I don’t think it’s quite as spooky as it wants to be. If you enjoy the unraveling of this kind of mystery, you’ll like it. I found it to be somewhat forgettable, unfortunately.
docs.title: The Iron Maid

docs.text: The Isos Network Early Adventures #2.4 Released: 13 January 2016 Listened: 10/4/20 This one is Nick Briggs’ attempt (as writer and director) to recreate as much as possible a story from Season 6, and...it kind of shows. Although Season 6 has some classic stories, they’ve got an awful lot of running around and shooting at things, without much high concept at all, and that’s what this story is. Some Cybermen have escaped after “The Invasion,” and the TARDIS crew tries to track them down on Isos II, a planet that was overwhelmed by Cybermen long ago and its entire population converted. There’s a ship full of space soldiers, but they don’t really contribute a whole lot; they don’t even particularly slow the Doctor down by failing to trust him. There are some giant slugs that can be ridden, which would make for an interesting visual if there were any. Because both Wendy Padbury and Frazer Hines were proficient by the time they recorded this, they swap off the narration, with Wendy narrating Jamie’s scenes, and Frazer narrating Zoe’s, which is a switch from how these stories are usually done. The soundtrack, as well, is very of-the-era, with some rather jarring horns that jump in a lot. I think Nick Briggs achieved what he was looking for, but I don’t find a reproduction of that era to be terribly compelling, I’m afraid.
docs.title: The Isos Network

docs.text: The Jigsaw War Companion Chronicles #6.11 Released: May 2012 Listened: 10/18/20 We’re back to another Jamie-focused story. In this case, there’s no narration at all, and no flashbacks, except in the vaguest sense. It’s a two-hander between Jamie and his interrogator Moran, except that sometimes Moran is taken over by a different entity, and the Doctor speaks through Jamie. It’s all timey-wimey, with scenes taken out of order, with Jamie trying to figure out the sequence. It’s set against a backdrop of the Doctor helping oppressed aliens, but the story leads Jamie to wonder if maybe the Doctor’s gotten it wrong for once. According to the extras, it’s possible to play the parts of the story in the correct order, but the download I have doesn’t allow that. Ultimately, the success or failure of the story depends entirely on how interesting you find the puzzle, and whether you’re willing to listen to it again to put it all together. Although I normally like timey-wimey stories, I didn’t find this one terribly compelling.
docs.title: The Jigsaw War

Jamie and Zoe don’t have any part in the story, just some cameo lines. There’s also a temporal projection with Polly and Ben, from just after “The Power of the Daleks.”

docs.text: The Memory Cheats Companion Chronicles #6.3 Released: 15 September 2011 Listened: 10/14/20 This is another Companion Chronicle read by Wendy Padbury, so Zoe has the focus, rather than Jamie. It’s also one of the connected ones where the frame story is almost as important as the flashback, if not moreso. Zoe tells her interrogator Kim this story, of when she, Jamie, and the Doctor land in a small village in Uzbekistan, shortly after the Russian Revolution, where the children are disappearing. The Doctor does his usual trick of letting the village believe he’s a government official sent to investigate, which works fine...until the official actually turns up. Zoe finds the official compelling, as well as his description of the new Soviet government. An idealized Communist system is what Zoe believes she was brought up in, so it appeals to her. Of course, what’s taken the children isn’t anything ordinary, but how that gets resolved is ambiguous. Zoe herself becomes an unreliable narrator, or maybe she’s pulling a Keyser Soze, or maybe she really doesn’t remember. It’s an unusual track for a Companion Chronicle to take, and it’s only possible because it’s part of a linked series of stories. That makes the story rather interesting.
docs.title: The Memory Cheats

docs.text: The Prints of Denmark Companion Chronicles #14.3 Released: 26 April 2022 Listened: 5/19/22 The first two stories of this boxed set featured Frazer Hines, but the last two feature Wendy Padbury. In this case, the second actor is Rufus Hound, which is a bit of a cheat, because that provides a pile of other voices as well. But if it’s Rufus Hound, then there must be the Monk, which is usually good fun. This story doesn’t take itself entirely seriously, as you can tell from the title. It’s based on a throwaway line from “The Time Meddler,” in which the Monk says he wants to change history so that the premiere of Hamlet in 1601 is televised. Zoe has gone off on her own, and the Monk swoops her up as a pseudo-companion, presumably because the Doctor and Jamie would recognize him, after “The Black Hole,” but Zoe wouldn’t. What follows is typical Monkish nonsense, as he tries to pervert Earth’s history to his own benefit. There’s plenty of funny dialog here, usually poking fun at Zoe’s ignorance of popular culture in history (although she knows who the Spice Girls are). And Zoe pulls out her clever-clogs persona when she tries to beat the Monk at his own game. In the end, there’s a twist that indicates this story isn’t as straightforward as it seemed. Rufus Hound is a delight as usual; the only thing more fun than smug Monk is apoplectic Monk, and this story has lots of the former, and a bit of the latter. The only narrative flaw is when Zoe appears to be talking to the Doctor and Jamie, but we only hear her side of the conversation. It’s a conceit of the Companion Chronicles style, but most stories work around it better. Still, this story seems to be the highlight of the set.
docs.title: The Prints of Denmark

docs.text: The Queen of Time Lost Stories #4.2 Released: 29 October 2013 Listened: 10/19/20 Now we’re on to a couple of Lost Stories, which are usually longer than Short Trips and Companion Chronicles. As it happens, this one is kind of short, as Lost Stories go, because there’s not a lot of plot to go around. The TARDIS gets trapped by one of those omnipotent beings, specifically one the Doctor seems to know, who has some mastery over time. She seems to just want the Doctor to play games, making this much like “The Celestial Toymaker,” only with less Towers of Hanoi, and more flirting. Frazer Hines and Wendy Padbury tag-team this one, and Lost Stories from the first three Doctors tend to be heavily narrated, so they’re doing a lot of talking. The story itself is pretty surreal, and I can see why they wouldn’t have wanted it in the same season as “The Mind Robber.” The descriptions of some of the scenes are actually disturbing, and I believe they were intended to be, although I wonder how that would have worked out on TV. Although it’s certainly a better story than “Prison in Space,” there doesn’t seem to be quite enough going on to justify a full four-parter.
docs.title: The Queen of Time

docs.text: The Rosemariners Lost Stories #3.8 Released: 19 September 2012 Listened: 7/31/22 This Lost Story is much less offensive than “Prison in Space.” In fact, it’s pretty normal for the era, if a bit dull. According to the extras, it was written by regular writer Donald Tosh, and they just never got around to producing it. The TARDIS lands on a scientific space station where one of the main researchers is botanist Arnold Biggs, played by the estimable David Warner. For once, he’s not a bad guy, nor even suspected of being a bad guy. The Doctor takes to him almost immediately, and he’s on their side through the whole story. The station is taken over by the titular Rosemariners, aliens from the planet Rosa Damascena, and boy do these guys like roses. Like, a lot. Roses are necessary for their life cycle, and now they’re trying to find a way to turn roses into weapons. Specifically, the rosa toxicaera, developed by Daleks on Kembel, along with the varga plants. What follows is a lot of running back and forth between the station and the Rosemariners’ ship, bluffs and double-bluffs, mistaken identity, and lots of talk about roses. Clive Wood (who once played a Roman commander in “The Pandorica Opens”) plays the Rosemariner commander as a straight villain, sneering, berating his underlings, and even letting out a full-blown evil cackle during one cliffhanger. Frazer Hines does his usual fantastic job as the Second Doctor. Wendy Padbury gets all the female parts, of which there aren’t many, and also plays the station commander, who has a ridiculous French accent (not particularly well). There isn’t really much to recommend this as a story, except that the actors all seem to be having a grand time.
docs.title: The Rosemariners
