docs.text: The Tactics of Defeat Companion Chronicles #12.4 Released: 20 June 2018 Listened: 10/23/20 This one is quite unusual, in that it’s not really a Companion Chronicle at all. It’s told by Captain Ruth Matheson, played by Daphne Ashbrook (Grace Holloway), and in the present tense, but her colleague Charlie Sato isn’t present. There’s no narration, for one thing, and the first half of the story is just Ruth verbally sparring with a bad guy played by Matthew Brenher, using an Australian accent, so there are no proper English accents for the first half-hour. Wendy Padbury plays Zoe, but the Doctor and Jamie are taken out of action almost immediately, presumably to give Frazer Hines a break, because he was already in the other three stories in this boxed set. The story ties more to Ruth’s other Big Finish appearances (even a Short Trip) than it does to anything Zoe’s done; she just happens to be the one here for this part. It’s a somewhat twisty story, fitting for one set in a Mayan temple, but how much you enjoy it depends on whether you want a Second Doctor story or a modern-series-ish story.
docs.title: The Tactics of Defeat

docs.text: The Uncertainty Principle Companion Chronicles #7.2 Released: August 2012 Listened: 10/18/20 This is one of the Companion Chronicles that’s linked to several others (like Steven’s trilogy following “The Savages,” or Sarah Kingdom’s trilogy), and the frame stories go in a different chronological order than the flashbacks (most of them written by Simon Guerrier). In all of these, the frame story is nearly as important as the flashback, which makes sense, because Zoe shouldn’t remember traveling with the Doctor, yet she has an eidetic memory, so there’s a conflict. In this case, the frame story comes after “Echoes of Grey” and “The Memory Cheats,” so you might want to listen to those first. Starting in “Echoes of Grey,” parts of her memories have started to come back, which means the Company (whoever they are) is interested, and has Zoe arrested on charges of sedition. The story is told as Zoe is interviewed by an agent named Kim. Wendy Padbury narrates, so Zoe has the focus this time. Jamie gets one big heroic thing to do, but is mostly sidelined for this story. Which makes sense, because it’s also one of those where Simon Guerrier is showing off his research, this time into quantum computing, an area outside of Jamie’s experience. Some of the science is a bit dodgy, unfortunately, including the definition of superposition, but it holds up well enough for the story. Zoe also gets a romantic interest, a doomed one, but it’s there. In the frame story, Jen is played by Wendy Padbury’s daughter Charlie Hayes, which doesn’t make a difference to the story, but it makes the extras fun. The frame story continues from here to “Second Chances,” down near the end of this era.
docs.title: The Uncertainty Principle

docs.text: Companion Chronicles #7.2 Released: August 2012 Listened: 10/18/20 This is one of the Companion Chronicles that’s linked to several others (like Steven’s trilogy following “The Savages,” or Sarah Kingdom’s trilogy), and the frame stories go in a different chronological order than the flashbacks (most of them written by Simon Guerrier). In all of these, the frame story is nearly as important as the flashback, which makes sense, because Zoe shouldn’t remember traveling with the Doctor, yet she has an eidetic memory, so there’s a conflict. In this case, the frame story comes after “Echoes of Grey” and “The Memory Cheats,” so you might want to listen to those first. Starting in “Echoes of Grey,” parts of her memories have started to come back, which means the Company (whoever they are) is interested, and has Zoe arrested on charges of sedition. The story is told as Zoe is interviewed by an agent named Kim. Wendy Padbury narrates, so Zoe has the focus this time. Jamie gets one big heroic thing to do, but is mostly sidelined for this story. Which makes sense, because it’s also one of those where Simon Guerrier is showing off his research, this time into quantum computing, an area outside of Jamie’s experience. Some of the science is a bit dodgy, unfortunately, including the definition of superposition, but it holds up well enough for the story. Zoe also gets a romantic interest, a doomed one, but it’s there. In the frame story, Jen is played by Wendy Padbury’s daughter Charlie Hayes, which doesn’t make a difference to the story, but it makes the extras fun. The frame story continues from here to “Second Chances,” down near the end of this era.
docs.title: The Uncertainty Principle

docs.text: The War Games TV Season 6, Serial 7 Aired: 19 April 1969 - 21 June 1969 The monster-length televised final story for the Second Doctor, and also the departures of Jamie and Zoe. Introduces the Time Lords and Gallifrey. The Doctor is put on trial, convicted, and exiled to Earth, setting up the major changes of the Third Doctor era. This is the final story of Season 6.
docs.title: The War Games

docs.text: The Way of the Empty Hand Short Trips #5.10 Released: 22 October 2015 Listened: 10/11/20 This is a fairly straightforward story about the TARDIS crew ending up on one of those worlds where conscripted warriors participate in arena combat for the amusement of a despot. However, because this is a Short Trip, they’re really no match for various non-violent methods of conflict resolution, or Zoe’s programming skills. As usual, Frazer Hines provides multiple characters, which elevates it above the standard short trip.

docs.text: The Wreck of the World Early Adventures #4.4 Released: 13 December 2017 Listened: 5/11/21 This is the only story with Jamie and Zoe from this particular boxed set. The TARDIS lands on the wreck of a generation ship launched in the late 21st century because of some disaster about to befall the Earth, but it never reached its destination, and has become a bit of a legend. There’s a party of scavengers on the ship as well, looking to retrieve Earth artifacts that had been aboard the ship. Writer Timothy X Atack unfolds the story gradually over the four episodes, with things being not what they seem, and the threat gradually evolving as the story goes on. The plot itself is a bit slow, but the secondary characters are diverse and interesting, from the dilapidated robot that’s all that remains of the ship to the diverse members of the scavenger crew. All of the characters get rather sharp dialog, even TARDIS crew, who are perhaps a bit verbally quicker than they would have been in the 1960s. It’s a decent story on the whole, although the resolution may be a bit predictable.
docs.title: The Wreck of the World

docs.text: The Second Doctor and the Time Lords Sometime in 2021, Big Finish embarked on a shake-up of their series lines. They’d had success recasting the Third Doctor with Tim Treloar, so they recast the First with Stephen Noonan, but the Second was a bit trickier. The Second Doctor up to this point only existed in Early Adventures and Companion Chronicles, almost always played by Frazer Hines, whose portrayal had a bit of caricature to it. Instead, the Doctor is played by Michael Troughton, son of Patrick, brother of David, and himself an occasional Big Finish actor, as well as having a small part in the TV series in “Last Christmas.” His portrayal is more naturalistic, sometimes sounding very much like his father; other times not. One can get used to it fairly quickly. The overall plot matches the “Season 6B” theory that fans invented to explain the inconsistencies in “The Two Doctors,” despite the fact that Big Finish already explained that in “The Black Hole,” sorta-kinda. Most of the stories in this section are considered to be "The Second Doctor Adventures," although Big Finish doesn't seem to officially number them, and instead refers to them by the title of the boxed set.
docs.title: Second Doctor & the Time Lords

docs.text: Jamie Second Doctor Adventures #2.1 Released: 25 July 2023 Listened: 9/2/23 Having established the Season 6B conceit, it’s time to get Jamie on board. This boxed set is devoted to, and named after, James Robert McCrimmon, making it a bit absurd to name the first story after him as well. The TARDIS lands in Edinburgh, 1776, once again at the direction of the enigmatic Time Lady named Raven. In the manner of CIA agents, she won’t tell him why he’s here. However, a much older Jamie is imprisoned in Edinburgh Castle, having revealed his former Jacobite status in a bar fight. He’s not doing well, frequently feverish, and with dreams that are flashbacks, to the Battle of Culloden, to the planet Zeiton, to a time when he was Laird of Clan McCrimmon, and a time where he was mocked for claiming to know the future. It’s a little fuzzy whether those are memories, alternate timelines, or what, and the story doesn’t explain. Since Jamie isn’t supposed to have those memories, it’s clear something is going on, which is where the Doctor comes in. The story is only a two-parter, so there isn’t a ton of time for plot, not when there’s a reunion to arrange. There are also an unusual number of bystanders killed off, which is a bit unusual for this kind of story. Daisy Ashford appears as a medical student, but there doesn’t seem to be any greater significance to that. It’s clear that Frazer Hines bears no ill-will for being replaced as the Second Doctor, but I don’t know what his companion status will be now.
docs.title: Jamie

docs.text: The Final Beginning Second Doctor Adventures #1.1 Released: 6 July 2022 Listened: 7/31/22 Kicking off the boxed set entitled "Beyond War Games," this somewhat odd story gets the ball rolling. It’s short, barely over an hour, but still consists of four parts. It’s written by series producer Mark Wright along with Nick Briggs, who also directs. The Doctor is snatched from the very end of “The War Games” by the CIA, which the Doctor has never heard of at this point. We’re told that the Third Doctor’s adventures are in fact happening, and even get snippets of “Spearhead from Space” reproduced by Tim Treloar and John Culshaw. Treloar is also present as a different character in the story, using his own accent, but that’s close enough to his Doctor to be just a bit strange. As for the story itself, it’s rather mysterious. Something has gone awry with the Web of Time. The Doctor apparently destroyed the Daleks for good in “Evil of the Daleks,” except we know full well they come back again, so what’s going on? It also provides an opportunity to tie in to the Doctor’s guilt in “The Death of the Daleks,” released around the same time. But there’s not really much “story” here. There’s some plot, but it pretty much just stops, rather than resolving. It feels like it accomplishes its goal of setting up the Doctor working with the CIA, drops a bunch of hints, and then quits.
docs.title: The Final Beginning

docs.text: The Green Man Second Doctor Adventures #2.2 Released: 25 July 2023 Listened: 9/6/23 Now that we’ve got Jamie, he and the Doctor can go off having Series 6B-type adventures, which they do in a montage sequence that includes the Third Doctor story “The Annihilators,” but also leaves plenty of room for other stories. It’s pretty clear that Raven isn’t to be trusted, and although the Doctor thinks she works for the CIA, I have my doubts. When Jamie complains about wanting a break, she sends them to a health resort called “The Grove,” with a bit of a mission to retrieve a missing Time Lord. Of course, there’s all sorts of trouble, and nothing is what it seems. The Doctor and Jamie get to work their double-act of pretending to be stupid while actually doing something else altogether. Jamie ends up doing a lot of the physical work, as the Doctor is confined to a wheelchair as part of their cover story. In fact, Jamie seems to be asked to do a lot, for someone of his age, who only had access to 18th Century health care for most of his life. It’s probably better to think of him not as the Jamie on the cover (Frazer Hines’ age at the time of recording), but rather as the 40-ish Jamie of “The Two Doctors.” Newish writer Paul F Verhoeven intended this story to be an homage to Rear Window, which is pretty clear, but it’s not long enough to have more than surface similarities. In fact, the story as a whole seems rather short. It starts at a sedate pace, fitting for its era and the Rear Window reference, but it feels like it skips Act 2 and goes right to the climax. A lot of the early-Doctor stories try to capture the feel of the original stories, and so feel padded. It’s pretty rare for one to feel too short.
docs.title: The Green Man

docs.text: The Piltdown Men Subscriber Short Trips #2014.4 Released: 19 December 2014 Listened: 9/30/20 This is an extremely short Short Trip, only 17 minutes. There’s not really time for much of a plot -- the Doctor is investigating the Piltdown Man phenomenon, and of course it’s alien, not a hoax. H.G. Wells is along for some reason, and the Doctor drags him into a very brief visit to an alien culture. Hugh Ross is the narrator for this story, and doesn’t do a great job of portraying the Second Doctor, especially not when contrasted to all these Frazer Hines stories. Placement of this story is annoying, because the Second Doctor seems to be alone, which he never was, so Craig Brawley has placed it here.
docs.title: The Piltdown Men

docs.text: The Shroud Second Doctor Adventures #2.3 Released: 25 July 2023 Listened: 9/7/23 It’s another mission where the Doctor and Jamie are dropped in without instructions. The planet Nineveh has been attacked by something called the Shroud, which blocks off their sun, and any form of artificial light as well. That’s bad news for the human colony there, but an interesting twist for audio, as the characters spend a while in total darkness. It seems like a simple case of alien invasion, but of course all is not what it seems. The mystery isn’t exactly a ton of mystery, although it is a story that’s specific to Time Lords, so that’s good. Writer Boy Ayers is another new Big Finish writer, and he seems more interested in the high concepts than the specifics of the plot. He does write the Second Doctor fairly well, though; he seems a bit more relaxed and jovial than he sounded in the past box. There’s also an appearance by the Doctor’s recorder, and a very brief one by the sonic screwdriver, both of which feel very appropriate. This is a pretty good one, playing with the “base under siege” format. It ends on a cliffhanger, as Big Finish tends to do in the second box of a series, when they know they’ll be continuing on.
docs.title: The Shroud

docs.text: Wrath of the Ice Warriors Second Doctor Adventures #1.2 Released: 6 July 2022 Listened: 8/1/22 Having established a new and previously unheard of situation for the Second Doctor, Big Finish immediately decided to play it safe. So we have a team-up with the Brigadier, against the Ice Warriors. This Brigadier is from roughly the same point in time as the Doctor, so he hasn’t seen Ice Warriors, has never seen the TARDIS, and knows nothing about regeneration. (This explains, in part, why the Brigadier seems to know a bit more about the Doctor than he should when the Third Doctor’s era begins.) Andrew Smith is the writer, but he doesn’t really lean into his usual “bad guy isn’t actually evil” approach, at least not in the main. The story is set in Scotland, and Lucie Goldie provides a lovely Scots accent as temporary companion Sheena Flynn. John Culshaw plays the Brigadier with his usual skill, and the surprise guest for this one is Katy Manning playing Ice Warrior royalty. She somehow straddles the line of doing a perfect Ice Warrior while still managing to sound like Katy Manning, which may not have been what they were going for. Michael Troughton is slightly more comfortable in this story, at times sounding quite a bit like his father. Where the story really excels is capturing the Second Doctor’s essential “Doctor-ness,” the qualities that have informed just about every actor since: His curiosity, his flippancy at inappropriate times, his willingness to laugh at authority, and the confidence he exhibits when he’s found the answers. The moments when he gets the Brigadier’s call sign wrong (intentionally? who knows?) are a beautiful encapsulation of their relationship. The actual resolution of the plot is a bit of a let-down, because it’s been done too many times before. And there’s not much here to resolve the greater mystery of what the CIA wants with the Doctor, just a hint about future stories. But there will be future stories, and that’s to the good.
docs.title: Wrath of the Ice Warriors

docs.text: The Seventh Doctor The Seventh Doctor, like the Fifth and Sixth, has been in Big Finish since the start of the Main Range in 1999, so he’s got a lot of stories. And a large number of them feature Ace, because she was still with the Doctor when the classic series ended, she’s so dedicated to the Doctor that it seems impossible to write her out, and Sophie Aldred has been a willing Big Finish participant the entire time. Like the Sixth Doctor, the Seventh Doctor’s TV stories all come fairly early in his tenure, and then Big Finish was free to go nuts. Well, more or less. From 1989, when the show went off the air, to 1996, when the Eighth Doctor appeared, there were a number of original novels written featuring the Seventh Doctor and various companions, and unlike all the other Doctors, Big Finish tried to work around them, which complicates the timeline. The novels also emphasized the Seventh Doctor’s darker, more manipulative side, and their placement in this timeline means that most of Big Finish emphasizes that part too. But the stories go on long enough that there’s also a reflective, regretful Doctor at the end of his tenure.
docs.title: Seventh Doctor

docs.title: The Seventh Doctor

docs.text: The Seventh Doctor and Ace Ace has a reputation as one of the best of the Classic Series companions, and it’s pretty well-deserved. She’s a much more active character, with her own goals. She sees herself more as a partner to the Doctor than an assistant, and she resents when he treats her as lesser...which unfortunately happens rather a lot, starting here. This stint with Ace includes the remainder of the TV stories, in which the Doctor’s personality became darker and more manipulative. It also, for the first time in this project, includes some novels. The novels started out almost immediately after the TV show ended, and took the characters to a more mature place than television would have allowed. However, that meant that the Doctor’s “chessmaster” personality manifested even more strongly, causing more friction between him and Ace. The novels are included in this timeline because Big Finish tried to work the novels into one seamless continuity in this era, which they don’t often do with the other Doctors.
docs.title: Seventh Doctor and Ace

docs.text: Ace has a reputation as one of the best of the Classic Series companions, and it’s pretty well-deserved. She’s a much more active character, with her own goals. She sees herself more as a partner to the Doctor than an assistant, and she resents when he treats her as lesser...which unfortunately happens rather a lot, starting here. This stint with Ace includes the remainder of the TV stories, in which the Doctor’s personality became darker and more manipulative. It also, for the first time in this project, includes some novels. The novels started out almost immediately after the TV show ended, and took the characters to a more mature place than television would have allowed. However, that meant that the Doctor’s “chessmaster” personality manifested even more strongly, causing more friction between him and Ace. The novels are included in this timeline because Big Finish tried to work the novels into one seamless continuity in this era, which they don’t often do with the other Doctors.
docs.title: The Seventh Doctor and Ace

docs.text: Animal Lost Stories #2.5 Released: 2 June 2011 Listened: 11/17/20 This story continues again from the previous, giving this season a much more tightly coupled feeling than I think would have been normal on TV. Raine gets her first trip, but it’s just a few years into her future, to the early 21st century, which is strange enough for her, dealing with cell phones and the Internet. She and Ace have to go undercover as university students, which should present a lot of fun opportunities for sniping (Raine went to uni; Ace didn’t), but that part doesn’t last very long at all. In fact, this story has a rather unusual structure, much like the last one, where the “monsters” don’t turn up until halfway through the story. Moreover, there are two sets of monsters, and they have nothing to do with one another: sentient plants, which aren’t ever really explained, and the Numlocks, which I imagine Cartmel named by looking at his keyboard. They’re also extremely polite and dull aliens, which causes the story to drag a little. The part that doesn’t drag is the return of Brigadier Winifred Bambera from “ Battlefield ,” who’s a fantastic character, and Angela Bruce is clearly enjoying the heck out of her. It’s a shame she doesn’t pop up more often on audio. At the end, Raine decides to stick around on Earth for a bit, so the Doctor and Ace leave without her. Once again, we have a strong set of characters, but the story doesn’t give them much interesting to do.
docs.title: Animal

docs.text: Colditz Main Range #25 Released: 22 October 2001 Listened: 11/24/20 This is one of my favorite stories from this era, because of the number of twists in it, but it’s also remarkably dark. The Doctor and Ace end up at Colditz Castle, shortly before the end of the war, and are promptly separated. Ace is watched by Kurtz, played by a young David Tennant, who’s pretty much a textbook bullying junior officer, petty and cruel, except his German accent slips a bit when he gets shouty, which he has to do a lot. Ace is being slightly too cavalier about the danger they’re in at first, especially when it comes to the contents of her rucksack, which includes some Nitro-9 and a portable CD player containing a laser. The Doctor, on the other hand, meets scientist Elizabeth Klein, a character so awesome she’ll recur for many years. She’s the real danger, as she knows about the TARDIS and the Doctor’s weak points. Exactly what’s going on with Klein takes a while to unravel, leaving this as one of those early Big Finishes that don’t so much build to a climax as come to an end with an explanation of what’s been happening all along behind the scenes. Ace gets a dose of maturity in this episode, as a result of the bleak surroundings. She decides to go by her real name for a while. This one is memorable because it’s so atmospheric, and because of Klein’s story, but it doesn’t really resolve well, at least, not for a long time to come.
docs.title: Colditz

docs.text: Crime of the Century Lost Stories #2.4 Released: 18 May 2011 Listened: 11/16/20 This story continues from the previous, and includes several of the same characters, although a lot of time has passed for some of them. It’s also the introduction of Raine Creevy, played by Big Finish stalwart Beth Chalmers, who was intended to take over as the companion, but in this version of the story, Ace is still around. The scene in which Raine is introduced, cracking a safe, is first-rate, and really sets the tone for the story. The Doctor has his “mysterious” act cranked up to 11, but Raine and Markus are enough in awe of him to let him get away with it. Ace certainly wouldn’t, but true to the Doctor’s promise from last story, she’s off in her own plot, infiltrating a group of freedom fighters in a Balkan country (it is 1990, after all). It’s an Andrew Cartmel script, the first time he’d written a complete script himself, and it’s rather all over the place, with many different locations and disjointed scenes, a lot of maneuvering going on in the background that the listener needs to keep track of. And he gets to introduce the Metatraxi, who he clearly has a fondness for. But the character of Raine comes through quite strong, especially at the beginning. Also somewhat at the end, when she and Ace have a rivalry that seems a bit sudden, but Sophie Aldred and Beth Chalmers are having a lot of fun with it. It’s not the strongest story plot-wise, but it may be from a character perspective.
docs.title: Crime of the Century

docs.text: Dark Convoy Short Trips #5.7 Released: 20 July 2015 Listened: 11/7/20 This one is a brief vignette with action, but not much of a plot, as the Doctor once again acts inscrutable. The TARDIS shows up on a British WWII naval vessel charged with escorting a convoy in northern waters, but it’s going rather poorly. At first, the Doctor is happy to assist, helping out with the sonar, and even using alien tech to help locate the rest of the convoy. Once it becomes a matter of fighting back against a German submarine, he stops helping and gets concerned about the Web of Time. Ace, of course, doesn’t care about any of that, and gets involved in rescue efforts. This seems like it’s a story that should have been longer, to delve into how the Doctor and Ace think about interference, but that didn’t happen.
docs.title: Dark Convoy

docs.text: Dead Woman Walking Short Trips #10.4 Released: 30 April 2020 Listened: 11/25/20 Placed here because Ace is still carrying Nitro-9, and the Doctor is still manipulating her without consent. This Short Trip is also a full story, rather than a vignette. While on a mission to bring peace between two warring factions on a planet, Ace accidentally becomes host to a parasite that will destroy the planet if she dies or leaves in the TARDIS. It’s good character development for Ace, but a lot of it is simply farfetched, from the world-ending parasite to how easy it is to get both sides of an entrenched civil war to talk. Again, the concept is fine, but this seems to want to be a longer story than it is.
docs.title: Dead Woman Walking

docs.text: Doctors and Dragons Short Trips #9.3 Released: 27 March 2019 Listened: 11/25/20 I’ve placed this story here, because Doctor is still dealing with elder gods, so fairly close to Season 26 seems appropriate. This Short Trip has an intriguing high concept, that the story seems to take place in a Dungeons & Dragons setting, down to random events being determined by the roll of a 20-sided die, and the Doctor has somehow stumbled into this. The point of view character seems to be on a noble quest to save a friend that brings her in opposition to the Doctor, which is a nice setup. However, something changes in the narration that makes part of the story unreliable, and that’s annoying. Sophie Aldred narrates, and in this case the Doctor has a bunch of dialog, so there’s quite a bit of her version of Sylvester McCoy’s accent. Thumbs up for the setting, thumbs down for the execution.
docs.title: Doctors and Dragons

docs.text: Dust Breeding Main Range #21 Released: 18 June 2001 Listened: 11/23/20 The big draw for this release when it came out was the character of “Mr. Seta,” played by Geoffrey Beevers, which is a pretty open secret to anyone familiar with later Big Finish -- it’s the Master -- but at the time it was his first appearance, so that was a pretty big deal. It’s also specified to be a post-” Survival ” Master, stripped of Tremas’ body and “de-generated” back into his crispy incarnation. That retcon wasn’t really necessary, but probably seemed so at the time. As for the story itself, it’s a slow boiler, to allow time before the Master’s reveal, so we get a lot of high concept -- a planet made of dust, a psychic entity hiding in Edvard Munch’s The Scream , and buried Daleks that can be heard screaming in the background for several episodes. Caroline John (normally Liz Shaw, and wife of Geoffrey Beevers) plays a wealthy art patron with an absurd “Italian” accent that sounds nothing like her, and is honestly fairly over the top. Writer Mike Tucker does some good work, but some of the names are pretty suspect: I don’t know why a psychic entity would be called a “warp core,” and calling the other monsters “Krill” just makes them sound like something harmless that whales eat. They were established in a novel, and Ace references those events here. Bev Tarant from “ Genocide Machine ” makes a return appearance, mostly to give the Doctor another character to explain things to, as Ace is becoming experienced. Everything kind of wanders along until a big pile-up at the end that falls a little short of satisfying. The set-up is interesting, but the execution isn’t quite there.
docs.title: Dust Breeding

docs.text: Earth Aid Lost Stories #2.6 Released: 16 July 2011 Listened: 11/18/20 This story follows closely after the previous, but a little time has passed, long enough for the Doctor and Ace to have infiltrated a human space fleet, with Ace somehow posing as a starship captain, and really not doing a great job of it. (You’d think the Doctor would have learned that this trick doesn’t work from “ Bang Bang a Boom ,” which wasn’t that long ago for him.) They’re reunited with Raine through a rather odd circumstance, which makes me wonder what the point was of splitting them up. She doesn’t even have all that much to do this time except boggle at what’s going on around her, as this is her first spaceship. They’re also reunited with the Metatraxi, who are still out for revenge for the events of “ Crime of the Century .” Once again, the structure is rather scattered, and the ending is somewhat contrived, but all the stories in this small set have been like that. The guest cast on this one is remarkable: Ingrid Oliver, a couple of years pre-Osgood, plays a military type. Paterson Joseph, a remarkable actor who’s sometimes projected to play the Doctor, does an American accent that makes him entirely unrecognizable, but it must be said, he does American better than most Big Finish guest actors. The Metatraxi plot thread from this season wraps up, but Raine’s plot doesn’t seem to have advanced all that much, and she only has one other appearance, much later in this project. Which is a shame, because I like Raine, and I like Beth Chalmers, but at least she has other Big Finish roles. On the whole, these particular Lost Stories aren’t quite as satisfying as they could have been.
docs.title: Earth Aid

docs.text: Forever Fallen Short Trips #6.X Released: 29 December 2016 Listened: 11/25/20 This is one of those stories that only works well in the Short Trips format, because it’s less about the big conflict than it is about what happens next. The Doctor stops a young would-be dictator, one of those misunderstood genius types, from using his army of androids, his orbital death laser, or his mind-control ray...and then lets him go. The Doctor claims he’ll check in on the man periodically, as he often says, but this time we actually get to see that happen, through a series of meetings one year apart. We see the changes he goes through, and the ups and downs of his attempts at redemption. This story really plays into the Seventh Doctor’s chessmaster persona, as you see him setting up his long game for once. Nick Briggs is the narrator, and although his Scottish accent sounds more Capaldi than McCoy at times, he’s a skilled reader, bringing some good gravitas to one of the Doctor’s high-minded speeches. It’s a quality use of the format.
docs.title: Forever Fallen

docs.text: Inside Story Short Trips #11.6 Released: 15 February 2022 Listened: 2/17/22 I’m placing this story here because Gabriel Chase is recent for Ace, and the Doctor thinks there’ll be a reckoning soon. This short trip is fairly meta, told from the point of view of writer Helen Howard, who is reading a story she wrote about Maria, who is also a writer, who has a sci-fi novel about creatures called the Betrothed, which attracts the Doctor’s attention. It gets a bit confusing because Sophie Aldred is narrating in-character as Helen, uses the same voice for Maria, and then her “younger” voice as Ace. Once the plot gets going, it’s actually not too deep, but there are references to the Doctor’s chessmaster persona, and the toll it’s taking on Ace, which is why I think this one goes well with " Fenric .” There’s always a point where the Doctor has to get called out on his nonsense, but it’s not happening here yet.
docs.title: Inside Story

docs.text: Shockwave Destiny of the Doctor #7 Released: 1 July 2013 Listened: 11/9/20 This story is part of the Destiny of the Doctor series from the 2013 anniversary. Which means it’s a short-ish story where both the Doctor and Ace act very much as TV viewers would expect of them. Which in this case means the Doctor is inscrutable, and Ace is headstrong, but with good intentions. They’re on a ship that’s trying to outrun a devastating shockwave, but the Doctor is actually after something else, which of course he didn’t explain. Writer James Swallow really nails both the Doctor and Ace’s speaking styles in this period. Sophie Aldred, as usual, plays Ace to perfection, and does great limited third-person narration from Ace’s point of view. Her Doctor continues to sound more like a parody of Sylvester McCoy, but I’m used to it by now. The communication from the Eleventh Doctor that appears in every story gets less and less subtle as the series goes on, and this time it’s right out in the open, but I appreciate that the Eleventh Doctor calls out the Seventh for the way he’s treating Ace, especially if this is right after “ Ghost Light ” and “ Curse of Fenric .” It’s a good addition to the series.
docs.title: Shockwave

docs.text: Destiny of the Doctor #7 Released: 1 July 2013 Listened: 11/9/20 This story is part of the Destiny of the Doctor series from the 2013 anniversary. Which means it’s a short-ish story where both the Doctor and Ace act very much as TV viewers would expect of them. Which in this case means the Doctor is inscrutable, and Ace is headstrong, but with good intentions. They’re on a ship that’s trying to outrun a devastating shockwave, but the Doctor is actually after something else, which of course he didn’t explain. Writer James Swallow really nails both the Doctor and Ace’s speaking styles in this period. Sophie Aldred, as usual, plays Ace to perfection, and does great limited third-person narration from Ace’s point of view. Her Doctor continues to sound more like a parody of Sylvester McCoy, but I’m used to it by now. The communication from the Eleventh Doctor that appears in every story gets less and less subtle as the series goes on, and this time it’s right out in the open, but I appreciate that the Eleventh Doctor calls out the Seventh for the way he’s treating Ace, especially if this is right after “ Ghost Light ” and “ Curse of Fenric .” It’s a good addition to the series.
docs.title: Shockwave

docs.text: Survival TV Season 26, Serial 4 Aired: 22 November 1989 - 6 December 1989 The final appearance of the Master as played by Anthony Ainley. Also the first appearance of Big Finish actor and director Lisa Bowerman, playing a Cheetah-person named Karra, rather than her usual role of Bernice Summerfield. Season 26 ends here, and so does the Classic series as a whole, not that anybody knew that when they filmed it, so there’s no dramatic send-off, just a rather nice speech.
docs.title: Survival

docs.text: 1963: The Assassination Games Main Range #180 Released: 15 November 2013 Listened: 11/8/20 This project has been ramping up slowly into Ace’s era, with a handful of short trips among the TV stories, but this is the first Main Range story for Ace in the project. This story is also the final part of the 50th anniversary trilogy of Main Range stories with the “1963” banner, which are unrelated except for taking place around the same time. It also features the Counter-Measures group, consisting of Group Captain Ian Gilmore, Professor Rachel Jensen, and Allison Williams from “ Remembrance of the Daleks ,” joined by Sir Toby Kinsella. This story is said to take place on November 30, so if “Remembrance” took place on November 23 (which is uncertain, for a variety of reasons), it’s only been a week since they’ve seen the Doctor and Ace, although they act like it’s been longer. Big Finish introduced their Counter-Measures spin-off in 2012, but this story takes place before those events, as Rachel and Allison haven’t fully joined the team yet. With all that going on, the Doctor is in full manipulative mode, having spent months gaining a seat as a member of Parliament, and then serving for some time, with Ace likewise undercover. Ace is in pre-Season 26 mode, very loud, excited, and eager to blow things up. As for the plot itself, it’s very political, with the government developing a new nuclear weapon, anti-nuke groups potentially turning violent, and politicians being ensnared in sex scandals. It’s written by John Dorney, so it’s a pretty complicated story, but not particularly timey-wimey. It does introduce a secretive organization called The Light, which the Doctor indicates will be a problem for him in the future, but they’ve only turned up again in a couple of Counter-Measures stories, so I guess the Doctor took care of them off-screen. It’s tough to beat “ Fanfare for the Common Men ” from this trilogy, but this one is probably second, and really, all three of them are quite strong.
docs.title: 1963: The Assassination Games

docs.text: The Fearmonger Main Range #5 Released: 4 February 2000 Listened: 11/20/20 This release goes way back to the beginning of the Big Finish range; this is the first appearance of Sophie Aldred as Ace in Big Finish, and only the second for Sylvester McCoy. Both actors are pretty good at sounding like their younger selves throughout their Big Finish work, but here they do sound a bit younger, especially when the Doctor uses his low, persuading voice. As a bonus, Jacqueline Pearce plays an authoritarian politician running for office, and of course she does that magnificently. From a plot perspective, “authoritarian, populist candidate running a campaign on fear” is more off-putting in 2020 than it probably was in 2000, although they may not have known that at the time. As with a lot of early Big Finish, the writing leans into the audio medium, with the monster being a psychic force that manifests through sound, but also through the Doctor and Ace’s rapid-fire banter, to make sure the listener is following the plot. The story also leans heavily into Season 26, with Ace not really trusting the Doctor, and the Doctor, frankly, not giving her a lot of reason to. Which turns into a bit of a twist ending, but it’s not too challenging to figure out, really. If this were the first release where you’d heard this spiky relationship, it would probably be fresh, but in the middle like this, it’s kind of more of the same.
docs.title: The Fearmonger

docs.text: The Genocide Machine Main Range #7 Released: April 2000 Listened: 11/22/20 Still back at the beginning of Big Finish, this story was the first appearance of the Daleks in their stories. It’s also the first part of the “Dalek Empire” trilogy that continued into “ The Apocalypse Element ” and “ The Mutant Phase ,” all of which have already happened from the Doctor’s point of view. This is also the first time Nick Briggs voices the Daleks for Big Finish, although Alistair Lock also provides some. The Doctor and Ace land on a dismal planet that contains an immense library behind a time-shield. Naturally, the Daleks want to get their hands on this library, and they’ve got a plan to do it. The plot development has an interesting high concept to it, one that’s pretty rare for Doctor Who . There are also some pretty good minor characters, one of them good enough to turn up again later. Ace is written as fairly young here, admitting to behaving like an adolescent, and carrying Nitro-9. They’re also still leaning into the audio medium, having a bit character who’s described as being talkative, but who only speaks once in the story. It’s a good premiere for the Daleks, not nearly as bombastic as other stories in the trilogy.
docs.title: The Genocide Machine

docs.text: The Grey Man of the Mountain Main Range #272 Released: 8 December 2020 Listened: 12/13/20 This story, a very recent release at the time of this writing, is the Christmas story for 2020. I’m placing it here because Ace is acting fairly “young,” craving adventure and carrying Nitro-9. The writing is clearly meant to evoke Season 26 as well, with Ace picking up a “temporary companion” of her own (with a hint of same-sex attraction), as she often did in 1989. It’s set in a contemporary time period with ubiquitous cell phones and streaming channels, but the exact year isn’t specified, in a nod to the UNIT dating controversy. Why bring up UNIT? Because the Brigadier is here! This is the first appearance of the Brig as played by Jon Culshaw in the Main Range, and he sounds pretty good. There are a few moments when you can tell, especially early on when the Brig is making polite conversation instead of barking orders or dropping wry observations, but the rest of the time, it might as well be Nicholas Courtney. The Brig is post-” Battlefield ,” having taken up a more active role again, serving as a kind of advance troubleshooter for UNIT (possibly connecting to “Minuet in Hell”), so he recognizes Ace and the Doctor readily enough. If I have any complaints, it’s that his relationship with Ace is rather distant, which is a bummer. However, Ace and her new friend spend most of the story separated from the Doctor and the Brig. The story itself is a little thin, in favor of the characterization. It involves “Scottish Yetis” who inspire fear and paranoia in those who look at them, so the Doctor spends a good chunk of the story being unhinged. It’s not so much a Christmas story as a story that happens to take place around Christmas. I’m not completely convinced that we need more Brigadier stories outside the Third Doctor era, but Big Finish is certainly doing them respectfully, so I have no problem with that.
docs.title: The Grey Man of the Mountain

docs.text: The Haunting of Bryck Place Interludes #3 Released: 29 June 2022 Listened: 8/19/22 This is another Interlude, an hour-long story told in narrated form, read this time by Sophie Aldred. Which means we get her exaggerated impersonation of the Doctor, but also very Ace-sounding Ace, down to the internal monologue. They’re in Tudor London, investigating a haunted house, which is odd, because Bryck Place is new, the first house made from bricks. And it’s odd because the ghost is apparently Ace. The tone is very Season 26, with Ace still seeking the Doctor’s approval, but also prone to flying off the handle. She remembers both Fenric and Gabriel Chase as recent adventures that have rattled her faith in the Doctor. More important, because of the narration, we get some inkling of how Ace sees herself, and it’s a pretty dark picture. In the face of that, the story is somewhat secondary, but it’s not predictable either, which is good.
docs.title: The Haunting of Bryck Place

docs.text: The Rapture Main Range #36 Released: 26 September 2002 Listened: 11/25/20 Big Finish was clearly trying to do something different with this story, perhaps an attempt to be cool. The cover of the story has an unusual design, the theme music has a techno beat behind it, and some episodes are punctuated with abrupt jump cuts mid-sentence. After the events of “ Colditz ,” Ace (now going by “McShane”) wants a break, so the Doctor takes them to Ibiza, 1997, where there’s a pretty hedonistic crowd, but they’re all fans of a club called The Rapture, owned by brothers Gabriel and Jude, who’ve got a religious theme going. But more than that, there’s someone here who knows Ace. As with a lot of early Big Finish stories, there’s more set-up than conclusion; in fact, the story seems to end once, rather mildly, only to have a more action-based ending that feels tacked-on. The story seems to want to play with more mature themes, dealing with drug use, religion, and the disaffectedness of youth. The monsters aren’t really all that monstrous, and it has an ethereal feeling not unlike Ghost Light ; it would fit fine in Season 26. Although the story hints at big changes for Ace, none of them really get followed up on. I can give it credit for being experimental, but the experiment doesn’t really come off.
docs.title: The Rapture

docs.text: The Riparian Ripper Short Trips #3.7 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 11/7/20 There’s a handful of stories sandwiched in here between Season 25 and 26, in which the Doctor isn’t so much “manipulative” as “inscrutable.” This one is typical of the era, which makes sense, as it was written by Andrew Cartmel. There really isn’t a monster or an enemy here, but there is a mystery. Of course, the Doctor figures it out right away, and spends the rest of the story proving it. The vast majority of Seventh Doctor Short Trips are read by Sophie Aldred, and in this case she does it in first person as Ace. Her Seventh Doctor doesn’t sound much like Sylvester McCoy, but it isn’t too blatantly Scottish either, although she does get in some rolled R’s, but with that title, who wouldn’t? It’s a decent little mystery the first time you hear it, but after that, there’s not much point in going back to it.
docs.title: The Riparian Ripper

docs.text: The Shadow Trader Short Trips #4.7 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 11/7/20 Like a lot of Short Trips, this one is just a little vignette intended to show off a high concept. The Shadow Traders of the title provide metaphysical reinforcement to great buildings and ships by using people’s shadows. Unfortunately, that leaves the donor without a shadow, which can have bad effects, and although donors are often voluntary, this trader chooses to steal shadows. Unfortunately, he’s chosen Ace as his victim, which doesn’t work out well for him. There’s a lot in this story that doesn’t get resolved, like the trader being considered a failure at his craft, but having a family obligation to continue. The story just kind of stops without resolving.
docs.title: The Shadow Trader

docs.text: The Shrine of Sorrows Subscriber Short Trips #2016-3 Released: 13 September 2016 Listened: 11/25/20 This is one of those Short Trips that’s told from the point of view of a third party, this time a young woman participating in a ritual with two friends, from which one of them won’t return. Naturally, the Doctor and Ace stumble into this, and the Doctor realizes that something else is going on, which involves the words “ancient” and “malevolent.” It goes about the way that you’d expect, but looking at the Doctor and Ace from the outside is always interesting. The narrator is Stephen Critchlow, who does his usual sterling job.
docs.title: The Shrine of Sorrows

docs.text: The Split Infinitive The Legacy of Time #2 Released: 17 July 2019 Listened: 11/10/20 The Legacy of Time project, like the Worlds of Doctor Who release that came before it, is intended to highlight the Big Finish-original characters and spin-offs, but in 2019, there were a lot more of them. This story is about Counter-Measures, which means they’re paired up with the Seventh Doctor and Ace. For the purposes of this project, that’s a bit odd, because they were just together a couple of stories ago, and “ Remembrance ” was shortly before that, but going by release order, it’s been a while. For the team, it’s even odder, because they work with Ace in the 1960s, and with the Doctor in the 1970s, on the same case. That reflects the time jump that was used to create the “New Counter-Measures” series. John Dorney specializes in this sort of timey-wimey plot, but I have to say I object to the concept of events being both ten years apart and “simultaneous,” because time travel doesn’t normally work that way in Doctor Who ... at least, not as far as I can tell. The plot itself isn’t terribly complicated, but the bad guys have a twist I didn’t see coming, even on a re-listen. It’s a fine story, but I think I’m having enough of the Counter-Measures team, which is fine, because they don’t appear again in this project.
docs.title: The Split Infinitive

docs.text: Thin Ice Lost Stories #2.3 Released: 14 April 2011 Listened: 11/15/20 This is the beginning of a set of Lost Stories that would have constituted Season 27, had the show stayed on the air. They’re script edited by Andrew Cartmel, so they mostly reflect the original intentions, but with some modifications for Big Finish continuity. This one is written by Marc Platt, adapting his own story, and Platt is a big fan, as well as one of Cartmel’s go-to writers, so this definitely has the Season 27 feel. (The original title for the story was “Ice Time,” but was switched to “Thin Ice” later, and has no relation to the 2017 Twelfth Doctor story “Thin Ice.”) The Doctor is at his most manipulative here, having set Ace up to be tested to enter the Prydonian Academy, without her knowledge or consent. However, said test involves dropping Ace into an Ice Warrior story to see how she copes. It’s set in Russia, with the Ice Warriors trying to recover some artefacts that the Kremlin is holding onto, and attempting to weaponize. The Doctor automatically assumes the Ice Warriors are hostile (no matter how many Peladon stories he goes through), but Ace makes a connection with at least one of them. She also connects with London criminal Markus Creevy and his girlfriend Raina Kerenskaya, who are about to have a daughter, which will become significant later. The Ice Warrior part of the plot is kind of predictable, leaving the emphasis on Ace and her reactions once she finds out she’s being tested -- surprise, she’s angry at the Doctor. (Spoiler: In the TV version, Ace would have gone to the Academy. Here, she fails, and agrees to stay with the Doctor after he promises her more responsibility.) Like a lot of stories Cartmel oversaw, this one is a little overstuffed, which leaves some plot threads feeling slack, but you can see him playing the long game.
docs.title: Thin Ice

docs.text: Lost Stories #2.3 Released: 14 April 2011 Listened: 11/15/20 This is the beginning of a set of Lost Stories that would have constituted Season 27, had the show stayed on the air. They’re script edited by Andrew Cartmel, so they mostly reflect the original intentions, but with some modifications for Big Finish continuity. This one is written by Marc Platt, adapting his own story, and Platt is a big fan, as well as one of Cartmel’s go-to writers, so this definitely has the Season 27 feel. (The original title for the story was “Ice Time,” but was switched to “Thin Ice” later, and has no relation to the 2017 Twelfth Doctor story “Thin Ice.”) The Doctor is at his most manipulative here, having set Ace up to be tested to enter the Prydonian Academy, without her knowledge or consent. However, said test involves dropping Ace into an Ice Warrior story to see how she copes. It’s set in Russia, with the Ice Warriors trying to recover some artefacts that the Kremlin is holding onto, and attempting to weaponize. The Doctor automatically assumes the Ice Warriors are hostile (no matter how many Peladon stories he goes through), but Ace makes a connection with at least one of them. She also connects with London criminal Markus Creevy and his girlfriend Raina Kerenskaya, who are about to have a daughter, which will become significant later. The Ice Warrior part of the plot is kind of predictable, leaving the emphasis on Ace and her reactions once she finds out she’s being tested -- surprise, she’s angry at the Doctor. (Spoiler: In the TV version, Ace would have gone to the Academy. Here, she fails, and agrees to stay with the Doctor after he promises her more responsibility.) Like a lot of stories Cartmel oversaw, this one is a little overstuffed, which leaves some plot threads feeling slack, but you can see him playing the long game.
docs.title: Thin Ice

docs.text: Washington Burns Short Trips #6.3 Released: 24 March 2016 Listened: 11/22/20 This one is a short semi-historical, which seems to have more plot than most Short Trips, a trick that’s pulled off by making this the epilogue to an unseen adventure. The Doctor and Ace are pursuing an evil psychic entity that can hide in the written word, and take over anyone who reads it. Lucky for them, the entity has fled to Washington in 1814, which is about to be burned by British troops. It’s remarkably accurate for such a short story, including Major General Robert Ross and Rear Admiral George Cockburn, down to Cockburn burning the National Intelligencer and destroying all the “C” type so that the paper could no longer slander him. President Madison doesn’t come off so well, but it’s an English story, so what can you do? It’s a clever concept, some nice history, and a fair chunk of plot, in addition to being set during an event I’m familiar with. That all makes for a nice Short Trip.
docs.title: Washington Burns

docs.text: The Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny Professor Bernice “Benny” Summerfield is one of the more significant characters from 90s Doctor Who. Created by writer Paul Cornell, she appeared in several of the New Adventures novels, and was the first character adapted by Big Finish, even before they had the Doctor Who rights. The Benny audios and novels attempt to follow a single continuity, and I’m not going to get into those in this project, but that led to a couple of Big Finish novel adaptations, which also try to tie into the novel continuity. Although Benny isn’t really to my taste, I recognize her significance in the larger story, and her role both as a friend of the Doctor’s, and as a precursor to River Song.
docs.title: Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny

docs.text: Critical Mass Short Trips #2.7 Released: 28 February 2011 Listened: 12/1/20 This is another vignette, with the Doctor and Ace interfering with a doomsday weapon, stopping it before it goes off. The Doctor gets one of his “moral high ground” speeches, which means that Sophie Aldred needs to put on her Doctor impersonation for quite a long stretch, but it’s halfway decent. Between the speech, the lack of Benny, and no mention of Ace’s military background, this might go better in or around Season 26.

docs.text: Love and War Novel Adaptations #1 Released: 24 October 2012 Listened: 11/30/20 This was one of the more popular novels, and therefore the first of the Big Finish adaptations, likely because it introduces Bernice Summerfield. Honest admission: I don’t much care for this story, and that affected my view of all the novel adaptations. I suspect the adaptations are a lot more palatable if you were fond of the original novels. Unfortunately, I sat out most of the wilderness years, and quit reading after the first couple of novels. The novels go to a different, darker place than the audios, so the characterizations seem inconsistent with the rest of this timeline. In addition, the pacing feels odd; there’s a lot of content to stuff into two hours of audio story, no matter how well acted. In this case, Ace falls deeply in love with someone she’s only just met, which seems bizarre. Benny is remarkably trusting of both the Doctor and Ace, even though she’s just met them, and she isn’t a trusting person in general. Minor characters die almost immediately after being introduced. There are a ton of characters compared to the average audio, and it can be difficult to keep them straight. There’s a version of virtual reality that was written in the early 90s, and it shows. There are bunches of big ideas flying around, which is typical of Paul Cornell’s novels -- a planet of the dead, futuristic Romany who use VR, malevolent fungus creatures, and tying the whole thing to the ancient history of the Time Lords, as the novels loved to do. Most objectionable of all, though, the Doctor is more manipulative than ever, deliberately keeping things from people for no reason, and deliberately taking on the role of Time’s Champion while also embracing that he’ll have to sacrifice and lose things he loves, which doesn’t make a ton of sense. When he sacrifices something that affects Ace directly, she goes ballistic on him -- justified, and maybe even overdue, given how much she puts up with in the rest of this timeline, but it really seems like she’s unpleasantly over the edge. The story ends with Ace departing as a companion, and Benny taking her place, although given what she’s just seen, I’m not sure why she does.
docs.title: Love and War

docs.text: Police and Shreeves Short Trips #1.7 Released: 5 November 2010 Listened: 12/1/20 This story is just a little vignette, about some aliens called shreeves, shapeshifters who eat electricity, hide on Earth, and are generally laid back about the whole thing. Ace and the Doctor get involved to stop a human from exploiting one of the shreeves for criminal purposes, and that’s about it. Benny isn’t around, but Ace’s military bearing is mentioned, so perhaps it goes here. There’s a tiny cameo from the Brigadier, which is nice enough.

docs.text: The Dark Flame Main Range #42 Released: 28 March 2003 Listened: 12/2/20 This one is considered another “side step,” which follows the novel continuity, which in this case means that Benny is around and Ace has military training. The Doctor drops in on an old friend, who is, of course, part of a highly dangerous experiment, and who gets killed fairly early on. Benny is also trying to help an old friend, another archaeologist, who’s forced into digging up a skull for some other scientists from the experiment, because they’re trying to resurrect yet another powerful being from another dimension. The whole thing feels rather too long, with the Doctor varying between being casual about his plans (because at this point, defeating extradimensional powers is what he calls Tuesday), and screaming as his mind is taken over. There’s a robot assistant named Joseph in this story, which is supposed to tie in with robot assistants that Benny has later in her timeline, but the continuity doesn't line up. With Benny and older Ace both in the story, there’s plenty of sarcasm to go around, but to little real end. There just isn’t a lot in this story to hold my interest. This is the last Main Range appearance of Benny, but far from her final appearance in Big Finish or in this project.
docs.title: The Dark Flame

docs.text: The Shadow of the Scourge Main Range #13 Released: October 2000 Listened: 12/1/20 This story was originally labeled a “side step,” in that it deliberately used the novel continuity, rather than the continuity Big Finish had been following (which there wasn’t much of, at the time). This allows them to use Benny without having to introduce her. Benny has clearly been with the Doctor a while at this point, and Ace has her Dalek-fighting military experience, allowing Sophie Aldred to play her a bit older. As Paul Cornell is the writer, the story is pretty confident with these characters’ voices. The first half of this story plays out at a good pace, with the TARDIS team investigating odd goings-on at a hotel with multiple conventions. There’s a standard bunch of Aliens From Another Dimension who are trying to get in, and of course they feed on fear. But when the Doctor enacts his usual plan to trip the baddies up, it doesn’t go as planned. That leads to a lot of mental jousting, soul-searching, and wandering around mindscapes, which Paul Cornell seems to enjoy doing. However, the ending that grows out of that seems a little pro forma, unfortunately. The minor characters are well-realized and colorful, which makes it seem a bit like a novel adaptation; appropriate. It’s a nice entry into this part of the project.
docs.title: The Shadow of the Scourge

docs.text: The Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny (Again) This section is almost entirely novels and novel adaptations, most of which I don’t have. However, it’s here to handle the novel continuity. There’s no connection from the previous section with Mel to this one. If anything, these continue from the previous Ace and Benny section, from before Hex. Because this is mixing the novel and audio continuities, it’s an open question whether these come before Hex, after, or if they’re two entirely separate timelines. Regardless, this era is where Ace leaves the Doctor more or less permanently.
docs.title: Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny (again)

Oddly, it does feature Colin Baker in his first work for Big Finish, except he’s not playing the Doctor.

docs.text: Set Piece Virgin New Adventures #35 Released: 16 February 1995 This is Ace’s last regular appearance in the novel range. From this point on in the project, she’s kind of in and out, frequently going off to do her own thing. She spends a lot of time in this story stuck in ancient Egypt, believing the Doctor to be dead.

docs.text: The Big Blue Book The Eighth of March #1.2 Released: 8 March 2019 Listened: 2/12/21 This is an entry from the “Eighth of March” boxed set for International Women’s Day. As a result, Ace and Benny appear, but the Doctor only has a small cameo. They’re both undercover at a university, and have been there for a while, Bernice as a professor, and Ace as a member of the cleaning staff. The Doctor intended it to be a break, but Ace has been on the lookout for strange stuff, and finds it when Benny vanishes. The story by Lizzie Hopley is a bit on the strange side, with alien criminals who turn people into books. There’s also a secondary character who hangs out with Ace, but he’s not given enough time to develop. The story feels like it’s a bit compressed and rushed, like it was a four-part story squeezed into an hour timeslot. Ace gets more to do than Benny here, and although she keeps getting suggestions that she’s not as bright as the other characters, she’s the one who figures out most of what’s going on and what to do about it. This suggests that she’s got a greater experience with the weird than she would have earlier in her life. Unfortunately, due to the audio nature of the story, she spends more time talking to herself than she probably would in other circumstances. It’s a fine story for what it is, but doesn’t advance either character much.
docs.title: The Big Blue Book

docs.text: Bernice Summerfield and the Criminal Code Companion Chronicles #4.6 Released: 24 January 2010 Listened: 2/14/21 This is the only Companion Chronicle to feature Benny, and Lisa Bowerman doesn’t direct this one. However, it means that Benny has to do a lot of narration, so it’s good that she’s separated from the Doctor for much of the story. The Doctor is trying to negotiate a peace treaty between a couple of planets, but it isn’t going well, and is taking longer than he anticipated. Benny is attending an archaeology conference on the planet where the talks are taking place, which appears to be unrelated, but of course turns out to have the key to the whole thing, and if only the Doctor had listened to his companion sooner, it might not have gone so far. The TARDIS translation circuits play an unusually prominent role in this story. You’d think that translation issues might come up more often, given Benny’s profession, as either a help or a hindrance, but it’s pretty unusual. If I have a complaint, it’s that the story builds nicely to a revelation, but then ends rather abruptly. I feel like it could have been a bit longer than it was. Charlie Hayes, Wendy Padbury’s daughter, plays the secondary character, and does a nice job providing contrast. It’s a good story that plays to Benny’s strengths, and a nice variation from the full-cast stories.
docs.title: Bernice Summerfield and the Criminal Code

docs.text: The Hesitation Deviation Short Trips #6.12 Released: 23 December 2016 Listened: 2/14/21 This one is ostensibly a Christmas story, but like a bunch of the TV Christmas episodes, it’s a regular story that happens to take place at Christmas, without that being relevant to the plot at all. Unusually, it appears to have a frame story, with Benny explaining to a psychotherapy robot why she can never see the Doctor again, and then the rest of the story told as flashback. Of course, this is a James Goss story, so it’s not what it seems. Lisa Bowerman doesn’t normally do a lot of narrating, but as a regular director of both Short Trips and Companion Chronicles, she certainly knows how it’s done. She only imitates the Doctor a little bit, and most of that is in an exaggerated Scottish accent, similar to how Sophie Aldred does it. Natural language, and the pauses in it, are a major part of the story, so it’s better that this one comes off as Benny telling a story, rather than Lisa Bowerman reading one. After this story, Benny gets a break for a while, but she’s important enough to Big Finish to warrant a solo series, so she’ll be back later. It’s a decent send-off for her.
docs.title: The Hesitation Deviation

docs.text: The Unknown The Diary of River Song #2.1 Released: 25 December 2016 Listened: 2/13/21 The Doctor is alone for this story, so Ace and Benny must be elsewhere, because they’re not in the TARDIS (or else this story is placed incorrectly). Up to this point in River’s (production) history, Big Finish had only paired her with the Eighth Doctor, and even then she avoided meeting him directly. This story explodes that somewhat by having them unable to remember each other, and ends with the events of the story being erased, so from the Doctor’s perspective, nothing happened at all. River’s on a ship with temporal shielding, on its way to investigate a temporal anomaly, except it collides with the TARDIS, and the temporal shielding doesn’t really work. This results in Escher-like corridors, memory loss and trouble focusing for the characters, and of course, imminent catastrophe. River and the Seventh Doctor don’t get on too well in general, because she’s not fond of his tendency to be mysterious (because that’s her gig). With their memories erased, the Doctor starts to warm to her...until she’s willing to shoot and incinerate the people trying to kill them. Of course, this is River’s story, so she’s proven right, more or less. And also because this is River’s story, it continues past the point where the Doctor leaves, with River learning some disturbing things about the planet that leads into “5:29” and the rest of the boxed set. From River’s standpoint, the story is just getting started, but for this project, it’s just an interlude. It’s a pretty good River story, though, if you like temporal engineering.
docs.title: The Unknown

docs.text: The Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny (Again Again) The Big Finish Bernice Summerfield chronology is almost as convoluted as the Doctor’s own. This set of stories comes from the “New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield,” which take place later in Benny’s life. The Doctor and Ace guested in the first two boxed sets, before Benny took off for another universe entirely (which I won’t cover here).
docs.title: Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny (again)

docs.title: The Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Benny (Again Again)

docs.text: Good Night, Sweet Ladies The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #1.2 Released: 13 June 2014 Listened: 3/4/21 This story takes a very sharp turn, being dark, mysterious, and an emotional wringer for Benny. Significantly, she’s separated from the Doctor, she’s looking for Ace, so Benny has to be the one making all the calls and being brave, which makes sense, as it’s her series. She gets a temporary companion, but a rather useless one, who she has to keep safe, but that gives her an exposition target. And there’s one other character doing the “knows more than they seem” trick, and admittedly, does it quite well. Una McCormack does a great job of writing both snarky Benny and vulnerable Benny, so that the emotional climax is really effective. In the larger story, it’s not clear where this is going yet, but the contrast between the first two stories is excellent.
docs.title: Good Night, Sweet Ladies

docs.text: Random Ghosts The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #1.3 Released: 13 June 2014 Listened: 3/5/21 This is Doctor Who , so we’re accustomed to those story openings where a bunch of confusing, seemingly random, possibly contradictory things are happening, sometimes out of order. This is a 49-minute story of just those. There’s a time-loop / groundhog-day thing going on, on the planet where Benny went searching for Ace, with everybody repeating each day with no memory of what came before. Except they can leave messages for themselves, so really it’s more like Memento , if Memento took place in a random order and the messages were untrustworthy. One thing that’s constant is that Ace isn’t happy to see Benny, and she’s being particularly insistent that this planet should not be rescued. That’s pretty unlike Ace, but because we’re getting the story from Benny’s point of view, it never becomes clear. I have no idea how Guy Adams wrote this without going mad, and it definitely takes a good amount of concentration to listen to. There’s a good slap-in-the-face climax, but there isn’t really a resolution as such. If it were a standalone, that would seem like a disappointing ending. As a cliffhanger, it makes you wonder if 49 minutes were really necessary to get to this point. But it’s well constructed and experimental, so points for that.
docs.title: Random Ghosts

docs.text: The Eye of Horus The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #2.3 Released: 12 June 2015 Listened: 3/6/21 You may want to do your own historical research for this one, as Benny ends up in ancient Egypt, at the end of the reign of Hatshepsut, regarded as King of Egypt although she was a woman. (The production had a historical expert to ensure accuracy.) The Doctor is here as well, serving as Hatshepsut’s chief advisor, although he doesn’t recognize Benny. It feels like the Doctor is doing quite a bit of unwarranted meddling here, and it’s true that he’s hidden part of his mind so Sutekh won’t detect him. Which once again leaves Benny to do a lot of the heavy lifting, although in this case she’s more of an accidental bystander to events. Nevertheless, when Sutekh makes his move, Benny gets another rather wrenching scene as it seems she’s about to die (again) and the Doctor can’t help her. Of course that’s not the way it works out, but it’s a good scene anyway. Trivia: Sakuntala Ramanee, who was in “ Survival ” back in 1989 with Sophie Aldred and Lisa Bowerman, plays Hapshetsut.
docs.title: The Eye of Horus

docs.text: The Lights of Skaro The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #1.4 Released: 13 June 2014 Listened: 3/5/21 Starting off with a necessary spoiler: The planet in the time loop is Skaro, and that’s where they’re all stuck now, with the time loop breaking down, so at least our characters can do things in order and remember them, but there’s still random time-shifts going on through Dalek history. That explains why Ace didn’t want to try to save the planet, but not why she was secretive about it. She says she told Benny several times, during the loop, but “it didn’t go well,” which is kind of a hand-wave. Benny, admittedly, has a bad history with Daleks, and reacts pretty badly to what’s going on around her, as well as the things she (unwittingly) did during the time loop. It isn’t really the slam-bang ending you’d expect it to be. There’s lots of introspection on Benny’s part, and Ace’s, and even the Doctor’s, as he turns up towards the end. He feels that he may have been responsible for the Daleks’ learning that alien races exist, and therefore causing their wave of conquest. Ace is having her best go at wiping out the Daleks before they get started, now that she has access to Time Lord tech, but she’s still too raw to do it right, proving that she does actually need what she’s learning at the Academy. The story ends with the Doctor rather disappointed in Ace, but we don’t hear much about that, as it’s Benny’s story. As a whole boxed set, it hangs together pretty well, and makes a nice showcase for Benny, although she does spend much of it in over her head.
docs.title: The Lights of Skaro

docs.text: The Pyramid of Sutekh The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #2.1 Released: 12 June 2015 Listened: 3/5/21 Some time seems to have passed between the last boxed set and this one, as Benny is on her own again, doing archaeology on Mars, which is one of her speciality areas. Unfortunately, in this case that means running afoul of Sutekh, who’s made the Doctor into his personal mental slave, which is unfortunate. Benny is placed in the rather unfortunate position of having to fight against the Doctor, with the help of a robot who sounds like her dead husband Jason. Once again, Benny’s in rather over her head, and ends up doing some rather foolish things as a result. Gabriel Woolf plays Sutekh, sounded exactly like he did 40+ years ago, which is amazing, but he does have a lot of exposition to cover, some of which could be a bit zippier. As a setup, it’s not bad, but it doesn’t do much on its own.
docs.title: The Pyramid of Sutekh

docs.text: The Revolution The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #1.1 Released: 13 June 2014 Listened: 3/3/21 The boxed set starts off with a Nev Fountain story, and as you might imagine, it’s completely off the wall and ridiculous, as Benny’s stories sometimes are. There’s a planet of absolute science, where even questioning scientific principles is a crime, but also a native population who have their own religious mythology, which Benny has been called in to disprove, but she won’t. The Doctor walks into all this and starts acting rather silly, as a result of being drugged, which allows him to channel the goofy Doctor of his first season while still fitting into the logic of the larger series. Benny even tries to get rid of him, reasoning that she’s about to have an adventure involving things the Doctor doesn’t approve of (sounding very River-like in the process), but fails. The way it all wraps up is amazing in its audacity, both that Fountain thinks he can get away with it, and the fact that he succeeds. And then there’s an abrupt shift in mood as the Doctor returns to his usual personality and announces that Ace is in trouble, leading into the next story. For my first venture into Benny stories proper, I’d have to say I enjoyed it, although it wasn’t what I was expecting.
docs.title: The Revolution

docs.text: The Tears of Isis The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #2.4 Released: 12 June 2015 Listened: 3/6/21 Una McCormack gets to write the finale to this set, and as usual for her, it’s slightly arch and off-kilter. Sutekh has won, apparently. The Earth is completely scorched and lifeless, and the only survivors are a modern-day cult of Sutekh, who are kind of surprised that the world did end when their prophecy said it would, and they’re kind of falling apart as a result. That’s an OK concept, but it leads to a plot of Benny trying to save a bunch of people who don’t really want to be saved, over the Doctor’s objections. It’s not really a slam-bang ending. Once again, the Doctor had a plan the whole time, or at least appears to have had one, and once again he didn’t let Ace or Benny in on it, in fact appearing quite despondent at the start of the story. Normally, there’s a reason he keeps his companions in the dark, but it doesn’t seem entirely clear this time. More unfortunately, there’s no real closure for our main characters, as they just head off in the TARDIS. Ace presumably goes back to Gallifrey, and Benny heads off into an alternate universe. Maybe there will be more stories in this time period, but I kind of doubt it. So that’s a wrap for Benny for this project, aside from the occasional guest appearance later on. I do like Lisa Bowerman’s portrayal of her, and I recognize her importance to the Big Finish story overall, but she’s not my favorite not-from-TV companion. ---The “Unbound” Benny boxed sets featuring David Warner as the Third Doctor take place here (from Benny’s point of view), but I’m not covering those right now.---
docs.title: The Tears of Isis

docs.title: The Tears of Isis

docs.text: The Vaults of Osiris The New Adventures of Bernice Summerfield #2.2 Released: 12 June 2015 Listened: 3/6/21 This story feels very much like a Part 2, in the way Big Finish boxed sets often do: It’s an adventure that’s complete unto itself, and it’s intended to move the overall plot along too, but it can’t move it too far, because boxed sets are long. In this case, the Doctor and Ace found a gem called the Eye of Horus in Egypt in 1941, but then the Doctor apparently died. So Ace fetches Benny to help her get the gem back (Egypt and all), but they end up in 2015 instead, and end up chasing the gem to Switzerland. In contrast to the last boxed set, although Benny and Ace don’t get along perfectly, they’re a lot more in sync now, and their individual talents complement each other nicely. They also get a temporary companion, who is honestly giving off “not what she seems” vibes from minute 1, so it’s hardly surprising when that turns out to be justified. There’s also a fairly high body count in this one, and Ace, at least, doesn’t seem particularly bothered by that, which is unfortunate. The Doctor appears again at the end, just long enough to be mysterious and vanish again with Benny, leaving Ace out of the next story.
docs.title: The Vaults of Osiris

docs.text: The Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Hex Thomas Hector “Hex” Schofield is one of the longer-running Big Finish original characters, created in the same period as Erimem and Evelyn . Like them, his story has a definitive beginning, middle, and end, but unlike them, Big Finish has returned to this era a few times to allow the character some more adventures. This section is rather lengthy, but it also features the “Black and White” series of stories, in which the Doctor spends some time separated from Ace and Hex, each group getting stories of their own. The Doctor is at the peak of his chessmaster phase here, with both Ace and Hex suffering because of it.
docs.title: Seventh Doctor, Ace, and Hex

Like them, his story has a definitive beginning, middle, and end, but unlike them, Big Finish has returned to this era a few times to allow the character some more adventures.
