docs.text: Mission Improbable Short Trips #2018-1 Released: 20 March 2018 Listened: 6/30/20 This Short Trip is the first Evelyn story released since Maggie Stables’ death, read by Stephen Critchlow, who as usual manages to capture the characters’ tone, if not their exact voices. Evelyn is already a prisoner when the story opens, bragging to her captor about her imminent rescue by the Doctor, whose skills and daring she praises highly. This is intercut with scenes of the Doctor bumbling his way through the rescue, succeeding mostly through dumb luck. It’s a funny story overall, and reflects Evelyn’s tendency to appear confident and glib even when she had no reason to.
docs.title: Mission Improbable

docs.text: Short Trips #2018-1 Released: 20 March 2018 Listened: 6/30/20 This Short Trip is the first Evelyn story released since Maggie Stables’ death, read by Stephen Critchlow, who as usual manages to capture the characters’ tone, if not their exact voices. docs.text: 100: My Own Private Wolfgang Main Range #100 Released: 26 September 2007 Listened: 6/6/20 Big Finish chose to mark their 100th Main Range release with a short story anthology, rather than the big blowout event they’d done for the 50th (to mixed reviews). All the stories feature the Sixth Doctor and Evelyn, and they all have a fair amount of “timey-wimey.” The first two aren’t very serious at all. Oddly, the second story in the set takes place first. The Doctor and Evelyn find themselves in a history in which Mozart never died, and continued creating music for centuries, with diminishing results over time. This leads to a very confused pile-up of Mozart clones, some of whom want to kill him, and others who want to save him. It’s as wacky as it sounds, which is what happens when you turn Rob Shearman loose. Significantly, though, Evelyn participates in changing what she knows as history, without bad results.
docs.title: My Own Private Wolfgang

docs.text: Pier Pressure Main Range #78 Released: 11 January 2006 Listened: 6/20/20 This is another rather dark one, as the TARDIS lands in Brighton, 1936, where an alien with mind-control tendencies has been living at the end of the pier for some time. I have a strong feeling this one will make more sense to the English fans, particularly ones who can picture Brighton, and in particular comedian Max Miller, who is an active character in the story. I didn’t know anything about him, but the type wasn’t hard to envision. (There’s also a young actor named Billy who is apparently intended to be William Hartnell .) The plot, though, is rather slow and meandering, spending nearly an entire episode before it gets going, and even after seems to spend a lot of time going back and forth between locations rather slowly. The Doctor is more maudlin and given to speechifying than usual, but Evelyn pretty much tells him that she’s not having any of it, which is her role in these stories. A forgettable episode on the whole.
docs.title: Pier Pressure

docs.text: Project: Lazarus, parts 1 and 2 Main Range #45 Released: 23 June 2003 Listened: 7/1/20 This is a multi-Doctor story, split between the Sixth Doctor in the first half, and the Seventh in the second half, so I’m only listening to half of it here. It’s also a sequel to “ Project: Twilight ,” with the Doctor discovering a cure for Cassie Schofield’s condition, but the TARDIS prevents him from arriving any sooner than two years after they’d left her. In the meantime, Cassie has joined the Forge, and the Doctor and Evelyn discover that Nimrod is still around and running the place. He takes a very genial attitude toward the Doctor; when he explains the purpose of the Forge, the whole scene is very similar to Yvonne Hartman showing off Torchwood One to the Tenth Doctor in “Army of Ghosts,” released a few years later. This half of the story has a complete ending, and concludes with Evelyn being very upset with the Doctor, which leads into “ Arrangements for War .”
docs.title: Project: Lazarus

docs.text: Project: Twilight Main Range #23 Released: 20 August 2001 Listened: 6/10/20 This story opens some threads that will continue into other Main Range stories, the start of more connected storytelling within Big Finish, something they felt free to do during the period before the TV show would come back. In this case, Nimrod and the Forge are introduced, which the Doctor will deal with for a while to come. Cassie Schofield makes her first appearance as well, and her son Thomas is mentioned. (Spoiler: Tommy grows up to be Hex, the Seventh Doctor’s companion.) And the “Zagreus” nursery rhyme makes a quick cameo. But what about the story? It’s dark, and somewhat convoluted. The baddies are vampires, genetically engineered human vampires, but the Doctor still reacts to them as though they’re the ancient enemies of the Time Lords. This leads to an awful lot of overreacting and shouting on his part, as well as some really questionable judgment calls. Evelyn spends a lot of time being upset, with good reason, and Cassie seems to do nothing other than scream or moan in pain. It’s pretty bleak on the whole, but that’s what the story seemed to be aiming for. It’s not just setup for later stories, but a plot along with it, which is good.
docs.title: Project: Twilight

docs.text: Real Time Bonus Release Released: 12 December 2002 Listened: 6/29/20 This story isn’t available for download from Big Finish, only on CD. However, it was created as an animation for the BBC’s web site (although designed so that you could follow it without visuals). That page still exists, but it no longer functions, so it’s best to watch one of the YouTube recordings of it. It’s a Cyberman story, although a somewhat different version of the Cybermen, from the future, although that’s a little hard to tell, because they behave mostly like they always do. There’s also a bit of timey-wimey paradox involved, but that mostly gets swept aside by the end. Yee Jee Tso (Chang Lee from the TV movie) has a major role, which means that for once, a Big Finish American accent sounds natural and unforced. Because this is an early Big Finish, it’s somewhat talky and the pacing is a little slower than standard. However, it’s also quite dark, with a cyber-conversion scene that goes on rather longer than it needs to. Finally, the audio version, but not the webcast, has an extra scene in which the Doctor and Evelyn discuss the Doctor’s blue outfit, with a reference to blue being the color for mourning from " Revelation of the Daleks .” The blue coat was obviously added to save the animators’ sanity, but it sticks around for several audio adventures after this point, and has been “canonized” to the point of appearing on action figures. On the whole, it’s not a great story, but memorable for what it tried to do.
docs.title: Real Time

docs.text: 100: The 100 Days of the Doctor Main Range #100 Released: 26 September 2007 Listened: 6/13/20 This one has the Doctor suffering from an illness, and needing to revisit all the times he’d been to a particular range of space and time, which means encountering some of his past and future incarnations, which lets Evelyn in on the secret of regeneration, and also to have some opinions about various other Big Finish companions. They also get a look at some of the spin-offs, and even the Unbound Doctor. In addition to which, they get rather meta, implying that their adventures have an audience, and noting that the First through Fourth Doctors don’t show up. The story itself is a bit slight, but does demonstrate that the Sixth Doctor is a kinder, less violent person than he was earlier in his life, during the TV adventures. It’s an appropriate closer for an anniversary story.
docs.title: The 100 Days of the Doctor

docs.title: 100: The 100 Days of the Doctor

docs.text: The Apocalypse Element Main Range #11 Released: 7 August 2000 Listened: 6/8/20 This story is part of the “Dalek Empire” set of Main Range stories (not to be confused with the “Dalek Empire” series itself), but the point is, it’s an event, so it’s big, and it’s loud, and it has Daleks. I think the intent of these stories was to restore the Daleks to “big threat” status, because they’d been somewhat diminished at the end of the classic series. The other big draw for this story was the return of Lalla Ward as Romana, in her role as President of Gallifrey, although when the story starts she’s been missing for 20 years. The Daleks are certainly violent and extreme in this story, and are targeting Gallifrey specifically, so this could certainly be considered a precursor to the Time War (Russell T. Davies said as much). However, as a story, it’s rather over the top. Romana seems to be rather high-strung, but she’s just spent 20 years in captivity. Colin Baker seems to be going for maximum volume to convey the scope of the threat, but given the amount of technobabble involved, it comes off sounding somewhat silly. Evelyn is particularly odd, seeming quite flippant most of the time, except when she’s in panic mode. It doesn’t seem like she’s been a companion long enough to have a completely casual attitude toward futuristic tech and Dalek threats. There’s also an attempt to explain one of the sillier aspects of the TV Movie, which really didn’t need to happen. It was probably a very big event on its initial release, and Big Finish may have wanted to make a splash early, but with the benefit of distance, it seems rather overwrought. -- The “Dalek Empire” series of stories takes place here, according to Craig Brawley’s chronology, but I’m sticking to the Doctor’s timeline for the time being. --
docs.title: The Apocalypse Element

docs.text: The Crimes of Thomas Brewster Main Range #143 Released: January 2011 Listened: 6/24/20 There’s a bunch of stuff going on in this one. It was the first story recorded with Evelyn in a while, and the first and only set recorded with her after Big Finish switched the Main Range to mostly feature trilogies. It also featured the return of Thomas Brewster, last seen during the Fifth Doctor’s era. On top of that, it has the return of D.I. Patricia Menzies, who had encountered the Sixth Doctor several times before in her timeline (and Big Finish release order), but this is their first meeting from the Doctor’s point of view. On top of all that , this is the first appearance of Philippa “Flip” Jackson, who will eventually become a companion to the Sixth Doctor, and her boyfriend Jared Ramon, but in this story, they’re just minor characters. Plus David Troughton appears in a minor role. There’s also a bit where Menzies pretends to be the Doctor, and various characters react to the idea that the Doctor could be a woman. The pacing in this story is very frantic, starting in media res and never really letting up. It definitely shows the influence of the modern series on the Main Range, more than previous Evelyn stories. As for the plot, you wouldn’t think there’d be any room for it, and there isn’t a ton, but as usual, Brewster is doing some very shady things for what appears to be the right reasons. His happy ending from “ A Perfect World ” is lost to him, and he’s engaging in reckless behavior as a result. There’s some hive-mind aliens, and a question of whether it’s appropriate to sacrifice one planet to save another. Brewster ends up tagging along with the Doctor and Evelyn, although he’s finding the Sixth Doctor to be rather less tolerant of him than the Fifth was.
docs.title: The Crimes of Thomas Brewster

docs.text: The Feast of Axos Main Range #144 Released: February 2011 Listened: 6/26/20 This story is much less frenetic than the last one, and also leans further into Brewster’s character. It involves Axos, the energy vampire from the Third Doctor story “ The Claws of Axos ” back in the 70s. The Third Doctor left Axos in space, in a time loop, and now it’s started to decay, so various Earth entities are trying to reach it to extract its energies. Axos itself, while a threat, doesn’t seem to be doing very much except trying to break out of the loop. However, it does suborn Brewster, who’s put in the very Adric-like position of joining the bad guys, maybe to betray them, maybe to his own advantage; who knows? Evelyn once again seems to be in a highly snarky mode, taking everything in stride and being sarcastic about it, right up to the point where she’s out of her depth. There’s a bunch of minor characters involved, all of whom know what the Doctor is and what he can do, which makes a nice change. There’s an extended spacewalk scene that results in a pretty effective slow-motion cliffhanger, which probably would have worked pretty well on TV, at least in the modern series. It’s a decent story that moves Brewster’s arc forward.
docs.title: The Feast of Axos

docs.text: The Marian Conspiracy Main Range #6 Released: 12 March 2000 Listened: 6/5/20 Welcome, Evelyn! The Doctor manages to meet her through that old stand-by, the causal nexus. Something isn’t quite right in Elizabethan England, and Evelyn is at the core of it. Naturally, if the Doctor wants to go help out Evelyn’s ancestor, Evelyn is going to go along; she is a history teacher after all. And she gets her wish, more or less, although she’s got some things to learn about how time travel and interference work in these stories. She also clearly has some strong opinions about Queen Mary’s and Elizabeth’s relative positions in history. She’s definitely not willing to put up with the Doctor’s nonsense, pretty much railroading him into letting her come along with him. For his part, the Doctor is still fairly pushy, and given to name-dropping and emphasizing his own importance, but he’s somewhat less shouty than he has been in the past. He’s clearly still fond of his coat, and Evelyn is definitely not. As for the plot, like a lot of early Big Finish, it’s quite talky, with not a lot of action. Writer Jac Rayner specializes in historical stories, and in portraying historical characters, like Mary here, as different than their traditional depictions. Evelyn makes it clear that she’s not up for running, and has a heart condition as well. The minor characters have a tendency to address one another by their full names, rather more than you would expect, as if the creators were concerned we couldn’t tell the voices apart. On the whole, though, it’s a good introduction for Evelyn.
docs.title: The Marian Conspiracy

docs.text: The Nowhere Place Main Range #84 Released: July 2006 Listened: 6/18/20 This one is supposed to be dark, spooky, and maybe just a bit mystical, but it doesn’t quite succeed. The TARDIS lands in the future, on a spaceship at the edge of the solar system, where there’s a strange door that sucks people in. The Doctor spends most of the story being ignorant, and complaining about what he doesn’t know. It’s a standard-length story, but it feels over-long and padded, with long stretches of the characters talking through what they don’t know, and a full-episode detour to 1952 that doesn’t seem to accomplish much. Special credit goes to Martha Cope (who played the Controller in “Bad Wolf” on TV) for playing a military commander under a lot of pressure, struggling to do the right thing when she’s been tossed into a mysterious Doctor Who episode, and has no idea what the right thing is.
docs.title: The Nowhere Place

docs.text: The Sandman Main Range #37 Released: 24 October 2002 Listened: 6/15/20 This one takes place on “The Clutch,” a massive fleet of ships, mostly populated by the Galyari. Both are spoken of as entities that would turn up a lot, but outside of this story, they’re only in passing mentions. This story also assumes a story from the Sixth Doctor’s past (presumably traveling solo), where he became kind of a boogeyman to the Galyari. The first episode makes a lot of that, with Evelyn being uncertain whether the Doctor is, in fact, a monster capable of horrible deeds. But then it’s pretty much dropped after that, and he’s right back into his standard mode. This story, by Simon Forward, aims for high concept with evolution and race memories playing a part of the plot, but the science seems a bit questionable. Like a lot of early Big Finish stories, this one ends up being more talky than actiony, but at least it has a dramatic purpose for the Doctor’s coat, instead of just poking fun at it.
docs.title: The Sandman

docs.text: The Spectre of Lanyon Moor Main Range #9 Released: 12 June 2000 Listened: 6/6/20 The main purpose of this one is to give the Brigadier an adventure with the Sixth Doctor, thus plugging a hole in the continuity. The Brig is retired at this point (and married to Doris), but still doing the occasional assignment for UNIT. In this case, he’s investigating one of those unfortunate “archaeological dig gone wrong” events when the Doctor and Evelyn drop in. There’s no question on the Brig’s part as to who the Doctor is, and they start working together immediately, with full trust. As for Evelyn, she immediately starts poking her nose in where it doesn’t belong, much like younger companions, although at first she does use her historical research skills. There’s probably one too many “minor character is not what they seem” twists, and as always with these early Big Finish stories, there’s a lot more talk than action, especially at the climax. The Brig remains stalwart and dependable throughout, and that’s the important thing. Aside from him, it’s not a terribly memorable story.
docs.title: The Spectre of Lanyon Moor

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Flip Philippa “Flip” Jackson was a bit character who appeared in “ The Crimes of Thomas Brewster ,” and later reappeared to become a proper companion. She’s very much in the mold of a typical companion, a contemporary young woman with a sense for adventure and an outgoing attitude, making her very similar to Lucie Miller, and therefore to Rose Tyler. By this point in his life, the Sixth Doctor had mellowed enough that he didn’t run roughshod over her like he did with Peri.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor and Flip

docs.text: Antidote to Oblivion Main Range #182 Released: 14 January 2014 Listened: 8/14/20 This story is rather longer than the previous Main Range entries, and is also more sedately paced, rather in line with its 1984 roots. It’s written by Phillip Martin, and is a sequel to his previous stories “ Mindwarp ” and the Lost Story “ Mission to Magnus ,” both of which feature Sil, who crops up here again. The daughter of Crozier from “Mindwarp” wants revenge on the Doctor, and the Time Lord Anzor from “Magnus” is here as well, but mercifully has little to say. Sil’s corporation has taken over the Earth, or at least the UK, but that’s not enough of a threat, so there are sentient microbes who want to take advantage of the situation. There’s also a fair dose of body horror, which is a theme in Martin’s work. There’s a young-ish couple who are reminiscent of the couple from “ Vengeance on Varos ,” and they drive a lot of the plot. In fact, the Doctor and Flip don’t really do much to resolve the situation, just spend their time trying not to get killed. Lots of bad guys end up dead or presumed dead, and the Doctor doesn’t seem to care all that much; this doesn’t seem like the same Doctor who was trying to save the Wirrn just a few stories ago. Because of the “Mindwarp” references, the Doctor is reminded of Peri for the first time in a while, and that’s going to run through the next few stories. Maybe it’s because I don’t like Sil all that much, but this story seems a regression for the Doctor. It probably would have been a better fit with the Lost Stories.
docs.title: Antidote to Oblivion

docs.text: Cortex Fire Main Range #225 Released: 16 May 2017 Listened: 8/12/20 In 2017, instead of doing a trilogy of Main Range stories that linked the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Doctors, Big Finish instead did three releases that each consisted of a pair of two-part stories, one for each Doctor. In this case, the second story on the disc seems to come first chronologically. Ian Potter has created a lot of sci-fi high concepts for this story: it takes place on a planet with a strong magnetic field, so the natives evolved with organs that sense that field for proprioception. Eventually, they created a computer network that they can tap into with those organs. The magnetic field also allows them to build a system of hover-cars, and results in spectacular auroras. Except the population has been plagued by instances of spontaneous combustion, and that’s what the Doctor and Flip run into. “Charge into” in Flip’s case, because she’s still behaving in a recklessly brave manner. However, in this story she seems to be more successful at thinking on the fly. The ending doesn’t quite add up to the setup, unfortunately, but it’s still quality. To get the most out of this story, it’s best not to listen to it right after the first story, or this one may get overwhelmed.
docs.title: Cortex Fire

docs.text: Scavenger Main Range #184 Released: 14 March 2014 Listened: 8/15/20 This one isn’t written by a classic series author, but it has the same slower pace as the previous two, with Flip and the Doctor separated for most of the story. Much of the plot revolves around the Indian Space Agency, and they’ve got actors with appropriate accents (as far as I can tell), so that’s a nice touch. However, the story is a bit all over the place, with lots of talk about space junk, an Irish administrator making a power play inside the space agency, a not-very-bright robotic scavenger ship sent by aliens, and a 400-year-old prince and his girlfriend somehow in the mix. Flip is awfully courageous once again, but she makes an effort not to be reckless. Unfortunately, things don’t work out for her, and she ends up in the worst danger she’s been in yet, which leads to the Doctor doing an awful lot of shouting. There’s not really a lot in the way of “villain” or “monster” in this story, so it’s mostly just drama surrounding Flip. She does get to interact with Anjli Mohindra, who played Rani Chandri in The Sarah Jane Adventures , and apparently they’re friends, which comes across in the story. Ultimately, the story leaves Flip on a heck of a cliffhanger, which is an interesting way to end this segment of the project.
docs.title: Scavenger

docs.text: Stage Fright The Last Adventure #3 Released: 17 August 2015 Listened: 8/13/20 This is another entry in the Sixth Doctor’s “Last Adventure” boxed set, and within the context of that set, the Valeyard is getting close to realizing his plan, and no longer needs to hide his involvement. He’s putting on private plays that re-enact the Doctor’s first five regenerations (with added melodrama), kill the novice actors he’s recruited, and give him their life energies. He’s rented out Henry Gordon Jago’s theater to do this, which gives Jago, Litefoot, and Ellie the opportunity to turn up and get involved. Flip is the first “modern day” companion to meet Jago and Litefoot, and her reaction to them is a lot more fun than Leela’s or Romana’s, who take them at face value. Flip leans more on the pop-cultural references than usual this time out, name-checking both Star Wars and Harry Potter at different points, to the Doctor’s consternation. Her characteristic fearlessness is put to good use within the plot, as we find out there’s one thing she is afraid of: performing on stage. The Valeyard is also full of references and foreshadowing as well, even hinting at Flip’s destiny, which we’ll see before too long. Although it’s a little self-indulgent, I think this is one of the more enjoyable stories in this part of the project.
docs.title: Stage Fright

docs.text: The Brood of Erys Main Range #183 Released: 14 February 2014 Listened: 8/15/20 This story is also by a classic-series writer, this time Andrew Smith. And again, the pacing is slower than previous stories with Flip. The Doctor and Flip end up near the living moon Erys, which is inhabited by a bunch of imp-like beings from the title. However, it’s a dangerous place, best avoided, and there’s a woman with no memory, Sarah, who has a mission to Erys, but she doesn’t quite know what it is. Of course, the Doctor can’t help but solve the mystery. Flip gets a good chunk of time apart from the Doctor, in which she continues to act rather recklessly. As with most Andrew Smith stories, the monsters have a reason for their behavior that’s the other characters don’t quite understand, although it’s not quite as big of a twist as his more famous stories, like “ Full Circle .” And there’s another reference to Peri at the end that reinforces the Doctor’s desire to find her. It’s a reasonable mystery, but it’s just not all that memorable.
docs.title: The Brood of Erys

docs.text: The Curse of Davros Main Range #156 Released: January 2012 Listened: 8/9/20 Welcome, Flip! And she gets to start out with a Dalek story, no less. You can see a lot of new-series influence in the start of this story. Flip and slightly-useless boyfriend Jared aren’t particularly phased by a spaceship falling on London, but they are split between “go help” and “alert the authorities, maybe make a buck.” Of course, they both had one adventure with the Doctor already, but Flip definitely wants to be involved as much as possible. She’s even angling for a companion spot right from the start. Unfortunately, the Doctor isn’t exactly what he seems in this story, and neither is Davros, in ways that are pretty obvious from the get-go, so it’s not really a spoiler. More interesting is that it seems the Daleks want to interfere with the battle of Waterloo, which gives Flip and Jared a chance to meet Napoleon and then the Duke of Wellington, and they’re both appropriately impressed. Jared gets over his uselessness, and is actually pretty effective, but Flip seems to be over him, and leaves him behind to run off with the Doctor. This really feels like a fresh start for the Sixth Doctor, with a new, enthusiastic companion, faster-paced storytelling, and a reset from the loneliness he’s had recently.
docs.title: The Curse of Davros

docs.text: The Fourth Wall Main Range #157 Released: 10 February 2012 Listened: 8/10/20 For Flip’s first trip, she gets a story that appears kind of silly on its face: She’s stuck in a TV show, specifically a cheesy sci-fi adventure. She comes very close to meta-commentary as she starts criticizing the program around her as it’s happening, which leads to serious consequences. Because while it’s a program, it’s also real, thanks to some reality-altering technobabble machine owned by a mogul whose broadcast channel is failing. This leads to the characters escaping into the real world, like a Star Trek holodeck episode. Flip is very much in the mold of Rose and Lucie (although this story was released after both of them), with sarcasm and pop-culture references for everything, but also brave and adventurous, even if her courage outstrips her abilities right now. It’s a John Dorney story, but an early one, so it’s not quite as twisty as you would expect from him. It does have the first appearance of the Porcians, the alien invaders who are terrible at invading, which always makes me laugh. Dorney does manage to balance the comedy with some very dark scenes, not to mention a high body count. On the whole, it’s quite memorable.
docs.title: The Fourth Wall

It’s a John Dorney story, but an early one, so it’s not quite as twisty as you would expect from him. It does have the first appearance of the Porcians, the alien invaders who are terrible at invading, which always makes me laugh. Dorney does manage to balance the comedy with some very dark scenes, not to mention a high body count. On the whole, it’s quite memorable.
docs.title: The Fourth Wall

docs.text: Vortex Ice Main Range #225 Released: 16 May 2017 Listened: 8/12/20 This story is by Johnny Morris, who can do twisty, but this is about as timey-wimey as any Moffat story (Colin Baker even uses the phrase in the extras). The trick is that Flip and the Doctor are in the story at two different points in their timeline. Saying anything more about that would be a spoiler, but I should say that the timey-wimey is confusing enough that you probably won’t be able to follow it on the first listen. Or the second, if enough time has passed between listenings, as it did for me. Even spending a chunk of time at the end of the story explaining it didn’t really help, and does drag the story down, although there is a thread about Flip having to do some agonizing things for the sake of preserving the timeline. I’m not sure that holds up, to be honest -- sometimes in this show the timeline is sacrosanct, and other times it’s more flexible. But that’s Doctor Who for you. How you feel about that contradiction will probably inform your enjoyment of this story.
docs.title: Vortex Ice

docs.text: Wirrn Isle Main Range #158 Released: March 2012 Listened: 8/11/20 Flip’s next trip takes a turn for the very dark and scary, set in the far future, after the solar flare disaster, when humans were just starting to restore the Earth. Which is pretty much a textbook setup for Wirrn and references to “ The Ark in Space .” This story also leans heavily on transmat technology and all the ways that can go wrong, which gives it a bit of a Star Trek feel, which is odd coming immediately after a “holodeck gone wrong” episode. Flip continues to be courageous, verging on foolish, a fact that even the Doctor has noticed by now. I’m not certain that the Wirrn behavior here really tracks with what we’ve seen before, and the writer seems to be going for “creatures doing what they must to survive” instead of “implacable force.” It also reminds me strongly of “Wirrn Dawn,” just as the previous story reminded me of “Max Warp,” which gives the impression that Flip is kind of a second-rate Lucie, which isn’t really fair, but there are parallels.
docs.title: Wirrn Isle

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Frobisher Big Finish doesn’t often delve into the comics continuity. Basically, they try to make sure that nothing Big Finish does directly contradicts the comics or novels if they can avoid it, and if there’s a particularly interesting element from other media, Big Finish will use it. In this case, that element is Frobisher, a Whifferdill private detective, which means he’s a shape-shifter who for some reason likes to spend most of his time in the shape of a penguin. As you can imagine, that’s a tough conceit to pull off on audio, which is probably why Frobisher only appears in a few stories, most of them specials. I think Robert Jezek does a pretty good job of capturing Frobisher’s tone. Whether these stories deserve to be “canon,” I’ll leave to your judgment.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor and Frobisher

docs.title: The Sixth Doctor and Frobisher

docs.text: The Holy Terror Main Range #14 Released: 20 November 2000 Listened: 8/2/20 This is Frobisher’s only appearance in the Main Range, and it appears to be seriously goofy at first. There’s a castle with a god-king, but upon his death he’s immediately declared blasphemy, and his son becomes the god-king. There’s a scheming half-brother, an evil queen, and a treacherous high priest, pretty much all conforming to the stereotypes you would expect. Except that the Doctor and Frobisher disrupt the expectations, and for a while Frobisher becomes god-king. Then it takes a turn for the seriously dark and even mythical, where it turns out that nothing is what it seems. The two halves of the story clash tonally, which was the intention, but Frobisher really isn’t a good fit for the second part. Fortunately, all anybody remembers about this story is the silly bit. All hail the big talking bird!
docs.title: The Holy Terror

docs.text: Main Range #14 Released: 20 November 2000 Listened: 8/2/20 This is Frobisher’s only appearance in the Main Range, and it appears to be seriously goofy at first. docs.text: The Maltese Penguin Bonus release Released: 12 July 2002 Listened: 8/2/20 This story is officially listed as bonus release #33⅓, because it was released as a freebie with Main Range release #33, "Neverland." This story takes place after the Doctor and Frobisher have already had several adventures together, and Frobisher wants a break, so he can be the hero of the story for once. As a result, the Sixth Doctor barely appears, except periodically popping up to ask Frobisher if he wants to resume traveling. However, Frobisher spends a large chunk of the story in the form of the Sixth Doctor (because he’s not good at humanoid forms, so gravitates toward people he knows), which means Colin Baker provides the voice, using a variation on the extremely nasal tones he uses to voice Peri in Short Trips. Frobisher is a private detective, meaning this is mostly a pastiche of noir detective stories, right down to the florid first-person narration. It also features the first appearance of Josiah Dogbolter, who will appear in at least one other Main Range story. On the whole, it’s awfully silly, but that’s intentional.
docs.title: The Maltese Penguin

docs.text: The Ratings War Bonus release Released: 10 January 2002 Listened: 8/2/20 This story isn’t numbered because it was originally a free inclusion with Doctor Who Magazine , and later a free download. It also doesn’t feature Frobisher, although Robert Jezek does appear, but as a different character. The Doctor is solo here, so the only reason I can see for it to appear at this point in the chronology is that it features another character who originated in the comics: the despicable Beep the Meep. Beep has a plan to take over the world through a signal in a television program, and because it’s a short special, the Doctor foils him right away. The whole purpose of the story is for the Doctor to complain about the sorry state of television in 2002. He specifically says that he doesn’t think television could handle a character like himself, which is kind of ironic after 2005. And I'm sure nobody in 2002 envisioned a televised version of "The Star Beast" in 2023 with the Fourteenth Doctor, so maybe it's best to just ignore this story. Aside from the continuity, it's fairly unremarkable. Big Finish hasn't attempted to use Frobisher since 2002, so this ends the Sixth Doctor's period of comic-book continuity.
docs.title: The Ratings War

docs.text: The Shape Shifter Doctor Who Magazine comic, #88-89 Published: 12 April 1984 - 10 May 1984 I’m not really including comics in this project, but Craig Brawley includes this one in his timeline, and I happen to own it, so I’ll note it here. This is the first introduction of Frobisher, although he's not using that name yet, nor does he take his traditional form of a penguin in this story. The Doctor is alone when he encounters Frobisher, who's working as a private detective.
docs.title: The Shape Shifter

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor, Jago, and Litefoot This section is a fairly extensive crossover with the Jago & Litefoot series...which I don’t have, because I don’t collect that series. At this point, Jago and Litefoot have met the Fourth Doctor several times with different companions, so they probably handle the temporal confusion and regeneration issues easily enough. At the end of this section, the Doctor takes them both for their first proper TARDIS trip, which was covered in two specials, which I do have.

docs.text: Voyage to the New World Jago & Litefoot #4.6 / Special Released: 20 December 2012 Listened: 6/4/20 After the previous harrowing adventure, Jago wants to go to a pub, so the Doctor accidentally takes them to the Roanoke colony in Virginia, in 1590. Most Americans will know this immediately as the failed colony that vanished without trace. What transpires is odd, and somewhat surreal, as the lost colonists are found, but in rather an odd prison, with even stranger jailers. The TARDIS ends up back in England, resulting in some Victorian era timey-wimey that seems partially mystical. It doesn’t really add up to a complete story. At the end of it, Jago & Litefoot end up in 1968, setting up the next season of their adventures.
docs.title: Voyage to the New World

docs.text: Jago & Litefoot #4.6 / Special Released: 20 December 2012 Listened: 6/4/20 After the previous harrowing adventure, Jago wants to go to a pub, so the Doctor accidentally takes them to the Roanoke colony in Virginia, in 1590. docs.text: Voyage to Venus Jago & Litefoot #4.5 / Special Released: 25 October 2012 Listened: 6/4/20 After the previous set of adventures, the Doctor offers to take Jago & Litefoot on a trip in the TARDIS, which the Fourth Doctor never did. So he takes them to Venus, which doesn’t seem all that far, galactically speaking, but there it is. The Doctor has mentioned Venus, and the natives thereof, many times in the past, but they haven’t actually appeared before. I’m not sure that the world actually needed an explanation of why the Venusian lullaby the Doctor used to pacify Aggedor in “ Curse of Peladon ” was sung to the tune of “God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen,” but now we have one. On the whole, it’s an attempt at sticking the Doctor into a Victorian style sci-fi story, a la Verne or Wells. So the trappings are strange, but the reactions of the aliens are very human, and caricatured. All Venusians are women (more or less) and of course the leader is a shrieking despot, so that’s not too interesting. For their part, Litefoot seems to be having a grand time, and Jago seems uncomfortable and out of his depth, which fits both of them.
docs.title: Voyage to Venus

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Jamie Since the Sixth Doctor met Jamie in “ The Two Doctors ,” it made sense that Colin Baker and Fraser Hines, two of the biggest supporters of Big Finish, would want to work together again. This is a trilogy that finds the Sixth Doctor encountering Jamie again, and then eventually Zoe.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor and Jamie

docs.text: Since the Sixth Doctor met Jamie in “ The Two Doctors ,” it made sense that Colin Baker and Fraser Hines, two of the biggest supporters of Big Finish, would want to work together again. This is a trilogy that finds the Sixth Doctor encountering Jamie again, and then eventually Zoe.
docs.title: The Sixth Doctor and Jamie

docs.text: City of Spires Main Range #133 Released: 30 April 2010 Listened: 8/3/20 This is one of the earlier Main Range stories to be told as a tightly connected trilogy. The Doctor ends up in the Highlands in what appears to be the late 1700s, but there are baddies around with technological knowledge from later eras. There are also creatures of myth around, such as redcaps, and legendary Scottish figures like Rob Roy Macgregor. Most importantly, though, he runs into Jamie McCrimmon, an older version of Jamie who doesn’t remember the Doctor, not even the events of “ The Highlanders ,” which Jamie should remember even after the Time Lords altered his memories. (In the context of this project, the Doctor met Jamie not long ago, in “ Last of the Cybermen ,” but that isn’t referenced here, because that story hadn’t been recorded yet.) A lot of time is spent re-establishing Jamie, who’s a heroic leader even without having ever met the Doctor. The story, though, involves an awful lot of running around, getting captured, uncaptured, and recaptured, because the real villain and its motivations aren’t revealed in this story. In that sense, this being the first part of a trilogy lets the story down. At the end, the Doctor sets off to retrieve the TARDIS, and Jamie goes along to keep him safe.
docs.title: City of Spires

docs.title: City of Spires

docs.text: Legend of the Cybermen Main Range #135 Released: 30 June 2010 Listened: 8/7/20 Now that the Doctor realizes that he and Jamie are in the Land of Fiction, references to “ The Mind Robber ” abound. This is one of those stories where you don’t have to have seen the classic episode, but it sure helps. That also means that Zoe shows up, with her full memories, claiming that it’s only been a month for her since she left them. She uses a bit of magic-tech to restore Jamie’s memories as well, so they’re all functioning on full trust as a team. When you’ve got a premise like this one, the writer can toss in any fictional character they like, and Mike Maddox certainly does. It doesn’t seem like the Cybermen would be a good fit for a Land of Fiction story, but that’s Doctor Who for you -- the Cybermen just accept it all at face value and get on with the converting. The latter half of the story focuses on Jamie and Zoe, and what their time with the Doctor meant to them, and how Zoe got into this situation in the first place. It’s a bit of an info-dump, and the ending really isn’t that strong, but this one really isn’t as much about the story resolving tightly.
docs.title: Legend of the Cybermen

docs.text: Night's Black Agents Companion Chronicles #4.11 Released: May 2010 Listened: 8/4/20 This is one of the only instances where a Companion Chronicle links directly to a Main Range story. After the event of “ City of Spires ,” Jamie and the Doctor need to go retrieve the TARDIS from the castle where they left it, but of course it’s not that easy. There’s another mythical creature disguised as a priest who’s holding the castle. Fortunately, Jamie and the Doctor take care of him fairly easily. Jamie gets to be the hero on his own, although the Doctor gets the big resolution. As a Companion Chronicle, this one is narrated by Jamie, and his vocabulary is a bit more advanced than we’ve seen in the past, but maybe he’s done some reading as he got older. It’s not a strictly necessary story, but it is a good opportunity to hear more of Jamie.
docs.title: Night's Black Agents

docs.title: Night's Black Agents

docs.text: The Wreck of the Titan Main Range #134 Released: 31 May 2010 Listened: 8/6/20 After the last adventure, the Doctor doesn’t seem to be too worried about the temporal confusion in Scotland; he just wants to take his old friend on a fun trip, and thinks that the Queen Mary would be a nice stop...except it’s not the Queen Mary , it’s the Titanic , except it’s not the Titanic , it’s...confusing. And then the Nautilus figures in. There’s lots of running, climbing, and escaping from peril in each of the four parts, but it does seem somewhat episodic. The background mystery is to figure out why the situations where they find themselves are so odd, and that doesn’t resolve itself until the very end, which ends up being a reference to a famous Second Doctor episode. This story doesn’t resolve so much as it just stops, and waits for the next part.
docs.title: The Wreck of the Titan

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Mel Once again, there’s a gap of undetermined length between the last section and this one. Somewhere in that gap, in a story we haven’t seen yet, the Doctor meets Mel for the first time from her perspective, and takes her along as a companion. Mel now goes from being the Doctor’s second young female companion to being one in a chain, on the older side of average, really. Her energy and enthusiasm make a contrast with even Flip and Charley, which can make her seem cartoonish, but Big Finish has fleshed out her character. The Sixth Doctor never got a proper regeneration story, so Big Finish eventually saw fit to provide him with one, which means Mel has to be present for it, so this is the last segment of his tenure.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor and Mel

docs.text: Broadway Belongs to Me! Purity Unleashed #1 Released: 23 May 2023 Listened: 5/27/23 In the cliffhanger from the previous story, Hebe vanished from existence. She doesn’t appear in this boxed set (barring a brief cameo), which may have something to do with Ruth Madderly’s appearing in the TV show. Mel is distraught, and the Doctor promises to find Hebe, so…it’s a good time for a comedy break? The Doctor traces the time distortion to New York, 1939. Although most Americans oppose the Nazis in Germany, there was a small but vocal group who supported them, and they were making noise in New York around this time. Mel didn’t know anything about that part of history, as it happens. However, she gets stuck joining the chorus of a Broadway play called “Behold America!” a pro-fascist song-and-dance extravaganza, and accidentally gets elevated to a starring role. Mel is both embarrassed to be in a musical, and disgusted at the subject matter, which is funny because Bonnie Langford is right at home on Broadway. In fact, the story is brimming over with jokes and references to musical theater, many of which I didn’t get, but there you are. As to what’s actually going on, credit to Matthew Sweet, you’ll never see it coming. And neither does the Doctor; he’s believably mystified right up until the reveal. Which somehow makes this comedy even more absurd than it already was. Maybe this wasn’t the best place to do a comedy, but when Big Finish wants to do a musical, they commit to the bit.
docs.title: Broadway Belongs to Me!

docs.text: Purity Unleashed #1 Released: 23 May 2023 Listened: 5/27/23 In the cliffhanger from the previous story, Hebe vanished from existence. She doesn’t appear in this boxed set (barring a brief cameo), which may have something to do with Ruth Madderly’s appearing in the TV show. Mel is distraught, and the Doctor promises to find Hebe, so…it’s a good time for a comedy break? The Doctor traces the time distortion to New York, 1939. Although most Americans oppose the Nazis in Germany, there was a small but vocal group who supported them, and they were making noise in New York around this time. Mel didn’t know anything about that part of history, as it happens. However, she gets stuck joining the chorus of a Broadway play called “Behold America!” a pro-fascist song-and-dance extravaganza, and accidentally gets elevated to a starring role. Mel is both embarrassed to be in a musical, and disgusted at the subject matter, which is funny because Bonnie Langford is right at home on Broadway. In fact, the story is brimming over with jokes and references to musical theater, many of which I didn’t get, but there you are. As to what’s actually going on, credit to Matthew Sweet, you’ll never see it coming. And neither does the Doctor; he’s believably mystified right up until the reveal. Which somehow makes this comedy even more absurd than it already was. Maybe this wasn’t the best place to do a comedy, but when Big Finish wants to do a musical, they commit to the bit.
docs.title: Broadway Belongs to Me!

docs.text: Catch-1782 Main Range #68 Released: April 2005 Listened: 9/13/20 This story is by Alison Lawson, who has written some prose Short Trips, but this is her only Main Range story, and it’s very different in tone. Mel goes to visit her uncle, a scientist and historian, learns some stuff about her family history, and then accidentally participates in it due to some involuntary time travel. Mel behaves oddly in this one, professing an interest in science, but demonstrating the opposite, and spending an unusual amount of time in distress. She also treats 2003 as “the present,” even though that would be nearly 20 years after her time. The Doctor also behaves much more carefully than usual about disturbing history, but it is Mel’s family history we’re talking about here. The plot itself is slow, and takes a while to get going, with a bunch of exposition in Part 1, but the story overall is shorter than most Main Range entries. There’s a lot of effort put into describing a paradox that will snarl the web of time, but it’s undone rather simply in the end. It really feels like there should be a twist ending, but there isn’t one, and the story just stops. On the whole, a rather unsatisfying story.
docs.title: Catch-1782

docs.text: Chronomancer Purity Undreamed #3 Released: 9 August 2022 Listened: 8/16/22 We get more Imogen Stubbs in this story, as the Doctor and company take Patricia to see the future of Earth…and she handles it very poorly indeed. Turns out Professor McBride isn’t as tolerant as she’s projected, and the future looks different than she expected. That leads to a rather charged scene where the Doctor decides not to engage with her anymore, and she responds the way any right-wing reply-guy would. It’s a scene that could have been cliche, but Stubbs makes you believe in McBride’s confusion and anger, and Colin Baker, for all that he plays a very shouty Doctor, manages to convey more anger and revulsion than he’s ever shown before, so credit to director Helen Goldwyn for that as well. The actual plot involves a pair of lost time warriors with connections to the Time Lords, but they don’t really make all that much of an impact. Rob Valentine gives Hebe some fun dialog where she drools over one of the warriors while Mel is aghast. Bigot Patricia is set up as the villain for the rest of this arc. I get what they were going for, with the villain being a regular bigot instead of a megalomaniac, but I’m not sure the leap to villainy is justified. There’s a dramatic cliffhanger, making it pretty clear that the next box set is a direct continuation.
docs.title: Chronomancer

docs.text: Girl in a Bubble Purity Unbound #1 Released: 30 August 2023 Listened: 9/18/23 The third boxed set starts with Hebe back in the crew, but not the Hebe you remember. Instead, it looks like Patricia has had another go at remaking reality, more or less successfully. Disability is unheard of, but Hebe still exists, having been “kept safe” in her home pretty much since birth, with Ron as a guardian/companion. That gives Toby Hadoke more to do, but it appears that Elise (also a wheelchair user) doesn’t exist this time around. It looks like keeping Hebe under her thumb allows Patricia’s alternate timeline to exist. Of course, what looks like a utopia on the surface is actually dystopian underneath: much of poetry and literature is banned, and there are “homes” for people whose disabilities are the result of injury or age. There’s a lot of running around on the Doctor and Mel’s part trying to figure out the timey-wimeyness. It’s partially successful because Colin Baker manages to lend a nice sense of urgency to the technobabble, but ultimately they’re talking about rather arbitrary time-travel “rules,” so there’s only so much gravitas it can have. And we’re clearly connecting the segments of the story together tightly, because there’s a bizarre cliffhanger ending.
docs.title: Girl in a Bubble

docs.text: Intuition Short Trips Rarities #2.3 Released: 22 December 2014 Listened: 9/17/20 A fairly typical short trip, as the Doctor takes Mel for a trip to the Alps so she can go skiing, and he can take a break. However, the people around him seem to be exhibiting an unusual amount of precognition, which leads the Doctor on a mystery trip to find an alien. There’s no monster or evil to be thwarted, just a mystery, which makes it perfect for this format. Mel barely appears, but that’s OK, as it’s a more introspective story for the Doctor. Which also means that Stephen Critchlow is more appropriate as the narrator, and he does his usual fine job.
docs.title: Intuition

docs.text: Loud and Proud Short Trips #8.2 Released: 25 March 2019 Listened: 9/14/20 This Subscriber short trip extra has an actual plot and a villain to defeat, and is a bit lengthy at 40 minutes, but it’s not a particularly complicated plot. Mel has somehow talked the Doctor into taking an anger management class in Pease Pottage, over his clear objections. Of course, it’s not just a simple class, as there’s an alien siphoning off anger for its own purposes. Fortunately, the Doctor sees through this rather quickly, and resolves the situation in a rather predictable manner. The only surprise here is some insight into Mel’s personality, in which she reveals that she’s aware just how her bubbly attitude comes across.
docs.title: Loud and Proud

docs.text: Maelstrom Water Worlds #3 Released: 17 May 2022 Listened: 5/27/22 The third story in this set takes the focus off of Hebe a bit, although her marine biologist background is still useful, because this is another water world. The high concept here, from Jonathan Morris, is that the colonists on this planet are body-swappers, with a number of stored minds in a computer who take turns in a very limited (and shrinking) number of bodies. This lets Bonnie Langford have some spotlight, as she spends a good chunk of the story playing somebody else. For the third time in this boxed set, what appears to be a monster actually isn’t, as such. That’s a fine Doctor Who trope, usually very effective, but I’m not sure we needed to use it in every story of this set. Hebe is an interesting character, a good addition to the series.
docs.title: Maelstrom

docs.text: Mel-evolent Short Trips #8.2 Released: 28 February 2018 Listened: 9/18/20 This short story takes place entirely within the TARDIS, which has a theater we’ve never seen before. It also features the Space-Time Visualizer, which the Doctor says he hasn’t seen in a long time, although he used it with Flip to watch cricket . Regardless, the story is a bit of a fairy tale, with goblins and an evil queen who has Mel’s face, stealing bits of the TARDIS. The unusual twist to this story is that it’s read by Bonnie Langford, who hasn’t done any other short trips, and therefore we don’t hear her narrate often. Simon Forward is the writer, and engages in a bit more word-play than Mel normally would, although Bonnie Langford carries it off pretty well.
docs.title: Mel-evolent

docs.text: Mind of the Hodiac Lost Stories Special Released: 30 March 2022 Listened: 4/2/22 This particular story stretches the definition of “Lost Story,” because it’s a script that was written, but never even accepted. The reason it merits recognition is because it was written by Russell T Davies back in the 80s, and he’s declared it the first Doctor Who writing he ever did. Unfortunately, it doesn’t make a lot of sense, although there are some distinctly 80s attributes to it. There’s a family who seem to be beset by a poltergeist, so they accept the invitation of a well-funded paranormal researcher to spend the night at her facility. How a paranormal researcher could be well-funded in the 80s is a mystery, as is the fact that she seems to be deeply religious. She’s played by Annette Badland, who’s normally quite good, but here she’s completely over the top. The titular Hodiac seems to be a powerful psychic out in space, who has an elaborate plan to destabilize the galactic financial market, just so he can make enough money to find his “other,” the other half of his gestalt mind. He also talks about himself in the third person – or actually gets his assistant to talk about him in the third person – and he’s obsessed with the Doctor’s coat, even before meeting him. You’d think that would be a plot point, but it isn’t. The Hodiac itself also makes no sense, a bifurcated being continually reborn on separate planets because they’re never supposed to meet. How does that evolve? Or was it created? Nobody’s saying. The Doctor is unusually absent-minded in this one, frequently quoting The Wind in the Willows for, again, no good reason. Mel is quite capable, carrying out a variety of plans, although none of them involve hacking a computer. It feels like there’s a story in there, but it doesn’t quite surface. I can see why it was rejected. I can also see why Big Finish didn’t want to step on the legendary RTD when it came to revising, but I kind of wish they had.
docs.title: Mind of the Hodiac

docs.text: The Doctor and His Amazing Technicolour Nightmare Coat Interludes #5 Released: 23 May 2023 Listened: 6/2/23 This is an Interlude, one of the “long short trips” that come as extras with the boxed sets. This one features the Sixth Doctor and Mel, so you can imagine it’s not entirely serious. Although the title says the story concerns the Doctor’s infamous coat, it doesn’t really, except in the loosest sense. The coat has a loose thread, so the Doctor returns to Kolpasha, where he bought it, to have it repaired. As a result, we’re told that the Doctor spends most of the story wearing a t-shirt with a picture of a cat on it. It seems like it’s one of those “comedy of errors” stories, except it immediately jumps forward a month, with Mel having spent that time working as a janitor, the Doctor having accidentally stolen the loot from a criminal otter, and the TARDIS on a different planet altogether. Their quest to get it back only leads to more silliness. It’s written by Gary Russell, a man who admittedly knows how to write a Doctor Who story, but here, he’s fallen into the trap that snares many Doctor Who writers, in which he’s trying to be Douglas Adams. The language is overly clever, the situations are overly absurd, and the descriptions are overly long. Adams spends a lot of time telling you what’s going on in minor characters’ heads, and while that’s amusing, it takes up a lot of narrative space. The story is read by Rosie Baker, Colin Baker’s daughter, and while she doesn’t try to imitate her father, she’s a pretty good narrator. I just wish the story were a little better.
docs.title: The Doctor and His Amazing Multicoloured Nightmare Coat

docs.text: Purification Purity Unleashed #2 Released: 23 May 2023 Listened: 5/27/23 This is one of those stories that would be murder to do on TV, because it hops around to many different places and time zones, and the actors play the same characters at different stages of their lives. The Doctor is trying to follow the time distortions again, and they end up in New Zealand, 1910, about to watch Robert Falcon Scott’s ship depart for the arctic. Oddly, nothing tries to interfere with the trip, but a deckhand decides not to go at the last minute. Then it’s London 1911, Hull 1916, Cambridge 1929, and Westminster 1935, where they eventually realize that Patricia McBride is who they’re chasing. She’s got a mostly functional time-suit, with an AI that’s helping her make changes to achieve her goal of a “better world,” which as we saw a couple of stories ago, is basically a fascist, eugenicist state. Patricia still thinks she’s doing the right thing, and the Doctor is once again shocked and appalled in a way he’s rarely been before. While he’s disgusted by Patricia’s beliefs, he’s more concerned right now with trying to get her to stop changing the timelines, because that never ends well. This one takes a bit of mental energy to follow because Patricia’s plan is amazingly convoluted, and the Doctor and Mel are a step behind most of the time. Still, it’s a decent middle episode.
docs.title: Purification

docs.text: Reverse Engineering Purity Undreamed #2 Released: 9 August 2022 Listened: 8/15/22 The second story reveals that this boxed set is going to be more tightly connected than the last, as Hebe has convinced the Doctor to hang around and help with the cleanup from last story. We’ve also got more of Patricia McBride, because if you’ve cast Imogen Stubbs, you don’t just use her in one story. She’s gone to visit an old friend at a health clinic he runs in Sweden, but of course something funny is going on, so she calls Hebe for help. Naturally, the health clinic is using alien-derived time technology to reverse-age the patients, but it’s all about to go horribly wrong. Mel gets more to do in this story, going undercover as an IT worker. Jonny Morris pays more attention to the plot than the last story too, giving us a few characters who aren’t what they appear, and folks who switch sides unexpectedly. And Patricia, having been dumped in the middle of a timey-wimey story, and being a fairly smart person, works out exactly what the TARDIS is.
docs.title: Reverse Engineering

docs.text: Spaceport Fear Main Range #170 Released: 11 February 2013 Listened: 9/16/20 I hope you like the phrase “Welcome to Tantane Spaceport,” because you’ll be hearing it a lot. The Doctor and Mel land in a spaceport that’s been cut off for 500 years, causing the trapped passengers to evolve a society around the tropes of airport life, reminiscent of “ Paradise Towers ” (which is in the future for both of them). It’s fun, and makes the people really distinctive, but it’s a bit off to assume that a spaceport in the year 6127 would be so similar to an airport in 2013, down to limitations on carrying liquids on-board. Mel’s tech background gets something of a workout, but it stays firmly grounded in the 80s, as she’s never seen a computer as advanced as the spaceport data terminals (although she will in “ The Juggernauts ”), and isn’t familiar with handhelds or wi-fi. (Again, it’s odd to assume that a 62nd century handheld works just like a 21st century phone.) The rest of the plot isn’t quite as satisfying as the setup, but there’s some betrayals and unexpected alliances, so it’s not bad, on the whole. It’s definitely a memorable episode, but more for the details than the story.
docs.title: Spaceport Fear

Mel’s tech background gets something of a workout, but it stays firmly grounded in the 80s, as she’s never seen a computer as advanced as the spaceport data terminals (although she will in “ The Juggernauts ”), and isn’t familiar with handhelds or wi-fi. (Again, it’s odd to assume that a 62nd century handheld works just like a 21st century phone.) The rest of the plot isn’t quite as satisfying as the setup, but there’s some betrayals and unexpected alliances, so it’s not bad, on the whole. It’s definitely a memorable episode, but more for the details than the story.
docs.title: Spaceport Fear

docs.text: The Brink of Death The Last Adventure #4 Released: 17 August 2015 Listened: 9/18/20 One of the more awkward parts of Colin Baker’s tenure is that he never filmed his regeneration scene, ending his time with the conclusion of the Trial instead. Big Finish rectified a lot of things about the Sixth Doctor’s time, and providing a proper regeneration is one of them. The other three parts of “The Last Adventure” have been scattered throughout the Sixth Doctor’s timeline, not necessarily in order, but in order for the Valeyard (and for the listeners, if they go straight through the boxed set). So it’s interesting that the Doctor thwarts the Valeyard’s plans by meddling with his own timeline, and forcing the events of “ Time and the Rani ” to come to pass. Although this story features Mel as the companion, she spends most of the story believing that the Valeyard is the Doctor (hints of the Unbound story “He Jests at Scars”), whereas the Doctor is accompanied by the Time Lady engineer Genesta, who for strange reasons has a pronounced Yorkshire accent. Michael Jayston, as always, is brilliantly menacing as the Valeyard, unafraid to go over the top as a baddie. Naturally, the story has to end with self-sacrifice, and a speech on the Doctor’s part as he regenerates (two, actually). They’re pretty good, if not quite up to Moffat-level speeches. Nick Briggs gets the job done, and with that, brings the Sixth Doctor’s era to a satisfying close.
docs.title: The Brink of Death

docs.text: The Corruptions Purity Unbound #2 Released: 30 August 2023 Listened: 9/22/23 After the cliffhanger, it seems we’ve moved from one bubble to another, as Purity tries isolating Mel this time. She’s in Pease Pottage in 1985ish, happy and fulfilled, with a vaguely defined job “in computers, somewhere.” Hebe owns the local cafe, and Elise is a florist. Ron doesn’t exist in this version. Presumably this is a prison where Mel and Hebe can stay preserved, and not threaten Purity’s timeline. Except that Mel is a complicated space-time event (even moreso than most companions, given how badly twisted her own history is), and the bubble starts to break down, letting in some kind of time-wraiths. The Doctor is trapped outside, literally; he’s imprisoned in a motorway services station on the M23, and simply told that he can’t interfere, or Mel will die. As if the Doctor is going to just hang out at a highway rest stop for all eternity. It’s kind of nice to see Pease Pottage again, and as a child of the 80s, I always appreciate stories set during that era, but this is more or less filler. It’s an extended version of “lock the Doctor in a cell for a bit,” which works as well as it ever does.
docs.title: The Corruptions

docs.text: The Death of Peladon Peladon #3 Released: 28 January 2022 Listened: 2/6/22 Placing this here rather arbitrarily. Although the Doctor appears several times in the Peladon boxed set, Mel is the only companion who does. Which is nice, because Peladon is being ruled by a queen again, with a somewhat recalcitrant princess for an heir, and they can both use a shot of Mel’s agency and energy. Unfortunately, it doesn’t get very far. Peladon is on the verge of dumping its monarchy, again; the miners are upset, again; and nothing has been done about the pollution that was uncovered in the previous stories. The Sixth Doctor is unfortunately rather ineffective here. His usual way of impressing royalty doesn’t work, nor does his penchant for being greeted warmly by old friends, except for Alpha Centauri, of course. Of the four stories in this set, though, this is the closest to a traditional Doctor Who story, with plotting, running through corridors, and certain death. It just doesn’t seem to amount to very much.
docs.title: The Death of Peladon

docs.text: The Dream Nexus Interludes #1 Released: 17 May 2022 Listened: 8/14/22 This is another Interlude, an hour-long story told in narrated form, this time by Toby Hadoke. Toby, as usual, doesn’t do impersonations, but he captures the Sixth Doctor’s speech mannerisms quite well. This time, they’re not on a water world; it’s a planet entirely inhabited by fungus. Except it’s not boring, because there’s a human military research outpost here too. And of course people are dying. Because of its short length, there’s less of the “authority figures don’t trust the Doctor and toss him in a cell” than usual, although there’s still some. And credit to writer Stephen Christopher in his first Big Finish story, it’s not easy to figure out what’s really going on, and who’s on which side. And given that one of the sides is mind-controlling mushrooms, that’s not bad. Mel’s programming skills are used for once, and Hebe acknowledges that her specialty isn’t all that useful here, although she helps. On the whole, it’s a pretty decent story.
docs.title: The Dream Nexus

docs.text: The Juggernauts Main Range #65 Released: 15 January 2005 Listened: 9/12/20 It’s a while (in release order) until Mel appears again, mostly because Bonnie Langford had been recording stories with Sylvester McCoy. Mel hadn’t encountered the Daleks as of yet, so this story gives Mel the Dalek adventure that all companions should have. It starts nicely in media res, and separates Mel from the Doctor for most of an episode, during which it looks like she may have to get on with her life on a colony somewhere in the future. This story takes place at a time after “ Revelation of the Daleks ,” when Davros is on the outs with his creations. As a result, Davros is manipulating the people of the colony, the Daleks are manipulating the Doctor, and the Doctor of course plans to play both sides against the middle, leaving Mel feeling betrayed from all sides. Into this mix are the Mechonoids from “ The Chase ,” or the Juggernauts as Davros names them. Unfortunately, they don’t add a lot to the story, as the Doctor is the only one who recognizes them (“The Chase” is in the future for this Dalek timeline), and the Mechonoids themselves have no memories. Given their soft voices and odd way of speaking, and general unthreatening appearance, it’s hard to take them seriously as a threat. The Doctor also doesn’t seem to be taking the Daleks seriously; he’s snarkier than usual toward them, although definitely softer toward Mel. As for Mel herself, she gets to show off her programming skills, and acquire some futuristic ones. She also displays a lot of empathy, and even a moral crisis near the end. This is one of those stories where the character work is better than the plot.
docs.title: The Juggernauts

docs.text: The Mindless Ones Purity Undreamed #1 Released: 9 August 2022 Listened: 8/14/22 With the Main Range having ended, Big Finish released stories for all the Doctors in boxed sets. Although the first box featuring Hebe was a standalone, the next three boxes (nine episodes) are essentially one story, all with "Purity" in the titles. This set opens back on Earth, not dealing with Hebe’s marine biology specialty, but rather, the university where she learned it. It’s written by Paul Magrs, so you can expect some off-kilter plot and biting satire. In this case, the university has funded a “mindfulness center,” aimed at helping struggling students, and of course it’s all brainwashing and alien interference. Thing is, it doesn’t quite work for me. The satire is far too broad, with the techniques being treated like New Age claptrap that nobody should fall for. Magrs also seems to be arguing that the “right” mental attitude is acerbic and cynical, which may be very British, but isn’t an attitude I hold with right now. Hebe’s old friend Elise has gone through some changes as well, which she calls “maturing” and Hebe thinks is “selling out.” But Elise is the one who called for help with the signaler given to her by Evelyn, so what’s going on behind the scenes?
docs.title: The Mindless Ones

docs.text: The One Doctor Main Range #27 Released: 17 December 2001 Listened: 9/11/20 Not only does Mel not get a proper introduction story, in her first recorded story, they go straight for the absurd. (Mel had already appeared in a Seventh Doctor story in recording order, but this is her first with the Sixth.) This is the first of Big Finish’s Christmas specials, with a distinctly silly panto theme. The high concept is that the Doctor and Mel have arrived at the far end of time, where a con man named Banto Zame is passing himself off as the Doctor, along with his assistant Sally-Anne. However, the listener is almost immediately clued in to the con, and even the assumption that the real Doctor may be a fake is dispensed with by the end of episode one. The four then go on a quest for three valuable items that are needed to save the system, each of which is quite silly and requires some absurd shenanigans to obtain. As often happens in these very early recordings, Colin Baker’s voice sounds much younger than recent recordings, almost to the point of being distracting. This story was written before all of his Big Finish character growth, so although he’s kinder with Mel than he was with Peri, he’s still prone to exasperation. In trivial matters, the third episode uses the “Delaware theme” for no reason I can determine. A couple of aliens are also played by Matt Lucas, many years before his time as Nardole, but his voice is so altered you’ll never recognize him. Finally, there are a couple of bonus tracks at the end of the last episode. If you don’t mind occasional silliness in your Doctor Who stories, this one isn’t bad.
docs.title: The One Doctor

docs.text: The Rotting Deep Water Worlds #1 Released: 17 May 2022 Listened: 5/26/22 The “Water Worlds” boxed set from 2022 introduces a new companion for the Doctor and Mel: Hebe Harrison, 21st century marine biologist and wheelchair user, played by Ruth Madeley. In her introductory story, Hebe gets most of the spotlight in this base-under-seige story set on an oil rig. She’s got a bit of a spiky personality, which meshes well with the Sixth Doctor, but doesn’t shout “companion material.” Perhaps to compensate, everyone else on the rig is phenomenally unlikable, but they’re all doomed anyway, so nobody misses them. There’s a lot of time spent on exactly how Hebe does and doesn’t want to be treated, and to be fair, it’s complicated. Mel is naturally helpful, and from an earlier era, so she gets things wrong a lot, but apologizes and gets better. The Doctor is better at accepting differences, of course, but he’s not perfect. The story could come across as a little preachy, but I can tell they were trying to avoid that. With all the interpersonal stuff going on, there’s not a lot of time for story. Although there is a very real menace, resolving it is pretty straightforward. Oddly, Ruth Madeley and Bonnie Langford would both appear on TV in 2023's "The Giggle" and 2025's "Wish World / The Reality War," but Ruth Madeley was playing UNIT scientific advisor Shirley Bingham. I haven't seen any behind-the-scenes material yet that acknowledged these Big Finish stories.
docs.title: The Rotting Deep

docs.text: The Seeds of War Main Range #171 Released: 14 January 2013 Listened: 9/17/20 At this point in production time, Bonnie Langford hadn’t been available to Big Finish for several years, and Big Finish had switched to doing the Main Range mostly in trilogies. However, the first part of this trilogy was “ The Wrong Doctors ,” leaving the other two scattered throughout this era. Periodically, Big Finish comes up with a character, usually an enemy, that they become fond of, and it appears through several stories that are close together in release date, but far apart in the Doctor’s chronology. In 2013, that was the Eminence and its Infinite Warriors. Admittedly, the Eminence is pretty formidable, and just the kind of thing the Doctor would fight. Although this was the first appearance of the Eminence in release order, this is sort of a middle story, in which the Doctor hasn’t seen the Eminence in some time. In fact, humanity has just finished fighting a 50-year war against the Infinite Warriors, but emerged victorious, or so they think. The plot is a bit more convoluted than normal, with several threads and different locations, and a bunch of well-realized secondary characters. In addition, the setting changes several times during the story, moving from one planet to another. Unfortunately, the ending doesn’t have the right emotional impact, as the Doctor and Mel accept the fates of the secondary characters rather cavalierly, although the dialog indicates that they were affected. The Eminence, which is built up as a big threat, and which certainly sounds like one, doesn’t really do all that much in this story. Odd that it suffers from middle story syndrome without actually being a middle story.
docs.title: The Seeds of War

docs.text: The Tides of the Moon Water Worlds #2 Released: 17 May 2022 Listened: 5/27/22 As Hebe is a marine biologist, she wants to see more water worlds, and the Doctor is happy to comply, or at least try to. It turns out that the “nearest” water world is Earth’s Moon, two billion years past. It’s also inhabited by amphibians, who are, of course, being threatened by disaster. This story is written by American writer Joshua Pruett, of Phineas and Ferb and some other offbeat stories, so you’d expect it to be a little odd. While some of the science is strange, the actual resolution isn’t too unusual for Doctor Who , albeit a little new-series. Hebe still gets a lot of the focus, as this is her first adventure, and it’s pretty even-handed with her. While she’s game to explore, she also messes up a lot of the standard procedures, and blows off Mel when she tries to help. Having her violate someone else’s personal space might be a bit much, but it does seem believable. She also acknowledges that her chair does impose some limitations on the adventuring lifestyle, which seems the right approach. There’s good characterization in this one, but the story is just OK.
docs.title: The Tides of the Moon

docs.text: The Vanity Box Main Range #97 Released: July 2007 Listened: 9/15/20 The fourth part of this release is nominally a separate story, supposedly to reveal the origin of the Wishing Beast, but it doesn’t really. It just ends up being a rather silly interlude in Salford. Paul Magrs is usually good for a farce, but it doesn’t add much to the story. Extras were a new thing for Big Finish at this time, and the ones here are rather long and rambly.

docs.text: The Wishing Beast Main Range #97 Released: July 2007 Listened: 9/15/20 This story is one of those spooky, atmospheric ones where you’re not entirely sure what’s going on, but there seems to be magic involved. Except it’s set on an abandoned planetoid, for no reason I can determine. There’s a spooky house with a couple of spooky old ladies, who want to take Mel into a spooky forest filled with spooky ghosts so she can meet the spooky monster from the title and have her wish granted. Except of course the Doctor wants to talk to the ghosts, who are the real victims here. Oddly, the story is only three parts, but it feels like it takes forever to get going, presumably to build the spooky suspense. The resolution is annoyingly talky, and doesn’t seem to amount to much. Paul Magrs is usually good with the surreal stories, but this one doesn’t seem to click.
docs.title: The Wishing Beast

docs.text: Main Range #97 Released: July 2007 Listened: 9/15/20 This story is one of those spooky, atmospheric ones where you’re not entirely sure what’s going on, but there seems to be magic involved. Except it’s set on an abandoned planetoid, for no reason I can determine. There’s a spooky house with a couple of spooky old ladies, who want to take Mel into a spooky forest filled with spooky ghosts so she can meet the spooky monster from the title and have her wish granted. Except of course the Doctor wants to talk to the ghosts, who are the real victims here. Oddly, the story is only three parts, but it feels like it takes forever to get going, presumably to build the spooky suspense. The resolution is annoyingly talky, and doesn’t seem to amount to much. Paul Magrs is usually good with the surreal stories, but this one doesn’t seem to click.
docs.title: The Wishing Beast

docs.text: The Wrong Doctors Main Range #169 Released: 14 January 2013 For the primary Mel in this story, it takes place here, after she’s helped the younger Doctor at the Trial. Presumably he gets her back to her Doctor before the next story, but those events haven’t been seen yet.
docs.title: The Wrong Doctors

docs.text: Main Range #169 Released: 14 January 2013 For the primary Mel in this story, it takes place here, after she’s helped the younger Doctor at the Trial. Presumably he gets her back to her Doctor before the next story, but those events haven’t been seen yet.
docs.title: The Wrong Doctors

docs.text: The Wrong Side of History Purity Unbound #3 Released: 30 August 2023 Listened: 9/25/23 Now it’s time for a jaunt to the future, specifically the future where Patricia got her time-suit from in the first place, except as it exists in the “Purity timeline.” Which is a decent start, until we learn that Patricia isn’t really in control, and hasn’t been for a while. The Chronomancers have been using her to get out of the trap the Doctor stuck them in back in “Chronomancer .” Honestly, these particular universe-conquerers are so dull that I didn’t even mention them in my recap of that story. That also absolves Patricia of responsibility for the nightmare she created. The goal for this set of stories was putting the Doctor up against not a typical villain, but a regular bigot, albeit one who lucks into an extraordinary amount of power. Except the rug-pull is that it was just somebody else using her bigotry to their own ends. Which renders her a somewhat sympathetic character again, at least enough for the Doctor. Unfortunately, the Chronomancers are so poorly developed that they’re more laughable than scary. Bottom line: Hebe’s great, and so is Ruth Madeley. I see what they were trying to do with this story, but it falls down at the ending.
docs.title: The Wrong Side of History
