docs.text: Thicker Than Water Main Range #73 Released: September 2005 Listened: 9/14/20 In Big Finish, the Sixth Doctor never seems able to escape his own past, and keeps revisiting the fates of his companions. Here, close to the end of his tenure, he does it one more time, with Evelyn. The Doctor seems to have backslid a bit in his personal growth, and Mel is becoming irritated with him, so the Doctor decides to introduce her to Evelyn. It’s been about three years on Vilag since “ Arrangements for War ,” Evelyn has married Rossiter, who is now one of the leaders of a united planet, and she’s taken up a political post herself, working with groups researching all the alien debris left behind from the invasion. She’s also had a medical procedure to help her heart condition, and while it worked, she’s been more angry and short-tempered ever since. She also fails spectacularly to get along with Rossiter’s daughter Sophia, who opposes the research efforts. When Evelyn is kidnapped after a big speech, Sophia’s the likely culprit, but she doesn’t act like it. The Doctor and Rossiter investigate from another direction, and uncover a story that’s satisfying in how it resolves, even though there’s not a lot of suspense about who the bad guy is. The story also features flashbacks to Evelyn’s departure from the Doctor (he doesn’t handle it particularly well, but to be fair, he pretty much never does), and to her wedding, at which she hoped the Doctor would turn up, but he didn’t. The best part of the story is the conversations between Evelyn and Mel, as they talk about the Doctor and what being a companion means (a year before Rose and Sarah Jane had a much more melodramatic conversation). There’s also an interlude with the Seventh Doctor, letting Evelyn know who Hex is, and how he’s doing. That seems a bit jammed in, but this probably seemed like the only opportunity to tie up that loose end. We’ll say goodbye to Evelyn for the Sixth Doctor’s era, but she’s not entirely done in this project.
docs.title: Thicker Than Water

docs.text: Time-Burst Purity Unleashed #3 Released: 23 May 2023 Listened: 5/27/23 Patricia is now calling herself “Purity,” has gone full cyborg, and is on to Plan B. Fortunately, that involves staying in one place, so the story isn’t hopping around so much, and it’s actually kind of a historical, set in Sheffield, 1864. Patricia is setting up a factory community there, with lousy pay, but lots of communal amenities to kick off her eugenicist vision. How’s that going to work, when factories are springing up all over Sheffield? Because there’s a great flood that’s going to wipe most of them out, but the Doctor doesn’t remember that right away. Ian Potter creates sympathy in this situation by focusing on a specific family, one who could benefit from a better deal at a factory, but is smart enough to know something’s up. There’s plenty of Sheffield flavor in this one, and lots of authentic history (so they tell me), but also a nice run-around, as the Doctor keeps accidentally finding himself in the 21st century, leading to a rather funny scene as he uses a bystander’s phone to do a bunch of research in seconds that would take hours in 1864. Thing is, the Doctor is a couple of steps behind the entire story, even when he thinks he’s won, which sets up another impressive cliffhanger, so clearly this story isn’t over yet.
docs.title: Time-Burst

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Peri The Sixth Doctor starts off his era with Peri already accompanying him, in the frankly disastrous “Twin Dilemma.” I have a very poor opinion of this first season, and I’m not alone. Fortunately, Big Finish seems to avoid setting stories there, probably because the Doctor and Peri spend most of their time bickering, and that’s not much fun to listen to. The good news is that their relationship seemed to improve sometime between “Revelation of the Daleks” and the Trial, so Big Finish sets a bunch of stories there, where they’re easier in each other’s company. Unfortunately, this era also includes the first set of “Lost Stories,” specifically, stories that were planned for Season 23 in 1986, but which were canceled and replaced with the Trial. The other Lost Stories come in singles or small groups, but this is an entire season’s worth of stories, ones where the Doctor and Peri don’t really get along too well. So this part of the Sixth Doctor’s era is rather lengthy, and has a big chunk of stories I don’t particularly like right in the middle.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor and Peri

docs.text: A Most Excellent Match Main Range #150 Released: 9 August 2011 Listened: 5/10/20 This story sees Peri trapped in a Jane Austen holo-novel, and the Doctor needs to get her out. However, there’s something more sinister going on here, and eventually other novels from that period are brought in and mashed up. It’s basically an excuse for the Doctor and Peri to face off against Mr. Darcy, Alec d’Urberville, and Heathcliff. Kudos to Philip Bretherton for playing them all with distinct voices.
docs.title: A Most Excellent Match

docs.text: An Eye for Murder Main Range #188 Released: 11 July 2014 Listened: 3/27/20 The Doctor and Peri arrive at a women’s college in 1939, where Peri is mistaken for a famous alumna, now a mystery novelist. Peri gets to hold her own as an investigator, and the Doctor gets to bluster a lot. Eventually there turns out to be some sci-fi involved, and everything falls back to the normal patterns. Not quite as compelling as I’d like it to be.
docs.title: An Eye for Murder

docs.text: Attack of the Cybermen TV Season 22, Serial 1 Aired: 5 January 1985 - 12 January 1985 Set in London in 1985, this story famously “fixed” the Chameleon Circuit, although it went back to being a police box by the end. It also featured Lytton from “Resurrection of the Daleks.” Season 22 starts here. The show is back to airing once a week, but the episodes are now 45 minutes each.

docs.text: Blood on Santa's Claw and Other Stories Main Range #259 Released: 10 December 2019 Listened: 3/26/20 This release is from near the end of the Main Range, the 2019 Christmas story. It’s another collection of short stories, all of which have a Christmas theme. The big difference here is that Peri has acquired a boyfriend named Joe shortly before the first story, and the subplots involve how he adapts, how Peri adjusts to having a partner on her journey, and how the Doctor (still somewhat abrasive at this point) copes with another human who he didn’t pick. All the stories are set in the 59th century, which the Doctor normally avoids, because it’s “silly.” The first story is fairly absurd, revolving around people who’ve taken Shakespeare, The Wind in the Willows , and any number of other things as official religions. The second involves designer children, and that’s where things start to turn dark. The third story is about people trapped at an orbiting Christmas party for three years. And in the final, the Doctor discovers that he’s made a big mistake. Peri gets a lot of spotlight in this story, and a lot of excellent dialog. (Spoiler: It isn’t, in fact, a collection of short stories, but one long story by Nev Fountain disguised as a series of Christmas stories. This is Nev Fountain, so the writing is at once silly, sharp, and dark, and Peri gets a lot of good lines. Joe isn’t what he seems to be, and is actually the bad guy of the story. This is one that benefits from re-listening, so you can find the clues that are dropped.)
docs.title: Blood on Santa's  Claw

docs.text: Breaking Bubbles Main Range #188 Released: 11 July 2014 Listened: 3/20/20 This release is an anthology of short stories, which Big Finish seems to like using the Sixth Doctor for. In this installment, the Doctor and Peri meet an imprisoned former empress who led a rebellion against her brother and was later deposed herself. She has an escape plan, but the Doctor delays her with technical wizardry, and Peri, somehow, talks her out of it, on the grounds that she doesn’t want to start another war (even though she’d already started one before). Jemma Churchill is pleasantly urbane as the empress, but the logic of the story doesn’t hold up for me.
docs.title: Breaking Bubbles

docs.text: Cryptobiosis Special Released: 13 December 2005 Listened: 3/18/20 This is a special release, an hour-long story from 2005. Although other special releases tend to be light or even farcical, this one is grim. It takes place on a steamship in 1901, where an avaricious sailor has discovered a race of mer-men, and is determined to exploit them. As often happens in historical stories, Peri has a particularly awful time, and most of the secondary characters end up dead. As a special, it’s pretty typical.
docs.title: Cryptobiosis

docs.text: Davros Main Range #48 Released: 19 September 2003 Listened: 3/18/20 This is the earliest Big Finish Main Range release with the Sixth Doctor, chronologically, and one of the earlier releases in general. It’s part of the Omega / Davros / Master trilogy that led up to “Zagreus,” and while “Master” is regarded as a classic, this one is...kind of just there. It’s the first appearance of Davros in Big Finish, and was likely quite a big deal at the time. The general idea is that Davros and the Doctor are forced to work together for a larger corporation, at least for a bit. This is clearly where Davros gets his big business ideas that we’ll see in “Revelation,” which is later in his timeline. As expected for an early Big Finish, it’s rather talky, and short on action. The Doctor acts like he’s in control of the situation at all times, but he doesn’t really do much; he just reacts to things going on around him. The emphasis seems to be on telling Davros’ backstory, particularly his relationship with Shan, another scientist who may have been even more brilliant than Davros. This is clearly the inspiration for the “I, Davros” series released shortly thereafter. The problem is that the background doesn’t make Davros into a tragic figure; it just makes him seem even more evil. Wendy Padbury (Zoe) makes an appearance as Lorraine Baynes, before the Second Doctor era was represented in Big Finish. This story is unusually long, with just two parts, each 75 minutes. Unfortunately, I just didn’t enjoy it all that much.
docs.title: Davros

docs.title: Davros

docs.text: Emissary of the Daleks Main Range #254 Released: 14 August 2019 Listened: 5/14/20 It’s been a while since we’ve had a Dalek story for the Sixth Doctor, and this one is...kind of standard, really. It’s by Andrew Smith, who’s usually pretty good at getting inside the psyche of the villains, but he doesn’t really do that this time around. The major story point is the leader of a Dalek-occupied world, and how much she’ll acquiesce to the Daleks to protect her people, and the point where that becomes collaboration. Which is a decent story, but it’s been done in the Dalek Empire series with Susan Mendez, which doesn’t seem to be a factor in this story at all. There’s some interesting ideas and a bit of double-cross. A lot of minor characters get killed, making the whole story seem somewhat grim, but it is a Dalek story. Peri has a good amount of agency, and gets to do action things, but the resolution is somewhat predictable. A bit disappointing.
docs.title: Emissary of the Daleks

docs.text: ...ish Main Range #35 Released: 29 August 2002 Listened: 5/6/20 This one is distinctly memorable, yet both more and less than it seems. The Doctor and Peri attend a symposium where an old friend of the Doctor’s has been compiling the ultimate dictionary of English, with an AI companion. Of course, as often happens with old friends of the Doctor, she dies almost immediately after their arrival. The monster is a semi-sentient word, which mostly seems bent on destruction and chaos. The story isn’t really the important part, though; it’s giving the Doctor lots of interesting words to say, lots of discussion about the relationship between language and meaning, and lots of praise of English (specifically British English). Peri gets in on the act too, displaying verbal dexterity and a penchant for word-play that she doesn’t really have in any other stories. The resolution is a bit flat, with the Doctor out-clevering the monster as usual. It’s a story that seems to be intended as the ultimate showcase of the Sixth Doctor, and in that sense it succeeds, but as a story itself, it’s rather suspect.
docs.title: ...ish

docs.text: Leviathan Lost Stories #1.3 Released: 21 January 2010 Listened: 4/8/20 The TARDIS lands in medieval England, only to quickly reveal that it’s not, in fact, medieval England, but a facsimile. A facsimile on a spaceship in the future, as it happens, but that doesn’t become obvious until Part 2. A generation ship that malfunctioned a long time ago, leading to one of those backwards dystopias run by a deranged computer, but this time, there’s a third party trying to kill everybody and sell the ship for scrap. The plot unfolds slowly over the course of the story, and mostly holds together (except for the villagers never noticing that when the children come of age, they get replaced with younger versions; kind of a plot hole there). The Doctor is abrasive, and unusually in favor of fighting, even dying, for a cause, but not taken to extremes. Peri is somewhat shrill, which is normal for this season, but does get a certain amount of agency. It’s probably the best Lost Story thus far, in terms of story.
docs.title: Leviathan

docs.text: Memories of a Tyrant Main Range #253 Released: 11 July 2019 Listened: 5/12/20 This story and the next are later Main Range releases (the third part of the set is much later, for reasons). Peri seems quite comfortable with the Doctor now, and he’s more kind towards her. They’re doing the “Doctor’s old friend calls for help” story, in this case a famous lawyer whose client may be a genocidal tyrant...except he can’t remember who he is, so they’re all at a facility specializing in memory recovery to find out. The first half of the story is a slow boiler, with very gradual revelations, punctuated by the cliffhangers. Ultimately, the story wants to be about deeper issues of how memory forms personality, and whether it’s ethical to punish someone for acts they can’t remember. So it ends up being ambiguous, and frankly a bit jumbled at the very end, but if you can concentrate on what’s going on, it’s a good story.
docs.title: Memories of a Tyrant

docs.text: Mission to Magnus Lost Stories #1.2 Released: 9 December 2009 Listened: 4/4/20 This is one of those stories that pulls in stuff from the Doctor’s past without considering whether it makes sense. It makes an awkward story, but one that probably fits in 1985, when JNT didn’t care that much about story quality. In this case, there’s a Time Lord named Anzor, on a mission from the High Council to the planet Magnus. Magnus is a planet entirely populated by women, where men die of a virus before they reach maturity. So of course Anzor is a raging sexist, which makes little sense for a 1985 story, but is even worse now that we know about Time Lords’ flexibility as relates to gender. Anzor is also an old classmate of the Doctor’s, a bully who the Doctor is terrified of at the beginning of the story, but not later, for no reason. Sil is here, also for no real reason, having lost face after his failure on Varos. In the second part, Anzor disappears, and the Ice Warriors turn up, trying to knock the entire planet out of orbit, which is a bit of a stretch even for them. The whole story ends up making little sense, and is shockingly sexist. The extras reveal that the cast knows it too, and thinks it’s OK because people will understand that it was meant to be performed in 1985, but I think it was appallingly sexist even for then. I really dislike this one.
docs.title: Mission to Magnus

docs.text: Murmurs of Earth Short Trips #3.6 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 5/15/20 Placed here because the Doctor and Peri are still sniping at each other, and the Doctor is still an inveterate name-dropper. The Doctor takes Peri to see the Oort Cloud, which unexpectedly has a habitable asteroid in it. It turns out to be the work of an alien who’s come to observe humanity. Peri seems particularly irritable, although she does have a headache. She also seems unusually stupid, not understanding basic science, and not remembering the Voyager missions, which as an American child of the 70s, she almost certainly would. Colin Baker reads this one, and his impression of Peri is quite grating.
docs.title: Murmurs of Earth

docs.text: Not Forgotten Subscriber Short Trips #2020.1 Released: 17 March 2020 Listened: 4/6/20 This Short Trip is pretty much the definition of the series -- it’s a short scene that resolves quickly. In this case, the Doctor and Peri track down a temporal anomaly to a New York diner and discover a young man from the future who’s inadvertently created a paradox, with grave consequences. Steven Critchlow captures the Doctor’s tone perfectly, and the dialog is spot-on for this period; he’s arrogant, grimly scary, and sympathetic by turns. His Peri is a good try, but he still mispronounces “Maryland.” It’s a decent story, and a good fit for this project.
docs.title: Not Forgotten

docs.text: Of Chaos Time The Main Range #188 Released: 11 July 2014 Listened: 3/27/20 Yes, I have that title correct. It reflects the structure of the story, which is heavily timey-wimey, as the Doctor bounces back and forth over the events of several hours. He needs to stop a temporal bomb from going off, which led to this problem in the first place. Unraveling the twistiness of the story is the real emphasis, because the payoff is somewhat weak.
docs.title: Of Chaos Time The

docs.text: Paradise 5 Lost Stories #1.5 Released: 10 March 2010 Listened: 4/12/20 This is one of those stories where the Doctor and companion investigate a luxury resort, but not all is as it seems. It was apparently written for the Doctor and Mel as part of the Trial, but was replaced by “Terror of the Vervoids,” which has a similar plot. Peri is inserted as staff, which provides an opening for semi-sexist comments, while the Doctor just kind of hangs around for a while. The story is a bit meandering, taking quite some time to show the baddies and their nefarious plot. This is probably because the courtroom scenes were all excised from the original script, leaving some gaps. The host of the resort is played by Alex MacQueen, who has an excellent voice for the role, although it’s hard not to imagine that the Master is behind all this.
docs.title: Paradise 5

docs.text: Paradoxicide Main Range #150 Released: 9 August 2011 Listened: 5/9/20 The Doctor and Peri run afoul of a race of women who regard men as inferior, and who are looking for weapons of domination. There’s a bunch of timey-wimey shenanigans, but it all hinges on the women being sexist, which takes something away from the story.
docs.title: Paradoxicide

docs.text: Point of Entry Lost Stories #1.6 Released: April 2010 Listened: 4/14/20 This is the first of the Lost Stories to take place in history, this time in London, probably 1592, as there’s plague and the theaters are closed. It’s too early for Shakespeare, so the Doctor and Peri run into Christopher Marlowe, who’s in the middle of writing Doctor Faustus, and actively seeking out sources of “other powers.” In this case, he meets up with what appears to be a skeletal Spaniard. There’s a lot of running around, and a brief detour to the Astral Plane, but it ends up being another one of those cases of ancient, uber-powerful beings who’ve lost their home and want to take over the Earth, disguised as mysticism, so the Doctor does something to stop them that looks mystical, but he claims is science. The highlight is probably Peri impersonating Queen Elizabeth, with Nicola Bryant doing a credible job of sounding like an American trying to sound like the queen. I wish I liked this one more, as it’s the only historical in the bunch, and it’s by Barbara Clegg, who wrote “Enlightenment,” but it’s just kind of flat.
docs.title: Point of Entry

docs.text: Power Play Lost Stories #3.5 Released: June 2012 Listened: 8/13/22 This particular Lost Story has several interesting elements, among them the return of Victoria Waterfield. Deborah Watling only participated in a few Big Finish stories, as her age and smoking habit left her unable to reproduce Victoria’s voice as she had been with the Second Doctor. However, this story takes place in the early 21st Century, so Deborah is able to use her own voice (Victoria stayed in 1968 after “The Fury from the Deep”). It does seem a bit odd that the Doctor would run into Victoria not long after he met Jamie; maybe that’s part of why this story was never produced. The other things it’s got going on are nuclear protests, which Victoria is involved in, an alien plot, and another group of aliens entirely trying to chase the Doctor down to arrest him for various crimes. Victoria was never the most capable companion back in the 60s, and in the first part of the story doesn’t make a very good showing of herself. However, she gets into gear later, even putting the Doctor in his place. Compared to some of the other Lost Stories plots, this one holds together reasonably well, even if there are a few unnecessary deaths toward the end.
docs.title: Power Play

docs.text: Prime Winner Short Trips #6.2 Released: 25 February 2016 Listened: 5/15/20 The Doctor is attempting to take Peri to a space cruise liner, but they end up on a casino ship instead. There’s rather a bit of timey-wimey that Peri has a hard time following, but she does get to have some character moments, expressing her frustration to the Doctor. There’s also an apparent plot development that turns out to be a red herring, which doesn’t happen too often. This story is read by Nicola Bryant in her native accent, which makes Peri seem like a different character altogether. It’s fine, but a bit slight.
docs.title: Prime Winner

docs.text: Question Marks Main Range #150 Released: 9 August 2011 Listened: 5/10/20 This is an “amnesia story,” very similar to Star Trek: The Next Generation ’s “Conundrum,” with characters trying to figure out who they are and what they’re doing, including the Doctor and Peri. Although the viewer gets some clues to figure out what’s up, the final twist is entirely different and you won’t spot it coming. That kind of damages the plot, but it’s got a good emotional core, so I can forgive it.
docs.title: Question Marks

docs.text: Recorded Time Main Range #150 Released: 9 August 2011 Listened: 5/9/20 The 150th release in the Main Range brings another set of short stories. In this first one, the TARDIS lands in the court of Henry VIII. He’s portrayed as a straight-up villain, creeping on Peri and trying to get rid of Anne Boleyn. Except there’s also a magical-science-y quill that turns everything it writes into reality. The plot isn’t really as important as a “glimpse into history” type of story.
docs.title: Recorded Time

docs.text: Revelation of the Daleks TV Season 22, Serial 6 Aired: 23 March - 30 March 1985 This is the Sixth Doctor’s only TV encounter with Daleks. It’s the end of Season 22, and closes with the Doctor promising to take Peri to someplace starting with “B” -- intended to be Blackpool. -- The "Davros" series of stories take place here, but I'll get to that later. --
docs.title: Revelation of the Daleks

docs.text: The Authentic Experience Short Trips #8.1 Released: 30 January 2018 Listened: 5/15/20 This one was written by Dan Starkey, and unfortunately it’s a little over-written, with expressive narration. Peri accidentally gets trapped in a time-travel tourism scheme that sends her back through Earth history, inhabiting other people’s bodies, trying to find the other tourists and pull them out. The bulk of the story involves Peri’s descriptions of various times she’s visiting, and the strange situations she finds herself in. Other than that, there’s the business owner trying to out-bluster the Sixth Doctor, and you can imagine how well that goes. It’s pleasant enough, but not terribly memorable.
docs.title: The Authentic Experience

docs.text: The Curious Incident of the Doctor in the Night-Time Main Range #188 Released: 11 July 2014 Listened: 3/28/20 The final story is a reference to the novel/play The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time , in that it involves an autistic teenager trying to solve the mystery of his father’s disappearance and running into the Doctor. The Doctor identifies with the boy because they are both puzzled by human emotional behavior from time to time. I think it perhaps pushes that part of the story a bit too hard, but it’s a reasonable story at this short length.
docs.title: The Curious Incident of the Doctor in the Night-Time

docs.text: The First Sontarans Lost Stories #3.6 Released: 23 July 2012 Listened: 5/3/20 This is a big one, in terms of scope rather than length, from Andrew Smith, who was the original author, but it was bumped in favor of “The Two Doctors,” because let’s face it, that was Bob Holmes. It’s unique in that it features both the Sontarans and the Rutans, in actual combat, which never happened on TV, although it has in other media. It bounces all over the place, from the moon, to late 1800s Sussex, to spaceships. It does indeed tell the origins of the Sontarans, but as an event that happened in the distant past, with repercussions to the present, so it’s not another “Genesis” story. Dan Starkey plays some of the Sontarans, of course, but plays them rather straight. Even though the soundtrack wants to make use of “Heroes of Sontar,” which was comedic, these Sontarans are a serious threat, as befits a story from Season 23. Peri gets to have a lot of agency, and even comes off as strident at times, which might be a step too far. It’s a convoluted plot, and maybe a bit overwritten, but on the whole, pretty good.
docs.title: The First Sontarans

docs.text: The Guardians of Prophecy Lost Stories #3.4 Released: May 2012 Listened: 8/10/22 After the success of the first season of Lost Stories, Big Finish managed to round up some more that had never been made, including this story from Johnny Byrne, a sequel to his “Keeper of Traken.” Of course, most of the Traken Union was destroyed in “Logopolis,” but the planet Serenity survived, and managed to mostly keep up Trakenite culture, except they’re governed by a computer instead of a Keeper. But there’s still a tangible air of goodness, which causes evil things to become Melkur statues. Except they’ve got a class system, and when rebels try to overthrow the aristocracy, they unleash an Ultimate Evil. Like, seriously ultimate. The story talks about Good and Evil as if they’re energy fields that can be tapped or directed, which seems a bit silly. The first part of the story with the rebellion is at least a bit interesting, with palace intrigue. But after the plan implodes, it’s just “destroy everything, blah, blah!” which isn’t very compelling. In the end, this story is disappointingly boring. Apparently there’s not much purpose in returning to Traken.
docs.title: The Guardians of Prophecy

docs.text: The Hollows of Time Lost Stories #1.4 Released: 18 February 2010 Listened: 4/9/20 This one is also one of the better Lost Stories. The TARDIS lands in contemporary England, and the Doctor wants to visit an old scientist friend, who’s caught up with a mysterious “Professor Stream,” who’s obviously the Master, but that’s never revealed in this story, because they apparently didn’t have the rights. The story was written by Chris Bidmead, who normally goes in for hard science, but this story mixes up gravity, quantum mechanics, and artificial intelligence in ways that don’t make a ton of sense. There’s also some robots, and the Tractators, even though they barely feature in the story except to provide gravitational power. Oddest of all is the Doctor being trapped in space in a disintegrating car, and somehow managing to drive it back to Earth. There’s an odd frame story in which the Doctor and Peri seem to be having memory trouble, and narrate the events of the story to each other. This is mostly intended to get around the more visual parts of the story that wouldn’t come through on audio, but it just comes off a little stiff.
docs.title: The Hollows of Time

docs.text: The Light at the End Special Released: 23 October 2013 This is an Eighth Doctor story, but for the Sixth Doctor and Peri, it probably takes place around here, because Peri is more comfortable in the Doctor’s presence, and while the Doctor is loud and bombastic, he’s not entirely unreasonable.
docs.title: The Light at the End

docs.text: Special Released: 23 October 2013 This is an Eighth Doctor story, but for the Sixth Doctor and Peri, it probably takes place around here, because Peri is more comfortable in the Doctor’s presence, and while the Doctor is loud and bombastic, he’s not entirely unreasonable.

docs.text: The Macros Lost Stories #1.8 Released: June 2010 Listened: 4/20/20 This one is pretty high-concept, with the TARDIS landing in the middle of the Philadelphia experiment, and then trying to solve the problem by contacting the inhabitants of a micro-universe. The plot itself gets a little fuzzy, with lots of back-and-forthing in the TARDIS, and some dodgy science, even by Doctor Who standards. The villain in particular is completely devoid of any redeeming qualities, and although the actress seems to be having a good time, there’s not a lot to her. There are also lots of American accents, most of them pretty decent, by Big Finish standards. So that’s the end of this batch of Lost Stories, which weren’t as bad as I remembered them, but pretty forgettable on the whole.
docs.title: The Macros

docs.title: The Mark of the Rani

docs.text: The Nightmare Fair Lost Stories #1.1 Released: 12 November 2009 Listened: 3/31/20 This is the first series of “lost stories,” most of which were salvaged from what would have been Season 23, had the show not been put on hiatus. The definition is stretched a bit -- some, like “The Nightmare Fair” were fairly far along when the season was canceled, but other stories were just plot sketches, and Big Finish substituted for some that they couldn’t get permission to re-make. The Doctor and Peri arrive in Blackpool, but dialog implies that’s not where they were aiming for, so that’s not what he meant to say at the end of “Revelation.” They take in the sights, and ride a coaster (sounds like it’s supposed to be The Big One, but that wasn’t built in 1985), which amuses me, as a coaster enthusiast. Eventually, they discover that the Celestial Toymaker is kidnapping people and generally up to no good here on Earth. His plan seems to involve building the “ultimate” video game, which creates monsters when people play it? That’s never quite clear. The Doctor is forced to play, and although it sounds like he’s not doing as well as he thinks he should, he wins anyway, which is an odd lack of plot twist. The climax is just kind of odd, as the Doctor seems to win through luck, and then traps the Toymaker in a prison cell that he himself admits is “horrific,” but he does it anyway. And they leave behind a couple of imprisoned aliens who helped them, without even checking to see if they’re OK. It’s all very scattered, which I guess is appropriate for the original story, but isn’t what I expect from Big Finish. As is appropriate for this point in their history, the Doctor is somewhat abrasive, but he and Peri are shown having fun together, sometimes. It seems like they’re softening the relationship, without actually softening the Doctor.
docs.title: The Nightmare Fair

docs.text: The Reaping Main Range #86 Released: 18 September 2006 Listened: 5/9/20 This is a rare (for the time) Main Range story with Peri and the Sixth Doctor, and wow, is it dark. Peri returns home to Baltimore after learning that her friends’ father was murdered. She returns in the middle of the funeral, after having been missing for months, which caused the breakup of her mother’s marriage to Howard. It’s pretty emotionally intense, and would be an early example of a companion experiencing the consequences to those who are left behind, except that Rose faced that on TV a year before this story was released. Of course, there’s plot going on here too, which involves the Cybermen. That’s because this story is a prequel to “The Gathering,” which I listened to in the fifth Doctor’s era. The Cybermen plot isn’t all that involved, but they’re a little more threatening than usual, because this time they have nothing to lose. Oddly, they have the stompy noise from the new series Cybermen, which is pretty effective on audio. And just when you think the story is over, there’s an even darker twist, which seems pretty gratuitous. The two stories still make more sense taken together, but listening to them in this order lets you see how the clues from this story were set up in “ The Gathering ,” especially the repeated “8-6-8-7,” which refers to the release number, but also a clue the Doctor left for himself...which totally fails. How much you like this one is going to depend on your tolerance for darkness in your Doctor Who stories. I think this one is up to the line, but not necessarily over it.
docs.title: The Reaping

docs.text: The Shadows of Serenity Short Trips #5.6 Released: 10 June 2015 Listened: 5/15/20 Placed here because Peri expresses a desire for a hamburger, so it must be before “The Two Doctors.” The Doctor and Peri land on Malgar, a planet known for being home to a species so belligerent that the Daleks and Sontarans won’t go there...except they find a race of pacifists instead. The Doctor doesn’t take this at face value and assumes that some outside force has interfered with the Malgarians, and of course he’s right, because this is a Short Trip. Despite Peri’s protests, he insists that all species need some level of aggression to survive, and puts things right. There’s also a few moments of the Doctor trying to fight back some of the anger and violence he feels in this incarnation, which is an unusual bit of introspection for the Sixth Doctor, especially in the early days. It’s not a particularly memorable story, but it is a little bit different.
docs.title: The Shadows of Serenity

docs.text: The Song of the Megaptera Lost Stories #1.7 Released: May 2010 Listened: 4/19/20 As you might guess from the title, this one’s about space whales. It’s a not-even-thinly-veiled allegory -- the space whales and space whalers are pretty much what you’d expect, and the Doctor plays the role of an ecological activist. The villains only care about money, of course. There’s a mystical shaman too, but rather than being presented as the obvious good guy, he also turns out to be opportunistic. On the whole, it’s just OK, nothing particularly special. The extras reveal that this story has been hanging around in one form or another since the Tom Baker era, so that tracks.
docs.title: The Song of the Megaptera

docs.text: 1963: The Space Race Main Range #179 Released: 29 October 2013 Listened: 5/11/20 This is part of the “1963” trilogy that came out for the 50th anniversary, with three stories that each take place in 1963. “ Fanfare for the Common Men ” is my favorite of the trilogy, and probably the most popular, but this story has a lot going on as well. It’s set at the Baikonur Cosmodrome, with the Doctor and Peri pretending to be Russian scientists, but it’s got high concepts all over the place: the fate of Laika the dog, a sentient black hole, and an American base on the far side of the moon. It’s also got some of the best cliffhangers the Main Range has seen. Unfortunately, the parts don’t really add up to a coherent story, as the high concepts don’t connect as well as you might think. There’s also some pacing difficulties. Because a rocket to the moon takes three days to arrive, the plot has to skip rather abruptly over the stretches where nothing happens. It’s also got rather a high body count, but that’s a Sixth Doctor story for you. Ultimately, it’s several good ideas that don’t quite gel as well as they ought to.
docs.title: 1963: The Space Race

docs.text: The Twin Dilemma TV Season 21, Serial 7 Aired: 22 March 1984 - 30 March 1984 This story was aired as the final story of season 21, so viewers wouldn’t have to wait to see the new Doctor. Unfortunately, it’s terrible. The Doctor is so unstable after his regeneration that he’s violent toward Peri, who’s probably wondering what she let herself in for at this point.
docs.title: The Twin Dilemma

docs.text: The Two Doctors TV Season 22, Serial 4 Aired: 16 February - 2 March 1985 The last multi-Doctor story in the classic series, and Patrick Troughton’s last appearance on the show. Unfortunately, it messes up continuity something fierce, because the Second Doctor is clearly older and working for the Time Lords, along with Jamie, which could mean it’s meant to be set after “The War Games,” or if you prefer, it takes place in the middle of “The Black Hole.” See the Season 6B theory for more info.
docs.title: The Two Doctors

docs.text: The Ultimate Evil Lost Stories #5.2 Released: 14 November 2019 Listened: 8/8/22 This particular story wasn’t available for the first round of Lost Stories, but became available later. Unfortunately, I had hoped that because it was a later release, some of the more irritating elements of the Lost Stories would be lessened, but I was mistaken. The Doctor decides to visit “old friends” yet again, and fortunately they weren’t murdered before he arrives this time. They live on a planet neatly divided between two hostile races, which have lived in peace for 150 years by simply having no contact with one another. But now the Tranquilans are suffering from a condition that sends them into a murderous rage at periodic intervals (except when the intervals are random), so they chain themselves up, and try to find a cure. This is all being orchestrated by a particularly odious sales-being named Mordant, who wants to restart the war so he can sell weapons to both sides. His “hate ray” works perfectly on everyone, including the Doctor, at great distances. He’s also got a mind-control gun, which also works on anybody, and you’d think would be a better tool for starting a war, but there you go. The Tranquilans can all teleport just by thinking about it, but apparently that has no effect on the story, because they toss people in cells and leave them unguarded. Peri is a close double for the girlfriend of the prince of the ruling family, for no real reason. At least she and the Doctor seem to be getting along better, but they’re only together at the beginning of the story. Like a lot of the Sixth Doctor Lost Stories, I wish this one had some more script editing, but it’s not to be.
docs.title: The Ultimate Evil

docs.text: The Wings of a Butterlfy Short Trips #1.6 Released: 5 November 2010 Listened: 6/2/20 No placement clues, so I’m arbitrarily putting this one here. This short is written by Colin Baker himself, apparently years before Big Finish even existed, although it was released in 2010. Baker has stated that he’s quite fond of “timey wimey” stories, and this one definitely is that. As a favor for a friend, the Doctor is investigating the unexpected destruction of a planet, discovers it was caused by an improbable series of events, and then crosses his own timeline several times trying to unravel it. That’s not quite the way time travel normally works in this show, so it’s probably best to treat this story as an amusing aside, not really relating to anything else. But it’s both enjoyable and silly at the same time.
docs.title: The Wings of a Butterfly

docs.text: To Cut a Blade of Grass Short Trips #4.6 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 5/15/20 Placed here because Peri still has a low opinion of the Doctor, not expecting him to be kind. This one is mostly told from a bystander’s point of view, a woman named Rosie, an aspiring writer whose father has recently suffered a stroke. Turns out he’s an old friend of the Doctor’s, and he turns up to do his friend a kindness. It’s a nice story for character development, although Colin Baker’s Peri impression is still tough to take.
docs.title: To Cut a Blade of Grass

docs.text: Trouble in Paradise Destiny of the Doctor #6 Released: 1 June 2013 Listened: 5/7/20 This is one of the 50th Anniversary stories featuring each Doctor. This time, the Eleventh Doctor’s appearance is quite overt, and a bit babbly, even for him. He sends the Doctor and Peri to find an “omni-paradox,” which happens to be hanging around Christopher Columbus just as he’s discovering the New World. Columbus, as it turns out, is cruel, vain, and stupid, all of which Peri knows from her history lessons (probably not accurate, if she grew up in the 70s). The story is written by Nev Fountain, which means Peri is more clever than usual, and has a number of sharp lines. There’s also plenty of absurdity, like a goat swallowing the TARDIS key, and the Doctor holding it up to the doors to gain entry. There’s also a ridiculous amount of timey-wimey paradox plot, which it’s best not to worry about. Nicola Bryant is the narrator, so she gets to use her natural accent for that, which only highlights Peri’s tones. In fairness, Bryant has gotten quite good at an American accent, although she still can’t quite say “Maryland” properly. This one is reasonably fun, as part of the specials.
docs.title: Trouble in Paradise

docs.text: Under ODIN's Eye Short Trips #9.5 Released: 30 May 2019 Listened: 5/15/20 This story, by Alice Cavender, is more of a full story than recent Short Trips usually are, with the Doctor and Peri investigating a mystery, traveling around, temporary companions, and unfortunate deaths of minor characters. Central to the story is the rather odd conceit of the ODIN megastore, a rather obvious IKEA parody that squashes local culture by creating a local mania for Scandinavian culture, which seems a bit silly, and at odds with the seriousness of the threat. The Doctor’s solution is reasonably clever, but the ending feels a bit rushed.
docs.title: Under ODIN's Eye

docs.text: Whispers of Terror Main Range #3 Released: November 1999 Listened: 5/4/20 Time for a trip way back to the beginning. This is Nicola Bryant’s first Big Finish appearance as Peri. It’s pretty clearly set in season 22, as there’s plenty of bickering to be found. Like some other early Big Finish stories, it leans very hard into the fact that it’s an audio story, with a monster that’s essentially sentient sound, a plot point that hinges on one character being blind, and a whole pile of audio-recording jargon and trickery. It gets bogged down a little by the Doctor being extra bombastic, and a lot of speeches about democracy vs. authoritarianism, which are pretty thinly disguised commentary on current politics (which, from 1999, pre-War on Terror, is almost funny). For her part, Peri gets to take action and scream in terror in about equal measure. Most of the cliffhangers feature discordant sonic attacks, so beware of that when listening. It’s clearly early days, but not bad for all that.
docs.title: Whispers of Terror

docs.text: Year of the Pig Main Range #90 Released: 18 December 2006 Listened: 3/22/20 The Doctor actually manages to take Peri for a holiday, to Ostend in 1913. The Doctor seems to want to relax and read Proust (and ends up insulting the writer himself at dinner), but they run into a bizarre range of characters played by rather significant actors: Maureen O’Brien (Vicki) plays a fanciful upper-crust woman; Adjoa Andoh, who has several roles in the modern series and Big Finish, plays a nurse; and Michael Keating, Vila of Blake’s Seven , but also several Big Finish roles, plays an outlandish French inspector. It’s a fairly bizarre story, revolving around genetically engineered humanoid pigs from the future, although no one is exactly who they appear to be, and being set in the early 1900s, everyone is unfailingly polite right up until they try to kill one another. I’m sure it’s got lots of Proust references, but I’m afraid I don’t get them. This one is also fairly long, at two 75-minute episodes. It’s a bit of an odd story, and not really all that good.
docs.title: Year of the Pig

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Peri (Again) In 2014, Big Finish released a trilogy of stories intended to resolve the problem that the Doctor essentially abandoned Peri during the Trial, and her timeline ended up skewed because of it. Although that ended up with the Doctor reunited with a somewhat older and more experienced Peri, there wasn’t a lot of resolution, and then Big Finish just left it alone for years. In 2020, they released a boxed set with the Sixth Doctor and Peri, possibly intended as one of the replacements for the Main Range, which was winding down. There’s no real resolution there either; it looks like Big Finish plans to tell more stories in this era of the Doctor’s life.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor and Peri (again)

docs.text: Conflict Theory The Sixth Doctor and Peri #4 Released: 13 August 2020 Listened: 8/25/20 You didn’t think they would do a Sixth Doctor and Peri boxed set and not invite Nev Fountain, did you? Of course not. And of course it has crazy concepts and a twisty story. The Doctor and Peri’s relationship finally comes to a crossroads, so they seek out therapy from a space station full of robotic Sigmund Freuds, which makes as much sense as anything else. This story does finally raise the question of just why Peri stays with the Doctor, even if it doesn’t quite answer. As usual in a Nev Fountain story, Peri has a lot of agency and strength, and gets quite a few zingers in dialog. As is also fairly common in a Nev Fountain story, nothing is exactly what it seems, and at least for me, it started to come together shortly before the story explained it, which is the sweet spot for that kind of revelation. The story has an ending, but there’s no grand conclusion to Peri’s story, although I didn’t expect one. I imagine Big Finish is setting up to have this pair continue for quite some time, but for now, this is the only boxed set with them.
docs.title: Conflict Theory

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor and Peri #4 Released: 13 August 2020 Listened: 8/25/20 You didn’t think they would do a Sixth Doctor and Peri boxed set and not invite Nev Fountain, did you? Of course not. And of course it has crazy concepts and a twisty story. The Doctor and Peri’s relationship finally comes to a crossroads, so they seek out therapy from a space station full of robotic Sigmund Freuds, which makes as much sense as anything else. docs.title: Conflict Theory

docs.text: Like The Sixth Doctor and Peri #2 Released: 13 August 2020 Listened: 8/24/20 Given the title, I was worried this one might come too close to the Twelfth Doctor episode “Smile,” but instead of an abandoned planet, the Doctor and Peri encounter an overcrowded one. They’re on a mission of mercy, to convince the planet to help some refugees, but here, social media is compulsory: likes increase your social status, but dislikes cause physical pain. And the government doesn’t want anyone liking the refugees’ cause. Of course Peri, and to a lesser extent the Doctor, are products of the 80s, so they’re both pretty baffled by all the liking. It’s a wonder this sort of thing doesn’t happen more often, a society whose culture is so unfamiliar that the companion, at least, simply can’t cope. Of course, that would ruin a lot of stories. The story is written by Jac Rayner, who normally does historicals, but she’s also good at social commentary, which this story has plenty of. It’s a bit more subtle than the first story, but not a whole lot. The Doctor’s solution is kind of ambiguous -- maybe it’s a good solution, but it’s kind of a compromise, which may be the best he can hope for. This story is probably the standout of the set.
docs.title: Like

docs.text: Masters of Earth Main Range #193 Released: 11 November 2014 Listened: 8/20/20 Immediately after reuniting, the Doctor and Peri end up on Earth, in Scotland. However, it’s 2163, which means it’s several years after the Daleks invaded Earth, and still at least a year before the First Doctor will show up to stop them , which means that the Sixth Doctor can’t do much to affect the course of events. Or so it seems, anyway. The Doctor is perfectly willing to bend the rules when one of his friends is in danger, and while he seems a bit aloof at the start of the story, to Peri’s annoyance, once she’s in trouble, he’ll stop at nothing to save her, Web of Time or no Web of Time. For her part, although Peri is under the influence for a fair chunk of the story, her characterization is more mature, less panicky, and a bit more world-weary. There’s also a vein of caution, as though she’s not entirely sure she trusts this Doctor, which is appropriate. Oddly, although the Doctor is quite strident while he’s trying to save Peri, when he’s verbally sparring with the Daleks, he’s casual, even flippant. It seems that 1964-era Daleks just aren’t very scary to him. As for the plot, it has some satisfying twists, and it’ll keep you guessing regarding who the secondary protagonists are, and who’s cannon fodder. It’s not a bad Dalek story, especially for one where the end is predestined.
docs.title: Masters of Earth

docs.title: Masters of Earth

docs.text: Plight of the Pimpernel Main Range #271 Released: 8 December 2020 Listened: 12/12/20 Placing this here because Peri seems rather older and more confident, and the Doctor seems calmer on the whole, less likely to fly off the handle. This seems like it would be a fairly typical historical at first, with the Doctor and Peri in the French Revolution, and encountering a historical figure, in this case the Scarlet Pimpernel . One hitch: The Pimpernel is fictional, and not based on a historical figure. He’s also been wounded by a distinctly alien weapon. The Doctor and Peri alternate between trying to figure that out, and playing the Pimpernel themselves, and discover a robot who’s trying to kill the Pimpernel. The whole story runs on the idea of identity and justice, and whether the good done in one persona outweighs the bad done in another. The Doctor seems to be showing his age (or maybe Colin Baker’s), in that he wanted to do something that was simple fun, and an easy case of right and wrong, but he’s disappointed to find it more complicated than he’d hoped. Peri is very much the partner in this story, a far cry from her TV persona, and she seems to be bolstering the Doctor quite a bit, carrying him along. If this is the start of a new direction for these characters, it’s a welcome one.
docs.title: The Plight of the Pimpernel

docs.text: The Headless Ones The Sixth Doctor and Peri #1 Released: 13 August 2020 Listened: 8/23/20 In 2020, Big Finish decided to end their Main Range, and replace it with a series of boxed sets for each Doctor. At the time of this writing, this is the first such boxed set, and it remains to be seen how they’ll be organized or numbered. However, it picks up the story of the older Peri’s time with the Doctor. They end up on a late 1800s African expedition, with some English folks who are looking for the legendary “headless men,” the B’lemyae. The actual nature of the B’lemyae and what they need form the core of the story. Even though it’s an hour-long story, it drags a little bit before the title monsters show up. The real enemy here is colonization, which is brought home fairly hard, as the traditional Englishman character has little in the way of redeeming qualities. As such stories tend to go, there’s also a rather high body count. It’s OK as far as it goes, but the themes could have been executed with more subtlety.
docs.title: The Headless Ones

docs.text: The Rani Elite Main Range #194 Released: 17 December 2014 Listened: 8/22/20 In 2014, Big Finish reached an agreement to use the Rani on audio, with Kate O’Mara in the role. Unfortunately, she passed away before recording. However, with her agent’s blessing, Big Finish cast Siobhan Redmond in the part. Her persona isn’t all that different from O’Mara’s Rani, a little less strident, and maybe a bit more sneering. She hasn’t lost her interest in biochemistry, especially neural experiments, hasn’t lost her penchant for disguises, nor has she gained any morals. She makes it clear that she’s later in her timeline than O’Mara’s Rani, as she remembers the Seventh Doctor. The Doctor and Peri’s relationship seems to have regressed a little bit. The Doctor is being more arrogant than recently, and taking a few cheap shots at Peri, but he’s clearly doing it with humor to soften the words. Whether Peri appreciates that isn’t clear, but she’s more independent and a bit wiser, but still prone to asking the exposition questions, so you could easily imagine the younger Peri in this story. As for the plot itself, it’s a bit slow, with the Doctor and Peri arriving at a university where something is wrong, but they’re not sure what for quite a while. It takes a while for them to figure out what’s going on and what to do about it. Rani stories aren’t known for their action sequences, so there’s a lot of talking and debate, although Peri goes through another round of body horror, and Nicola Bryant sells it well. It’s a good debut for this version of the Rani, but not the best story in general.
docs.title: The Rani Elite

docs.text: The Vanity Trap The Sixth Doctor and Peri #3 Released: 13 August 2020 Listened: 8/24/20 This one is deeply timey-wimey, to the point where I had some difficulty understanding it, and so did the actors. The bulk of this story is set in 1972 on a movie set in England. Actress Myrna Kendal is worried that she’s aging out of her career. There’s a frame story, though, with an older Myrna meeting the Doctor and telling him about this adventure before he has it. What follows is a bunch of technobabble about paradoxes and temporal anomalies. It’s one of the ones where there’s not really a monster or a villain, just a bunch of people making questionable decisions. And there’s some friction between the Doctor and Peri, who isn’t as amenable to following orders without explanations as she used to be, which sets up the next story. As an aside, Peri convinces the Doctor that his usual outfit would be out of place on a movie set, so he decides to “blend in” by wearing what he wore in 1972, meaning the Third Doctor’s outfit. I really wish I could see that.
docs.title: The Vanity Trap

docs.text: The Widow's Assassin Main Range #192 Released: 31 October 2014 Listened: 8/18/20 If you’re going to bring Peri back after the events of the Trial, it has to be Nev Fountain writing it. Which means it’s going to be off-beat, and Peri’s going to be snarky. In this case, though, off-beat borders on silly. Turns out that this Peri married King Ycarnos and became queen, as we discovered at the end of the Trial. When the Doctor tracks Peri down, she’s still furious with him, and throws him in jail, where he stays for quite some time. Presumably Brian Blessed was unavailable, so King Ycarnos is likewise made permanently unavailable. I’ve never liked “so then the Doctor did a thing off-screen for several years” plot elements, and in this story it’s even more than it appears. There’s a big twist at the end of Part 2, which I won’t spoil, but it’s impressive. The remaining parts have a lot of exposition and running around in people’s mindscapes. It feels long, because it is. Almost all the minor characters are silly in some way, with special mention going to Guard 1 and Guard 2 (their actual names). There’s a definite Moffat-era feeling to this story, and since it came out in 2014, that makes sense.
docs.title: The Widow's Assassin

docs.text: The Sixth Doctor Solo This section of the Sixth Doctor era opens with the Trial, in which Peri departs and Mel...well, Mel is introduced as a character, but the Doctor hasn’t met her yet. Although this was never shown on TV, Big Finish has established that the Doctor returned Mel to her proper place and time (sort of) and didn’t choose to meet her until later. This creates a large gap where the Doctor basically wanders around on his own, which he never did on TV. Big Finish seems to have been fond of this idea, with several stories in 2018 and 2019 featuring a solo Sixth Doctor. This also means that this Doctor’s last televised adventure takes place rather early in his “life,” as far as Big Finish is concerned. That gives them a lot of latitude to make changes, and add new companions and stories, which is frankly all to the better.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor Solo

docs.text: Excelis Rising Special Release Released: 8 April 2002 Listened: 5/23/20 This is another of those stories that runs across the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Doctors, meaning that they’re really best listened to in sequence, but for this project, they happen months apart, and I forget the details. In this case, the Doctor returns to Excelis when it’s in a modern or slightly pre-modern era. It’s a rather small story, compared to the first , with an attempted theft of the Relic from the museum where it resides, and the former Warlord Grayvorn still hanging around to try to get his hands on it. It seems remarkable that he’s waited all this time, only to have the Doctor turn up and foil him again, but that’s how it went. The characters involved are a little blase about the prospect of regeneration and living for a thousand years, but it’s handled relatively realistically. It’s very much a “middle story,” with Grayvorn rather easily defeated, and left around, if disembodied, for the Seventh Doctor to meet later. No matter what happens, having Anthony Stewart Head playing a slimy villain is worth the price of admission, and he’s much less shouty this time around.
docs.title: Excelis Rising

docs.text: Harry Houdini's War Main Range #255 Released: 17 September 2019 Listened: 5/25/20 This release is part of the trilogy that came out with “ Memories of a Tyrant ” and “ Emissary of the Daleks ,” and once again features Peri, but it takes place here, for spoilery reasons. Nicola Bryant plays Peri as more than usually annoyed and frightened, but with a more strident quality, and again, there’s a reason for that. The big attraction, though, is that Harry Houdini shows up as a character. Although the Doctor has mentioned meeting Houdini many times before, he hasn’t turned up as a main character, except for “ Smoke and Mirrors ,” also by Steve Lyons. This time, Houdini is at the height of his abilities and fame, and has a strong urge to contribute to the U.S. efforts in World War I, because of his German background. He gets an awful lot to do, displaying many of his skills, and having his trust in the Doctor tested harshly. The German characters are played mostly as straight evil, with several actors calling them “Nazis” in the extras, although they weren’t in the 1920s. The plot has a lot to unravel, and many things aren’t what they seem, but it takes its time getting there. Overall, it’s a fine addition.
docs.title: Harry Houdini's War

docs.text: Her Final Flight Bonus Release Released: December 2004 Listened: 5/22/20 This is a special release that takes place shortly after the trial, when the Doctor is still missing Peri. He seems to land on a primitive planet, where Peri crashed several months ago, 20 years older than the last time the Doctor saw her. The TARDIS is damaged, and leaking time energy that’s wreaking havoc on the local population. Except none of it is real; it’s just an illusion from someone who wants the Doctor dead, and someone else who wants to steal the TARDIS. That’s not a spoiler; it’s revealed before the Doctor even turns up. Nicola Bryant gets to play Peri at closer to her own age, and it shows. There should be a lot of emotion in the Doctor seeing Peri again after the trial, and there’s some, but it’s undercut by the fact that it’s all fake. The identity of whoever wants the Doctor dead is never revealed, either. On the whole, it makes the story seem rather unimportant.
docs.title: Her Final Flight

docs.text: Hour of the Cybermen Main Range #240 Released: 12 July 2018 Listened: 6/1/20 This is the second portion of the “UNIT Trilogy” that started with “ The Helliax Rift ” with the Fifth Doctor. The Sixth Doctor part of these Five-Six-Seven trilogies often suffers from “middle episode syndrome,” and I think they made a definite effort to avoid that here. Both Daniel Hopkins and Colonel Price return, but they’re decidedly different than they were. Price has moderated his views, whereas Hopkins has suffered a personal tragedy and come out the worse for it. It also helps to explain why UNIT didn’t call on the Doctor much during the late 80s and early 90s. The Cybermen here are definitely the 80s versions, being played by David Banks and Mark Hardy, and they have a typically convoluted plan for taking over the Earth, involving a ray that destroys water. It’s some seriously dodgy science, and requires several actors to pretend to be dehydrated, which doesn’t come across quite as well as it would have on TV, especially with modern effects. Still, the Cybermen’s plan isn’t the important point here, but rather the idea of pain and loss, and whether they’re an acceptable price to pay for joy and happiness. On an emotional level, the story succeeds.
docs.title: Hour of the Cybermen

docs.text: I.D. Main Range #94 Released: April 2007 Listened: 5/26/20 We’re finally done with the Trial and its aftermath, and the Doctor is just wandering around unaccompanied, having normal adventures. This story takes place some time in the future, where brain/computer interfaces are ubiquitous, and having your personality edited is commonplace. The TARDIS lands in a data junkyard, where scavengers are searching for personal data to sell on, a quasi-legal identity theft. Of course, any time profit-motivated humans are doing something ethically dodgy, it’s bound to go horribly wrong, and the Doctor will be there to call them on it. In this case, it’s a dead scientist who left behind a copy of his mind that overwrites anybody it’s downloaded into. The data junkyard concept is pretty interesting, as is the idea of a disability that leaves people unable to interface with computers, but the “selfish humans” trope is in full effect, and once you get to the running around in corridors portion, it’s pretty standard. This is still comparatively early in the Sixth Doctor’s life, so he seems pretty irritable, but to be fair, he considers personality editing to be immoral, and every other character is selfish to one degree or another, so it’s reasonable that he spends most of the story annoyed. This is a fairly short story, only three parts, each less than 30 minutes, which leaves room for a second story and very long extras.
docs.title: I.D.

docs.title: I.D.

docs.text: Iron Bright Main Range #239 Released: 19 June 2018 Listened: 5/30/20 This one starts out seeming like a true historical, but doesn’t stay that way for long. The Doctor ends up in London, 1828, during the digging of the first Thames Tunnel. It’s one of those times when the Doctor gets a little star-struck, this time by Isembard Kingdom Brunel and his father, the engineers in charge of the working. It turns out that there are invisible portals to another planet all around London, which originally provided entertainment for the aliens, but now are dumping deadly pollution, and the Thames Tunnel will drive straight through one of them...so naturally Brunel the elder wants to invade, for King and Country. The Doctor is mostly passive through all of this, wanting to give Brunel the benefit of the doubt, but he has the most experience with alien governments. Also, this is the first Main Range story to use the Jodie Whitaker version of the logo on the cover, although there’s also a version with the traditional Sixth Doctor logo as well.
docs.title: Iron Bright

docs.text: Judoon in Chains Classic Doctors, New Monsters #1.2 Released: 28 July 2016 Listened: 5/24/20 If you’re setting up a box set with old Doctors and new-series monsters, then the only thing better than getting Colin Baker to trade words with a Carrionite is to get him to speak Judoonese...and why not in a courtroom, while we’re at it? That’s pretty much the extent of what’s going on in this story, where the rest of the plot isn’t all that important, but does feature an unusually enlightened Judoon making long speeches and reciting poetry, so full credit to Nick Briggs for pulling that off. The Doctor seems to be over his distaste for courtrooms by this point, and if anything, most of his trickery in the second half of the story is a bit too smug, because everything goes according to his plan, which is pretty rare for him. It may not be the best of the CDNM’s, but it’s a good one.
docs.title: Judoon in Chains

docs.text: Peri and the Piscon Paradox, parts 3-4 Companion Chronicles #5.7 Released: January 2011 Listened: 5/23/20 Still hurting from the Trial, the Doctor comes back again to Peri, this time the older version whom the Fifth Doctor met in L.A. Most of the two episodes of this story completely pick apart and undermine the first two episodes from young Peri’s POV. It turns out that nothing was what it seemed at all. If anything, this half of the story is even sillier than the first, with a lot of cheap shots taken at show business and even the show itself, with the Doctor running around in an awkward monster costume. And just when it can’t get a lot sillier, the purported story ends, and it veers hard into tragedy, with older Peri attempting to tell her younger self about the horrible things that caused her to end up in L.A. Except young Peri doesn’t hear her, so the Web of Time is unaffected. This is followed by a denouement where a Time Lord turns up and explains why there are multiple Peris running around the cosmos (basically, there just are; deal with it). If you were looking for a story that explains all the paradoxes neatly, Moffat-style, you won’t get that. If you want some Nev Fountain showcase Peri writing, or an extremely silly story about fish-aliens, or a multi-Doctor story, you’ll get all of those. On the whole, the plusses outweigh the minuses.
docs.title: Peri and the Piscon Paradox

docs.text: The Acheron Pulse Main Range #166 Released: 25 October 2012 Listened: 5/28/20 This is another one of the Five-Six-Seven trilogies, meaning this is the middle section, and again, it’s probably best listened to as a set, but this project doesn’t work that way. It depends a lot on the events of the previous episode (“ The Burning Prince ”), but everything seems to have gone wrong from there. The Doctor was supposed to watch over the empress, but he doesn’t show up until 30 years after he left (not entirely his fault). The Prince from the first episode is back, and he’s thoroughly nasty this time around, although he also has his reasons. It’s not the same actor, and honestly James Wilby does menacing well, but doesn’t really convey any other emotions. A bunch of secondary characters get killed, somewhat uselessly. And the Doctor ends up reprogramming a bunch of monsters with his own sense of justice; there’s no way that’ll go wrong. This should be one of those interesting trilogies, but honestly it’s all rather bland.
docs.title: The Acheron Pulse

docs.text: The Carrionite Curse Classic Doctors, New Monsters #2.3 Released: 27 July 2017 Listened: 5/23/20 The second CDNM story with the Sixth Doctor seems to come before the first , because the Trial seems to be still very much on his mind. The Doctor encounters a 1980s English town that’s troubled by witches, in this case, Carrionites from “The Shakespeare Code.” Unusually for these CDNM stories, the Doctor has heard of Carrionites, but has never encountered any before. These Carrionites, however, seem to remember the Tenth Doctor and their other encounter. There’s even a sly reference to the Harry Potter series. The Doctor meets a potential companion, who seems to foreshadow Flip and other young women who don’t take the Doctor seriously, but she’s unable to come along. Fortunately, Carrionites are affected by words, and almost no Doctor has as much of a command of verbiage as the Sixth, but his lack of experience with magic nearly does him in. On the whole, this is one of the better CDNM stories.
docs.title: The Carrionite Curse

docs.text: The Doctor's Coat Short Trips #2.6 Released: 28 February 2011 Listened: 6/2/20 Not a lot of placement data for this one either, so it might as well be here. The Doctor is visiting a desert planet, where the inhabitants have shells that they shed periodically as they grow. Lost in thinking about Peri, he leaves his coat lying around and loses it. Getting it back requires a little work on his part, and causes him to think a bit about what the coat means to him; in short, not nearly as much as his companions do. It’s an interesting visual story, but mostly valuable for insight into the Doctor’s thoughts.
docs.title: The Doctor's Coat

docs.text: The Hunting Ground Main Range #246 Released: 11 December 2018 Listened: 6/2/20 This story isn’t a part of any trilogy, just a standalone solo adventure for the Sixth Doctor. This one is set in Iceland, and while it isn’t a “Scandi-noir,” at least, not as much as River Song’s “Colony of Strangers,” it does have a strong police presence. As is customary, the Doctor gets a temporary companion in police Inspector Yrsa Kristjansdottir, whose father, also a police officer, was murdered under mysterious circumstances some years ago, and the same thing seems to be happening again. The main plot involves aliens using Earth for hunting, but they only seem to hunt things that aren’t much of a challenge, which sort of undercuts that plot. Their hunting wolves don’t seem to be particularly loyal or interested either. The Doctor seems very casual about the goings-on, and is unusually boastful even for him. Yrsa is the main attraction of this story, and it’s left fuzzy whether she leaves with the Doctor or not.
docs.title: The Hunting Ground

docs.text: The Lure of the Nomad Main Range #238 Released: 15 May 2018 Listened: 5/30/20 This story finds the Doctor with a previously unmentioned companion, Mathew Sharpe, a pilot from the year 2715 who doesn’t appreciate Monty Python. If this chronology is correct, Mathew is the Doctor’s first companion since Peri, and he kind of fits the role. He’s mostly bland, although he does have a tendency to get chirpy under stress, which mostly just gets him shouted at. The Doctor is still fairly arrogant at this stage, not really paying much attention to his companion’s wants. There’s also an interior designer who’s a gaseous being, and squid in exo-suits who apologize while they’re murdering you. Most of the story seems like a typical “base under siege” story, though, until it takes a very abrupt turn in Part 4. It would be terrible to say more than that, so I’ll just leave it that this is a decently memorable story.
docs.title: The Lure of the Nomad

docs.text: Trial of a Time Lord: The Mysterious Planet TV Season 23, Serial 1 Aired: 6 September 1986 - 27 September 1986 The Trial is all of Season 23, although it’s divided into four stories. This one is the “past” segment of the trial, clearly set a while since “Revelation,” as Peri is dressing far more conservatively, and seems more comfortable with the Doctor. It also introduces the Valeyard, and Sabalom Glitz in the flashback. The show is back to half-hour-ish episodes, airing once per week, but only 14 to a season, a dramatic reduction. It's also back to airing in the fall, after the 18-month "rest" ordered by Michael Grade.
docs.title: The Mysterious Planet

docs.text: The Sirens of Time, part 3 Main Range #1 Released: 19 July 1999 Listened: 6/2/20 The third part of Big Finish’s first story takes place here. The Sixth Doctor’s story is the last of the three separate pieces before the Doctors join up, so this one has a plot that’s most connected to the climax. On Gallifrey, the Time Lords fall to the Knights of Velyshaa. The Doctor is on a cruise ship examining the “Kurgon Wonder,” which turns out to be the prison of a Temperon, whose freedom drives the final part of the story. The Sixth Doctor doesn’t really get to do much, compared to the other two. He just shows up, finds a disaster, and tries to figure out what’s going on. Colin Baker’s voice is noticeably younger than other stories (especially the more recent ones just before in this chronology), so much so that it’s distracting. As a solo story, there’s very little to it.
docs.title: The Sirens of Time

Features the Master, and at the end Mel departs with the Doctor, even though that’s out of order from the Doctor’s point of view. This is the Sixth Doctor’s last TV appearance.

docs.text: The Wormery Main Range #51 Released: 31 October 2003 Listened: 5/23/20 This one is lengthy, and layered. Still needing a rest, the Doctor stops at Bianca’s, a cabaret in 1930s Berlin...which isn’t what it seems. Iris Wildthyme shows up, acting like her usual scattered, drunken self, but that’s not what it seems either. Describing any further would reveal the layers of spoilers, but there’s alien worms making wormholes, references to the Trial, and even a frame-story containing narration that isn’t what it seems either. It all unfolds rather slowly, so on a relisten it seems somewhat draggy. How much you enjoy the early parts depends a lot on how entertaining you find Iris, because she’s being extra Iris-y in this story. Katy Manning does a credible job, sounding a bit young for Iris, actually (although this came out in 2003). She even gets to sing, and the song is a bit of an earworm (pun intended). If you like your stories twisty, this one has you covered, unlike “ Her Final Flight .”
docs.title: The Wormery

docs.text: Together in Eclectic Dreams Classic Doctors, New Monsters #3.3 Released: 28 July 2022 Listened: 8/6/22 For the first time in this particular CDNM set, there’s an actual “new monster,” this time the Dream Crabs from “Last Christmas.” That means there’s going to be a lot of dream sequences and misdirection, and Roy Gill is up to the challenge. The Doctor has another new companion in this one, Mari Yoshida, played by Susan Hingley, who is of Japanese descent, so everybody gets their pronunciations right, which is nice. Mari is a nice match for the Sixth Doctor; she’s forthright, possibly even aggressive, and definitely doesn’t put up with being told what to do. However, she’s not actually with the Doctor a whole lot, so we can’t see if they clash much. The story itself involves dreams, layers of dreams, and things that come get you in dreams, much like “Last Christmas,” so it’s foolish to say more than that. There is, however, a surprise appearance by a character you may not have been expecting. It’s all satisfyingly twisty, which is a challenge nicely met.
docs.title: Together in Eclectic Dreams

docs.text: Trial of the Valeyard Bonus Release Released: 17 December 2013 Listened: 5/25/20 We’re still not done with obsessing about the trial, and it’s getting a little tiresome, at least within the context of this project. This special release sees the Doctor called back to the judicial space station, where the Valeyard is on trial now, with the Inquisitor once again presiding. The whole thing is an excuse to get Colin Baker, Michael Jayston, and Lynda Bellingham back together again for a 50th anniversary story. Much of it is spent with the Doctor blustering on and on about being kept in the dark, but the Valeyard has some interesting things to say about the limits of regeneration, and he would know. (Spoiler: As of 2020, this is even more interesting with the revelations about the Timeless Child.) Unfortunately, the story falls apart at the end, and it all becomes rather petty. Even for a short special, this seems over-long. It’s half an interesting story in search of an ending.
docs.title: Trial of the Valeyard

docs.text: Urgent Calls Main Range #94 Released: April 2007 Listened: 5/26/20 This one-part story fills out the disc, and it’s an intriguing little story. A woman, Lauren, calls the Doctor by accident, who convinces her to go to the hospital, because she’s infected with an alien virus. As an after-effect, she keeps getting wrong numbers and then being able to call the Doctor, seemingly by accident. So the story is told from quite an isolated point of view, as Lauren never meets the Doctor in person. She also convinces him that having a more pleasant manner will help people respond to him better. It ends on a bittersweet note, because Lauren doesn’t know how the Doctor’s story resolved. (But if you want to know, it’s continued in “Patient Zero.”) It’s an effective short story, and I like it.
docs.title: Urgent Calls

docs.text: Main Range #94 Released: April 2007 Listened: 5/26/20 This one-part story fills out the disc, and it’s an intriguing little story. A woman, Lauren, calls the Doctor by accident, who convinces her to go to the hospital, because she’s infected with an alien virus. As an after-effect, she keeps getting wrong numbers and then being able to call the Doctor, seemingly by accident. So the story is told from quite an isolated point of view, as Lauren never meets the Doctor in person. She also convinces him that having a more pleasant manner will help people respond to him better. It ends on a bittersweet note, because Lauren doesn’t know how the Doctor’s story resolved. (But if you want to know, it’s continued in “Patient Zero.”) It’s an effective short story, and I like it.
docs.title: Urgent Calls

docs.text: Vampire of the Mind Main Range #212 Released: 9 May 2016 Listened: 5/29/20 This is yet another of the Five-Six-Seven trilogies, this one the sequel to “ And You Will Obey Me .” The Doctor is alone, once again trying to visit an old friend, who turns out to be in trouble, and picks up a pseudo-companion, this one brighter and more capable than usual. It’s set roughly in “the present,” but there’s a lot of references to the 70s UNIT and the Delgado Master, circa “ The Mind of Evil .” This Master, though, is the Alex Macqueen version, but not as he normally is. This time he’s much more subdued, and quite a bit more cruel. There’s a reason for that, which is implied to be post-regenerative trauma, but you’ll need the third part for the rest of the story. The actual plot isn’t all that much, really; the Master is making scientists into zombies, but with an ulterior motive. The Doctor seems to have slid back just a bit in his growth, because he’s still very arrogant, given to bluster, and rather heedless of the people around him. The secondary characters are quite good, capable and with real personalities. It’s a perfectly decent story, but definitely a middle part.
docs.title: Vampire of the Mind

docs.text: Wink Out of Time #3 Released: 8 June 2022 Listened: 6/8/22 This is the third of the “Out of Time” set of multi-Doctor team-ups, and that means this is really a Tenth Doctor story. I’m placing it here because the Sixth Doctor is solo, still somewhat arrogant and stuck-up, and hasn’t yet worn his blue coat. He gets along a little better with the Tenth Doctor than you’d expect, although he does lose patience with him fairly often. When it comes to executing a plan, though, they work together more smoothly than most other sets of Doctors.
docs.title: Wink
