docs.text: The Sixth Doctor Solo (Again) After Charley’s departure, there’s another set of solo stories, although a couple of them seem to be immediately after Evelyn’s departure. (Craig Brawley has a theory that the Doctor has had all of his Charley memories wiped.) A lot of these don’t have any specific placement, but they’re clearly a later version of the Sixth Doctor, so it helps to have another place to put them. They also involve a higher than usual amount of timey-wimey, so maybe it doesn’t matter where we put them.
docs.title: Sixth Doctor Solo (again)

docs.title: The Sixth Doctor Solo (Again)

docs.text: Last of the Cybermen Main Range #199 Released: 20 May 2015 Listened: 7/30/20 This is the second portion of the “Locum Doctors” trilogy, in which the Sixth Doctor changes places with the Second. He has it a little easier than the Fifth Doctor did, because Jamie and Zoe know about regeneration (Polly told Jamie, who told Zoe), so they get past the identity crisis portion pretty easily. (Jamie doesn’t know this Doctor yet, as “The Two Doctors” is still in his future.) They also have the advantage that the baddie is the Cybermen, who they’re all familiar with. There’s a lot of callbacks to “Tomb of the Cybermen,” and frankly lots of callbacks to various Second Doctor stories. Jamie and Zoe each get a large chunk of an episode to interact with the Sixth Doctor one-on-one. Jamie’s interactions are more distinctive, because Jamie’s a larger personality, and keeps rubbing the Sixth Doctor the wrong way, but it doesn’t go on so long it becomes annoying. As the story goes on, there’s a lot of timey-wimey, where causality gets knotted up, making some of the earlier parts seem stilted in retrospect. There’s more of that than would have happened in the Second Doctor’s era, and unlike “ The Secret History ,” it doesn’t seem as much like an authentic 60s episode. It is a lot of fun, though, and the actors are clearly having a good time.
docs.title: Last of the Cybermen

docs.text: Mind Games The Worlds of Doctor Who #1 Released: 8 September 2014 Listened: 7/25/20 In 2014, Big Finish released a boxed set for their 15th anniversary of the Doctor Who license, featuring several of their spin-off stories crossing over with the Doctor. Which is kind of funny, because they hadn’t yet received the license to make new-series stories, after which they’d go crazy with the spin-offs, so this collection feels pretty restrained. The focus is on the spin-offs, and the Doctor doesn’t really appear until the end, so technically I should only have the last chapter in this timeline, but I hadn’t listened to them before. For Jago & Litefoot, this story takes place rather early in their spin-off series. The villain is a hypnotist named Rees who’s performing at Jago’s theater. Rees is played by Jamie Glover, who’d played William Russell in An Adventure in Space and Time at this point, but hadn’t yet played Ian in the First Doctor Adventures, yet his voice is similar enough to be distracting. It seems to be a typical Jago & Litefoot story, in that it’s slightly over the top, and the language is definitely mannered. However, it does all resolve rather easily, and with quite a bit of luck.
docs.title: Mind Games

docs.text: Second Sight The Worlds of Doctor Who #4 Released: 8 September 2014 Listened: 7/28/20 This segment is part of the Gallifrey spin-off, more or less, because instead of trying to carry the plot into the political intrigues of Gallifrey, they just move Leela and Romana to Earth for the duration of the story. And of course, the Sixth Doctor appears, which was Big Finish’s intent because the Sixth Doctor is the one who’s changed the most under Big Finish. Unfortunately, his reunion with Leela, Romana, and Mike Yates is very understated, almost underplayed. And the story itself, unfortunately, is kind of a disappointment, with twists that frankly don’t hold up. Louise Jameson gets to play Leela acting like someone else, which she does effectively, and is no doubt great fun for her. Jamie Glover reappears from the first story, playing a different character that’s supposed to be a secret, but his voice is so distinctive, I don’t know who they thought they were fooling. It’s an unfortunate let-down for the conclusion of the big anniversary story.
docs.title: Second Sight

docs.text: The Eye of the Storm The Diary of River Song #2.4 Released: 25 December 2016 Listened: 7/30/20 This story features both the Sixth and Seventh Doctors, but I can’t place it definitely in either timeline, because River is the main character. So I’ll just have to cover it twice. There’s an apocalypse going on, coinciding with the Great Storm of 1703 , and both the Sixth and Seventh Doctors are trying to stop it, from opposite directions, with River caught in the middle. We haven’t seen these two Doctors meeting very often in this timeline, but at least here, they really don’t get along. This seems to be the “chessmaster” version of the Seventh Doctor, and he’s got no patience for anybody else trying to have their own plans. In fact, both the Doctors seem to be indulging the worst aspects of their personalities: The Sixth Doctor is arrogant, bombastic, romantic, and prone to large gestures, including the sacrifice play. The Seventh Doctor is cynical, scheming, and determined to work alone. And both of them think they know best, which is often true, but they’re unaware they’re in a River story. River gets to the core of both of them: she finds the Sixth Doctor’s confidence romantic, but needs to bull over him sometimes. She doesn’t seem to like the Seventh Doctor very much, but she’s aware that underneath, he’s not as ruthless as he acts, and she wants to rescue him from that. Big Finish seems to have realized, even in boxed set #2, that they can’t have River continually hiding her identity from the Doctor, so she’s more honest with them, and then cleans up at the end. That’ll become a cliche in itself, but the last scene with the Seventh Doctor is excellent. Like most new-series spin-offs, it has a faster pace and is more peril-driven than other stories, but it’s a lot of fun. And that’s the last we’ll see of River in this project for a while.
docs.title: The Eye of the Storm

docs.text: The Reesinger Process The Worlds of Doctor Who #2 Released: 8 September 2014 Listened: 7/27/20 This set features the Counter-Measures crew, which frankly I’ve never had a lot of interest in. It also takes place during their first series, so a lot of the later developments in their story hadn’t happened yet. As such, it feels kind of slow-paced, and the characters aren’t really accustomed to weird happenings yet, even though that’s where they started and what their remit is. Group Captain Gilmore in particular seems out of his depth much of the time, and although Dr. Jensen is clearly the science-capable member of the team, her role gets downplayed, in accordance with the times. Sir Toby Kinsella, the one character who isn’t from “ Remembrance of the Daleks ,” seems to be the most decisive of the lot. As it is, they spend a lot of time reacting in this story, and carefully putting together a pretty basic mystery that the Doctor would likely have jumped right to the end of. It makes this feel very much like a “middle story.”
docs.title: The Reesinger Process

docs.text: The Screaming Skull The Worlds of Doctor Who #3 Released: 8 September 2014 Listened: 7/28/20 This chapter is only tenuously a spin-off, as it has to do with UNIT, which at the time had a few independent stories, but the new-series UNIT stories were still a little while off yet. It stars Richard Franklin reviving his role as Mike Yates. It also features Daphne Ashbrook and Yee Jee Tso, who were the companions in the 1996 TV Movie, but Big Finish doesn’t have the rights to those characters, so they’re playing unrelated UNIT agents, who both happen to be American. They’d appeared before, in the Companion Chronicle “Mastermind,” where it was established that they work at the Vault, a UNIT storage facility for strange items. It’s the same concept as the Black Archive from the 50th Anniversary special, and even though the Vault predates the Archive, it still gets a little shout-out here. As in his appearance in “ Real Time ,” Tso has one of the most realistic American accents I’ve heard in Big Finish, and Ashbrook’s is pretty good as well, although the writer has given them both English speech habits, rather than American ones. The story is mostly straightforward, and a good redemption arc for both characters, who have nicely distinct attitudes. However, it takes an unexpectedly dark turn at the end, because the larger story isn’t over yet.
docs.title: The Screaming Skull

docs.text: The Wrong Doctors Main Range #169 Released: 14 January 2013 Listened: 7/25/20 From Mel’s and the “colorful” Doctor’s point of view, this happened just after the Trial. From the “blue” Doctor’s point of view, it happens here. (Or right after Evelyn departs; doesn’t really matter.) This is a candidate for the most timey-wimey story from the main range, as it’s got two Doctors and two Mels running around, and that’s just the beginning of the temporal shenanigans. Even worse, the title is accurate -- both of these Doctors are in the wrong place at the wrong time, and that place isn’t what it appears to be, either. The younger Doctor is trying to return Mel to her proper place in the timestream after the Trial, but he gets it wrong. The older Doctor is attempting to meet Mel for the first time (from her perspective), but it’s not time for that either. Colin Baker does an excellent job of differentiating the two Doctors, with the younger one sounding much more arrogant, although a lot of that is in the writing. Bonnie Langford has a similar challenge, but the two Mels have to sound mostly the same, but the older one being more confident and capable. The bit of the big corporation mining for temporally sensitive material is a bit silly and overdone, leaving the story without much of a villain, but any villain they could have used would’ve been overwhelmed by the two Doctors anyway. Definitely good for a brain twist.
docs.title: The Wrong Doctors

docs.text: World Enough and Time The Diary of River Song #2.3 Released: 25 December 2016 Listened: 7/29/20 Not the Twelfth Doctor story (which is great), but a story from River Song’s second box set. (It’s a wonder nobody had used the title before, really.) This story is from one of the early River boxed sets, so Big Finish was going through the exercise of having her meet up with all the classic Doctors they had available, while still hiding her identity. This time, she’s trying to investigate an apocalypse that happened in one of her earlier stories, and it leads her to the Golden Futures company, whose managing director, much to River’s surprise, is the Sixth Doctor. Unfortunately, because it’s River’s story, the Sixth Doctor doesn’t come off too well. Golden Futures is distracting him by saddling him with pointless administrative tasks, and he falls for it. It makes me wonder if these stories really should take place here, because the Doctor at this point is more likely to bluster his way into doing what he wants, rather than follow someone else’s agenda. He’s also got a sonic screwdriver, which seems odd. He gets tricked out of a sacrifice play, and then even fumbles the big sciency climax. The plus side is his obvious affection for River (even though he’s never met her, as far as he knows), which River returns, also somewhat unexpectedly. She’s annoyed with him being a bit slow to solve the mystery (as she should be), but she seems to appreciate his kindness. She even says she likes his coat. I kept expecting there to be something deeper to the plot, but if there is, it’s not revealed in this story, which is fine, because it’s still the middle of the set.
docs.title: World Enough and Time

docs.title: World Enough and Time

docs.text: The Third Doctor The era of the Third Doctor represented a major change in the format of the show, and for the most part, the Big Finish series reflects that. The most prominent change was that the show was in color, but along with that, the pacing became more dynamic and action-oriented. At the same time, Jon Pertwee played the Doctor as a more physical character than his predecessors. He was more physically imposing, and more likely to take charge of a situation. In addition, he spent a lot of his era exiled to Earth, for budgetary reasons, but that also means that he had a “home base” and a regular cast of supporting characters in UNIT. Although I’ve divided the eras by companion, the UNIT characters are often present in these stories. Exactly which UNIT actors were available for a story varied, especially after the death of Nicholas Courtney in 2011. Although there are some Companion Chronicles from this era, Big Finish drew a line separating out the first two Doctors for their extended Chronicles series and the Early Adventures. Instead, in 2015, they made a deliberate decision to recast the Doctor for the first time, bringing in Tim Treloar. They seem to have done this with great care and even trepidation, going very slowly to see how the audience would react to a recast Doctor. However, the reception seems to have been positive, leading them to risk recasting the Brigadier in 2019, and Liz and Sarah Jane in 2021.
docs.title: Third Doctor

docs.text: The era of the Third Doctor represented a major change in the format of the show, and for the most part, the Big Finish series reflects that. The most prominent change was that the show was in color, but along with that, the pacing became more dynamic and action-oriented. At the same time, Jon Pertwee played the Doctor as a more physical character than his predecessors. He was more physically imposing, and more likely to take charge of a situation. In addition, he spent a lot of his era exiled to Earth, for budgetary reasons, but that also means that he had a “home base” and a regular cast of supporting characters in UNIT. Although I’ve divided the eras by companion, the UNIT characters are often present in these stories. Exactly which UNIT actors were available for a story varied, especially after the death of Nicholas Courtney in 2011. Although there are some Companion Chronicles from this era, Big Finish drew a line separating out the first two Doctors for their extended Chronicles series and the Early Adventures. Instead, in 2015, they made a deliberate decision to recast the Doctor for the first time, bringing in Tim Treloar. They seem to have done this with great care and even trepidation, going very slowly to see how the audience would react to a recast Doctor. However, the reception seems to have been positive, leading them to risk recasting the Brigadier in 2019, and Liz and Sarah Jane in 2021.
docs.title: The Third Doctor

docs.text: The Third Doctor and Jo The era with Jo Grant is pretty extensive, as she had three TV seasons, more than Liz or Sarah, but it’s also extensive within Big Finish, because Katy Manning has been one of the more enthusiastic participants, voicing not only Jo, but Iris Wildthyme as well. Katy does a decent job of sounding like her younger self, and although not perfect, you get used to it quickly. In narrated stories, her version of the Doctor sounds...well, a lot like Jo trying to imitate the Doctor, so that’s fair. Jo always was kind of an odd fit within UNIT, and these stories vary from showing her as part of the UNIT team, to displaying her independent streak. The Doctor regained his ability to travel in the middle of this era, allowing Big Finish to nicely split stories set on Earth with stories on other planets. Most of the latter don’t have much UNIT in them, and feel more like traditional Doctor/companion stories. Katy has also worked on the Third Doctor Adventures series with Tim Treloar, helping to ease concerns about the recasting with her enthusiastic support, so most of those (thus far) appear in this era.
docs.title: Third Doctor and Jo

docs.text: The era with Jo Grant is pretty extensive, as she had three TV seasons, more than Liz or Sarah, but it’s also extensive within Big Finish, because Katy Manning has been one of the more enthusiastic participants, voicing not only Jo, but Iris Wildthyme as well. Katy does a decent job of sounding like her younger self, and although not perfect, you get used to it quickly. In narrated stories, her version of the Doctor sounds...well, a lot like Jo trying to imitate the Doctor, so that’s fair. Jo always was kind of an odd fit within UNIT, and these stories vary from showing her as part of the UNIT team, to displaying her independent streak. The Doctor regained his ability to travel in the middle of this era, allowing Big Finish to nicely split stories set on Earth with stories on other planets. Most of the latter don’t have much UNIT in them, and feel more like traditional Doctor/companion stories. Katy has also worked on the Third Doctor Adventures series with Tim Treloar, helping to ease concerns about the recasting with her enthusiastic support, so most of those (thus far) appear in this era.
docs.title: The Third Doctor and Jo

docs.text: Conspiracy in Space Third Doctor Adventures #8.1 Released: 19 October 2021 Listened: 10/23/21 This story is a bit of a prequel to “Frontier in Space,” although it takes place later for the Doctor and Jo, with a minor reference to “Colony in Space,” so it seems pretty well named. (Although Alan Barnes considered “On His Draconian Majesty’s Secret Service,” which would also have been awesome.) Because it takes place before “Frontier in Space,” the Doctor can’t bulldoze in and claim to be nobility like he does in “Paper Cuts,” and he has to avoid meeting the Emperor out of order. The plot is a typically twisty story, as you would expect of the Draconians, with lots of politics, subterfuge, back-stabbing...and quite a bit of front-stabbing too, honestly. There’s also machinations of a human mining corporation, because it seems that all humans want to do out in space is mine stuff. The Doctor gets caught flat-footed a couple of times, which is a bit out of character for him. The character of Ruji, the Draconian Secret Service agent, is quite well done, with a typically heroic sense of honor, but also a fondness for Earth culture. I wouldn’t mind seeing him show up again somehow. The big threat involves a magnetized planetoid, so even though the science is a bit dodgy, the Doctor gets to say “reverse the polarity” several times, and be accurate. Tim Treloar does his usual excellent job, although it must be noted that his impersonation slips a bit when he has to get shouty, which happens a few times in this story. It’s not a bad addition to this set of audio stories.
docs.title: Conspiracy in Space

docs.text: Damascus Short Trips #6.8 Released: 30 August 2016 Listened: 5/30/21 This one is pretty complicated, for a Short Trip. It takes place concurrently with the Eighth Doctor Short Trip “The World Beyond the Trees,” and most of the action happens in that story, so what goes on here feels somewhat incomplete. The Third Doctor even suspects he may have crossed his own timeline. To complicate things even more, the story is told from the point of view of Prime Minister Jeremy Thorpe. In our reality, Thorpe was a Liberal Party leader, but within Doctor Who, he’s Prime Minister, specifically mentioned during “The Green Death” as an inside joke. When some aliens turn up rather visibly, the Doctor declines to get involved, considering them harmless, and Thorpe goes to intercede personally with the Doctor. It turns out the aliens were mostly harmless, but during the events, Thorpe reveals that a certain Project Damascus is still being funded, despite the Doctor’s recommendation that it be shut down. This leads to the Doctor angrily telling Thorpe off, much the same way the Tenth Doctor reacted to Harriet Jones in “The Christmas Invasion.” There are a number of new-series references in the story, not the least of which is writer Jonathan Barnes slipping in a reference to “All the Strange, Strange Creatures.” It’s an enjoyable Short Trip, but not really because of the plot, but rather for everything else going on.
docs.title: Damascus

docs.text: Find and Replace Companion Chronicles #5.3 Released: 13 September 2010 Listened: 6/16/21 This is a weird one, but written by Paul Magrs, what do you expect? It features an older, present-day Jo Jones, but takes place at this point in the timeline for the Doctor. Jo has attracted the attention of Huxley, one of the Novelizers of Verbatim Six, who are a quite funny concept, but only appear in one other story. Except Huxley thinks Jo’s history is quite different than what she remembers. Because this is a Paul Magrs story, Iris Wildthyme is involved, meaning that Katy Manning gets to play Jo, Iris, and a bunch of other incidental characters. Fortunately, Alex Lowe has a lot of lines as Huxley, or poor Katy Manning would be quite worn out. As it is, her Iris sounds rather deeper pitched than usual, perhaps to emphasize the difference from older Jo. The action moves to the 1970s, where the Doctor helps to unravel the mystery, and it’s not quite so sinister as the setup implied. The first part of the story sets up a strong mystery, but the second half runs on nostalgia, and probably worked better when it was released, during a time when Third Doctor stories were basically unavailable. It’s a good premise, though, and ends with some amusing hints at other stories.
docs.title: Find and Replace

docs.text: Frontier in Space TV Season 10, Serial 3 Aired: 24 February 1973 - 31 March 1973 A somewhat random story featuring the only TV appearance of the Draconians, but also the Master, Ogrons, and Daleks. Roger Delgado’s death means this is the final appearance of this version of the Master, who disappears without any closure. Connects directly to the next story.
docs.title: Frontier in Space

docs.text: Gardeners' Worlds Short Trips #7.2 Released: 28 February 2017 Listened: 7/1/21 Placed here because Mike has a prominent role. This one is a bit high-concept, but Short Trips are good for that. The Doctor, Jo, and Mike investigate an English village in which probability seems to have gone a bit haywire, and discover some plants with the ability to affect quantum possibilities. That requires quite a bit of exposition on the Doctor’s part, so it’s a good thing that Tim Treloar is narrating. In fact, his narrating voice sounds more than a bit like the Doctor, and his version of Jo doesn’t sound a bit like Katy Manning, but you can’t have everything. It’s a nice little story, if one that requires your attention.
docs.title: Gardener's Worlds

docs.text: Ghost in the Machine Companion Chronicles #8.4 Released: 11 October 2013 Listened: 6/30/21 This is the final Companion Chronicle to feature Jo Grant (which is OK, because the Third Doctor Adventures started up not long after), and it’s definitely different than the others, as many Series 8 chronicles were. For a start, there’s no flashback; the story takes place in “real time” with a younger Jo, meaning that Katy Manning plays both Jo and the Doctor, not a narrator relaying the Doctor’s words. Thanks to some liberal body-swapping in this story, co-star Damian Lynch has to play his own character, Jo, and the Doctor, and it must be said he does so reasonably well. This is also one of those stories that leans hard into the audio medium: Jo needs to record what’s going on for a comatose Doctor, finds recorded station logs, and then discovers that the monster is made of sound and can record not just voices but also people’s essences onto tape. That makes the first part of the story rather spooky and atmospheric, and the second part distinctly brain-twisty as characters interact with recordings of each other. Supposedly, recorded people can only use the words that they’ve been recorded saying, but I’m not engaged enough to re-listen to the first part and see whether they held to that strictly. Finally, this is the first Big Finish story directed by Louise Jameson (Leela), who will continue as an occasional director for the range. It’s different and interesting, but I wouldn’t want too many like this.
docs.title: Ghost in the Machine

docs.text: Lost in the Wakefield Triangle Short Trips #4.3 Released: 10 August 2011 Listened: 6/10/21 The Doctor and Jo go looking to buy some rhubarb, and accidentally stumble across aliens. It’s one of those Short Trips that’s more of a vignette than a story, because it’s all resolved fairly quickly and with minimal peril. However, it does take advantage of the unique popping noise that growing rhubarb makes in a dark forcing shed, so it’s one of those rare stories better suited to audio than TV.
docs.title: Lost in the Wakefield Triangle

docs.text: Operation: Hellfire Third Doctor Adventures #6.2 Released: 14 May 2020 Listened: 6/12/21 Now we reach the point in this era where the Third Doctor Adventures series kicks in, which means the stories are longer, and more like what would have been on TV at the time. This particular story comes from later in that series, though, when Big Finish was feeling more confident in what they could do, which means a story set in WWII, because the Third Doctor never had a historical, which in turn means pulling in Ian McNeice to play Churchill again, because apparently he always says yes. It’s not quite a true historical, because the TARDIS currently isn’t working, so the Time Lords send the Doctor on yet another mission, to steal a Gallifreyan macguffin that could mess up the course of the war. However, the main point of the story is around British disinformation efforts during the war, and a cult of British, fascist devil-worshippers who are trying to work for the Axis cause, but may have been caught up in a German disinformation effort. Writer Jonathan Barnes manages to keep you uncertain about which characters are actually trustworthy, which is good, because there’s not a ton of action. There is a vein of humor, though: A Venusian aikido fight that sounds pretty funny on audio, plus the Doctor’s line when he’s about to be killed in a demonic ritual: “We’ve all got to make sacrifices in wartime.” On the whole, it’s reasonably good for a historical.
docs.title: Operation: Hellfire

docs.text: Peepshow The Diary of River Song #6.3 Released: 27 Augus 2019 Listened: 6/25/21 This is a story from the River Song set where she pops up in and around classic stories. In this case, the action is concurrent with “Carnival of Monsters,” with River running around the miniscope at the same time as the Doctor and Jo. River’s trying to steal a battery from inside the miniscope, but ends up having to rescue all the creatures inside the miniscope’s “recycle bin,” which includes a squad of Sontarans, a group of Ogrons, and a 21st century Earth office building containing a security guard and a sabre-tooth tiger, because Vorg never did do his homework. Lots of times in the extras, actors describe a story as a “romp,” but this one really is. It’s just fun from start to finish, and even though there’s a threat of being eaten by Drashigs (because of course there is), nothing happening is very serious. Guy Adams has given River an absurd amount of wonderful dialog, and also gifted her with an excellent companion in the security guard, who has a habit of stating things that are right in front of him, which makes him an excellent audio character. (He’s also played by Clive Wood, who played the Roman commander in “The Pandorica Opens,” so he’s worked with Alex Kingston before.) Dan Starkey plays the Sontarans, which will never be anything short of awesome. He’s deliberately playing them as classic-series Sontarans, but they’re still terribly funny. And Guy Adams himself plays the Ogrons, who are always comedy gold. This is possibly the best story of the boxed set. Plus, it features a lot of running, which was good, because I was running while listening to it.
docs.title: Peepshow

docs.text: Poison of the Daleks Third Doctor Adventures #6.1 Released: 14 May 2020 Listened: 6/22/21 This was the first story with John Culshaw as the Brigadier, and they added in Sgt. Benton to give him someone to work with. Plus, it’s a Dalek story, which always means a good time, at least for Nick Briggs. There’s the usual evil industrialist / corrupt government official combo, except this time they’re one person, and nominally working to fight pollution. But of course it’s a trick, and as a result the Doctor, Jo, the Brig, and Benton all end up on another planet dominated by Daleks. Fortunately, they’ve all encountered Daleks before, so they grasp the situation immediately and join the resistance. In fact, the Brig and Benton pretty much take over the resistance, since they’ve got the military experience; it also gives those characters something to do, and a chance to look capable. The Doctor, unusually, gets paired with an alien scientist almost as smart as he is; it’s an intriguing character who just rubs the Doctor the wrong way. It’s fun to see him irritated, and I don’t think they would have challenged him like that in the 70s. In addition, a number of the secondary characters are women in leadership positions, which also wouldn’t have happened in the 70s. Unfortunately, the Daleks’ plan isn’t particularly complex, and having it revolve around Earth’s air pollution hammers the point just a little too hard, even if it’s something that Barry Letts and Terrance Dicks would have approved of. Excellent characters and portrayal, but not the best story.
docs.title: Poison of the Daleks

docs.text: Pop-up Short Trips #3.3 Released: 11 May 2011 Listened: 6/26/21 This is another story that basically does what it sounds like. The Doctor and Jo visit a planet with a heavy presence of advertising robots, and Jo smuggles a tiny broken one on board, because she feels sorry for it. The TARDIS is soon overwhelmed with adware and viruses, forcing the Doctor to reinstall the OS. The story is nothing more than an extended joke about ads, which Jo is unable to appreciate because of when she’s from.
docs.title: Pop-up

docs.text: Primord Third Doctor Adventures #5.1 Released: 8 May 2019 Listened: 6/14/21 This is another story from later in the Third Doctor range, where Big Finish was willing to take more risks with recasting: In this case, the first appearances of John Culshaw as the Brigadier, and Daisy Ashford as Liz, both of whom we’ve already heard in this project. Because Liz comes back! Or more specifically, the Doctor and Jo go to Cambridge at Liz’s invitation. Jo is pretty intimidated about meeting Liz, which makes sense, as Liz does have a lot of credentials, but they get along fine. The Doctor spends most of the rest of the story with Liz, and Jo with the Brigadier, so the interaction between Jo and Liz is limited after Part 1. Also, Liz isn’t telling the Doctor everything, for good reasons, but it casts her as a baddie for much of the story, which makes me wonder about Big Finish’s confidence in the character. The bulk of the story is about the Primords, the ape-like creatures seen in “Inferno,” but mostly in another dimension. Writer John Dorney is smart enough not to just repeat the “drilling accident” story, but instead speculates on what the military would do if they knew about these creatures. So we get some corrupt soldiers and one corrupt MP for the Brigadier to deal with, while the Doctor tackles things from a scientific angle. As usual with these Third Doctor adventures, I think the pace could be a little better, but it’s a deliberate choice to mimic the era the story represents.
docs.title: Primord

Also, Liz isn’t telling the Doctor everything, for good reasons, but it casts her as a baddie for much of the story, which makes me wonder about Big Finish’s confidence in the character. The bulk of the story is about the Primords, the ape-like creatures seen in “Inferno,” but mostly in another dimension. Writer John Dorney is smart enough not to just repeat the “drilling accident” story, but instead speculates on what the military would do if they knew about these creatures. So we get some corrupt soldiers and one corrupt MP for the Brigadier to deal with, while the Doctor tackles things from a scientific angle. As usual with these Third Doctor adventures, I think the pace could be a little better, but it’s a deliberate choice to mimic the era the story represents.
docs.title: Primord

docs.text: Prisoners of the Lake Third Doctor Adventures #1.1 Released: 2 September 2015 Listened: 6/17/21 Here’s the very first experiment with Tim Treloar’s version of the Third Doctor. Katy Manning is there for backup, and just in case, they’ve got Richard Franklin as Mike Yates, too. To Justin Richards’ credit, Mike isn’t just a stand-in for the Brig, but has a more active role than you would expect from a UNIT Captain. The story is told partially narrated, not quite as much as a Companion Chronicle would be, but it’s clear Big Finish is hedging their bets, and possibly positioning this as an Early Adventures kind of story. The story is a very typical Season 9 story as well. There’s something strange at the bottom of a lake, and UNIT gets called in to investigate, because guess what, it’s aliens. For a change, it isn’t an energy or mining company that discovered the aliens, but rather an archaeological expedition, which means that for once, they’re mostly inclined to listen to the Doctor, except for the project director, but there’s more going on there. Also unusually, the expedition has some serious equipment, in this case an armored exo-suit made for diving, which is probably rather advanced for the time period, but it’s crucial to the plot. The pace is kind of pokey, with lots of scuba diving and opening and closing of airlocks, but that’s fairly typical of the era as well. The key question is: How is Tim Treloar? The answer is, pretty good. He’s not leaning too hard into a Pertwee impersonation, but he definitely captures the flavor. He doesn’t sound quite as confident with it as he will in later stories. Treloar also provides the narration, and his normal voice is close enough to his Pertwee that there’s a bit of confusion there, but one can get used to it easily enough. It’s not the strongest story, and doesn’t really break any ground, but it does what it sets out to do successfully, which is what’s needed to kick off this range.
docs.title: Prisoners of the Lake

docs.text: Still Life Subscriber Short Trips #2019-2 Released: 19 June 2019 Listened: 6/10/21 This Short Trips special is unlike most of the stories from this era, but the specials do that sometimes. We meet Jo’s father, Terry Grant, a professional painter and art teacher. Unfortunately, we meet him when he has late-stage cancer. But because Jo’s life isn’t normal, she’s able to make a deal with some aliens to buy more time with her Dad. There isn’t a monster or a baddie in the traditional sense; it’s just time, and what we do with it. It also doesn’t really fit nicely into continuity, but that doesn’t really matter in this case. It’s just a small, personal story.
docs.title: Still Life

docs.text: Storm of the Horofax Third Doctor Adventures #3.2 Released: 17 August 2017 Listened: 6/18/21 At this point in Big Finish recording time, they were feeling pretty confident about their recast Third Doctor series, enough to take some chances with the writing. This story is by Andrew Smith, who wrote for the classic series, but has also done quite a few Big Finish stories. Even though it has a number of Third Doctor touches, I think there are a lot of new-series elements in this story. There’s the alien with multiple agendas, a helpful minor character who suddenly has his worldview upended but sticks with it (and has a distinctly modern turn of phrase), a glimpse into the future of humanity, and a heaping helping of timey-wimey. The Doctor rather typically is on the side of the stranded alien, but also isn’t willing to go along with her agenda. It’s somewhat high-handed, but that’s the Third Doctor for you. Katy Manning was ill throughout the recording of this story, so Jo has a cold, which Nick Briggs gamely tried to turn into a plot point, but it doesn’t quite work out. Finally, there’s a UNIT major who we’ve never seen before and never see again, but there’s a reason for that, and it shouldn’t be sad, but it is, and that’s a testament to both Andrew Smith and Katy Manning. He seemed like a good character; it’s a shame he wasn’t around more. This is a pretty solid entry for this point in the timeline.
docs.title: Storm of the Horofax

docs.text: Taken for Granted Subscriber Short Trips #2018-2 Released: 19 June 2018 Listened: 5/29/21 Jo gets an origin story, even before her semi-disastrous introduction scene in “Terror of the Autons.” On her final day before joining UNIT, Jo attempts to meet her influential uncle for lunch, but finds herself pursued by mysterious cars, nefarious agents, and even alien insectoids. Calling upon all of her training, she evades them without too much difficulty, even slipping out of a pair of handcuffs and taking her assailant’s gun. It turns out the whole thing is a final exam (although it seems as much hazing as test), which she passed with flying colors. Honestly, Jo seems rather more capable here than she ever did on TV, but she is supposed to have had this training, and earned her place in UNIT, not just through nepotism. So I don’t mind a little retcon. Stephen Critchlow provides the narration, with a range of effective voices.
docs.title: Taken for Granted

docs.text: Terror of the Autons TV Season 8, Serial 1 Aired: 2 January 1971 - 23 January 1971 First appearance of Jo, Mike Yates, and also of the Master -- the Roger Delgado version, but this was the character’s first-ever appearance in TV continuity. Also features the return of the Autons and the Nestene Consciousness. Season 8 begins here.

docs.text: The Conquest of Far Third Doctor Adventures #3.1 Released: 17 August 2017 Listened: 6/27/21 We’re starting to get close to the end of Jo’s tenure, so Big Finish slips in a Dalek story that takes place immediately after “Planet of the Daleks,” yet isn’t connected to it. This one takes place during the one of the Dalek Wars that Big Finish has often portrayed, with large cinematic space battles that probably wouldn’t work on TV, not to mention the Doctor slamming a Dalek saucer into a planetary atmosphere at hyperspeed, which I’m sure Jon Pertwee would have loved to film. The Doctor and Jo are separated almost immediately in this story, which did happen sometimes. That leaves Jo free to deal with an emotional story of the resistance and unwilling collaborators, which can be heart-rending, although you can kind of see the twist coming. The Doctor, instead, gets the usual array of imprisonment, escape, rescue, and gaining the trust of authority figures. Fortunately, he has a human on his side who becomes more capable as the story goes on. And his reputation precedes him (or the reputation of his later selves, or whatever). This one is big and sprawling, not really what Terry Nation would have done, although perhaps if he’d had an unlimited budget, who knows?
docs.title: The Conquest of Far

docs.text: The Curse of Peladon TV Season 9, Serial 2 Aired: 29 January 1972 - 19 February 1972 Another off-earth mission introduces the planet Peladon, its rulers, and Aggedor, which will pop up again on TV and in audios. It also introduces several alien ambassadors, including a couple of Ice Warriors, Arcturus, and the wonderful Alpha Centauri.

docs.text: The Doll of Death Companion Chronicles #3.3 Released: September 2008 Listened: 6/6/21 This story, released in 2008, is the first time Katy Manning returned to the character of Jo Grant, which seems odd, given how much work she’s done for Big Finish, as Jo, Iris, and other characters, but she was initially reluctant. As such, Jo gets a lot of narration and background, as well as a reminder of how “modern” Jo Jones is doing (very well, thanks). The story itself is a bit on the odd side, with what are initially thought to be ghosts, but turn out to be an entity from a universe where time runs backward. Writer Mark Platt splits the story right in the middle, with the first half uncovering the mystery, and the second winding backward to the beginning. It’s absurdly difficult to write a coherent “time runs backwards” story, and I’m not sure this one follows all the logic, but it does a good job of letting us know how Jo feels about it at the time, which is good. Likewise, “creepy doll” is a pretty good Doctor Who villain that doesn’t get used a lot. It’s not my personal favorite, and this story isn’t a standout, but it does the job. It’s a decent story, and opened the door for others to follow.
docs.title: The Doll of Death

docs.text: The Green Death TV Season 10, Serial 5 Aired: 19 May 1973 - 23 June 1973 The first story back on Earth since the beginning of the season. Introduces Professor Clifford Jones. Jo falls for him, and leaves the Doctor and UNIT to go marry him and have lots more adventures, some of which we’ll hear about later. Season 10 ends here.
docs.title: The Green Death

docs.title: The Green Death

docs.text: The Havoc of Empires Third Doctor Adventures #1.2 Released: 2 September 2015 Listened: 6/26/21 This is the second story from the inaugural Third Doctor Adventures set. This one takes place after the TARDIS is functional again, so it starts with Jo and Mike wanting to use it to go on a date. (Mike wants to see a famous cricket match; Jo thought they were going to the Cavern Club to see the Beatles. I gotta say I’m with Jo on this one.) Of course they end up somewhere else entirely, in this case a space station that’s about to host a diplomatic wedding of two space-faring powers. Jo, Mike, and the Doctor pretend to be security inspectors for somewhat complicated reasons, giving the whole thing a “Curse of Peladon” feel, which is pretty deliberate. Jo gets a lot to do in this story, as she’s nominally in charge, given their cover. She takes to it pretty well, which doesn’t quite match her TV characterization, but isn’t out of line with her background. We’ve never seen Mike in a full-on companion role like this, but he does well enough, kind of like Harry Sullivan. It’s clear that Big Finish is still hedging their bets, giving Mike a larger role and including the narration, both of which stick out a bit more than in “Prisoners of the Lake.” Richard Franklin is clearly trying, but there are times when he doesn’t sound like a young Mike. There are also a few moments of rather silly humor, all involving the wedding planner and her trained eels. I guess it’s supposed to be like Alpha Centauri, but it comes off as absurd. There’s also a brief appearance by the Delphons, the species that communicates with their eyebrows, as mentioned in “Spearhead from Space,” so if you’ve been waiting for that, there you go. On the whole, it’s a fine story, but maybe a bit too derivative, and the humor goes a bit far.
docs.title: The Havoc of Empires

docs.text: The Hidden Realm Third Doctor Adventures #2.2 Released: 3 November 2016 Listened: 6/20/21 This story is a slightly unusual one, in that there’s something strange going on in the English countryside, but it’s not a UNIT event. Instead, Jo goes to help out her cousin, whose husband has disappeared. What follows is a story about alien body-snatching couched in a mystery in a small village. Richard Earl and Alex Lanipekun provide a nice double-act as a pair of Scotland Yard inspectors, not too far off from what Robert Holmes would have written in this same era. The atmosphere of the village is well-played, although perhaps a bit condescending to modern ears. The mystery, though, isn’t all that huge, and the alien’s plan isn’t exactly complicated. It’s a story that doesn’t seem to stick in the mind quite the way you might want it to.
docs.title: The Hidden Realm

docs.text: The Magician's Oath Companion Chronicles #3.10 Released: April 2009 Listened: 6/7/21 This is the second of two Companion Chronicles narrated by Richard Franklin as Mike Yates. The plot involves a street magician, and an alien-seeming spate of sudden temperature drops around London. The Doctor and the Brigadier head off in one direction, leaving Jo and Mike to follow up on the magician, but not exactly with orders to do so. How that all resolves isn’t something you could really guess, and even though it all hangs together logically, it seems a bit contrived as a resolution. A lot of the audio stories from this stage play on the Doctor’s resentment of his exile and his feelings of isolation, and this one is no exception. Richard Franklin is an acceptable, if not a gripping narrator. Many Companion Chronicles, including this one, have a conceit of an older character telling the story to another party. That means that when the narrator uses overly descriptive language, or changes pacing to make the story more exciting, it doesn’t really fit with one individual relating a story to another. Franklin is more of the “just telling the story” kind of narrator. It’s not particularly gripping or paced, at least not as much as other narrators do. His imitations of the other main characters aren’t quite as good as in other stories, but that fits as well. This story is a little cliched, but a decent one for Yates.
docs.title: The Magician's Oath

docs.text: The Many Deaths of Jo Grant Companion Chronicles #6.4 Released: 14 October 2011 Listened: 6/26/21 Here we’ve got a Companion Chronicles story that very much does what it says on the tin: Jo dies. A lot. In very nearly Rory Williams fashion. Of course there’s something else going on, something alien, but the point is that Jo is very much willing to sacrifice herself for the Doctor, perhaps a little too much so. That’s not a unique attribute for a companion, but Jo is quite devoted to him. Because this story is so action-oriented, Katy Manning ends up doing a bit more narration than impersonating Jon Pertwee or Nicholas Courtney, but there’s nothing wrong with that. The plot is tricky on the jeopardy, because of course listeners know that Jo’s not going to actually die, but we also don’t know exactly what’s happening. There’s a twist that’s unexpected, but at the same time not really surprising. It’s a good story, if not a classic.
docs.title: The Many Deaths of Jo Grant

docs.text: The Mega Lost Stories #4.4 Released: 18 December 2013 Listened: 6/3/21 This is the only one of the Lost Stories from the Third Doctor era. It’s also a six-part story, which makes it one of the longest of Big Finish’s Third Doctor offerings, although it’s not out of line with its era. Unlike the rest of Season 8, the Master doesn’t figure. The monsters are the titular Mega, which have glowing swirls for heads, so I imagine that would have been tough to pull off on TV. There’s a distinct Barry Letts feel to this story, as the villain’s goal is disarmament and overall improvement of the human race, but he intends to use force to do it, in the form of an alien death ray that can strike anyone, anywhere on the planet. The Doctor states several times that he agrees with the goal, but not the means. The Doctor is also in conflict with various military figures throughout the story, in a way that’s consistent for him, but usually wasn’t quite so sharply drawn at this point in the show’s history. As is typical with a six-part story, the first part zips right along, and the middle bogs down. There’s even a sequence where the Doctor and Jo break out of a prison cell, go do a thing, fail, and have to break back into the same prison cell before anybody notices they’re gone, so that’s a bit frustrating. The part-three cliffhanger of the British Prime Minister getting vaporized live on TV certainly grabs the attention, though. Katy Manning and Richard Franklin take turns with the narration, which means Manning gets most of the Doctor’s lines.
docs.title: The Mega

docs.text: Lost Stories #4.4 Released: 18 December 2013 Listened: 6/3/21 This is the only one of the Lost Stories from the Third Doctor era. It’s also a six-part story, which makes it one of the longest of Big Finish’s Third Doctor offerings, although it’s not out of line with its era. Unlike the rest of Season 8, the Master doesn’t figure. The monsters are the titular Mega, which have glowing swirls for heads, so I imagine that would have been tough to pull off on TV. There’s a distinct Barry Letts feel to this story, as the villain’s goal is disarmament and overall improvement of the human race, but he intends to use force to do it, in the form of an alien death ray that can strike anyone, anywhere on the planet. The Doctor states several times that he agrees with the goal, but not the means. The Doctor is also in conflict with various military figures throughout the story, in a way that’s consistent for him, but usually wasn’t quite so sharply drawn at this point in the show’s history. As is typical with a six-part story, the first part zips right along, and the middle bogs down. There’s even a sequence where the Doctor and Jo break out of a prison cell, go do a thing, fail, and have to break back into the same prison cell before anybody notices they’re gone, so that’s a bit frustrating. The part-three cliffhanger of the British Prime Minister getting vaporized live on TV certainly grabs the attention, though. Katy Manning and Richard Franklin take turns with the narration, which means Manning gets most of the Doctor’s lines.
docs.title: The Mega

docs.text: The Mind of Evil TV Season 8, Serial 2 Aired: 30 January 1971 - 6 March 1971 This is the season where the Master appears in every story (which Terrence Dicks admits was overkill). This one is quite well regarded, and features the Master’s penchant for mind control, in this case with the Keller machine.
docs.title: The Mind of Evil

docs.text: TV Season 8, Serial 2 Aired: 30 January 1971 - 6 March 1971 This is the season where the Master appears in every story (which Terrence Dicks admits was overkill). This one is quite well regarded, and features the Master’s penchant for mind control, in this case with the Keller machine.
docs.title: The Mind of Evil

docs.text: The Mists of Time Companion Chronicles Special Released: 23 July 2009 Listened: 6/9/21 This is a Companion Chronicle, but not one released in the normal course of that series. Instead, it was a special with Doctor Who Magazine, but it’s not clear why this story in particular. It’s a little odd in that the Doctor can get to another planet in the TARDIS before “The Three Doctors,” but there’s a Time Lord connection to their trip, so maybe that’s it. It’s a bit lengthy for a Companion Chronicle, and Katy Manning does the lion’s share of the work. It’s one of those deals where there’s an alien planet where there’s nothing but ruins, but it’s apparently inhabited by ghosts, as well as a handful of archaeologists (not Benny or River). And of course the ghosts aren’t exactly what they seem. But it feels like there’s really not enough plot for the length of the story, so it’s not particularly memorable.
docs.title: The Mists of Time

docs.text: The Other Woman Short Trips #5.11 Released: 20 November 2015 Listened: 6/10/21 I’m setting this story at the end of Season 8, in defiance of Craig Brawley, because: a) UNIT HQ is still in London, b) Jo has only been in the TARDIS a few times, and c) Jo dates a UNIT soldier who isn’t Mike. As for the story itself, an alien shows up in England who needs the Doctor’s help. She appears to be an attractive woman, which has the Doctor and all the UNIT staff falling all over her, although it doesn’t appear to be a psychic power; she’s just really charming. Jo doesn’t buy it, and immediately starts looking for a catch. Of course, because this is a short story, she’s right, and not just jealous. It’s pretty straightforward, but the Third Doctor’s mannerisms are captured well, as is his obvious longing to escape the Earth. This story probably wouldn’t have worked so well with a less charming version of the Doctor.
docs.title: The Other Woman

docs.text: The Rise of the New Humans Third Doctor Adventures #4.1 Released: 21 March 2018 Listened: 6/21/21 This story takes place after “The Three Doctors,” but the Doctor doesn’t have the TARDIS working to his satisfaction yet, so he’s still primarily occupied with UNIT concerns. In this case, that means a number of mysterious deaths involving people who seemed to be evolving into something new. When the Doctor discovers a private hospital full of anachronistic medical technology, he and Jo naturally suspect the Master -- it is Season 10, after all -- but it turns out to be the Monk, the Rufus Hound version. (For him, it’s after his encounters with the Eighth Doctor and Lucie.) That involves a bit of snarling of the timelines, mostly because Big Finish really likes Rufus Hound’s Monk, and Hound clearly loves playing him, so he gets stuck in all over the timeline. As far as the plot itself goes, the Monk is behind it all, for his own purposes, but as usual he loses control of the goings-on and finds himself depending on the Doctor to save his own skin. There are a couple of twists, but nothing terribly unexpected or surprising. Even the other minor characters are somewhat pale beside the Doctor and the Monk sniping at each other, although all the actors do their best to be distinctive. Basically, this one depends on how much you like Rufus Hound, which for me is a fair bit, so I’m happy.
docs.title: The Rise of the New Humans

docs.text: The Sacrifice of Jo Grant Legacy of Time #3 Released: 17 July 2019 Listened: 6/8/21 “Legacy of Time” is one of the Big Finish anniversary sets that tries to include all the available Doctors plus Big Finish spin-off material. That means this story involves the Third Doctor (whose series was still relatively new) and UNIT plus modern-series UNIT, in the form of Kate Stewart and Osgood, with Jo Grant as the natural link between them. Which means that only half of this story takes place at this point in the timeline. The rest of it happens in the modern day, after Jo and Osgood have met and become friends (and visit a water park together!). Present-day Jo and Kate end up bounced back to the 1970s by a temporal anomaly to encounter the Third Doctor, while Osgood works the same problem in the present. The Doctor is close to a caricature of his persona from this period, being ever so slightly patronizing and kind of oblivious as he works the problem; he doesn’t recognize at first that Jo is 40 years older. Jo takes advantage of the opportunity to spend some more time with the Doctor, while Kate is torn over the decision of whether to call her father. There’s some serious timey-wimey going on that’s more new-series than Season 8, but that’s necessary for the resolution. Tim Treloar does his usual excellent job as the Doctor, and there’s a brief cameo by John Culshaw as the Brig. Because only present-day Jo appears in the story, Katy Manning doesn’t have to force her voice into a higher register, which she probably appreciated. It’s designed to make you feel nostalgic, and it does its job.
docs.title: The Sacrifice of Jo Grant

docs.text: The Same Face Short Trips #9.6 Released: 27 June 2019 Listened: 7/1/21 From the title, you might think this Short Trip has to do with regeneration, and it does, but not the one you were expecting. In fact, it’s kind of complicated, mixing politics (both alien and Gallifreyan) with a knowledge of how regeneration works, so the reader has to be pretty up on their lore if they want to get the full effect. Even better, there’s a spoiler that fits nicely into Season 10, and which I didn’t see coming. It’s long, for a Short Trip, and it rewards the nerds, but I’m OK with that. Katy Manning narrates, and does a good job with the Doctor as always, as well as the various other characters.
docs.title: The Same Face

docs.text: The Scorchies Companion Chronicles #7.9 Released: 7 March 2013 Listened: 6/26/21 This one is definitely...something. It’s a somewhat famous Companion Chronicle for how silly it is. There’s no flashback in this one, just straight Jo, being held prisoner by puppets and forced to participate in their TV show. The Scorchies invade planets by mesmerizing the populace through television and then taking over. The plot, well, there isn’t really much of one. The point is the rather strange format, the silly voices (provided by Katy Manning and Melvyn Hayes), and the songs, which, wow. Big Finish has done in-story songs a few times now, and they’re often pretty good (“Fanfare for the Common Men,” “The Horror of Glam Rock,” and some others). These fit the bill of sounding like they stepped right out of a kids’ show. If you find yourself with “Jo Is Making a Thing” stuck in your head for a few hours afterward, don’t be surprised. Don’t take this one too seriously; just come along for the laughs.
docs.title: The Scorchies

docs.text: The Scream of Ghosts Third Doctor Adventures #5.2 Released: 8 May 2019 Listened: 6/15/21 Whereas the last story had Liz, this one has John Levine as Sgt. Benton, who hadn’t appeared in too many Big Finish stories before. So once again, we’ve got a full set of UNIT characters to work with. In this case, there’s a lot going on with radio and sound waves: a scientist is inventing the mobile phone slightly before it should have been, and Benton is revealed to be a CB radio enthusiast with a friend who likes to make musique concrète. All of which ties in to an enemy who didn’t have a lot of time on TV, but has gotten their due from Big Finish [spoiler: it’s the Vardans]. In appropriate fashion for this era, the mystery builds for a while, and the villains aren’t revealed until about halfway through. Jo gets a fair amount of agency in this one, especially at the end, where the Doctor basically needs her to save the day in a fairly new-series manner. Benton doesn’t really have a lot to do, but then again, that’s not much different than it ever was on the show. The main appeal for both stories in this box is getting the characters together, and at that, it succeeds.
docs.title: The Scream of Ghosts

The story also introduces the Master’s fondness for children’s television.

docs.text: The Sentinels of the New Dawn Companion Chronicles #5.10 Released: 14 April 2011 Listened: 6/5/21 A bit of a throwback: This is a Liz Shaw story, even though it takes place during Jo’s tenure. Liz calls the Doctor for advice a year or so after leaving UNIT, and he comes to help, without bringing Jo. Caroline John voices Liz and provides the narration, which means she offers her version of the Doctor, which isn’t bad. Unfortunately, her version of an African general sounds rather stereotyped, but he only has a couple of lines. Liz is concerned because a colleague is working on a time machine, or at least a time window, and wants the Doctor’s opinion. Messing with it gets the Doctor and Liz tossed forward to 2014, which was a few years after the story was released. There, they encounter the titular Sentinels of the New Dawn, an Illuminati-type group who have the time machine plans, and are using it to make money in the stock market. They’re also planning a weaponized release of Ebola, so they can take over the world. (Ironically, while Ebola was known in 2011 when the story was released, they couldn’t have known there would be an outbreak in actual 2014.) The most interesting story point is that Liz finds the Doctor more jovial and playful than he was when Liz was at UNIT. That could be Jo’s influence, or it could just be that the Doctor doesn’t take this problem all that seriously. The group doesn’t seem like all that much of a threat. Liz gets to show off her smarts a few times, even knowing immediately how to prevent being knocked out when she’s unexpectedly gassed. There’s a bit of a frame story, also taking place in 2014, with a twist that’s honestly pretty easy to spot. And sadly, we’ll now bid goodbye to Caroline John for this project, although not to Liz.
docs.title: The Sentinels of the New Dawn

docs.text: The Switching Subscriber Short Trips #2010-2 Released: June 2010 Listened: 6/9/21 This particular Short Trip, read by Duncan Wisbey, mostly features the Master, and the “Switching” of the title is pretty much what you’d expect, as the Master swaps bodies with the Doctor. That’s not exactly a spoiler, as it happens within the first couple of minutes of the story. Oddly, the Master seems to realize that he won’t accomplish anything with this scheme, and settles for doing some mischief, primarily changing the console room to the “washing-up bowls” configuration seen only in “The Time Monster,” and locking it that way. He also spurs forward the relationship between Jo and Mike, leading to the most affectionate scene between them that we’ve seen. Really, it’s just a lighthearted joke of a story, and an exercise in continuity references.
docs.title: The Switching

docs.text: The Three Doctors TV Season 10, Serial 1 Aired: 30 December 1972 - 20 January 1973 The famous 10th anniversary story, and the first televised multi-Doctor story. In addition to bringing back the First and Second Doctors, it introduces Omega and provides more information about Time Lord history. At the end, the Time Lords restore the Doctor’s ability to travel, leading to more stories away from Earth. Season 10 starts here.
docs.title: The Three Doctors

docs.text: The Transcendence of Ephros Third Doctor Adventures #2.1 Released: 3 November 2016 Listened: 7/1/21 More space adventures for the Doctor and Jo, because that seems to be what they’re doing right now. (Although it’s still in the same time zone as “Frontier in Space,” because the Doctor knows the President of Earth personally.) They show up on Ephros, which is supposed to be a garden spot, but it’s desolate. In fact, it’s about to explode soon. Which should be bad, but there’s a big galactic corporation there ready to harness the energy of the explosion, and also a religious group who believe that standing on the planet when it explodes will cause them to ascend to a higher state of being. Writer Guy Adams puts a lot in here, from the cranky, nasty corporate project leader to the friendly but snarky religious leader, and also gives Jo a moral dilemma to struggle with, because she’s in favor of religious freedom, but doesn’t want people to die. Then Adams turns just about everything on its head in Part 4. [Spoiler: The religious leader is a former companion of the Master, which allows for a Master-like villain without the need to recast Roger Delgado. And the corporate type remains cranky even while helping the good guys, so that’s a nice reversal.] Jo and the Doctor spend a lot of time apart in this one, which allows for Jo to use her intelligence on her own, and also allows for an empathetic reunion scene. Jo is becoming a very capable person by this time, which is good, because she’s about to go off to do her own thing. I remembered this one as being someone long on my first listen, but this time around I didn’t find it so. I appreciated the twist in the writing, which marks this out from a lot of the Third Doctor stories.
docs.title: The Transcendence of Ephros

docs.text: The Tyrants of Logic Third Doctor Adventures #4.2 Released: 21 March 2018 Listened: 6/29/21 Many fans are quick to point out that the Third Doctor never faced the Cybermen, and that’s the sort of thing Big Finish likes to fix, although they did that a while ago in “The Blue Tooth,” but never mind. This one is also set out in space, on a failed colony, after a time when the Cybermen have supposedly been defeated, but the galaxy is still trying to recover from the war. Which means a small group of desperate Cybermen trying to find a MacGuffin that’s ended up on this planet. Writer Marc Platt has created an interesting set of supporting characters, including a cyber-hunter and a traveling musician whose instruments are all internal, but they’ve also all got their own agendas and spend a lot of time being secretive in ways that are understandable, but contribute to the problem. The Cybermen, much like Star Trek’s Borg, have undergone an evolution over the decades where instead of surgically upgrading certain individuals, they just release nano-bots that convert anybody and everybody. Which is scary, to be sure, but it doesn’t really fit with their early appearances. The Doctor, in the process of being converted, has to sound flat and robotic, which puts a strain on Tim Treloar’s impersonation abilities. Maybe that’s what a mind-controlled Third Doctor would have sounded like, but it’s hard to tell. Jo seems a bit harder-hit in this story than previous ones, but the Cybermen are pretty scary, and she forges a connection with the secondary characters who get killed. The ending is a bit more emotional than dramatic, but it’s not bad for the official Cybermen outing.
docs.title: The Tyrants of Logic

This one is also set out in space, on a failed colony, after a time when the Cybermen have supposedly been defeated, but the galaxy is still trying to recover from the war. Which means a small group of desperate Cybermen trying to find a MacGuffin that’s ended up on this planet. Writer Marc Platt has created an interesting set of supporting characters, including a cyber-hunter and a traveling musician whose instruments are all internal, but they’ve also all got their own agendas and spend a lot of time being secretive in ways that are understandable, but contribute to the problem. The Cybermen, much like Star Trek’s Borg, have undergone an evolution over the decades where instead of surgically upgrading certain individuals, they just release nano-bots that convert anybody and everybody. Which is scary, to be sure, but it doesn’t really fit with their early appearances. The Doctor, in the process of being converted, has to sound flat and robotic, which puts a strain on Tim Treloar’s impersonation abilities. Maybe that’s what a mind-controlled Third Doctor would have sounded like, but it’s hard to tell. Jo seems a bit harder-hit in this story than previous ones, but the Cybermen are pretty scary, and she forges a connection with the secondary characters who get killed. The ending is a bit more emotional than dramatic, but it’s not bad for the official Cybermen outing.
docs.title: The Tyrants of Logic

docs.text: Time Tunnel Short Trips #5.3 Released: 5 March 2015 Listened: 7/1/21 This is a fairly brief vignette, with a melancholy mood that doesn’t quite match its placement on the timeline. The Doctor is still feeling pensive and trapped, and there’s a small echo of “The Silurians,” but it’s also specifically stated to be after “The Three Doctors,” which doesn’t make a ton of sense. There’s also an unusually high body count, which seemed unnecessary to the story. The Doctor doesn’t really solve the problem at all, which makes the story a bit unsatisfying. Katy Manning narrates, and voices the Doctor, the Brig, Mike, and Benton, making all of them sound distinct, which is pretty impressive. Unfortunately, it’s not a memorable story.
docs.title: Time Tunnel

docs.text: The Third Doctor and Liz This period of the show lasted only one season, with Barry Letts realizing (correctly) that if the Doctor had an intellectual equal as his companion, there wouldn’t be much for Liz to do, hurting her development. In Big Finish terms, this section had been pretty short because Caroline John passed away in 2012, before Big Finish had committed to Third Doctor stories. However, with the advent of Tim Treloar as the Doctor, and Daisy Ashford taking over her mother’s role as Liz, this section is starting to fill out now.
docs.title: Third Doctor and Liz

docs.text: A Home from Home Short Trips Rarities #3.2 Released: 22 December 2014 Listened: 5/27/21 This was one of the “Subscriber Short Trips,” but fortunately released in the “Short Trips Rarities” collection, so I could get my hands on it. It’s a fairly basic story, but well-suited to this particular Doctor and companion. The Doctor is feeling depressed about his exile, so he seeks out one of those hidden communities of aliens that are dotted around the planet, and leaves without telling anybody. When he doesn’t come back for a while, Liz concludes he’s in danger, and goes looking for him with Benton. She’s clever enough to track down the community in the Scottish Highlands, even though it’s very well-hidden. Unfortunately, that allows a bounty hunter to follow her to the aliens, but since this is a Short Trip, the Doctor settles that quickly. Stephen Critchlow does the narration, and again provides an excellent Third Doctor. His Benton isn’t all that great, but he only has a couple of lines. It’s a nice little story for a Short Trip.
docs.title: A Home From Home

docs.text: AWOL Short Trips #12.2 Released: 2 February 2023 Listened: 3/6/23 The very first story from the Liz Shaw era...doesn’t feature Liz at all. Canon has established that there’s a substantial gap between “The Silurians” and “The Ambassadors of Death,” during which the Doctor took quite a while to cool off from his anger at the Brigadier for wiping out the Silurians. It takes a brave writer to tackle the conversation where they reconcile, but Angus Dunican proves himself up to the task. This is helped by the fact that Jon Culshaw is reading…in fact, contrary to Short Trips style, he’s not reading at all; he’s playing both the Doctor and the Brigadier (and a UNIT captain), with no narration. There’s a clear difference between Culshaw’s style and Tim Treloar’s, although we haven’t heard Treloar yet in this project. Regardless, he does both men well enough that you believe the conversation, which is good, because it’s well-written, and emotionally laden. I don’t know if the two of them really would have been that heartfelt in 1970, but it feels right in the here and now. Another note is that the music in this story is extraordinary. It’s intended to evoke the story’s setting in Peru, but it also underscores the emotions nicely.
docs.title: AWOL

docs.text: Binary Companion Chronicles #6.9 Released: March 2012 Listened: 5/28/21 This companion Chronicle is the last appearance of Caroline John for a little while in this project, but not of Liz. Liz finds herself assigned to deal with a salvaged alien computer, as a result of her having dealt with this race before in an untold story. However, she’s under instructions not to tell the Doctor, who’ll want it destroyed as something the human race isn’t ready for. That’s indicative of the red tape she has to deal with at UNIT, along with the early-70s sexist attitudes (even from the Doctor), all of which has her strongly considering going back to Cambridge. The computer seems to have a lethal defense mechanism, so it’s a tricky job. While she doesn’t get killed, Liz does find herself shrunken and trapped inside the computer, faced with the choice of destroying it from within or escaping. It’s a decent plot that gives Liz a lot to do, but always within her capabilities. The Doctor is a minor character, and doesn’t really drive the plot much, which is somewhat unusual for these stories, but appropriate in this case. There are a couple of twists that you can see coming if you look for them, but Caroline John plays Liz’s reaction to them well. It’s a decent middle-of-the-road story.
docs.title: Binary

docs.text: Blue Boxes Short Trips #10.11 Released: 4 November 2020 Listened: 5/29/21 Placed here more or less arbitrarily. This is one of those Short Trips that doesn’t exactly tell a story, but plays with an idea. In this case, writer Erin Horáková clearly knows something about the history of hacking, or in this case, phone phreaking, because the devices that were used to fool tone-based phone systems were called “blue boxes,” which suggests an obvious link. I only know a little about phreaking (before my time), but the exposition given in the story sounds accurate, including famous hacker Captain Crunch. However, once the exposition is done, there’s really not a lot of story left. Narrator Mark Reynolds does a decent job of imitating Jon Pertwee, and has enough flexibility to voice the other characters effectively as well.
docs.title: Blue Boxes

docs.text: Inferno TV Season 7, Serial 4 Aired: 9 May 1970 - 20 June 1970 The first appearance of an alternate dimension on the show, in this case of the “everyone’s an evil fascist” flavor. The evil Brigadier gets an eye-patch instead of a goatee. The final televised appearance of Liz Shaw, although she’s not shown to depart. Possibly the first appearance of the Third Doctor’s Sonic Screwdriver, although it’s referred to as a “door handle.” Season 7 ends here, having been much shorter than previous seasons.
docs.title: Inferno

docs.text: Old Soldiers Companion Chronicles #2.3 Released: 7 December 2007 Listened: 5/24/21 The next story from this era also doesn’t feature Liz. Instead, this is the only Companion Chronicle told from the Brigadier’s perspective, and narrated by Nicholas Courtney. It’s pretty appropriate that this is the only story to really get inside the Brigadier’s head, because it takes place right after “The Silurians,” in which the Brig and the Doctor had a falling out over the Brigadier’s decision to destroy the Silurian base, and there’s a substantial gap before the next TV story. It’s a very Brigadier-appropriate story, dealing with an internal UNIT experiment that’s gone entirely wrong. It’s rather heavily narrated, even for a Companion Chronicle, and starts off quite slowly, with the Brig doing his own investigations for a while before calling in the Doctor. Like other actors called upon to say the Doctor’s lines in a narrated story, Courtney goes very light on the imitation, trying for the cadence of Jon Pertwee, but no more than that. But the Doctor is fairly secondary in this story, with the focus being on the Brigadier as he reflects on what soldiers owe to one another, the responsibilities of command, and just how far he personally is willing to go in order to carry out his duty of protecting humanity. I don’t think you’d want too many stories from the Brig’s point of view, but this one is appropriate.
docs.title: Old Soldiers

docs.text: Rivers of Light The Diary of River Song #9.4 Released: 27 October 2021 Listened: 10/31/21 – The River Song stories “The Blood Woods,” “Terror of the Suburbs,” and “Never Alone” take place here for Liz, but the Doctor isn’t in those, so I’ve covered them in River’s portion of the project. -- This is the final story of a River Song boxed set, in which River filled in for the Doctor for a while, early in his UNIT tenure. This is the one we’ve been waiting for, where River meets the Third Doctor along with the Brig, Liz, and a special guest star at the end. The Third Doctor, especially this early in his tenure, despises being pushed around, and really hates anyone touching his stuff, which is exactly what River’s been doing for weeks now, having sent him off on a wild goose chase. So the expected shouting scene ensues, and while Tim Treloar does an excellent Third Doctor, he’s not always at his best when shouting. Because this is River’s story, she handles him the way she always does: does her own thing and expects him to trail along behind, being irritated. This time, though, she really does know what’s going on, and has most of a plan to fix it. Basically because it’s her fault. There’s some alien tech down a mine, and it’s awfully dangerous, so she needs to get it back. The plot stays pretty basic so there’s more time for banter, but there are some fairly well-drawn secondary characters, and a nice visual of subterranean lightning. There’s a little bit of dodgy science mixing up gravity and magnetism, but it’s forgivable. There’s also a nice throwaway line about some time fluctuations messing up the entire decade, which is cute. Liz kind of takes a back seat this time, but does demonstrate considerable trust in River, which built over the stories. As a boxed set, it works quite well, and this story provides the ending you’d expect.
docs.title: Rivers of Light

docs.text: Shadow of the Past Companion Chronicles #4.9 Released: 30 April 2010 Listened: 5/25/21 Finally, we get a story featuring Caroline John as Liz. This story is by Simon Guerrier, who knows how to twist a plot, and it really uses the Companion Chronicles structure well. An older Liz has returned to UNIT to follow up on an investigation that she was part of in the 1970s. There’s a soldier there on guard, so she ends up telling him the story of what happened originally. The writing for the Doctor is strong, as it often is. It takes advantage of the fact that this is early in the Third Doctor’s life, so he’s feeling frustrated at being stuck on Earth, and his relationship with the Brigadier is still forming, so he’s more likely to act on his own and disobey orders without explaining. The story takes a while to get rolling, appropriate for this era, but once the enemy is revealed as a Mim (a race of shapeshifters who don’t turn up too often), there’s a typical UNIT response, with an unfortunately high body count. Part of the shapeshifting shenanigans hinges on the fact that Liz doesn’t really know the Doctor all that well, which wouldn’t have worked as well with Jo. Liz also comments on changes in UNIT procedure since the original event (having an HQ in London, for example), which positions it nicely in Season 7. The plot twist isn’t too hard to figure out, but it does wrap up nicely. It’s a quality Companion Chronicle story.
docs.title: Shadow of the Past

Also the first story filmed and broadcast in color.

docs.text: The Annihilators Third Doctor Adventures #9 Released: 8 February 2022 Listened: 2/10/22 This is a rather unusual Third Doctor story in several ways. It’s a 2022 release, so stars Tim Treloar, John Culshaw, and Daisy Ashford, who keeps getting better at sounding like Liz. It’s clearly part of Season 7, because it’s a seven-part story, although most of the episodes are considerably shorter than normal for Big Finish. But the really special bit is that it features the Second Doctor and Jamie, played by Michael Troughton and Frazer Hines respectively. Up until now, Frazer Hines played the Second Doctor, but the role has now been given over to Patrick Troughton’s son. Admittedly, Hines’ version sounded something like a caricature, but Troughton’s version doesn’t sound a whole lot like his father, most of the time. It lacks the characteristic pauses and drawing out of words that Patrick did. For the Second Doctor and Jamie, there’s really no telling when it takes place (yet), as the Brigadier notes that Jamie is quite a bit older than the last time they met. But it’s before “The Two Doctors,” as Jamie hasn’t met any other incarnations yet. According to the extras, this will all be explained later. In any event, it’s primarily a Third Doctor story, the usual alien invasions that lead to strange happenings and UNIT gets called to investigate. Because it’s a seven-parter, the story can spread out quite a bit, with the Doctor and Liz doing sciency things separately. We’ve even got two alien races in opposition, each one claiming that they’re doing the right thing. Honestly, working out which is which isn’t all that difficult, so it’s not much of a mystery. If it weren’t for the extra Doctor in the story, this would be awfully drawn-out for as little story as there is. Fortunately, it does have that extra bit to recommend it.
docs.title: The Annihilators
